reviews.review: Nice touristy place. This is a very touristy location but great to be. Nice combination with the Sensoji temple next door

Has many cute souvenirs!. many kind souvernir price range 300yen - 10000yen++
and also has various snack while browsing the place.

Rickshaw tour. Thoroughly enjoyed the tour of Asakusa and nearby Sensoji temple area. Our driver, Leo the Ninja, was super. Great personality, knowledgeable about history and fun to spend 22minutes with. This, in addition to the kimono rental was the highlight of our trip.

A Littler Of Old Tokyo. Asakusa is one of the few places left where you can see old Tokyo. The best way to get there from downtown Tokyo (Ginza Station) is take the Asakusa Line. At Asakusa exit at Gate 4 which is close to the Kaminarimon Gate which is the entrance to the Asakusa ( Sensoji) Temple. There is also the Nakamise Shopping Street where there are many tiny stores selling clothing, crackers and toys and almost everything else. This whole area reflects how people worked I=and lived in the Edo era and you get a feel for old time Japan.

Worthwhile half day trip. Lovely temple and surrounding area, plenty of local souvenirs and delicacies on offer, and a rabbit cafe! Pretty streets and rickshaw guides too if you want s quick local tour. Definitely worth a trip.

Worth a visit . It was a short train ride from central Tokyo, but definitely worth a visit especially for first time visitors in Japan. A good but interesting mixture of traditional and modern experiences. Pros: Easy site to get to. It was good fun to walk down the main street to see the variety of souvenirs and of course traditional Japanese snacks. My favourite would have to be the delicious fresh mochi. Good photo opportunities too on a clear day to see some of the new structures mixed in your background such as the skytree tower. Cons: I'm not a believer of fortune telling so I wasn't interested in that whole area at the back. The food areas got overly crowded and uncomfortable at times.

district in Tokyo with beatiful shrine and hundreds of shops. main attraction is Senso-ji Temple as well as dozens of restaurants and hundreds of shops. Closest metro station is Ginza Line G19 (orange line) or Asakusa Line A18 (pink line). Nice promenade on the river bank with views on Sky Tree. You will need 1-2 hours to see the shrine and walk some shopping streets. Of cause add extra time for shopping or dining:) This was highlight of our visit to Tokyo.

Temples & Tourists. I really wanted to like this area, but the main area near Sensoji Temple seemed like a massive tourist trap, with a high markup on "trinkets" and even wandering away from the main area it still seemed like a very tourist focused area. In saying that, it was certainly worth the one off visit, but as I went with friends, I wouldn't take my partner back. There were LOTS of people which made it difficult to stop and browse even though we went on a weekday. The Positive: I did have a DELICIOUS Age Manju filled with Sakura Cherry and sweet white bean paste which was priced at 200Yen and so tasty I wish I could eat it every single day!

Interesting neighbourhood.. This was a very interesting part of Tokyo, a huge contrast to the modernity found elsewhere. It was fun to wander down the small streets and alleys, it had a great atmosphere.

Best place for the budget-conscious Tokyo traveller. Though 10kms away from Central Tokyo, Asakusa is probably the best place to stay if on a budget. Nice neighborhood, lots of places to visit, cafes and restos abound, mini malls and 24 hr convenience stores and dept stores dot the area. Accommodations is much lower compared to Tokyo proper, less crowded and easy access via subway. Anywhere form 11 to 18min travel time.

Full of restaurents! . We have visited here for sensoji temple and we found out that full of restaurents here and all nice
we came here for lunch and dinner, I prefer to come this area at night becauce not too crowded
You can find japanese dessert as a gift and souvenir here

Worthwhile. This is a must for tourists. I have been three times now. Souvenirs stores line the path to the temple.
This is like a concentration of Japanese culture manufactured into souvenirs. You can't resist buying.
I will definitely visit again.

Fun place to visit. Things to do here:
- Visit shrine
- Kimono rental
- Food and souvenirs
- Rickshaw rides
You could spend a good half day here. My girlfriend enjoyed the whole kimono rental experience. Kimono rentals are between 3,000 to 4,000 yen.
Local place. yes it's tourism spot, and there are lots of foreign people. still, yet, furthermore, you should go once at least. you can find japan like japan.

Beautiful and very crowded. The temples are here with shopping and dining streets. It gets really crowded so be patient.Lots of tourist wearing the traditional Japanese robes- which you can rent too for a fun experience.

Beautiful. Very crowdy, kaminarimon and sensoji were similar like the picture. Very beautiful.
Small shops offers snacks and cute merchandise that I very much love (and buy)

Nice Temple!. I'm so impressed with the architecture of the museum. Very nice red colour. The surrounding area also big, can cater to high volume visitor. Also can find Halal food restaurant nearby and lots of street food nearby.

Very crowded tourist trap.. If you are in Japan for a while, travelling around, there are some more serene places to visit. I would personally not recommend visiting it is a real tourist trap and a little disappointing compared to other similar structures both in Japan and abroad.

Red Roof Shopping Street. Touristy Attraction! Came on a Sunday and it was so crowded so first tip is to avoid weekends if possible. If you come on a weekend better to come earlier to avoid the crowd. The shopping street that leads to the temple sell a lot of the same things: japanese style clothing, key chains, fans, etc. Make sure to compare prices as some stores in the front sell the same item about $1-2 dollars more than stores in the middle. Make sure to get their red bean cakes. oh so good! also many stores don't want you to take photos thus be mindful of their request!
Beautiful Serine . Very nice place. Little crowded as we have visited on Sunday. Lots of shops to buy mementos. Really liked it.

Souvenier shopping heaven. This place was crowded with tourist when we visit it. Full of souvenier shops and we can ride a rickshaw around this place. The temple is very beautiful and its offer the different side of Tokyo.
One of Landmark in Japan. Everytime I've visit Japan, I've to visit here. for respect the temple, shopping on the road in front of the temple. Easy to come here by Mwtro Subway.
Asakusa is a part of traditional Tokyo. This is a part of old Tokyo city and frequently visited by tourists. Lot of things to see around and you may need 2-3 days to go to all places.

Busy temple with lots of shop. Temple is nice with lots of shop line up leading to the temple. I went in the afternoon and it was very crowded. Recommended to go in the morning when the crowd might be lesser.

Great area to stay in Tokyo. Asakusa is a great area to base yourself to see the rest of Tokyo. Calmer and more relaxed than Shibuya and Shinjuku areas, Asakusa is itself quite touristy mostly due to Senso-ji Temple which is beautiful and quite impressive and worth a visit even if youre not staying in Asakusa. Furthermore it has lots of shops and restaurants and youre one stop away from Ueno another beautiful area known as the museum area where Tokyo National Museum is located.

Busy but a lot of fun stuff. I went to Asakusa on Sunday afternoon. It was packed with tourists..to me, it was too busy and didn't feel relax to enjoy the temples. I have been to Asakusa long time ago, and it was very nice and peaceful. So I guess you need to avoid weekends if you really want to enjoy the atmosphere. There are many many little shops along the streets and there are some quick bite places. People will line up to get a good/trendy food, so you will notice it. There were some picture perfect spots of the temple and it was quite nice.

Very nice shrine. Leading to the shrine is a tourist-trap alley, with many souvenir shops.The shrine is very impressive, and the Japanese visitors pay their respects. The gardens are beautiful. Easy access by subway - it's the end of the Ginza line.
Nice temple and shops. This is a nice stroll between many shops of food, clothes, stuff... Very nice temple with kimono women praying.
Asakusa. The temple here is very impressive , lots of buildings to visit .The surrounding streets are full of tourist shops and malls ,a lot of interesting stuff to look at.

A place with charm. Stroll around and enjoy every things you see.. Still has a tinge of tradition culture here, with rickshaw pulling (although more for tourists), shops in the back alley selling local snacks, and a charming temple. Walk further away from Sensoji Temple and it will get less busy for appreciating the surrounding.

A Tokyo Tourist Must See . This is a great place to visit and people watch. It's crowded with locals and tourists having fun and soaking in authentic Japanese culture. People offering incense, people interpreting fortune telling sticks, people washing their hands with holy water, families posing for selfies. The temples are well maintained and look gorgeous providing great backdrops for picture taking. The smoke & smell of incense drift in the air. The surrounding alleys some with covers are lined with all kinds of shops ad restaurants. This is the place to try street foods such as shaved ice as well. What a great experience.

Long stretch for shopping. The Nakamise shopping street is not to be missed when you're in Tokyo, the Senso-Ji temple is also at the shopping street. It can get touristy and crowded but it's worth a visit if you're in Tokyo.

Enjoy the touristy walk!. It is interesting to be walking along Nakamise St with all the shops and foods everywhere. A lot of souvenir to choose from and a lot of people to avoid bumping into :) ... I enjoyed it even under the heat of the scorching sun! Have the experience! See the photos :)

Shrine & shopping. My friend and I did a walking tour around Asakusa starting at the Asakusa information centre, the shopping strip before the temple and winding our way around to the kitchen area. Great shops to get you touristy knock knacks and small snacks. The Buddhist temple is huge- very impressive compared to the tiny Shinto temple beside it. The information centre has a great lookout on the top floor to see the area. Well worth a visit.

Very impressive!. Expect that there will be lots of People there so one must walk in a line all the time, so do not expect it will be a calm and relaxing atmosphere. But it is a bit too busy for my taste!
Nice temple. Nice place to visit in Tokyo. An old street with a lot of shops, and a beautiful temple. In the shops you can try typical small cakes that are baked in front of you.
Unique. I was there when i was 16 an still remember its elegance, its solemnity, Simply must you should not lose
Nice neighbourhood for a wander. Lovely neighbourhoods, lots of touristy market stall. Best place for souvenirs for sure. Definitely worth it for an afternoon.

Popular Place. When we lived there we used to take out of town family/friends there because it's a convenient Buddhist temple to go see. Very close to the metro and plenty of shops selling cheap souvenirs. I've only bought key chains and post cards/ prints (suitable for framing). We always followed this up with a ferry ride to Odaiba.
Good tradition . Good view and good culture. You can shop all around with traditional snack and food and souvenirs . Nice view and you can see skytree tower

Amazing !!. We visited this temple on our first day on a tour of japan and it set the bar vey high for the rest of our Japan experience.The ornate detail everywhere was just breathtaking and highly impressive in its appearance. Needless to say, it is a place which had the camera shutter pleading for mercy.This site was also made more impressive by the detailed account of all we were seeing by our excellent guide

Unforgettable visit. Out from the train station, while walking toward Asakusa, we saw a shop that dress all the 4 of us in traditional costume, my girls said feel like a star as lots of people wanna take photos with them.
Awesome!. typical and traditional japanese style all around, rickshaw, people wearing kimonos, temples and much more. It is a must!

This Place Is A Must. Another side of Tokyo worth checking out.Plenty of merchants selling a variety of souvenirs as your walk towards the temple.Within the vicinity there are good options for restaurants & deco shops.Suggest you get here early morning to visit the temple & shop around, have your lunch & take the boat ride to Odaiba.The temple is nice but you will spend more time in the shops for sure.

Curios and Culture Galore. The merchants stalls offer all of the souvenirs or trinkets that you could want from Japan, and the food shops offer tasty treats as well. The walk to the temple can be crowded, but the grounds are immaculately kept, creating a pleasant atmosphere.

First day in Tokyo, a deep dive in the Japanese culture. On the day we landed, we walked to Asakusa. The walk to the temple from our hotel went through the Sky tower, Asahi brewery and then to Asakusa. A broad mix of architecture. The merchant street is a tourist attraction and we did not spent much time there. The temples are huge and varied, and stopping there is refreshing. Walking the streets nearby was also very interesting to get a first immersion in Japan.

Your ususal temple scene. To me, this area is just like any other part of Japan temple scene. There are shops along both sides. Those shoppers and tourists make it really not so nice to walk in between.I suppose that it is all right first temple trip for some.

Survival trips for Tokyo. Survival Tips for Tokyo1- Planning ahead is number one rule. Book everything in advance, make reservations, make calculations as your ad hoc needs unlike most other countries can not be accommodated or could me time wasting and costly. Transportation is easy but takes time by any method. 2-Financially Tokyo is expensive to reach and to stay in hotels mostly with small rooms though well equipped.However food, entertainment, shopping are not expensive as expected especially for Dubai residents . Be aware that you should have a small packet for dozens of coins you will get and use. Credit cards are mostly accepted and there are exchange machines almost on any street. For calculations one USD is around 93-97 yen. 3- As mentioned before Transportation between destinations are taking time however you have so many options if you stick to number one rule which is planning ahead. Especially in metro people helping you a lot for any inquiries as the system is a little bit more complex as operated by two companies.Taxi requires more money, some Japanese language skills and patience as roads are mostly only two lanes , has so many traffic lights. 4- High Tech is default expectation in Japan however it is not you will see in daily life. On one side there is solid but aging infrastructure on the other you see lot of encounters with robots in museums which is most interesting how they will shape the future. You can refer to my Asimo videos for that. 5-Fashion is a little bit different in every street . A non-tie business dressing policy adopted for energy saving purposes thus men normally wear just shirts even not jackets . Kimono and obis both are also popular in traditional streets of the city though not for business. Most surprising will be Disneyland where most visiting people are dressed in their beloved characters  6-Traditions are most important part of your visit. You might surprised that tipping is not welcomed in this part of the world. You have all sorts of traditions. ikebana,calligraphy, curtain design,garden design, Sushi,Onsen,Sumo, martial arts,..which are not only practiced for touristic purposes but also still part of life. Look for venues of performance and do not forget to plan ahead. 7-Shopping is easy as there are thousands of stores in this city of cities.You can also shop tax free after 5000 yen for 8% discount. Malls are everywhere with different shop mixes mostly with no bargains.In traditional parts like Asakusa you will also have souvenir shops on the streets. 8-Food is what Tokyo stands for. Almost 100,000 restaurants welcoming you for all sort of food at very attractive prices. Over 200 Michelin restaurants defines a record for a city.if you are looking for restaurant , do not expect them at ground level or street level as they might be at 6th floor of a building as well. Menus in English are widely available and language does not creat a barrier for food as mostly they are shown with pictures or with plastic display models in the entrance. 9-Fuji Mountain trip is a must either as daily one or with stay over for a night. It is amazing landscape with history and tradition. Hato bus tour with a back turn with Shinkansen / Bullet trip is a recommended one. Expect more harsh weather conditions than the city. During the visit you will also experience beautiful five lakes and thermal town Hakone. 10-Other cities are also within reach of hours with Bullet trains though for the one wishing to go to Kyoto either landing to or departure from Osaka airport is better. Yokohama is much shorter by bullet train almost 30 minutes. Except historical reasons Yokohama also hosts one of the insane roller coaster of the world ,Hakkejima and its 107 meters vertical drop closed blue fall. 11-Tokyo has two airports from which Narita is almost 90 minutes drive and taxi cost USD 200. You have other options as well but expect 45-60 min to reach the city even with the fastest train. 12-Disneyland is not the best however practically a must for families. It is cheap and easy to buy online.However fast track needs on site printing and planning for allocated slots. 13-Language is in Tokyo not a problem though not as easy as in Dubai. Japanese is derived from Chinese however also has two modernized alphabets with 100 characters thus any newspaper has all alphabets. Most web sites have also English version. 14-Politeness defines the culture. Be ready for thanking for almost everything by everyone as pronounced " domo arigota gozai mas " the people are most respectful and friendly . 15-Waste bin is one of the most rare things on the streets thus expect to carry your waste with you for a long distance. 16-Smoking on the streets are usually not allowed though mostly allowed inside. 17-Sweets are part of life , try as much as you can smile emoticon:) 18- GSM & wifi are fast and almost available everywhere. 19-Fitness is required as you might walk around 10 km each day without noticing and also you will eat a lot more than your hometown with great pleasure. 20- Japanese people have two religion choices as Shinto and more recently Buddhism thus shrine and temples are almost everywhere. 21-Traditional houses are wooden but Tokyo is constructed as earthquake, typhoon resilient thus only traditional districts still has some flavor. 22- Gardens are amazing, especially Imperial Palace gardens but also Hamarikyu, Kiyosumi , Yoyogi and most important Ueno. 23-Souvenirs reflecting the rich culture and are awesome thus buy some especially in Asakusa Shopping districts. 24- Visit Tokyo station and understand why it is believed that you can spend 24 hours there easily. 25- Ginza district is associated with wealth. High end retail and 14 three star Michelin restaurants , mind blowing large stores and malls define Ginza. Similar districts in other parts of city are Roppongi,Daikanyama,Ometesando and Harajuku. 26- Second to Burj Khalifa Tokyo Skytree is 634 meters. It is next to Asahi Beer HQ and has amazing architectural view from Sumida river. 27- Odaiba represents entertainment with replica of Statue of Liberty, Giant Ferris wheel, Toyota cars show center, Madame Tussaud's museum, Emerging Science museum, Gundam statue and shopping malls. 28-Shibuya is center of clubbers and fashion freaks where Shibuya crossing is amazing for photographers to catch thousands of people crossing it. 29- Shinjuku metro station is hosting 3,5 million people each day. Here western part Metropolitan Government buildings observatory decks have the best view of Fuji mountain from Tokyo. 30- Last but not least the best timing will be spring and duration should be not less than 10 days to really consume the culture of this beautiful country.

Another view of Tokyo. What makes Asakusa unique is the scent of old Japan you can feel by wandering through its streets. There're a plenty of traditional-like restaurants, specialized shops, the atmosphere you get by the way people interact with you is incredible, the main temple Sensô-ji is absolutely gorgeous... You can also go for a walk alongside the Sumida river or get lost between the little streets nearby the temple, maybe an old grandpa will stop his bike next to you to give you a map of the neighborhood, just because you seemed lost and he had one in his pocket...

Beutiful temple, unfortunately the 5 story part is covered due to repair. Large temple complex whcih is beautiful to see. The downside at present is the 5 story element is currently completely covered in drapes and scaffolding due to repair work which was a shame. Still worth paying a visit however as the area surrounding is also interesting with many stalls.

Interesting area. We enjoyed walking around this area both during the day and at night. It was very busy during the day with the markets and tourists, however it didn't take away from the traditional architecture and interesting things to look at. A must-see while in Tokyo.

great place to visit and stay in Tokyo. a much more relaxed place to stay in Tokyo compared to other very bustling areas of Tokyo. Great food and attractions make this part of the city a well worth visit for the day.

A beautiful suburb of Tokyo. The Senso-ji temple is a beautiful introduction to Japanese temples and religious culture, and is certainly a must do. The Asakusa area has plenty of traditional Japanese restaurants contracted with a plethora of modern, exciting places. We loved the tempura restaurant around the corner from Senso-ji right near the subway exit, and also enjoyed the traditional Japanese sweets which can be bought along the many shops leading up to the temple. Senso-ji and the Tokyo Skytree are within easy walking distance from each other and make for a wonderful introduction to the Tokyo way of life.

Shop for souvenirs here! . Take a stroll through the shops on the way to the temple located just next to the station. You can find a few chopsticks specialist shops where you can engrave your Japanese or English name on for a small fee. After the temple, do explore the many streets between the shops.

Love the side streets. Wandering from Asakusa station to the temple I took a wrong turn and had a great adventure. There's lots to see here - including the towering Skytree - but I loved finding odd little shops that sold only one thing, like only beads, or chopsticks or small red bean fried treats. Most of area rebuilt after WW2 so lots of 1950s architecture. But some odd little wooden buildings too. You really can't get that lost with the Skytree as your marker. So don't worry. Some of the best things happen when you least expect it.
mixture of old + new japan. this place has a Kyoto feel in it but with a modern touch. The Sensoji Temple is really nice. Lots of restaurants.

A feel of traditional Tokyo. Asakusa is for those who want to experience Tokyo beyond the awesome lights and glitzy signboards of the modern downtown West. Don't get me wrong. The neighbourhood is far from underwhelming especially with the awesome crowds milling through the covered shopping areas during the weekend. But the old theatre neighbourhood has a different energy to it - it remains unique and traditional, with dramatic theatric figures on top of cafes, tourist souvenir stores alongside decades old wholesale shops, shops selling kimono fabric, handmade crafts and paper goods and traditional Asakusa soba, ramen and sweets like the creamy sweet potato tart. Plenty of good eateries and dessert shops around, some hidden along small side lanes. We loved staying here for a week. We recommend taking early morning and early morning/late evening walks around the Sensoji Temple and Kaminarimon area. Being near the Sumida River, travellers also get to experience Tokyo from the water with the Tokyo Cruise terminal just a few blocks away from Asakusa Station and Kaminarimon/Sensoji area. You can sit along the river facing the Skytree, or cruise along the River all the way to Odaiba Seaside Park on a round trip, somewhat pricey but worth it. It is also a stop away from the Tokyo Skytree on the Tobu line. All this 30 mins away from Shibuya.
Still enjoyable. This is a great area to wander. A mix of shops, traditional streets and temples. A really fun place to spend half the day. Easy access by train (Asakusa Station).

Asakusa. If you are going to Ueno, you would like to include Asakusa in your itinerary.After our Ueno sakura viewing, we went to Asakusa via the Tokyo Metro Ginza line. Once you get out of the park, do not cross the street, but facing the Ueno sta., walk towards your right and when you reach the crossing, cross the street going to Metro sta.Once you reach Asakusa sta., cross the street towards the shopping street and go inside one of the streets. First is the covered shopping area, then as you go further you will reach the open shopping area where you will find so many souvenirs and even food.At the end of all this shops is Sensoji, the famous Buddhist Temple.The place can get crowded during weekends.

Great Old Style Japanese part of Town. Asakusa area has maintaned its own Japanese style and culture. This area is different from the modern (west) Tokyo. Close to Skytree, this place with its narrow lanes, old style architecture, river cruises, souvenir shops attracts a lot of tourists.Very popular for the Senso-Ji temple and the Samba festival.
Traditional area. We visited this area with my family it was a nice area for traditional food clothes you can found soviner and there was a delicious halal restaurant

The Disneyland version of Japan. The central tourist area of Asakusa will blast you with a little bit of everything, from temples and shrines to traditional-looking shops selling food and souvenirs, but somewhere among the swarms of tourists, rickshaws, and people walking around in rented kimonos, you'll start to get the feeling that it's all a little fake. And it is! As in a lot of tourist areas, you'll find that the food is slightly more expensive and slightly worse than what you'll find elsewhere, the shops sell nothing but the same kind of souvenirs you'd see anywhere, and the temples are superficially beautiful but have been "restored" to the point where they fail to retain a good portion of their historical charm (and are next to impossible to enjoy in the crowds anyways). In spite of that, Asakusa can still merit a visit, especially if you only have a few days in the city. There's a much wider variety of food than you'll find in the typical Tokyo neighborhood, including several outstanding places (Ichiran Ramen!), the walk along the Sumidagawa is beautiful by any standard, and Senso-ji is quite nice at night when the crowds have gone home but the temple grounds remain open. The neighborhood calms down quite a bit at night, which is very nice if you're staying in the area and want to get a good night's sleep but not so nice if you're looking for any sort of nightlife.

Compulsary for Souvenir shopping!. You can get any Japan souvenirs with cheaper price here from their samurais, to shirts, keychains and even yukatta. You also can visit the famous shrine here as they are one of the attraction in Asakusa.
Must visit. Loved the area as it had the feel of traditional Japan. Lots to eat and see and souvenir shops. Senso Ji shrine is at the end of the food street. good atmosphere in the evening.

Don't go home without visiting the place.. There is lots to see and explore. Temples and shrines, eating and shopping, and so much more. It gives you a taste of old Edo. It is a must for every tourist who visits Tokyo.
Must do. Asakusa is a must do on a visit to Tokyo. It is easily accessible by metro and is in a part of town where there are lots of shops. Good place to visit.
Great area to visit. Plenty of temples, which are all great and beautiful, shops and restaurants. The shops are local and home made and the the type of stuff sold is of the souvenir variety but cool.

Cool Shops, neat temple. The shops are cool along the street, mostly of the souvenir variety. But I did see a few things in Asakusa that I did not see elsewhere. The temple is also neat right at the end of one of the shopping streets. Free to go in as well. We went up one side of the street, took a break from the shops with the temple, then back to shopping on the other side. Restaurants in the area are also quite good. It is right by the river with a nice river walk.Only issue was it was quite crowded. But not terribly.
A must see in Tokyo!. Temples galore, cool old school izakaya and get your fortune told! I received the best of all fortunes which is a mixed blessing by all acounts. Lol! Awesome Dudes!
Newly Preserved Temple. The temple had recently completed its conversation works and it looks brand new. It is easily accessible by subways and serves as a centre for religious praying.

Asakusa. We loved our trip to japan it was a nice experience. :) going to tokyo, tsukiji, to osaka castle to universal studios japan! :) etc.
Asakusa was a nice temple :)

Sanja Matsuri Festival. Arrived Asakusa during the festival of Sanja Matsuri. Streets were very lively with many street stalls. We saw many shrines being carried around the streets with groups of people.

Tourists, shrines and hundreds of stores. Tokyo's traditional quarter is really more of a tourist quarter, but is still fun. Places to eat and shop are plenty, from Brazilian BBQ to traditional Japanese. You can buy pretty much anything that has been ever marketed in Japan as a souvenir. And you can attend the fully functional Sensoji temple and smaller shrines nearby.

Don't go there for the temple, go there for the food. Asakusa is a nice place to grab some food. The area has a wide variety of good restaurants. The fact that it is close to the Sumida river, makes the place quite charming at night. Do not expect to much from the Senso-ji though. A temple which does not feel authentic whatsoever.

Asakusa by night. We are amazed how beautiful Asakusa shopping street toward Sensoji was.
All the shop has some sort of painting subject of Kabuki, Ukiyoe and other Japanese classics as theme. It was much less crowded than day time and the illumination of
Sensoji temple, from sunset to 11 pm everyday was so precious to see.

The Edo Relic. Set in the north of Tokyo, this is old Tokyo (or what's left of it). Interesting just meandering around the back streets but also the lure of the Senso-ji temple (biggest in Tokyo I think) and the giant pagoda (which was, sadly, covered-up by scaffolding for renovations during my visit). This area is really the only area where old Tokyo remains in any scale.
great tourist spot. you can reach asakusa by subway or by car.. this is a great tourist spot, you can enjoy traditional sight of tokyo.

Traditional Tokyo. Walking through the market of "Old Tokyo" with its delicacies and souvenirs was quiet special-- one of the best ways to experience the past culture in the modern city. Traditional temple and store architectures took you a step back in time.

For traditional Tokyo - this should be no.1 on your list. Pros:- Best place to view a pagoda in Tokyo- Biggest temple in Tokyo- Lively and bustling area brimming with life and activity- Huge variety of shops and restaurants- Wandering the streets and backalleys has that traditional 'feel' about itCons:- Check on the website to see if any of it is under construction/maintenance. It is really worth seeing the pagoda, for my last visit the view was sadly obstructed.Advice:- If visiting in late August, check dates for the Asakusa Samba festival.- Wander the streets to the West of the temple.- The long shopping street between the gate and temple is arguably the best place in Tokyo to grab those souvenirs.- The Asahi Sky Room in Sumida offers a great view of Asakusa and of Tokyo.

Must visit. The region is amazing! It is close to the river where you can see Skytree tower. The shrine is great place to visit. Do not forget "Onikuji"If you want to buy souvenir of any kind, even sweets it is the best place.

Asakusa Main Attraction. Asakusa , the place to visit in your Japan trip . I was informed that Asakusa is the centre of Tokyo's shitamachi ( means "low city") it's located one of the Tokyo's districts where the atmosphere of old Tokyo of past decades survives . The main attraction here was the Sensoji the famous Buddhist temple believed to be very old . When your walking towards the temple you will pass through shopping street which filled with lots of traditional local food , souvenir and many colours of natural beauty and life . The only way to enjoy it's to walk , they also have rickshaw tour which is about 10,000 yen but if you have the budget why not experience it . Well I did and but after that I just walked and just enjoyed the atmosphere . Since its popular make sure check the weather so it good and go early as the place is alway packed with people . This one of the location you should not miss. I loved it .
Worth a visit. Worth a visit to see a little of 'traditional' Japan. Very busy and touristy but one of our holiday highlights.
Best Temple to visit . When you are in Ueno, you must visit this famous Temple. Just absolutely beautiful. Be sure to take pictures with the girls in Kimono walking around.

Spirit of old traditions. Must see location in Tokyo. The temple itself as well as street market full of traditional gifts and street food. Lovely atmosphere. Be sure to visit this place not only during the day but also in the evening, enlightened.

A definite must do whilst in Tokyo. We initially were only planning to do a quick pit stop in the area but ended up spending a few hours here. The walk up to the temple and pagoda through the market street alone made the time fly by and this place all the more enjoyable. There were plenty of delicious sweets along the way and souvenirs were reasonably priced, many items cheaper than found in other parts of Japan. We came at around 10am and while the crowds have started, the pedestrian traffic flowed quite nicely and it didn't feel claustrophobic.Hint: When you do a omikuji fortune in front of senso-ji temple, you will notice bars which some people have tied their fortune papers to. Only bad fortunes need to be tied and left behind. If you end up with a good fortune, take it with you.

Traditional Tokyo. We were lucky enough to stay 4 nights in Asakusa, our final evening was the night of the Sumida river fireworks. We were able to buy ourselves Yukatas in the lovely variety of shops in Asakusa and dress appropriately for the occasion, the whole area was packed with people wearing traditional outfits so we didn't feel at all out of place! The area centres around the Senso-Ji temple, an impressive collection of buildings where you can watch people carrying out daily prayer rituals. Nakamise-dori has lots of traditional craft shops selling traditional umbrellas, Japanese sweets, fans, dolls and kimonos, plenty of opportunity for souvenir shopping!

Old Tokyo. Really enjoyed wondering around the atmospheric streets in this district, it was not hard to get away from all the crowds at the Senso-ji temple and find old streets, family run restaurants and food vendors stuck in a time warp!
Scaffolding!!!!. Unfortunately most of the pagoda was covered in scaffolding and tarpaulin for our visit. It was however still an impressive sight, just bad timing

Go on a festival day. I went there when the Iriya festival was on - it was packed with people and inside the temple, I was able to see a ritual take place with the banging drums, praying and lots of people throwing their coins into the donations box. It was a completely new experience for me and I really enjoyed it. Try not to go when it is raining though as you will get hit in the face with so many umbrellas.

A step in the old Tokyo. the ancient tokyo district. Away from the modernity of Tokyo usually imagined. You can walk the Ueno Park, and walking around the street (about 2-3km) arriving in Asakusa. From here then through the tsukuba express come to Akihabara.

History aplenty + Skytree nearby!. The Asakusa area is the older part of the city; and situated at the very end of the Ginza line from Shibuya. In 40mns subway ride, you move from the modern to the ancient. Great place to eat eel, walk around tiny streets, take a boat to Odaiba and of course view SkyTree.

Great Place to Visit for Food and the temple. Went here today to see the Asakusa Shrine and the Senso-Ji Temple but also went to market and got a Japanese Sweetbread with Vanilla Ice Cream which was delicious.

Good for Shrines and food!. Senso-ji temple was beautiful! There seemed to be many options for food in this area and we found the Sometaro Okonomiyaki restaurant there, which was one of our favourite dining experiences in Tokyo. Close to the sky tree and easy to get to and navigate around.

part of original downtown Tokyo. very well-known spot in Tokyo with the Kaminari (lightning) Mon (gate) where the huge lantern donated by Konusuke Matsushita (founder of Matsushita Company selling National brand electric home appliances) which cost Yen1 million then. On either side are wooden temple guardians (Nio) which according to Buddhist beliefs protected & accompanied Buddha & are justified to use physical force to protect cherished values & beliefs against evil. On the right is Agyo with mouth open & Ungyo on the left with closed mouth which has specific significance & meaning.Past this gate will be souvenir & food shops lining both sides of the street. Behind these main shops, on either side, are not so well-known but shops selling authentic traditional Japanese things including handmade dolls, specialty knives that can cost tens of thousands of Yen per knife, some run by the same family for generations. Towards half way down, on the right, you can get a clear view of Tokyo Tree which was built to replace Tokyo Tower. An authentic wooden gate built without using nails guards the entrance to the Sensoji Temple housing the Goddess of Mercy. On the back of this gate are hung giant straw sandals (zori) supposedly Buddha's. A giant brazier at the center where people crowd around to try to grasp some of the smoke from the burning incense to relieve ailments on their bodies. So if you have headaches, get some smoke to pat on your head. On either side are shops selling charms & talismans. Nearby is the Asakusa shrine which is famous for the Sanja Matsuri (festival). Though not many trees, cherry blossom viewing is also part of its attraction.On the right just after the brazier is where you use the water to wash your hands & mouth (misogi) to purify yourself before getting to the temple. The correct ritual is:First, scoop up water in a ladle with your right hand and pour water over your left hand. Next, hold the ladle with your left hand and pour water over your right hand. In your left hand, take some water that you have scooped with the ladle and rinse your mouth. Never touch the ladle directly to your mouth. Lastly, using the remaining water, tip the ladle to rinse it off. Scoop up water only one time, at the very first step of the process. There are different rituals for praying at temples (otera) & shrines (jinja).Back at the entrance, young college students do part-time work pulling rickshaws making a short circuit around the area which are popular with tourists. Average price is around Yen2500-3000 for the ride. Diagonally across is the Tourist Information mostly manned by volunteers who do speak some English.

Historic, colourful and vibrant. Asakusa is a unique destination — a true kaleidoscope where times and cultures intersect and create ever-changing patterns: East & West; old and new; incense and samba; tempura and ragtime; religion and vaudeville. Just around the corner from the venerable Sensoji Temple, you'll find a rinky-dink amusement park, on one side, and Japan's oldest Western-style bar, on the other side. The whole area hums with a down-to-earth energy that you won't find in other popular tourist destinations in Tokyo — partly, we learned, because the local traditional businesses are still mostly (and proudly) owned and operated by folks who have lived in Asakusa for generations. Highly recommended as a full afternoon excursion for a taste of the authentic "downtown" ambience of old Edo (as Tokyo used to be known).

Liked but didnt loved it. It is an interesting temple and area as a whole. I was in Kyoto first and I think temples there are more interesting.I went ti asakusa by taking the hop on hop of bus... Yes, it is worth it if you are in Tokyo, for sure

A beautiful traditional Japanese buddhist temple in a Tokyo neighboorhood with so much to see and do. This is a great area to spend an afternoon in Tokyo It is very near the Sumida River and can the local subway can get you very close to the temple. Along the way to the temple there is interesting shopping in the Nakamise-dori street to get souvenirs, small local restaurants for excellent food, souvenir and Japanese culture gift shops, etc. If you get tired, you might even get a chance to take a rickshaw ride around the area.This Sensoji temple is a favorite tourist spot, and we were there on a nice day, so there were people everywhere!

A Must Visit if in Tokyo. There are some places which must be visited when visiting certain countries. Asakusa is one of the must visit areas to visit when in Tokyo. Its traditional, colourful, interesting and, above all, enjoyable. The market stalls and Temples, take you back to a time of history and wonder and the food available from stalls, restaurants and bars will keep up your energy levels so you can enjoy the whole day without flagging.Make sure you have a camera with you, the buildings are colourful and breathtaking.

Pagoda is closed . Pagoda is covered up with cloth for repairs and you can not see it, however the temple is interesting. We went to Kyoto ofter visiting Tokyo and Kyoto temples and old neighborhoods are more impressive, but if you are staying only in Tokyo should definitely visit Asakusa.

Traditional shopping street. The shopping street leading to the Sensoji temple was buzzing with life. They had everything traditional there, from snacks, to kimonos, to slippers and souvenirs, you name it. One of the stalls had the best Taiyaki I've eaten during my trip.

Always clouded with people from in and out of Japan. We were wearing Yukata this time and strolling Asakusa,many people asked us take pic with us. If you like you can rent a yukata(summer cotton kimono)or kimono near here. It must be a special experience !

A walkable historic neighborhood. By sheer chance I booked a hotel in this district (trying to be close to Ueno for transit reasons), and was thrilled to learn I was on the edge of this wonderful area. The pedestrian zone is about ten blocks by ten blocks, maybe a bit more, and it is chock-a-block filled with wonderful shops and restaurants. The jewel in the crown is, of course, the park that contains the Senso-ji Temple and associated buildings. This is clearly a part of town that is loved by tourists and locals alike - I was particularly charmed to see that a lot of folks rent traditional dress and walk around the Edo-era alleys in beautiful kimonos and assorted items. There are lots of places to make wishes, a fountain for washing your hands, a caldron of incense, and all manner of statues and monuments to discover. Don't miss it.
Buzzing and all our shopping. A lively and great location to buy all your souvenirs. We then took the short walk to buy Japanese knives from Kamata! Awesomeness.
Touristy and crowded. This place is about as traditional as Times Square in New York. Go to Nakano if you want to see the real Japan.

A must visit. If you find yourself in Tokyo for only a short time I think this is a must visit. The feel of the area is very different, there is a very nice temple and a great market area to pick up good Japanese souvenirs.
very tradional japan. good for tourist if too busy to go far out of Tokyo. This place can find many Japanese items, like souvenirs for your friends and family!

Nice walking area. Asakusa is a good place to visit if you get out early, and want to walk around a bit. Senso-ji is here, the Nakamise shopping district is great for souvenirs for people back home, and the Sumida river and Skytree are close. If you want Japanese kitchen items, Kappabashi is also close, with lots of great deals on knives and such.

Traditional Tokyo. It was really neat to visit Asakusa on the weekend. I'm not sure if the people here do it all the time or not but a lot were wearing traditional Japanese clothing. Both men and women were adorned in Kimonos. At first I thought they were on their way to a ceremony or to a job that required they wear traditional clothes, but after some observation it appeared they were just out and about enjoying he weekend. We didn't wander too far from the area near Sensoji Temple but what I could see, the area is not built up as much as downtown, Shinjuku, Shibuya or Ginza.

Fun neighborhood!. The Asakusa neighborhood is fun to walk through with food stalls (the maple pastries are yummy!) and shops (visit the umbrella shop, they only sell umbrellas). You can take a direct train from the airport, so you can get here easily during a long layover.

Ozeki Supermarket Asakasu. This little shops selling complete and fresh daily supplies with lots of fresh looking vegetables and fruits..... just loved this shop.... Opposite the train station ear Asakusa... and its easily located.

Traditional neighbourhood . I stayed here during my trip in Tokyo. It is one of Tokyos most traditional neighbourhoods so everything is lovely to look at. It houses some of the best Buddhist temples and museums aswell meaning that it is a very cultural place to visit. A must go to when in the capital.
Must visit!. Probably the most famous temple in Tokyo for tourists. It was great and you can also buy tons of souvenirs outside.

Wandering the temples . The temples at Asakusa were pretty however they were very busy and somewhat spoilt by the modern world encroaching on them. It was difficult to take a photo without getting telephone wires or other modern items in the photo It was incredibly busy which was made worse by the rows of shops just by the entrance. I definitely preferred my visit to the temples in China much more than those on Japan. I found the Japanese tour guide new very little about their own culture and history which I found very surprising

Interesting cultural experience. We loved the Asakusa temple which is rich in japanese tradition and culture. The nearby street is busting with activities and tourists. We got to try many tasty japanese treats from the roadside stalls. Our favourite is the okonomiyaki and tako balls.

Touristy However Worth a Visit. Asakusa's main attraction is Sensoji, a very popular Buddhist temple, built in the 7th century. Kaminarimon is the first of two large entrance gates leading to Sensoji Temple. First built more than 1000 years ago, it is the symbol of Asakusa. The temple is approached via the Nakamise, a shopping street that has been providing temple visitors with a variety of traditional, local snacks and tourist souvenirs for centuries.Asakusa can easily be explored on foot. Alternatively, you can consider a guided tour on a rickshaw (jinrikisha, literally "man powered vehicle"). A 30 minute tour for two persons costs around 9000 yen. Shorter and longer courses are also available.The area is very busy with many tourist filled with souvenir stalls and people taking pictures with kimonos. Go to the visitor building and up to the top floor for a great view of the area.Shin-Nakamise or "New Nakamise" runs perpendicular to the Nakamise Shopping Street. It is a covered shopping arcade lined by various shops and restaurants. In addition, there are additional department stores, restaurants and cafes that line the adjacent streets.A must see if and worth your time if your first visit to Tokyo.

Pleasant to walk around. The main shopping street with all the little stalls appears like a runway straight up to the temple. There are dozens of these places around Asia: big temple, surrounding grounds, and shopping stalls. The architecture of the temple is similar to others in Japan (but lovely to see nonetheless) and the grounds are pleasant enough. The shopping streets have all manner of trinkets and there are a few places to eat. We probably walked around for an hour. As a point of reference, the main shopping stall area begins right in front of the Asakusa Tourist Information Center. This is a great place to visit for information, toilets, and a good view from the top of the building.

Treasure Gate . Do you want to be knowledgeable of religious buildings in Asakusa?This is Hozomon Gate,Which is translated to Treasure House Gate in English.This name cames from the fact that the second story of this building houses Sensoji's historical treasures like Buddhist documents.Additionally, muscular deities, huge size of lanterns also attract visters’ attentions. Arac
Great place. One of my stops for my travels in Tokyo. Looks good with a variety of shops selling different things.
Like the place. Many people, interesting for kids. Nice spot with water makes you a bit cool. Visit tourist information, at 8 floor good view point for asakusa.

Turistic but still keeps its charm!. The temple is magnificent, the only thing is tht's full of tourists, even though, locals still go to pray and it's nice to see how the two co-exists. Also, I liked all the walking that can be done around that area for all kind of diferente shoppings (souvenirs, different foods, small markets, clothes, spas, typical restaurants where to eat AMAZING fulfilling udon noodles, etc)
Great place to visit. It's an amazing place to visit and also to buy some typical japanese products. All the neighborhood is also very interesting.

Traditional Japanese at the heart of Tokyo . This area is fantastic, it's quite old, has many temples, shops and houses , gives you a feel of how Tokyo used to be like.It's very nice to walk through the small streets, grab a bite, and get someSouvenirs. We took a tour for 30 minutes and then continued on our own, we found a small place that gives traditional massage ( fantastic) and we had sushi at one of restaurants there.Totally worth seeing

Historical Town. Enjoy strolling alone the small shopping streets, Many side streets, make sure to explore the area don't just stay on the main one. All streets merges into the area where multiple Temples co-locate. A must see. Explore Green Tea and byproducts, small restaurants serving original Japanese cuisine, Ramen, Noodles, and many things I do not know and never knew existed. Make sure to take a boat back to Downtown.

Too Crowded but Still Worth a Visit.. I wasn't really considering to visit this place but my Japanese friend recommended this place and took me here. Since it was Saturday when I went, there were so many people but not too bad. Also, if you're looking to get souvenirs from Japan there are so many gift-shops here and I basically bought all the Japanese traditional souvenirs from here because the price was pretty good.

Great area to stay in. Tokyo is huge, literally enormous, so there is a lot of choice on where to stay. 2/4 times I have stayed in Tokyo I have chosen Asakusa. Easy metro access, great local shrines and temples and the lovely Sumida river for company. Even if you don't stay a visit to this area is highly recommended.
Repairs. Couldn't actually see this pagoda as it was shrouded in scaffolding for repairs. Quite disappointed but I'm sure it will be amazing on completion.

Heritage building. First time when enter it, you will recognize pedicab and the riders with short pants, great muscles. They has it all cause they pull the handle, with the passanger sitting comfortably behind them. i should have took one since it only costs about 300 YEN. after that you will see the big lantern flankes with two scluptures of God (God of Wind and God of thunder). behind the hanging big lantern, there are shopping street combined with street food. the temple is right after long walk shopping street and its buddhist temple. Japanese believed the smoke from incense can cure to anyplace that you put on it. if you put it on pocket, so you would gain more money.. they said :p Try forecast too! pay for it and shake until stick comes out (its written number and japanese's kanji) then take it from the box with the same write. If you got bad fortune, dont worry! hang it in the tree or available palace and if you got the good one, save it!

Peaceful oasis . I had a few hours to kill between work obligations and so took the subway here. It's a bit out of the way but definitely worth the trip. The temple and grounds are beautiful, and very tranquil. The tourist shops leading up to the temple can be a bit off-putting, but to be honest, I got several good gifts for my family in these stalls.

The historical part of modern Tokyo and my unique birthday experience!. This entire experience wouldn't be as good as it was if I was to organize everything on my own. Actually I was a real guest while in Asakusa as my Japanese friend has organized my special day from A to Z. The day started early in the morning in Asakusa where I went to rent a kimono which I was supposed to use during the day and visit the nearby temples and maybe go to the area of Ueno zoo(which I also did). Since Im European I have attracted a lot of Asian attention on me by wearing their traditional Kimono....Many Chinese asked me to take a picture with me. On the downside the slippers I got as part of the dress were quite hard to wear around...It was an unique experience... I felt just a tiny bit like a Japanese. Though not sure I am willing to do it again (at least not in the same area). I went to the traditional spots of Asakusa, prayed at Buddha and tried some beans delights which were adorable. Bought also some for my family and took 10000 pictures. Unfortunately te time was not enough to try and see everything but that is another reason to visit again Tokyo.I took the metro and went to the zoo which was another great experience. The giant pandas were the highlight of the visit there, though I liked the entire concept as you get very close to the animals yet at a safe enough distance. The kimono here was even more attractive to the visitors as I was literally the only one wearing a kimono in the zoo... especially the only one in kimono and eating hotdogs...

Beautiful temple. Impressive Buddhist temple. Many many people were there but it was very pretty and the grounds. So glad they have kept this and they were working on a part of it too--keeping it in good repair. The shopping area there was a good place to get souvenirs too!
Beautiful Tokyo soul . I know crowded but unmissable , you have to be there and once again do not forget yo now and to clap. The shopping street is also very authentic you can find nice fill staff.

Very touristy but great one-stop spot for souvenirs. Asakusa was probably the most touristy spot I visited during my one week in Japan, but it's easy to see why. The shops are heavily catered for tourists with food and souvenirs for tourists to buy for themselves or as gifts. Apart from the gift shops, you also had lots of food outlets to go for lunch. There were also shops selling kimonos, yukatas and Japanese fabrics. Any kind of Japanese souvenir you would want as a tourist, you will be able to find it here. There were also touristy services such as getting to rent a kimono/yukata and wear it around for a few hours, and also the Japanese rickshaw guys offering their services. There were many photo-ops for tourists as well like the Kaminarimon Gate and Senso-ji template. You can also see the Tokyo Skytree which is not far from here. I didn't get to explore the surrounding areas but you should give it a try if you have more time than me. Despite it being really touristy, I did enjoy myself there and bought many things to take home including the signature Asakusa pancake doll (ningyo-yaki) which is a must-try!

nice district.... Home of Sensoji shrine. Asakusa can easily be explored on foot. There are also guided tours on a rickshaw. You have the shrine, Tokyo Skytree, Sumida river & park plus the Asahi headquarters. One can spend close to half a day here. I even had the best soba here. Definitely a must stop for tourist.

Good but logically crowded. Try to avoid week-end /crowd (hard i know) . if you arrive by subway, go around and enter from the north side. you ll go counter flow at least. sneak around and get yourself carried away. pagoda actually under renovation . nearby got numerous cute streets (as everywhere in Tokyo) go further in to lower you bill if you intend to eat around. Drum museum few minutes walk from there.

Beautiful. Stopped here on our tour of Tokyo, Japan and it did not disappoint. The small shops that lined the walk to the actual temple were really cool as well and the fact that it was a free admission made it even better. A definite stop on your trip in Japan.

Touristy thing but this is somewhere you have to go.. Been there about 10 years ago so decided to take a friend/colleague there on this trip. Took the subway from Shinagawa and fortunately did not get lost. Asakusa has not changed in 10 years, The street leading to the Shrine which is packed with little "Tourist Trap" stores are still there - crowded as I remembered it. Nothing changed. 99% still the same. Just make sure you carry cash if you want to have a meal at the really nice looking small restaurants lining Asakusa shopping street. No "Cardo" is accepted by nearly 95% of these restaurants. (Disappointing for this being in Tokyo)

Enjoyable and Fun. We really enjoy the visit to Asakusa. The big lantern is the icon in this area. You will not miss this area as you will see this big lantern.To have a panorama view of this place, you may move up to top level of the Tourist information centre. And it's free to have a nice view from there.The staff at the Tourist information centre is very helpful and they will recommend you where you can go at Asakusa.There're lots of small stall around this area, you will spend the whole day or at least half a day there. You may try out the food and there're lots of souvenir to buy at this area. During our visit, we saw TV station shooting at 1 of the stall. You may also see a lot of tourist rented the traditional costume (Kimono) and walk around this area. It'll be a different experience.
Interesting temple amid a fun market. Interesting temple amid a fun and diverse market- a bit crowded, so be aware of that- had the best matcha ice cream in the market nearby-

So classic Japan . It was the great temple with big/gigantic japanese lantern in front of the gate and there so many shops sells souvenirs, traditional snack,etc. If you go to Japan you must visit this temple for sure.

Lots of Fun. A great are to visit if you like shopping for souvenirs or eating street food. A very lively part of the city with a fun marketplace to bring the whole family to. Easy access from the Subway.

Heart of Tokyo tourism. Could spend a good portion of the day here.. If you're a tourist, you'll almost certainly visit Asakusa at some point, and if you're a backpacker, there's a good chance you're staying nearby. Far from the towering skyscrapers, this is a relaxing area with a temple, pagoda, statues, a park, countless shops, restaurants and stalls. Visit the tourism office to get a free tour of the area.

Beautiful but crowded temple complex. This is a very beautiful but crowded temple complex in Tokyo where a Buddhist figure of compassion and mercy, was supposedly fished out of a local river by two fishermen and it has been enshrined in a temple since. It is hidden by a curtain and only the monks can see it. The grounds of the temple are quite large with very nice relaxing landscaping and water features, as well as a large market section. You really need a guide to explain all the different features to you.
A cosy and safe corner of central Tokyo. We stayed in Asakusa and had a great time. Lots of shops and restaurants, Sumida river and nice walks along it. Not far awy from Tokyotree.

Magnificent temple. Great temple that I must come to visit every time I'm in Tokyo. Very crowded though. Get your fortune done by shaking metal containers with sticks containing numbers that correspond to fortune slips. English explanation available on the slips! The fried manjou near the main temple is also something I'd go for every trip. Plenty of shopping available in the area.

Huge temple with good architecture. It is one of the most famous place must visit by visitors. It does not matter whether you are Buddhist or not. The temple is huge and very nice architecture for you to visit. You may pay only Yen100 for a fortune stick to check your wishes. The stalls outside selling souvenirs, handmade cakes, giant buns and clothes that you could spend half a day there easily. I consider it is a place you must visit if you are in Tokyo.
A MUST. Fantastic place with temples and historical sites. The market of souvenirs is really beautiful...and cheap...

Perfect place for tourist. I really love the place because there are souvenirs stores, shopping centers, temples, traditional crafts stores and restaurants around the place. Asakusa is one place in Tokyo where you can take a traditional rickshaw ride. Rickshaws are available in front of the temple. Prices start at 2,000 yen each for a 30 minute ride. Senso-ji temple, one of the oldest and most visited temples in Japan is also in Asakusa. Kaminarimon is the first of two large entrance gates leading to Sensoji Temple, adorned with a large red paper lantern that bears the inscription "Kaminari-mon" (Thunder Gate). This place is a must see when you're in Tokyo. A perfect place for tourist indeed.
Best for munchies. Best place to sampled japanese tidbits. Each stalls varies from one another but all selling fresh produce/bakes biscuits and cookies!
Japanese Culture. Saw a lot of people praying and looks like they don't mind all the tourist around them. Free entrance and a lot of gift shops

Just fell in love with it. The place was about 10 minutes from my hostel, and it just had everything. Aside from the temple, the place was just packed full of little shops selling almost anything and everything.There were all sorts of food stands and gift shops, you'd be hard pressed to go into them all in just the one day. Plenty of restaurants as well who also provide English menus so you're never lost in translation when you're here.
Average at its best. Nothing special. Though I enjoy taking some photographs here. There are street vendors selling tons of souvenirs and food, which looks interesting.

Great temple with shopping . A beautiful Buddhist temple but the people watching made it more interesting. Lots of craft and souvenir shops. What makes these nice is that the majority of the souvenirs are made in Japan and most of the shoppers are Japanese

Stay away. Typical touristy place. Lots and lots of people all around. There are better temples in Kyoto less crowded and more beautiful. Lots of shops selling all kinds of stuff line the pathway. Could not find anything impressive about it. All the tour groups find their way here . The plus is there is no entry fee.Most of the others charge , maybe this is the reason the tour groups prefer this temple. More of an industry than a place of worship. Can see a lot of women dressed in Kimonos. My advice is to stay away.m
Very crowded but worth it . Omg, it was so crowded, I couldn't move. Otherwise a great place to visit with lots of little shops, selling ice cream and other sweets. Don't miss out!!

Big crowds and Markets. We had heaps of fun in the crowds and looking at little stalls with gifts. Would not be good on a rainy day though.Look for the shop with Ghibli goodies at the entrance to the street

Busy Area Around Senso-ji Temple. It’s a busy area around Senso-ji Temple in Taito District. There seemed to be more tourists than the local people! I’ve found that the speech and the manners of the local people were much faster than the ones in the western suburbs.

Blazing hot in july. A few things to note:- Nothing in the area opens until lunch time. Not shops, not restaurants.- Shade is very scarce at midday. Next to the temple itself is a great little shaded patio with water misters. Use this as home base while exploring the area if your here in the hot season.- Surrounding the temple and related buildings is a great walking neighborhood with tons of shops, restaurants, etc. best to go in the late afternoon or evening if you're here during the summer.- Fairly deserted early in the morning. Great time to shoot photos if you're jet-lagged and not intent on shopping.

Fun market and great culture/history in this area. I lovely part of Tokyo. The market is full of fun souvenir stalls. Not extremely cheap but it's a great experience. We bought a few woodblock art prints there. The temples, shrines and pagodas in the area are worth a visit! Would love to go back again in the future.

Lovely Tourist Desination. My wife and I visited Tokyo this spring while the cherry blossoms where blooming. We loved visiting this excellent example of traditional Buddhist architecture. Before the temple complex there were lots of great little shops and food stalls. This is a great place to get a general understanding of Buddhist temple and worship, as most visitors are tourist and you wont be out of place asking questions or doing the rituals incorrectly.

Buddhist temple popular with local people. The Kannon Temple in Asakusa is a place of worship very popular among the local people. It has a number of structures and devotees throng the same every day.

Asakusa fun. The Asakusa area around Senso-ji Temple is a great place to spend an afternoon and evening especially if its raining. Mostly undercover streets of interesting shops and restaurants aimed at the Japanese tourists visiting the temple so prices aren't to bad. Lots of choices for food with most places having menus in english. You can also catch the river ferries from the terminal just opposite Asakusa train station

Asakusa Kannon Temple, Tokyo. Legend says it was completed in 645, this Buddhist temple, Tokyo's oldest, was built to honor Kannon, the goddess of mercy. Many buildings were destroyed by the war and rebuilt in 1649.
Tourists attracation and shops. Preserved old Japanese town including gate, shrines, 5 floor pagoda.Many souvenire shops and some food stallsAlso there is a theme park nearby/

Where souvenirs are!. The temple is few minutes away from the metro. You can just follow the crowd and you'll get there. I went on a weekday, but still, the its crowded. Once you reach the main gate, you'll be surprised to see all the souvenir shops. Lots of them! Ive been dying to find stores to get Japanese Handicrafts and this is the right place to get gifts for friends. Prices are reasonable, you can try to haggle :)) further in, there were tourists wearing kimono roaming around (you can rent it to have a feel walking around wearing their local costume) i believe they are conducting prayer during my visit :))

Too crowded . Sensoji Temple or Asakusa Buddhist Temple is delightful. When we visited, there were perhaps a contingent of men and women in Kimonos that presided inside with an afternoon ceremony. Although it is much storied as the oldest temple, it was much too crowded to even appreciate it. This is true to a travel warrior who have seen far better and well- run temples.

One good place to enjoy trational Japan. You get to see the iconic Kaminari-mon, Senso temple (Buddhism) and Asakusa shine (shin-do)You will get to see the Japanese version of amusement park, a little exhibition hall for tokyo craftsmen and their wares in a shopping area 10 minutes from Senso temple.PS: Kaminari-mon is under maintenance as of Jun 2016.

The red temple in Asakusa is a must. The area is crowded with people at most times. In the weekend it is enormous how many visitors come here. To get to the temple you walk from Asakusa metro station along a long lane filled with small shops selling all kind of stuff, most of it not needed, I would say, but quite entertaining.The temple is impressing. It was bombed during the war and totally destroyed - and now built up again as it was. However, the old temple was in wood - the new one is in concrete!

A must stop when you are visiting Tokyo. Asakusa is a beautiful typical Japanese city. Quite touristy though but the shopping street leading to the temple is great to buy not too expensive souvenirs. You can also try the traditional taxi but it is quite expensive (it might be worth if you want to make your girl friend happy). For food lovers, you have a huge choice of awesome food

Great area filled with temples, shops and unique Japanese culture.. Great area filled with temples, shops and unique Japanese culture. Definitely a must for any visitors to Japan. I would highly recommend the Shrine and the markets surrounding it. Make sure to try some of the local items from the stalls - oh and Green Tea Ice Cream!
Beautiful. Very beautiful and amazing! A must see in tokyo! Definitley a recommendation to see if you want some tokyo history
Feel the old world. It's a good place for the whole family with shops lining all the way from the gate to the shrine. There's all types of tourists knock knacks and packaged artisan food on offer.

Popular Temple with fun Shopping Area. I came here in the morning while I waited for the Sky Tree (within walking distance) to open. Since I was here pretty early most of the little shops were still closed but I also beat the crowds which allowed for some good picture opportunities. Sadly both Kaminarimon and the pagoda were undergoing restoration so I didn't get to see these. I enjoyed a leisurely stroll around the area and some tasty red-bean paste pastries which smell divine and tasted great.

Good place to absorb some of the culture and check out a traditonal temple. if you have a couple hours to spend and want to get the feel for the culture, albeit touristy , you should visit this place. conveniently located right off a train station. plenty of curio shopping and local food options. I noticed some things at the temple I handnt seen ever before which was pretty cool.

A Fun, Upbeat Area!. When visiting Tokyo, an afternoon spent meandering through Asakusa is well spent. The kitchen district is just between Asakusa and Ueno, which is what brought me here! The big temple in Asakusa is striking, and worth seeing all on its own.
Close to Sensoji Temple. Asakusa Shrine is steps from the Sensoji Temple. It was built in 1649 during the Edo period. We went on a Sunday in June, and we saw a couple getting married there.
My great stay in Asakusa. Great city, quite and I got what I needed. It's a charming city close to the center of "madness",aka Tokyo!
Loved it.. Great location, easy access to rail and subway. Good food and shopping too. The temple and shrine were great. Also, the street leading to the temple has great shopping for souvenirs.

Good market for buying Souvenirs. This is a good place for buying Souvenirs, like - Umbrella, T-Shirt, Sweets etc. Prices were bit expensive. So many food joints to choose from. A Tokyo visitor must pay visit to this place.

Nice for photo shooting and shop souvenir. Very close to subway, 5 mins walk from station and 15 mins walk from Skytree. Recommend to group Asakusa and Skytree together in one day travel. A long shopping street in front of the temple, many souvenir and food. The temple is nice, colourful and crowed, but overall it's worth to visit.
Business Trip. Due to our Business Trip we just had a short walk to Asakusa. The Main Gate is currently under construction, so you cannot see it. There are many constructions on-going until July.

To busy. This place had been at the top of my list to visit in Tokyo. On arriving it was just a mass of tourists so no clear photos or space to move freely. Shops the same tat as everywhere. Temple and lanterns were inpressive and would be worth a quiet look round if you got up early enough. The pagoda was covered in scaffold unfortunately.
Nice area to walk around. Good view of the river and a nice park with covers serval miles long the bank. Also this region has the Senso-ji Temple which is worth a visit
Glimses of old Edo. Great experience for shopping, eating and drinking in a neighborhood with old buildings surrounding Senso-ji temple.
Not only a temple. Temple with lots of shops and restaurants around. One won't be bored. Currently, some parts of the temple are under renovation.

Culture and shopping. This is a great area to explore in the North East of central Tokyo. After lunch at the Hard Rock Cafe at nearby Ueno station, we visited the Sky tree, Asahi Brewery (pictures only, it was Sunday and therefore closed), got great pictures of both across the river by the Tokyo Cruise departure area and then walked past hundreds of stores and restaurants. On a previous trip we went to the Senso-ji temple

Crowded but worth it. It seems like everyone who visits Tokyo comes to this Temple. It can be very crowded. But it is also very beautiful and worth seeing. Look for the dragon underneath the red lantern in the entrance gate.

Great Attraction. Ita was really great to spent a few hours there. Beautiful place. Great antique architecture and history.A lot of small shops around make the environment colorful and happy.A lot of small things and souvenirs can be purchased there.Apart from that, there are so many restaurants around that certainly you will find one that pleases you.

Traditional Japanese architecture and culture in the middle of Tokyo. Yo can see traditional homes and an impressive temple in the middle of Tokyo. Very easy to access via the subway (chikatetsu), dozens of mini stores on the front way to the temple and many cafes and restaurants in the area for a quick bite. Full of tourists, but big enough to accommodate everyone.

Bread. If you have the chance there is a little bread store that sells sweet bread. The line was long as when we went there but in honest truth, well worth the wait. I would fly over then again just for that bread.

Amazing Food Stalls & Wonderful Shrines. Not a place for calm and tranquility as the area is busy with worshippers and tourists but it's a great place to enjoy street food and see the wonderful shrines. The food in the area is to die for especially the Japanese sweets that are freshly made and sold.
Colorful. I would describe the place in one word - colourful. many shops selling expensive but high quality souvenirs.
Worth the Visit. A very beautiful temple with great culture and a huge selection of shops along the street. Could easily spend a few hours.
best part of town. I wished our hotel was here. It has the best restaurants, fun shopping and a gorgeous temple. Go to Tiger Gyoza!

Needed more time. We visited this area during the end of a tour and I was disappointed that we didn't get a chance to visit the markets properly to shop as it seemed like the best place in Tokyo for gifts. If I went back this place would be on top of my list.

Should visit the Shrine and the surrounding area and market. Very peaceful, and should visit when in Tokyo. Also the street leading to it with shops on each side is also nice to walk through and try some of the Japanese locally made sweets.

Great shopping. So much to see and do! Plenty of opportunities to try green tea ice cream, Japanese snacks, and Japanese food! Shops to purchase ninja shoes, Japanese socks and kimonos! A great selection of pottery, toys, fans, and Japanese souvenirs! A must do while in Tokyo!

Perfect for Tourists. Asakusa has a lot to offer to all tourists. Sensoji Temple and Tokyo SkyTree are all within walking distance. A ton of great restaurants, shops and everything else you could ask for.

Must See in Tokyo. Asakusa is a must see location for visitors to Tokyo. It is a tourist location and crowded but well worth the visit. The gates leading up to the temple make for great photo ops and if you need to buy any souvenirs from Japan this is a great place to do it. There are also some wonderful shaved ice and traditional sweet shops just off the main walkway leading up to Asakusa if you feel like having a treat.

Fantastic old world feel. Tokyo is a city built on a reputation of innovation and technology. Luckily, Asakusa is a throwback to the old world charm and history of Tokyo, and should definitely be near the top of the list for any tourist looking to come to Japan for an authentic experience.There are temples and shrines and souvenir shops, as well as a whole stock of fantastic restaurants. My recommendation would be to spend one full day/evening here, if not two full days, to get a full sense of the place.
Lovely complex. Definitely check this out while in Tokyo, at least if you're in the area. This is a nice temple complex, but it can be a bit touristy in the nearby area.

Asakusa by day, Asakusa by night. This is one of this places that you need to see by day and obligatory by night as well. Has a lot of charm. There is a beautiful area with handy-crafted things and lot's of places to eat. Also a big market, but is closing with the end of a day. Anyway stay around to come back and admire Asakusa by night time.

Very Touristy, But don't miss it. Lot can said, but, instead of just taking pictures, find a place to sit down and meditate!The Temple is surrounded by hundreds of shops and eating places.Best time to visit is early morning and then late evening after dark.

Nice visit. I stay in this area and happen to walk through Asakusa. This is a nice area but also very touristy. I suppose Tokyo is like that. But it was nice to see and explore. I bought a hat from a local vendor and she was very kind. It was rainy that day so not very nice to walk around. I also noticed the hype for melon buns which had a long queue.

Beautiful Shrine & Great shopping. This Shrine is located in a very busy area on Kaminarimon Avenue. The entrance was under remodeling when we arrived, however there was an information center across the street which gave us direction on how to get there. Take the train to Asakusa Station and walk one block to Kaminarion Avenue. Once you get to the entrance of the shrine, you will encounter a walkway with shops on both sides of the street, selling anything from souvenirs to ice cream.
