Once you walk down all of these shops, you get to the shrine which is very beautiful. At this location you can see the 5 story pagoda, which is part of the shrine. No fee to see this shrine. Great shopping.
Must visit. We stayed in a residential area of Asakusa, so wandered around a lot. Lovely area with good shopping.

Temple in the City. Asakusa, a religious centre in a busy Tokyo suburb. Pass through the Tori Gate and enter the Nakamise, a street of market stalls leading to the Senso-ji dedicated to Bodhisattva Kannon. Each of the stalls offering a myriad of gifts and souvenirs to the numerous visitors. Wander around the precincts of the temple and take in the flavours and aromas of the many restaurants and cafes mingling with the incense burners of the temple. A wondrous experience for any visitor and home of the Sanja Matsuri.

Mostly excellent. One thing you should know: Asakusa is LARGE. This means you'll get a lot of cool sights as well as countless ugly buildings and street. As is often the car in Tokyo, you find oases of beauty amidst oceans of squalid architecture. So don't be afraid to step into the side streets, discovering old houses and temples, pre-war bathhouses and of course, a score of temples!

Always very crowded but a must-see. Asakusa is one of those tourist attractions you actually do have to see while in Tokyo, and not because of just the temples themselves, but also the absolutely splendid gardens and the impossibly large variety of vendors on your way to the front.
Kind of a tourist trap. While nice, I find the place somewhat underwhelming, especially since Tokyo has so many other interesting places.

Meh . . .. We went to Asakusa expecting the charm of Old Tokyo but instead walked into pretty much a modern tourist trap. Given we only walked around Sensoji and Nakamise but all the buildings surrounding these 2 area were definitely modern. The only highlight for us is an open space behind sensoji where it seems to be where the local dog owners hang out in the evening. Plenty of cute shiba inus and other dogs :)

The cultural nucleus of theatre and literature in Tokyo. The residents of Asakusa were originally known as Edokko and this area is chic, stylish and great fun to wander round. Apart from the giant Senso-ji Temple founded in AD 628, Asakusa also has the Taiko-kan Drum Museum

Wonderful home base for a stay in Tokyo. . My wife and I used Asakusa as our home base for a two week trip to Tokyo. It was perfect for us because you're just a short 5-10 minute walk from the Asakusa station which connects via Ueno to Tokyo station. Not only that but the whole area is great. Senso-ji temple is an amazing stop for all visitors to Tokyo regardless of where you stay. Tons of shopping, tons of wonderful food and access to the rest of Tokyo at your fingertips. Can't ask for more!

traditional place. in the big city it's not easy to have this kind of place to see , especially in tokyo , asakusa is first place i visited in japan , my hostel was in there , I went there every day when i was there . you can pray and buy some gifts , and nice food too .
Nice but crowded. If you didn't have time to leave Tokyo then this is a nice temple. Super crowded, felt very touristy but that comes with the territory. Asakusa and the area is nice

I loved the surrounding area. Visited here with my family and we really enjoyed the temple and surrounding area. Yes its crowded AF but what do you expect? The temple was nice but what we really enjoyed was the surrounding areas of the temple. Yes, the streets were lined with souvenir shops and food stalls which you can find everywhere in Japan but the vibe was different. It was just relaxed, the air smelled of amazing fresh bread, and the crowd wasn't chaotic. Super chill. I'd definitely go back just to walk around and spend some quality time with my family.

A unique town with Senso-ji Temple, old Edo atmosphere, nice restaurants with Tokyo SkyTree and many foreign visitors!!. Asakusa is a must place to visit for foreigners with Senso-ji, the oldest and most important Temple in Tokyo, especially if they don't visit Kyoto. But, I've recently learned from my foreign friends and guests that Asakusa is a must place, even if you visit Kyoto and I always take then there. First, foreigners love Asakusa: not only because of Senso-ji Temple, Tokyo SkyTree and Kappabashi Kitchen Town, but also because of nice restaurants, such as Imahan, Kikko, Semetaro, etc. and unique old Edo atmosphere of the town. Second, towns in East Central Tokyo, such as Asakusa, Ueno, Ryogoku, Kinshicho are old downtown(called Shitamachi in Japanese) of Tokyo with nice frack open-minded people for generations. Third, these are mixed with the international atmosphere with so many foreign visitors: you can see more foreigners in Asakusa than in other towns in Tokyo. I can understand why many foreigners like staying in Asakusa!!

Procession during Sakura period... back to the olden days. Went to Asakusa in April, coincide with Asakusa Kannon-ura Ichiyo Sakura-Matsuri Festival. It is around Asakusa Komatsubashi-dori Street. Do get more information on the exact time procession will start. Need to be there at least half hour earlier if you want a good spot for photo taking. The crowd is massive and yes, please be careful if you are bringing kids along. It is a norm that people will try to walk together with the procession. My experience tell me not to do the same in future if I ever go again. Some people will not understand that there are barrier at the end of the road and yet they will keep pushing for you to move on. Luckily I took a U-turn and go to the opposite direction with much effort.This procession is a must go. So beautiful the costume, hair do and the performance. Everyone was very excited. See the pictures included with this review.

Touristy Place but still a Must-See. Like most of the reviews, yes it does look like a small pocket of Kyoto in Tokyo. As you enter the shrine you pass through Nakamise street which is lined up with food and souvenir shops. You'll be tempted to try out the goodies for sure. This is part of the experience. If you are only there for the temple, best to see it in the evening when the lights are on. Either that or early in the morning when there is less of a crowd. It is very much a tourist place and you wont be able to take a decent picture with a bunch of tourists in the shot. We enjoyed it nonetheless. You can't have all the spots for yourself of course. Being there was awesome and once in a lifetime experience.

little kyoto in tokyo. asakusa reminds me of kyoto city which have shirnes n lots authentic n unique traditional goods that u can purchase as souveniri came in evening around 7pm..the stores start to close down

Asakusa - Senso-ji Shrine. Sensō-ji is an ancient Buddhist temple located in Asakusa, Tokyo, Japan. It is Tokyo's oldest temple, and one of its most famous and significant. The shopping street leading up to the temple is Nakamise where visitors swarm to purchase a multitude of all things traditional. Once inside, the atmosphere changes to one of purification and tranquility.

Disappointment. I have been to Sensoji temple three times since 2007. This trip was the first time i felt that it was truly a touristy place with throngs of tourists making a mess of the place. The nearby shops have also lost its charm and seriously I will not include this in my to do list during my next trip.

Another temple in Tokyo. Its better to go early in the morning. I came here around 10am on sunday...and it was very crowded hence theres a ceremony going on here. They have nice snack along the way to the temple and souvenir also.

A must place to visit. The temple is very big but very crowded... the price of the japanese goodies & souvenirs are pretty expensive..But you will enjoy the streetfood... the temple is amazing & very pretty... for some photo you can visit my instagram #mayawanderlust

Shopping! . The shops in front of the temple are so much fun. Also wander into the side streets for more finds! The quality of souvenirs surpasses much of what we are used to in the US. Make sure you see the shop closest to the temple with the incredible miniatures.
Cool walk-around. Nice neighborhood, tons of little shops, many of the streets are covered which is obviously great in the rain. Touristy for sure, but what part of Tokyo isn't??

One of Tokyo's Highlights. We arrived by boat under the Red Bridge and walked through Kaminari Mon (Main Gate) into the Nakamise Shopping Arcade. It was a Sunday and although very crowded with locals (a lot of girls in Kimonos) and tourists, it was like a well organised street market from Hong Kong. The shops sold everything from arts and craft souvenirs to food and drink and clothing. It was a great place to wander as well as people watch. After passing through Hozo Mon (Middle Gate), we then were able to enter the Kannon Temple and also view the Five-Storied Pagoda. It is also accessible by subway. Do not miss seeing and experiencing it.
An Imperial Temple!. Plenty of shops in front of the temple. Rickshaw in front of the temple entrance is worth to try, but quite pricey.

Don't miss Asakusa. Plenty to do in this area - both for the traditional tourist groups, as well as the intrepid traveler. There are the typical souvenir shops and 'tourist trap' restaurants, but with a little bit more searching away from the main strip, there are plenty of cool and exciting things to come by - kimono tailors and traditional goods (not souvenirs!). Also, the Asahi building is across the river, which is a great rooftop place to have a beer to watch the sunset! Head back to Senso-ji temple at night time when its all lit up!

Fantastic area.... Well, if you happened to visit Tokyo, and gave Asakusa a skip, please don't tell anyone..they will declare you an idiot. I believe Asakusa would be among the best neighbourhoods in Tokyo. A delightful blend of modern and traditional, the area is full of locals and tourists alike. The Asakusa shrine happens to the center piece, but the shops selling made in Japan souvenirs also share the limelight. And as you shall observe is the rest of the city, this place too is packed with restaurants of all hues and colours. Trust me, your trip to Asakusa will be among the highlights of your trip to Tokyo. I actually started my journey of discovering the city from Asakusa. And what a way to start...

A must do, even if you only have one day in Tokyo. This is a must do. Nakamise dori is one of the most charming old shopping streets in japan (if utterly “Disney-fied” at this point). The key is the array of fantastic foods available in the various shops – highlights for us were the “Sofutu Aisu” (soft ice cream) and the “meron pan” (melon bread) – the best example of the latter was actually not in nakamise dori but in a covered pedestrian street just as you exit Senso Ji to the west. Also consider getting tempura at one of the many local spots (we liked Aoi Marushin) and the Hana Yashiki amusement park is a great diversion for kids aged 5-14.

Spiritual experience. There were very few people visiting Asakusa in the early morning before 8:00 AM, but no shops were open at this time. If you are lucky, you can observe a traditional Shinto's ceremony.
hidden treasures. It’s one of the best places in Tokyo to find traditional Japanese items and souvenirs. Cheaper than places in central Tokyo

Amazing, plenty to do!. Asakusa is aaawesome! I did plenty of shopping here in the main street, and even more shopping in the side streets, so please feel free to do some exploring! I discovered a lovely taiyaki place, purse maker, and UFO catcher place in the side streets, so please explore! The main strip itself is wonderful, and even more beautiful at night when the stores are lit up (but keep in mind that the stores close in the late afternoon!). The shopping culminates in a beautiful Buddhist temple is plenty to do and explore, and most important structures have plaques in English explaining their significance. My person favorite aspect of the temple portion of Asakusa is the area to the left of the main temple if you're facing it (north of the pagoda). There's a lovely koi pond and bridge that provided the backdrop for some of the greatest photos I took during my trip to Japan.Oh, and just a bone I need to pick with other reviewers: Yes, the place is filled with tourist, but that's because it's gorgeous! And here's a little secret: YOU'RE A TOURIST TOO! Why else would you have visited it and reviewed it on TripAdvisor?! A hefty number of tourists means the place is so fantastic, everyone knows about it or was told to visit it. So see tourists as a positive, not a negative!

Worth an early visit . We were staying nearby so we visited a few times. The first time during the day was very very busy so didn't really appreciate it. We then visited after dark and again at 7 in the morning and then you get a better sense of it. So worth trying trip but try to go early or late in day.

One of my favorite parts of Tokyo!. Asakusa has a great shopping street leading up to a very cool temple. We wished we had more time to explore this part of the city. It's a little outside of the regular Tokyo center, but worth the connecting subway trip to get out there!

Many tourists, nice structure. Depending on how many temples you have already visited, you may or may not wish to give this a miss. It is large, elaborate, but so many people. I saw more tourists here than any other location in Japan.I did enjoy playing the game outside of the temple. Spend 100 yen to get your fortune. You shake a jar, a chop stick drops out, tells you the number of the drawer to open and alas your fortune is written on a sheet of paper. If you get a good or regular fortune you keep it and give thanks. If you have a bad fortune, you tie the paper to a railing nearby and hope for something better next time. We were with locals so they explained the whole thing. Fun to see so many people doing this.

Beautiful, folkloric... JAPANESE . Asakusa was definitely one of the places we will remember from Tokyo, it's beautiful, especially at night, has a great deal of things to do from bars, restaurants, shopping, temple, sight seeing is just great in that area. Must see.
Crowded but worth it. Great area for shopping. the temple was beautiful and the side streets are full with street food vendors, restaurants and a variety of little stores. We had a great time there.

The Traditional Side of Tokyo. A nice and calmer area in Tokyo. The main attraction is the temple and shrine with signature of big red bell. A lot of souvenir shop and restaurant, including halal restaurant for muslims.

Beautiful & amazed one. instead of shorts of time, when reached here, i overwhelmed & speechless. very crowdy but all traveler & devotees are in disciplined manner.the Sakura blooms add more fragrance on it. i became very nostalgic .

Perfect for kimono shopping. This area of Tokyo has a much older feel to it than most of the other areas. Tempura is is speciality. Many tour groups come here making it very busy. If you're looking to rent or buy kimono and accessories then this is the place in Tokyo to go to. You can also have rickshaw rides here. The shrine at the top was very impressive. Not so impressive what the performing monkey on a chair outside. Lots of little shops in the shopping street. Go to Wargo to buy traditional Japanese hair accessories (kanzashi).

Night glory. Beutiful temple the best to see in night. It wasn't crowded at all. We haven't seen so busy street and finish dining in area. There is many restaurants around to choose it. Highly recommending.

Great temple, less great shopping street. When arriving at Asakusa, we were kind of shocked, how people keep pushing each other along the narrow streets between the souvenir shops.This was a bit annoying, as in the rest of our stay, we were never pushed around like that.Anyways, when finally arriving at the temple itself, we were impressed by all the people praying and respecting their religion and belief even with all the tourist around.The shops around that area sell a lot of cheap and some good quality souvenirs on a rather good price. We haven't tried the restaurants, but a lot of smiling and happy people when they were eating or just leaving the restaurants.
Traditional and beautyful. Small shops, beautiful temples and architecture. Hotels around here are also a great choice if you'd like to try the traditional Ryookan style hotels

Great temple. The best one in all Japan that has has all the picture postcard shots. Can get very crowded so visit early in the morning or in the evening which gives a different perspective with all lights.
Cultural experience . Easily accessible by a quick train trip. Interesting cultural experience in Tokyo. Great place with young families because there are parents rooms in nearby shopping centre.

Plenty to experience. Lots of culture and shopping. Had an amazing busy atmosphere I'd recommend to anyone of any age. For cat lovers I recommend the Nekoen Cat Cafe over others - not really much food or drink but these are rescue cats you'll be helping!
Lovely!. A must see in Tokyo. It has an amazing temple but is also worth for its typical market and the old houses and restaurants. A nice place to 2-3 hours.
We loved this area. Stayed at Gate Hotel, which was outstanding and wonderfullocation. The area around Sensoji Temple, across street from Gate, was extra special at night, the tourist herd was gone.
Great location to spend a few days. Asakusa is a vibrant area with lots of attractions and is ideal for anyone who does not want to be located in central Tokyo.
Asakusa!!. One of the best places to know the culture and temples in Tokio. I found a lot of places to buy souvenirs and a lot of good restaurants.

Nice at night. We went in the evening which I think is ideal. For one, all the shops were closed so it felt less commercialized. And there weren't a lot of people around. And it looks cool all lit up a night.

Perfect place to buy souvenir. Here, the souvenir is quite cheap, you can get key holder for 300-350yen. the pretty napkins or small towel is around 400yen. You can also find the ghibli store in front of the tourism centre/the front gate on the right side.I bought totoro finger doll around 300yen.
Great sightseeing and souvenir area. This is a great sightseeing and souvenir area. Easily accessed via the train. Lots of touristy shopping. Close to the Skytree and other areas of interest.

What I like about Japan.... Asakusa is totemo kakkoii (very cool). I only gave it an "average" review, because I don't believe in overrating things, just because I like them. It doesn't mean that it's not good, it just means that not everyone else out their is as hypnotized by Japan as I am. After all, there is a reason that I had to return to live & work there on 3 separate occasions, after my first visit there (right after college in 1999)... For me, Asakusa represents everything that is so spectacular about Japan. It has this peculiar blend of the traditional/ancient, mixed in with the ultra-modern, all at once. Everything is convenient, organized, efficient, and clean. Just thinking of words to describe it now, makes me want to go back again!

Must Visit Temple in Tokyo. Must visit temple in Tokyo.Many street food around Nakamise Street, rice creakers, ice cream, accesories, etc.When u get out from Asakusa Temple, u can walk a hundred metres to take a photostop in front of Tokyo Sky Tree and Asahi Beer Building.

An Amazing Place to Visit. We toured Asakusa Kannon Temple as a part of a Gray Line tour. This is a beautiful Temple and it is adjacent to Nakamise Shopping Street which is filled with vendors selling food and goods of all kinds. The Temple has the traditional aspects of the incense and the hand rinsing area. There is also a beautiful garden with Koi in the stream. There is lots to see inside the Temple area and in the Shopping Street.

Nice shine and old street. Visited during the sakura seasons, the shine have lots of photogenic spots to take photos at. Enjoyed walking down the old street of Asakusa with my gf. :) lots of foods to eat and try! *thumbs up*

Very crowded but interesting Nakamise & beautiful Sensoji Temple. If you wanna take nice photo, must go as early as possible. We went in a weekday 8.30am, the crowd started, after around 9-10am super crowded, felt sad that most of the photos was many people around me!人形烧, Ningyo-yaki is a small snack cake, made by cooking batter of flour, eggs and sugar in an iron mold. They are sold both with and without sweet bean paste. I prefer the store which an old uncle was baking, an uncle packing then an aunt selling, it was instantly from the baking machine, red bean fillings & the outer skin was so balance, selling one in a packing then u can just try one, if nice then to buy more；another store quite outstanding at the corner but I felt the red bean fillings was too much as the skin is too thin, selling a few in one packing. Watch out a corner ice-cream store, the mocha ice-cream was superb. A lot of souvenirs specific "Asakusa logo" cannot find elsewhere so must buy here but design & quality was so so.Don't just walk the Main Street Nakamise, walk to the back alley, you will find something else to see! Thanks for the vote if you found this helpful :D

Fantastic Area. We stayed in Asakusa area for the Tokyo portion of our stay and we loved it, lots of good places to eat and things to do. We even got a Rickshaw through the streets of Asakusa and were lucky enough to do so when the blossoms were in full bloom.

Vibrant area. Suggest you disembark at the Asakusa subway stop and turn right and right again and travel up Nakamise street to get to the shrines at the top end. The markets on Nakamise are great fun to shop at with some great street food and a huge variety of products to sample. Some junk and some not too bad.After having visited the temples and shrines at the top, you casn head right again and cross the river to the skytree if you so wish.

Traditional Tokyo. Great place to experience the more traditional part of Tokyo. The many people who were dressed in yukatas and walking around add on to the experience. Lots of interesting and yummy traditional snacks especially the sweet potato pastries to try all over. When I was there, temporary stores selling food were set up all over.

Put this in list!. How a lovely place with a lot of restaurants aside. Must be add on vacation list especially when you are in Japan. Nice and beautiful surrounding completed with pagoda also. Be ready for crowded visitor!

Beautiful at night. We enjoyed an evening visit to Asakusa, and very much enjoyed the way it was lit up at night. Many of the temple buildings were understandably closed, as were many of the shops in the street, but enough were still available for some souvenir shopping. The surrounding area has a lovely atmosphere with many restaurants etc. I would have liked some extra time to visit during the day as well.
Superb experience. . Located in the Sensoji comping this is a superb example of classic Japanese architecture. Must also visit the adjoining gardens and water features.

Make it a priority for your trip to Tokyo!. This is a must destination for anyone visiting Tokyo and make sure to stray away from the Nakamise and temple and wander into the alleyways. There are many stores and restaurants to check out and while it is usually very crowded, the alleyways are a little less so. Many of the authentic Japanese stores are resident here including one that will custom mix your red pepper selection. Get a talisman at the temple (can be found at the right hand side of the temple) to protect you from a variety of things. I always get one for traffic safety though there are others for luck in romance, school, work, etc.

A "must visit" site for tourists. We had been to Asakusa many many years ago and by chance we visited this spot in late April this year. Much improvement was seen around the spot. There were lots of shopstalls selling food and souvenirs and the main alley just led visitors to approach Senso-ji Temple. The rest garden and the restaurants on the side streets also attracted tourists and we did took some pictures on such during our visit here. Highly recommend tourists to visit this spot during stay in Toyko.

Great shopping around. Asakusa district is a great place for shopping in local small shops, for eating and of course for visiting the famous Buddhist temple Senso-ji. You can find luggage in best prices there.

Cool place for strolling, shrining and eating. Our hotel was located in Asakusa and really happy it was. The area is quite pedestrianised or at least has very few main roads and cars, meaning it is good for strolling around.Nearby is the Senso-Ji Temple - a must see in Tokyo. Very big and red. The temple is lit up at night when it's a lot less crowded. Perhaps head here after dark for dinner? Also close by is Nakamise shopping street - crowded but good fun. Lots of snack food, and all the cute souvenirs you could ask for.This is also a good area for restaurants especially Izakayas (Japanese pubs). When the working day is over, these are filled with office workers squeezed onto benches and stools enjoying beers and Yakatori (skewers of food). Can get pricey once you have more than 2-3 skewers but is fun and very different.

Lovely day exploring the area. Wonderful way to see the area, with a guide to show the best sights and explain more about the history.Worth going up to the viewing deck of the Tourist Information Centre to overlook Sensoji Temple. Is free.

Tourist attraction. A large temple, alleys with an array of light bites, and souvenir stores. What else can we ask for? Take lots of photos from many angles as all of them are most likely beautiful. Get some bites such as honey sweet potato (daigaku imo) and ice cream. They look so ravishing and taste so heavenly that I forgot to take pictures of them.
Quaint with a relaxed vibe . The place is laid back as compared to the other parts of Tokyo. There's a merry mix of culture, history and modern life.

A must if you are in Tokyo. This area is quite busy but it's one of the most beautiful places in Tokyo. Asakusa Shrine and Senso-ji temple are the highlights of a trip here but until you reach these 2 attractions you pass through a pedestrian area with lots of shops. You can buy lots of souvenirs here like kimodolls, shinkansen miniature trains, temples and much more. There is also an icecream shop closeby from where you can buy sakura or sweetpotato icecream.

great area of Tokyo !. A must go area while visiting Tokyo, many shops , temples, hotels, river side, sky tree not far, Ueno park not far, access to and from airport is easy too. my favourite place to stay while staying in Tokyo. downtown side as i love :)

Tourist trap. Spent a few hours exploring the area and apart from the crowded Senso-ji and the nearby garden, this area is pretty unpleasant. It's completely overrun with tourists and there's no 'old tokyo' feel in my opinion. Most of the old low rise buildings in the area seem to have been long knocked down. Much worse than comparable areas in Kyoto and even in Tokyo. If you don't like crowds and tourist markets and tour groups... skip here.

Traditional Tour. The shrine was very beautiful with architectures and green with large trees.Around the shrine, there were many interesting souvenir that tourists should not miss. You could find good food, souvenirs, and the best japan sweet rice desserts (Dun Go) around the neighborhood.

Very nice area. I loved the little shops outside the temple! but if you're going to buy the food and eat, you have to finish eating in front of their stall and you cannot walk away because they will push you inside their store...we bought the icecream and had to finish it before leaving the icecream place...anyways, it was nice to take pictures outside the temple, there were cherry blossom trees but not fully bloomed when we went there.

Impressive but crowded. We arrived in the area around 11am and there were lots people. I'm guessing a very early morning visit would be better.The market leading up to the temples might interest some people but for me they are a bit tacky, and many things made in China, we didnt buy anything here.The temples are amazing though, and possible to get a photo of the temples with the Tokyo skytree in the back ground for old/new shot. If you feel like a good walk then head towards Tokyo Skytree afterwards, and on the way, a short walk from the east exit of the temples, have a break at kaminari issa/Omatcha cafe. They sell matcha ice cream, matcha beer and obviously tea and have a few tables to sit.

Fun time in an interesting part of Tokyo. Lots of people here, but it's to be expected. It's a great place for photos (both of the architecture and of the people), a lot to see and do here. It's a very charming, nostalgic place which every visitor to Tokyo should see at least once. Also, there's no shortage of restaurants, souvenir shops, and even a Don Quijote store.For additional fun, try Asakusa while dressed in a kimono! There are numerous kimono rental places around Asakusa.

Nice temples and gardens and lots of markets nearby!. Asakusa is a lovely old temple, about 10 minute's walk from Asakusa metro station. On the day I was there, there were also lots of interesting market stalls on the way selling all sorts of random souvenirs and clothing. Also, there were around 50 food stalls very close to the temple itself. I sampled a few things and they were very nice! The temple itself was very crowded but the surrounding gardens and smaller temples allowed for some great photo opportunities! Admission to the temple and gardens is free!
beautiful shrine. beautiful shrine complex with many tourists, both local and international, as well as many market stalls to buy souvenirs

Energizing yet tranquil experience. Asakusa relives the charm of a old Japanese location (town) with a temple and lots of local traditional shops. It is next to Asakusa train station and hence very easily accessible. The entrance to his place as well as the Sensouji Temple inside the complex is free. Right outside the main gate is the Information visitor center which can provide all the required information about this location including maps and few insighful tips. As you enter the main gate, right there on the gate are large bells, impressive and mammoth. The entrance is followed by lane of orderly shops on both sides, have all kinds of items to sell (products, knick-knacks, souvenirs...) and food items. It is an energetic and vibrant experience.As you get through a long corridor of shops, you arrive at another massive gate, again with large bells and it leads you into Sensouji Temple. The temple is serene and a tranquil experience. As you get in and observe some of the local rituals and leave there is a large Buddha statue outside and has a very calming effect. There is a also a Japanese Pagoda in the complex and right from the complex you can also see a modern Sky Tower which is several blocks from Asakusa location.Overall, worth visit and plan on spending 3-5 hours.Right outside next to the visitor center is the Denny's restaurant so if you are tired and hungry after the visit, it is a great place to eat a good bite including tea/coffee to refresh. Down the lane, I was told, there is also a Burger King for those want American fast food.The Asakusa train station is very close and you can connect to any location in Tokyo, in some cases with a train change.

Sights and Shopping Combined. A visit to Asakusa is a must . Locals frequent it. If you're lucky some nice ladies in traditional Kimono would be seen and oblige for photos . Highlights include the temple , the ritual of cleansing the soul with water and incense . With the many small stores lined up at the front , you can indulge in shopping for food and souvenirs as well.

Asakusa - Geisha for a day!. Asakusa offers a great variety of Japanese temples, culture and nature. If you want to get a full Japanese geisha outfit experience I'd recommend you to rent a kimono at any of the local rental shops around Asakusa. You can choose from a variety of kimonos and also have your hair done to complete the full geisha look. Once you're all set you can walk around the temples to get amazing photos and feel like a star.(If you don't like to have your picture taken by random people all day then this is not for you!)In Asakusa temple you can find out your good or bad fortune that you afterwards will hang along other people's fortunes.There's tons of small tourist and souvenir boutiques and stands everywhere, most places will only accept cash unless you'll purchase things for over 2000 yen.

Something for everyone. Just as you enter from the main road, you will find many souvenir shops and things to buy. Worth to shop around to get a bargain.Bought some small gifts made in Japan for friends and family.

Wonderful area with lots of different traditional shops. Its the area where you can find two major attractions...the tokyo sky tree and most importantly...the Sensoji temple...you won't be disappointed...i guarantee you that...the place is full with small souvenir shops ...lots of small places that sells traditional food and sweets...an unforgettable walk...

Amazing neighborhood with many attractions. We decided to stay in this neighborhood during our visit to Tokyo, it was a great choice! Near iconic attractions as Asakusa Shrine and Tokyo Skytree, you can also find great restaurants and services nearby. The streets are calm and safe even during the night.
Nice place. Mostly crowded, but worth visiting. :))Beautiful temple within 2 min walk from train station. The 'Must' when you visit Tokyo.

Amazing experience. Don't mind the heaps of tourists coming in and out of this area from Sensouji Temple! This area in Asakusa is a must. If you really want a full depth guide, you can get one for FREE (and if you're lucky, you can get someone that speaks great english) if you just visit the Asakusa Culture Tourist Information Center right across Kaminarimon Gate. We were also able to watch a free Geisha Ozashiki Odori (Traditional Dance) organized by the said Info Center but you need to get your hands on tickets early because the seats are limited (PS they have mini games after the show and my brother won a prize!). You can also enjoy window shopping at Nakamise-dori. If you really want to buy something, be sure to check out every shop because most, if not all, shops jack up their prices because their target market is the pack of wide-eyed tourists that are just so excited to bask in the cultural awesomeness of Japan. There are other temples surrounding Sensouji so be sure to walk around the area before leaving.
So many things you can do here !. Beautiful traditional place but also lots of fun shops and delicious authentic Japanese restaurants and cafe ...you can hang around all day !

Impressive building. The actual shrine/temple are beautiful and when I went (first couple of weeks in April) there was a mini parade on which was good to watch (the name of it has slipped my mind) The only thing I would warn of is there are loads of people on the way up to the area, I mean you will struggle to move through the crowds.
Loved it. Really enjoyed this area. Great parks, shops, restaurants. Near the river. Brilliant transport options. Very calm and quiet in the evening.

Don't stop at the temple, look behind it. Asakusa is brilliant at night, something that a lot of visitors may not realise. Stay after sunset and look behind Senso-ji temple to find a lively down to earth neighbourhood where 'old' traditions and new hipster Tokyo meet. The temple is spectacularly lit up, there's a quaint tiny amusement park that locals line up for to visit. If you're looking to stay somewhere in Tokyo that's easy to access and away from the hustle and bustle of Shinjuku and Shibuya, Asakusa may be your best choice.

Favourite Place to visit in Tokyo. One of my favourite places to visit in Tokyo. Senso-ji Temple absolutely amazing (although very touristy, but if you go there at night, the lighting is beatuiful and you miss the crowds...and sadly the souviner stores). The shopping out the front of the temple is also great as are the shops around the temple, a fantastic place to get souvenirs (kitschy and non-kitschy varieties), we actually came back on our last day to stock up! Great food in the area, and several other smaller temples worth a visit too. First timers to Japan, a solid spot to visit.

An all in one stop. Asakusa is part of the city which provides entertainment, dining, and history in one stop. The main street leading up to the Senso-ji temple (Nakamise-dōri) is lined with small shops for confections and souvenirs. The smells are intoxicating and it is impossible to resist buying at least one of the delicious treats. There are restaurants and cafes down the sides streets if you are looking for something a little more substantial to eat as well. Once you reach the temple, the site of this enormous and active temple is astounding. The level of artistic detail is rarely seen in the western world in this magnitude. The temple sits on garden grounds that are spacious and beautiful. It was not originally a destination on our itinerary, but I now would have regretted missing it.
World. Old Buddhist temple.A lot of shops in the compound for souvenirs .good photo opportunities.crowded by tourists and locals .on the way ,one can get a snapshot of Tokyo 100 years ago.

Best Place for Souvenir Shopping. We got the best deals at Asakusa. The collection of souvenirs and eatables were the best out here. From hot rice wine to gooey rice balls to hot fresh pancakes to wasabi flavored rice crackers and the list goes on and on. We had never tried these goodies earlier and dint know about them as well but Asakusa really made our taste buds happy. Loved everything about this place.

Very touristic place but still interesting to visit. Very touristic place of Tokyo old downtown. From above, you can see a very crowded shopping street leading to a Budhist Temple and a Shinto Shrine side by side.

Definitely go, but expect crowds and touristy shops. Initially posted this for the eponymous shrine. The tourist crowds notwithstanding, this is yet another exciting example of an enclave of history, tradition and religion in the heart of a bustling city. In that, it is splendid and a must see. The crowds and the shops in the surrounding area which mostly feel like tourist traps detract from the whole experience.

Old downtown. It is the traditional style, old downtown of Tokyo. It is just a hop skip and jump, or short train ride if you prefer, away from the Tokyo Skytree. It has many famous areas, temples, and shrines to visit. If you find yourself stopping at one of the many street vendors, which is a must try when you go. Please stop and eat, as it is considered very rude to eat on the go. There is plenty to stumble upon. I suggest walking down the streets and just taking everything in, check out some of the traditional areas, and some of the shopping areas, there is a little something for everyone there. Hope that you enjoy your visit in Asakusa.

Best place for souvenirs in Tokyo. Asakusa is an easy train ride away from most big places in Tokyo. It is by far the best place for gifts and souvenirs. It has a plethora of shops along its markets and prices are decent. You can find something for everyone here. It can get a little crowded and spaces are very tight so it can be hard if you have a young family with you. The temple is also a nice sight but not the best in Tokyo. Recommended as a one stop shop for gifts and souvenirs
Great place to see.. Be a tourist! Go see this place. It's worth the trip. I recommend this place to all visitors. Great food all around.

Buzzing with life. There are many shops and places to eat here. It is quite loud and difficult to navigate with a stroller because it is so crowded. In saying that, it really was cool to see what the little stalls had to offer and to absorb the chaotic environment.

Must-see. If you're in Tokyo, don't miss it. You'll find a Budhist Temple and a Shinto Shrine side by side, and a shopping street leading to them, where you can buy all sorts of goods at reasonable prices.

Really good shopping and an impressive temple. Asakusa market is one of he top places to visit in Tokyo, you can pay for a guided tour or just go and absorb the atmosphere yourself. The main Street is full of food stalls , the cooking aromas and the smoke really make you feel hungry, the side streets are full of cheap watches and shiny suits. Quite a place.At the top of the street is the temple, which is a oasis of calm, you can get your fortune for 100¥ Definitely one to visit day or night, or both!

Shopping at Asakusa. Asakusa is another district most frequented by tourists. It is easily accesible by train. The souvenir shops along the road leading to the Sensoji Temple offers various authentic Japanese products, from food to gift items, bags and even shoes. We expected that their prices would be higher than those in the souvenir shops in the city. BUt it turned out, theirs are even lower. So if you find something you fancy in this area, better grab it. Good bargain here.

Wonderful.... If you are in Tokyo for a few days, add this shrine to your list. It really is a beautiful place with a lovely pagoda on the site as well. This is a magnet for locals and tourists alike so be prepared for some serious crowds! The gardens are also beautiful and when we were there in late April, the azaleas were just coming into bloom with a brilliant array of colours. There are dozens of food stalls so you won't go hungry while you are looking round.

Hustle n Bustle . One of our favourites, we love the busy vibe of this area. The temple is wonderful by itself but the surrounding market, shops and restaurants are fantastic. You could wander the small streets for hours. A must do in Tokyo.
Beautiful . Near beautiful streets for sweets and souvenirs and local restaurants. Recommend exploring and planning a day at this side of Tokyo when visiting the shrine.
Cool little area in Tokyo. Good location to the main city and to Narita Airport. Lots to do and see, easy to navigate and great places to eat.
Must see in Tokyo. A great place to combine some history and shopping - a quintessential Tokyo experience. Don't miss out on the food vendors, either.

Fabulous half day (or more!) way to spend the day.. This was one of our favorite places during our two and half week stay in Japan with a good mix of different things to do and loads of variety in such a small area. Firstly, it is a highly touristy area so there might not be a true authentic feeling if that's what you're looking for but it's a great romp enjoying the crowd's energy, multiple food stalls, souvenir shops as well as exploring the temple. We arrived hungry so we pigged out along Nakamise Street. Our favorite item was fried manju (rice flour, savory or sweet filling and then tempura coated before frying) but there were also popular stalls selling soy rice crackers (senbei), flavored rice dumplings on skewers (dango), sponge cakes, sweet pancakes, filled pastries (ningyo yak) and quite a lot of bean paste and strawberry items as well. (Note: It is considered polite to loiter / eat your food items in front of the stall you purchased them from and not block any other stall/store's space.)
Wonderful architecture and feeling. This part of Tokyo is great for browsing around and the Temple and Shrine are among the finest in Japan. Well with the visit.

Asakusa. Absolutely stunning Temple, in the most wonderful setting, busy with both tourists and locals just soaking up the atmosphere and architecture and culture. very popular with young Japanese dressed in formal costume who are happy for you to take their picture to add to your memorable day. Lots of food around to try. A Simply must see.

Junky but fun. Couple insider suggestions.. This is a huge Buddist temple that was basically rebuilt in 1964 after being destroyed in the war (sorry), but it looks way older. It has one of the best cornball tourist souvenir shop districts IN THE WORLD leading up to it, which is why I come here. Next to Ye Olde Curiosity Shoppe in Seattle and Buffalo Bill Cody's Trading Post in North Platte Nebraska, this is as good as it gets (Tokyo Tower may be #5, after South of the Border). Tons of Japanese geegaws as well as typical tourist junk -- I got a pair of DEVO style cyclops sunglasses for 1000¥, while my wife bought actual nice textiles from Japan for 1300¥. So there's a variety. Lots of good, if touristy, places to eat around here. The actual temple leaves me flat, but I'm team Shinto, so I really groove on the quiet, reflective atmosphere of the Meiji Jinguu Shrine in Harajuku, versus this crowded loud claptrap.Here's my insider suggestion: Turn left at the main temple and walk to the amusement park. While the temple is so packed with tourists it feels like you're in Des Moines, the amusement park is 100% locals only (totally friendly to tourists though). It's a great peek at older post-war Japan, and it has real Japanese people in it. Plus you can ride a giant battery powered plush panda bumper car for like 400¥. There are lots of mega cornball attractions outside the park, like a "ninja photo booth" and I recommend those as well, if you like corny stuff. But the amusement park is a real part of Japan not many westerners take the time to see -- I only went when a Japanese friend who knew of my love of schmaltzy things took me there. It's neat.Also, if your family has been bugging you to go to a cat cafe, there are cheap ones around there. I think we did 30 minutes for like 600¥ each? Or 400? I forget but it felt cheap and the cats were chill. We went to the one on Orange street. (Turn left at the ninja model on the souvenir walk, and left again at the next street -- then look up, it's on floor two).
Shrine... Japaneese culture. Amazing placeAsakusA famous shrine nice architecture beside shops for souvenirs Food lovers are well servedPeaceful place its a must visit if u r in Tokyo

My first vist to Asakusa Temple. I really liked the place. It was during the night time when I've visited, and the light up on the 浅草寺, the temple was so beautiful. The place was very lively and many souvenir shops were seen. A very good place to buy present for your acquaintances.

Sensoji and neighborhood. Beautiful temple and environs. Beautiful at night . Lots of tourists during sakura season !!!Go to the top of the Asakusa cultural center food beautiful views of the temple and Sumida river.
Fantastic place. We have been back to Asakusa for the third time. Both the temple and shrine are amazing and the old buildings which surround them are so different to the rest of Tokyo.

Great Temples and other Structures. If you don't mind the crowds or the tacky street vendors this isn't a place to miss. The pagoda is stunning and there are a few gardens around to give the photographer some interesting foreground. The 'street food' is varied, reasonable and delicious. Proximity to the Asakusa Train Line makes this a good stop. There are great restaurants within an few blocks walk.
Nice temple. The only minus... too many tourists. It is a nice temple with a beautiful garden and very nice illumination during night. From my point of view is the nicest temple in Tokyo area.

Over rated. Asakusa is one of the famous landmark in Tokyo. So I have taken my family & friends to Asakusa numerous times over the years; during this March visit I was very agitated with the crowd. In my opinion it is not worth my time to visit & be in a slow moving mass of people.
Too crowded to enjoy. Far too many people (us tourists) to really enjoy this and the shrine seems to be a bit of a money making machine. Very commercial.

Always the most popular temple to visit.. I like this temple though it's really very touristic. But the transportation is convenient and welcomes international tourists (they have abundant experiences toward tourists from abroad).

Pretty, but very touristy.. Lots of cool architecture and plenty of history for those that want to read before going, so you know what you are looking at. A lot of tourists that take some of the fun out of the experience.
fantastic photo shots. Wow this place was amazing best photo shots I have of beautiful scenery. a few blossom trees Buddha statues , marble lions and beautiful kept gardens
Tourist spot close to everything. This is a great place to soak up the atmosphere of a large shrine and tourist stalls to buy some lovely souvenirs. Very easy to get around this area on the train

Great Place to Walk. Great area of Tokyo to walk around and enjoy the sites. The river, temples, parks, bridges, and museums are available for your tour. You can also book an inexpensive trip in a boat into Tokyo Harbor from here.

Tourist Spot. Asakusa definetely is a tourist spot. For me its a bit too crowded , avoid go there on sunday or you gonna stuck in the sea of people. There's a lot of shop sells souvenir, snacks with a good price.
Beautiful Temple. A beautiful temple to visit during lunar new year. Don't forget to make a wish for the new year for your family. There are also many specialty shops and food to discover as well.
Beautiful!. You have to come to Asakusa! Its bustling, lots of stores, lots of food and most importantly such a beautiful area with lots of great photo opportunities! I spent a good 2-3hrs here.
Crowded, as always, despite the rain. Many museums and small shops, fun to just wander around. Some of the streets are covered, so convenient when it rains.

Nice attraction. If I had not already seen more of these throughout Japan before coming to Tokyo I would have probably rated it higher. The crowds were unbelievable and it was ridiciously busy. Best to go early morning to avoid tourists and locals going there.
Popular temple. Very famous temple many tourist. Good place for shopping food and souvenir. Recommended shoes for elder people and key chain

Booked using BA Avios points. I decided to use some BA avios points and booked this tour while my husband and I were in Japan. It was a great day out. We were picked up from Shinjuku station, transported around a lot of the main sites you have seen listed and then had lunch and went on a quick cruise around Tokyo Bay. We went on this tour day 2 of our trip which was great to get familiar with the areas and learn some of the history and facts from our tour guide. I would certainly recommend it and if would encourage an organised tour at some point in your stay as you pick up little bits of useful info and get to ask some of those burning questions you have.

A must-see in Tokyo, but a bit crowded. Beautiful place, definitely recommended to everyone. It's definitely crowded, but if you can catch it at night, or in the evening just before the street/souvenir shops close (around 7 PM), it's wonderful. You can hire a rickshaw to take you around the area - the country's equivalent to hiring horse carriages in Europe - and it's fun even to just peoplewatch here. There are many, many foreigners to interact with here if that's your thing, and there are some pretty decent food establishments in the area, such as a Toriyoshi that serves meat and vegetables on sticks (though they're pretty pricey).Really, though, just bathing in the atmosphere here is fantastic, especially when the cherry blossoms are falling in the wind, framing the scene for perfect photo opportunities in spring. It's also right next to the Tokyo Skytree tower!
Good place during Anami. Full of cherry blossom. best at night when there's absolutely no-one!Usually crowed during day time
One of most favorite tourist attraction. This is a very popular place for local and foreigner, many people come here especially in cherry blossom

The Montmartre of Tokyo. To some extent, I alway compare Asakusa to Paris' Montmartre: an old fashioned and quaint area, very iconic, well designed for the tourist and with an extensive offer of food outlets of any kind. And like Montmartre: overcrowded!
Busy and Fun. They have a great travel guide center just across the street from the main gate. Once you get a handle of the subway system. Tokyo is at your fanboy-girl mercy!

very touristy shopping spot at a traditional site. Asakusa temple combines nice japanese tradition with a shopping area ans a tourist invasion. It is great to visit it during plum blossoms at early morning, before most of tourists wake up. There are some good shops selling traditional items.
5-Tiered Pagods. The 5-tiered pagoda houses memorial tablets for thousands of people. It is not open to the general public.
Beautiful Pagoda. This is within the sense-Ji temple compound and is beautiful. It is a nice place to go and hang around for a bit to soak in the culture and architecture.
Very interesting. The place was full of people but even though that it is very interesting cause you feel you are in the old japan

So much to do!. Asakusa was home for 3 weeks as this was central to many other places. Akihabara (Anime central), Ryokan (Sumo Wrestling), Toyko city (Imperial Palace) are all in walking distance (30-45mins), or a very very short train trip away. Asakusa also has a lot of shopping,amazing food places and lots of temples. LOVED IT

Must see in Tokyo. Spent about half a day in the Asakusa section of Tokyo. This should be part of any Tokyo iternary as it provides a glimpse into the city's past. Yes, it was crowded and touristy. This area is easy and inexpensive to travel to using the Metro system.

All I could see were people. Apparently it's a must go for first time tourists, but it was so full of people and tourist groups that I could not fully immerse in the temple building and religious ritual.

Interesting Place. As the first city I've been stayed in Japan, Asakusa gave interesting moment for me and my wife. We got warm and lovely city, with good tourist attaction and place, and we stayed in nice hotel. This is one of city you have to visit in Japan

Temples are everywhere. One of a must-visit place in Japan!! There are lot of Buddhist temple in Asakusa. You can buy alot of souviners for your family. Take a visit to the Kaminari mon and you'll be amazed by the place
Beautiful!. Beautiful, well maintained temple. Nice pagoda. A bit crowded on Sunday's. There are many traditional shops on a way to the temple.

Beautiffuly maintained Temple Compex. On a busy Saturday morning we visited the Asakura Kannon Temple for an outstanding experience. Couple of things are notable. Firstly the temple is heavily used for prayer and worship. Buddhists from all over the world come to pray. We noted visitors from Thailand, Taiwan, Indonesia, China as well as Japan.Secondly the temple is beautifully maintained. The appointments, fittings and even the painting are first class. Its possible that a major restoration has been recently completed. Regardless this is a standout.and finally the complex is sizable, particularly for a city as dense as Tokyo. Many smaller temples and some small gardens with plenty of cherry blossoms made this visit really memorable. If you are in Tokyo at the moment his is a must do.

Good Photo Ops. The main attraction in the Asakusa area for tourists is the temple and shrine which is an easy walkfrom the metro station. Just follow the crowds from the Ginza station. Many restaurants along the way to this beautiful temple and grounds.

Great . This is the most famous shrine in tokyo, located in Asakusa, the road to the shrine is full of souvenirs shops,kimonos and plenty of local food! Is a really nice walk and if you are going to Tokyo you cannot miss it!

A beautiful temple . Asusaka Kannon Temple is very beautiful .....Very crowded with tourists during the day. Along the temple gate ....there are rows of small shops selling souvenirs and many local Japanese eateries shops around Love it ....it's very nice to walk around ....beautiful temple !!!!

Very crowded. Good. Traveling to this place is easy. Take the Asakusa line. Once you are there, follow the crowd. If not, the policemen there are quite helpful. A lot of stalls selling varieties of foods, clo5hes, souvenirs

Foods, Shops & Souvenir Galore!. Asakusa is a perfect place to go for lunch and shopping after Ueno Park as it is only a few stops away. Do be there before 3pm as most of the stalls close about 5- 6pm. Besides the famous shrine, there are lots of souvenir items and local produce that you are not likely to find them anywhere in such variety and value, not even in Shinjuku. I regretted not getting them the first time round and fortunately had time to revisit the area to stock up for family and friends before heading home.Look out for matcha mocha, ice-cream, summer-time kimono costumes and accessories which are affordable and great keep sake!

Clean and not too busy.. The Asakusa area is super clean and not busy like a lot of other places around Tokyo. It does have its moments during peak time but that's expected. I'd highly recommend just wandering around the tiny little streets as they offer lots of little surprising discoveries and cute little bars and restaurants. Don't forgot to head down to the river to get a stunning view of the Tokyo Skytree and the Asahi Beer Headquarters.
Too many tourists. The temples were beautiful they are a stark contrast to other parts of Tokyo (Shinjuku, Shibuya etc.) Worth a visit, but it was packed wall to wall with tourists!

Great!. Nice place and crowded. This is one of the famous tourist site (I think), so it's very crowded. There are a lot of shops for merchandise also. But you better look around bcause some stores just sell cheaper than others.

you must also visit when you are in Tokyo. one of the oldest temple in Tokyo, a "touristy" place, can buy local delicacies and souvenirs and its a picture perfect too especially if there is not a lot of people. still worth a visit.
Excellent example of Buddhist Temple. Well worth seeing. Allow ample time to get from one gate to the other through the massive street shopping complex leading to the temple.

Asakusa Temple. For me, for a european, that never seen Asia, Japan before I can say that the temple is out of this world.
I would like to say that the place should be seen day time when there are lots of turists and night time (when the place is empty, no people around).

Tokyo highlight. This was a highlight of our Tokyo stay and we very much enjoyed the temple grounds. The area is heaving with tourists and the approach road with all the tourists was very busy, but also easily avoided. Many of the shops in the area sold tourist tat and at a premium too. I've been to much calmer temples and noisier ones too, but this is still a great place to visit.
old-town, tourist spot, historical. packed with tourist, Asakusa offers its own uniqueness. it is said to be the home based of Geisha and Maiko.

Great scenery with lots of local delicacies!. The people are generally nice and the pace is relatively laid back as compared to main city area. The highlight of the place is obviously the temple with the huge Lei Mon red lantern! The long street of local goodies shops leading to the temple are great for browsing and getting local snacks !

Beautiful place to have leisure walk between shopping city. You can do a lots of shopping, visit famous zinja near by station, you can take ferry to odaiba from here, actually you should try to take ferry in evening time so that you can enjoy beautiful view of Rainbow bridge by ferry....
Very touristic and crowded . It's an interesting touristic area with a lot of shops and restaurants We have taken our hotel in this district which is convenient It's also very crowded of course
Great for shopping, but extremely crowded.. Great for finding bargains, but some of the store merchants are really nasty. Still a great place to look for souvenirs.

Great place to visit, very busy with lots of shops. JR does not take you there if you're using the JR pass, so need to arrange a different method, worth the visit, good market next to it, reasonable prices, We actually noticed more tourists here compare with anywhere else in Tokyo.

Rainy visit. I hadn't intended to visit here but thought while in Tokyo I should see some of the culture of the city and it's history. I am glad that I did go visit, its very pretty but very busy with tourists and their giant umbrellas. You don't need to spend a lot of time here either, just a nice walk around.

Lovely weekend walk, great shopping. If you have little time in Tokyo, make sure you visit Asakusa, because here you will find alllll the possible souvenirs, meals, sights to feel a bit of the Japanese culture. I believe it's packed with locals and tourists all the time, not only on weekends, the temple is beautiful and the surrounding area as well. Recommend!

Wow!!. After one week of moving to Japan's countryside, visiting this culturally dense area in the city of skyscrapers is mesmerizing. Walking through the main shopping street can be fun even if you are not into buying souvenirs. Maybe it's only personal preference but you'd rather go for some bites of food like mochi. However, try to avoid weekends or holidays, otherwise you have to take the parallel streets to be able to move. It's only defect is that it can be way too busy.Japan is worth to visit, and if you are there, Tokyo is a must, and if you are in Tokyo, you don't want to miss this place out!
One of the thing you should miss in Tokyo. It was really crowded but the place is nice, and was worth the time, some how it is one of this places that make you have the felling of being in Japan.

Traditional for foreign visitors, full of souvenirs and good restaurants. The restaurants around the main avenue in front of the Kaminari-mon are traditional, old and very nice restaurant with high quality dishes. There are some behind the shops that are not good, but anyways all around Kaminari-mon is colorful and fun. Not a fan of crowded places? Then, this is not a good choice. It takes just an hour to see around, try some traditional japanese food, sweets and buy some souvenirs.

A cultural trip into ancient Japan. We were there to visit the temple and worship the Gods. It is a very impressive temple and it is a must visit place to understand some of the cultural past of ancient Japan. We also took a leisurely stroll around the streets outside to admire the ancient architectual as well as to explore the many back alleys decorated with colorful flowers since it is spring time. The shopping to us is just like any other tourist town.
Nice oasis in the middle of the city. If you have at least a morning to spend in Tokio, don't hesitate in visiting this place. Very nice to walk around and see some typical architecture...

Another must explore. Traditional area of Tokyo that offers so much that you won't get in other parts and only if you go a bit into the countryside. Well worth putting up with all the other tourists around to do.
Amazing. This is one of the icons of Tokyo known everywhere in the world. Is a must see attraction in this city, plan to spend an afternoon there to discover the true ancient japanese couture.
Cool. A very interesting place to visit! The temple is very cool and the you can get some very unique things from the market outside! Careful though things are a bit over priced.
all you need. There is a temple a pagoda lots of restaurants and some over priced shops. The day tree is within walking distance
Cool place. Cool place to visit. Temple is cool, market outside of temple has lots of cool unique shopping/gifts.

A definite highlight!!. I absolutely loved this temple and the surrounding area. It was by far my favourite part of my trip. Worth a visit during the day as well as at night to see it lit up. You can catch a nice view of the temples and the Skytree. The surrounding area and small marketplace are touristy, but nice for a stroll, with a distinctly Japanese feel. The small side streets and shops have so much character and make this whole area really enjoyable. Walk around, enjoy, buy some souvenirs and make sure to visit the street tents for some yummy and cheap food!

Lovely area. For some reason or another we ended up returning time and again to Asakusa.It was not to far from our hotel so we could just walk up there, and so we roamed through a lot of the back streets.It has nice river views, the amazing Senso-ji, and the Kappabashi street with all the kitchenware shops.Certainly worth the trip.

Touristy, crowded, but fun.. I've been here twice in different times of the year during the day and I think it's crowded all the time. The street does look like olden day Japan with lots of mini gift stores and food stands. I think it's a must go to place whenever I visit Tokyo, because it's really nice here to spend a morning or afternoon because there's lots to see. But as mentioned previously, be prepared, it's very crowded.

Overrated. If you are not going to visit Kyoto, Asakusa is a must. But if you'll visit the best city in the country (which is Kyoto in my opinion) then Asakusa is a little bit boring. And it is incredibly crowded.

Lovely area. I'm told this is like "Old Tokyo". Unfortunately, we didn't get to spend much time exploring around Asakusa, but we did go to Sensoji. It was filled with tourists but it didn't actually feel overcrowded. It is beautiful and definitely worth a visit.

The One of the Most Visited Attraction in Tokyo Area. This is one of the most visited attractions in Tokyo area besides the Tokyo Disneyland and the Tsukiji Fish Market.Nearest Yamanote Circle Line Station is Ueno. It is about 15 minutes walk to Asakusa.Head for the Asakusa Tourist INfo Center first as they are able to provide you with the walking map and the English intro to this place.Enter the temple ground by its main gate. In front of this gate are two rows of shops selling souvenirs and behind these 2 rows are eateries.Visit this place in the fall as there will be lightup and night market

When in Tokyo, must visit Asakusa. Very touristy area, especially if you are just roaming around Sensoji and Nakamise area. If you take a detour off the main strip of Nakamise, you will find authentic downtown Tokyo.

good atmosphere. The streets to the temple is full of tiny old shops, from rice cookies, souvenirs, Japanese umbrellas and so on. Enjoyed tempura lunch at an old tempura canteen. Nice good old area, even for Japanese!
Visit in the morning before it gets too crowded. Interesting place but can get busy obviously. In a good area so plenty to eat and drink around. Just a short walk to the Tokyo Sky Tree.
temple visit. one of the famous attractions. it has become too tourist oriented. so it kinda lost some of it charms. nevertheless walk around and enjoy the view, ambience and serenity.

Nice visit if on your first trip to Tokyo. The temple itself is really beautiful to look at if you can get past all the tourists. Its always super busy so try to get there earlier in the morning. There is a small garden and pond area to the left of the main temple that contain koi fish which are lovely to watch so it pays to walk around the site for a few minutes.There is a line of shops leading towards the temple which make shopping for Japanese souvenirs like chopsticks or fans a delight for all tourists

Good place to visit but crowded. Asakusa temple is a good place in the middle of modern city. Place is quite near subway station. You will find a very big red gate by the main street, inside there will be an alley of shops to help you find anything you need. The second gate after shopping alley, then you will enter the temple main area. A lot of people come to pray and make wishes, so don't expect solitude. Nevertheless the beauty will still easily felt. Best time to visit is early morning or near sunset.
Famous in Tokyo . Famous in Tokyo. Just five minutes walk from our hotel. On weekend so busy and crowded. Have many shops both sides to Asakusa. Good spot should visit.
Asakusa temple. Nice temple, so crowded. If you travel with small kids, please pay more attention for your kids, because thousand of people around you.
Crowed. Great Place but too many people at there.It's not suit for family and kids. if you try to Asakusa, you must be stand of pack of sardine.
Historical part of Tokyo. Stay in a ryokan in the area to get maximum historical experience! Check out the shops at Kaminarimon Gate and the Sensoji temple
interesting but crowded. temple itself is worth to visit, but its very crowded so this was fast visit for us. Nearby marketplace is perfect to buy Japanese souvenirs

Fun but crowded. Asakusa Temple is huge and nice to visit. there is a few huge incense stands with a lot of smoke coming out of it. it's been said that when you put that smoke on your head, it will make you smarter (haha). Leading up to the temple is a shopping promnade called Nakamise. Definitely try Ningyo Yaki, Japanese small sponge cakes in different shapes and Kaminari Okoshi (tastes like really good sweet rice crackers). There is a very small but nostalgic amusement park called Hana Yashiki nearby. it's cute. we went there on a weekday but it was still crowded, especially in the afternoon.

Nice area but very crowded. Of course this is a famous area in Tokyo and hence it is crowded. It is worth going there one time but for us it was a bit too much of the touristy staff, souvenir selling, etc. You can start from the entrance of the walking street and make your way down to the temple. You can also walk to take a boat tour on the river if the weather is suitable. There are some nice hotels and restaurants on the adjacent streets so if you get tired of the crowd you can take a side street and look for a nice place to eat or have a drink.It is suitable for a few hours or half a day trip if you include the temple.

Visit this neighbourhood to see the shrine and also the skytree from a distance. Visit this neighbourhood to see the shrine and also the skytree from a distance. The neighbourhood itself doesn't have much else

Amusing!. I went to Asakusa on my first trip to Japan in 2012. I got to feel the real ambiance of a Japanese temple and the omiyage shops around it (gift/souvenir shop). There were also a lot of food stalls with a huge variation. Definitely, I will go back to Asakusa!!

Fabulous Place to Spoend a few hours. A great place to shop and sightsee. We came here to look for an art shop which was unfortunately closed, but still we wandered around looking at the famous temple and strolling through the small streets that sold food and clothes and souvenirs. I would recommend Asakusa as one of the best places to visit in Tokyo because it seems to have everything. But be warned it is a very busy place.

Crowded and The Goods are Expensive. It's a famous tourism spot, therefore all tourist will go there in the first place when they getting around Asakusa. I visited just to see its famous temple, but I don't recommend to buy souvenir in the temple complex, since it's quite expensive.Rather you can get around Asakusa outer side, especially in shopping complex, you can get cheaper souvenirs with same collection.
What a temple experience. Great area to witness religious practices, to eat, and to shop. Now, that's a visitor's delight. Visited several times and each time was different.

Amazing Zen spot. I have a video on you tube under ' j lito diaz' of my trip to Tokyo if you want to check it out. Asakusa is an amzing zen area full of places to eat, right next to the water and has a beautiful temple.

Traditional, cultural, fun. If you are a foodie, if you like photography, shopping, architecture, you must visit Asakusa.Traditional food, traditional gifts, temple, shrine, old buildings, old restaurants, all here.I could spend the whole day here.It's very interesting how a lot of non-Japanese-people (mostly Asian girls) dressed in Japanese traditional costumes, and a lot of westerners take pictures of them.1 mile walk to Tokyo Skytree.

Really nice area of Tokyo with several attractions. The Sensoji temple, a park, nice shopping area, close to Tokyo Skytree, Sumida river walk, multiple nice restaurants.... and close to Ueno, another nice part of Tokyo. I think it's a great area to visit.

Architecture lovers. If u love traditional architectures this might be a good place. Good to shop some souvenirs here, price is acceptable. There's some volunteers to guide tourists in front of the entrance which truly impressed..

What I had been missing . Went to this area on the last day of my stop in Tokyo, and this is what I had been missing This truly made me feel like I was in Japan, the markets, the smells, the geisha girls, the architect, the locals at the temple prayingAlso great place to get souvenir gifts A must !!

Great day site seeing and shopping. This is the place to go if you dont have much time to spend in Tokyo. The are a bunch of shops and a beautiful temple. You stop and eat at the food stands near the temple. So delicious! !

Interesting temple and grounds. The 5 story pagoda and the temple and shrines are all interesting buildings in the classic Japanese style. There are some lovely spots in the grounds as well. The bustling market streets around the temple are also worth browsing through for souvenirs (chopstick stores, etc.).

A must visit to Asakusa for Tourist. Asakusa is a must visit for Tourist to Tokyo. They have very nice and beautiful small shops that offer many different items .
There are also lot of nice food there and some very locals but in Japanese menu.

Asakusa is a must for tourist to Tokyo. Asakusa is a must for tourist visiting Tokyo as they have plenty of nice little small shops with traditions. You also get to see the local small eateries but all in Japanese
Tradition yet urban place to be. Asakusa area is a must go place when come to Tokyo. The area bring in the uniqueness, quiet and yet friendly area to be in.

Beautiful and Fascinating. During my tim in Tokyo I stayed in a hostel in Asakusa, it is a really beautiful area, with a great contrast between the modern new Japan and the old temples and shrines. It is definitely one of my favourite areas; it can be very busy, and is a very touristy area but there is plenty to see and do. It is definitely worth a visit! It's a great place to stay for more than one day.

Loved the shops and ally moe than the temple. I had a blast walking around and trying all the snacks. I've seen so many temples. This one wasn't anything special. I liked the shops though. Spent around 4 hours there

Asakusa is a good place to see oriental culture of japan.. It is beautiful traditional temple. a big temple and a big tower is there.Simple design, roof of temple shape looks like korean temple.  I was visited Tuesday, I wanted to eat street food, but I can't find a various store.

Great experience! . We stopped here as part of a bus tour and it was my favorite. There were lots of food stalls with delicious items. Since it was New Years it was crowded but super fun! We loved pulling our fortunes from the chopstick fortune thing. ( not sure what it is called) Lots of families dressed in traditional wear to celebrate the new year. Allow about 1-2 hours for your visit. A break from the " big city life"
Amazing visit. Visited during a trip to Tokyo, amazing place. Lovely to wander around the temple and the grounds. Worth spending a morning or afternoon there.

Fascinating Temple!. I visited the Asakusa Temple with some friends in September 2015. It really is breathtaking! It stands high above other buildings in the area and has some nice gardens to wander around in. A great place to come and see Tokyo and Japan in full!

Huge Temple with a nice market. This is a stunning temple with a large surrounding marketplace and various other Buddhist relics to see. The marketplace is quite large but offers a variety of souvenirs, food and traditional Japanese souvenirs. It is largely marketed to tourists and can be quite overpriced. You would better off being cautious about souvenir prices, but definitely try some of the Japanese sweets on offer.

A taste of traditional Japan in the heart of Tokyo. The temple is well worth a visit and is at the end of several lanes of both shops and market stalls offering a wide variety of merchandise that is a must for every traveller and tourist. Some of the great things on offer include special tea, teapots and cups, beautiful umbrellas that show patterns when wet and much much more. It's a busy place so be prepare for crowds of tourists as well as local school groups on school trips to the temple. Some great restaurants and cheap eats in the area too.

Huge temple . This temple is huge! With lots of things to do around it. There's shopping for trinkets all the way leading up to the temple. There's snack vendors (note you have to eat there, can't be on the move with the food), you can check your fortune (good luck -bring it home with you, bad luck-leave it there by tying it to the board), make a prayer, take some pics, and go outside of the area for some more shopping at the bazaar. We spent 2-3 hrs just because we were shopping and looking around. I would recommend it, but I wouldn't return. It's kind of a one time thing to do/see.
Great market close to the temple. The market close to the temple was fantastic with various food samples, i knew it must be cheap if all the Japanese school children were purchasing food,
Very nice place. Have to visit this place in Tokyo. The shops around are also of good quality and the outdoors bazaar is a great opportunity to buy souvenirs.

Great fun with shopping, eating, drinking and templing. Busy and full of tourists - but you are probably a tourist too so that's fine. Yummy things to eat and beautiful things to look at. All in all a must see in my opinion.

Such A Small Place Has A LOT Going On. Asakusa is a very small area of the city, only a few city blocks, but there are quite a few things to see while you're there. Asakusa opens up with Karinarimon, "The Thunder Gate". Once you go through the gate Asakusa becomes a bustling center of little shops and stores that sell many different Japanese goods called Namikaze Street. The Street is always packed with people so you will have to go slowly down the street. once you are through you will find the multi-floored pagoda and of coarse Senso-ji Temple. you can get an aerial view of Asakusa from The Tokyo Skytree about a mile down the road.
Good cultural experience. Very interesting, lots of older buildings, temples, etc. Great market and variety of restaurants. Very crowded though, as are most tourist areas.
Touristy Japan. A good area to get a quick taste of the touristy side of Japan. Lots of traditional shops, nice restaurants that cater to non-Japanese speakers.
amazing. Nice shrine and pagoda in the area. Lots of food stalls and other stores can be found down the street. A must see when in Asakausa area.
Interesting temple. It was pretty busy, being Chinese New Year, so the crowds were a bit crazy. Beautiful old building though and looked beautiful in the soft light of sunset.

Another trip here & still we would enjoy revisiting again!. Well from the market shopping through to the interesting & tasty food stalls & the significant variety of souvenirs this is one place you must visit when in Tokyo.
