One of our best visits in Tokyo. Small shops with lots of souvenirs and sweets, nice places, temples, i could not imagine a visit to Tokyo that doesn't include a visit to Asakusa. Great place for taking photos as well.

Go at Sundown if Possible. I went to Asakusa at around 5pm (shops start to close on the Nakamise shopping street at around 6) when the sun had gone down and all of the lights along Nakamise leading up to Senso-ji were lit up beautifully. A great place to find souvenirs!

Traditional + foodie. Asakusa is a beautiful district, famous for the Senso Ji temple. Full with history and nice things to visit. You can get there by metro and walk arround, buy souvenirs, eat local eats you wont find anywhere else and have a nice time.
great place. very much crowded sight but definitely worth it.lots of restaurants and shops around selling traditional stuff.

Traditional Tokyo with street market and temple. This place is rather big and good to allocate at least 1hour to enjoy taking photos and try different foods. Came here under a guided tour and there are many locals and tourist at this place. Very crowded and busy location.

Tradition and food. Old area of Tokyo where you feel like in a village. Plenty of excellent restaurants and the beautiful Senso-Ji temple. Easy access to everywhere in Tokyo. This is the traditional Japan we were looking for.

A must see for traditional Tokyo. We loved Asakusa, browsing the streets, Senso-ji shrine, and great restaurants with queues as long as the street itself. Lots of street food to sample and souvenir shopping to be had at great prices and I love how the Japanese beautifully wrap all of your gifts. You must try the hot sweet sake and dango - I wish I could have more right now!

Loved the Asakusa area, lots of small streets with markets, shops ans restaurants.. Asakusa was where we stayed for our time in Tokyo. Its really well connected with a number of different subway and train lines. There is a Tourist information center with a foreign exchange office which is helpful. Lots of restaurants to choose from though many are not easily found as they are on higher floors in what look like office buildings so check the location as we walked past a restaurant 3 times before realizing it was on the 9th floor! There is the Sensoji Temple and the Asakusa Shrine in Asakusa. There are a few supermarkets, doughnut shops as well as more traditional Japanese restaurants. There's also western chains like Mc Donalds, Starbucks and Dennys. Its a pretty easy area to navigate and is very lively in the evening.

One visit is great but more is too much. We 1st went to Asakusa in 2014 and it was a weekday tour which was great-no crowds, only 2 tour buses and plenty of time to roam around. The street stalls directly in line with the main temple are interesting and suggest trying the little cakes with plum filling (not sure what they're called). The temple is very pretty but the overwhelming smell of incense burning is a bit off putting when you're not used to it. There are beautiful gardens with plenty of photo opportunities, fishponds with koi and many side streets to explore. Our 2nd visit was on a Saturday and it was so crowded you virtually couldn't move !!! As we had already seen the temple and main street area, we went and further explored the side streets. Highly recommend but NOT on a weekend !
A must do in Tokyo. Asakusa is a good place for sightseeing and gift shopping. Take the time to go and check Senso-Ji temple, it is a beautiful place, I wish all stands would open at night...

Walking and people watching. Great area. Authentic old Japanese feel. Good local restaurants serve food at reasonable prices. Shopping Down the Nakomise and visits to Senso Ji temple and Tokyo Sky Tree. An interesting couple of days here. Also a brilliant base for tsukujji fish market.

Traditional Toyko. This is a must see when in Tokyo. Temples, street stall shopping, amazing restaurants and even the chance to get photos of the beautiful ladies in their traditional Kimono attire. loved this place for every reason.

If you aren't in a rush.... Give yourself a good day at least to explore Asakusa - sensoji temple, kaminarimon, nakamise and surrounds. Optionally walk to Sumida River, Matsuya department store, Philippe Stark Asahi Building across the river. If you're feeling fit and feel like some culture you can walk all the way to beautiful and historic Ueno Park and check out the Museum of Modern Art. About an hour return.

Top 5 things to see in tokyo. I throughly enjoyed visiting the Kammon temple, five stories pagoda and Hazo mom / middle gate. I was a bit disappointed with the Nakamise shopping arcade. I found some nice Japanese puzzle boxes. Many of the items for sale were of poor quality.I went on a Sunday afternoon which was very crowded.
Great experience☆☆☆. its nice to walk around and to buy some souvineers. And tried some aunthentic oishi Japanese food. I love it.
Must visit place in Tokyo. There is the one hot spot and popular shrine is Asakusa area that you must visit. After that you may take a walk at Nakamisme Street for some souvenir and food.

Crowded but lots of fun for travelers!!!. This was where we went dressed in kimono with my Japanese friends. We had all gone to get kimono professionally fitted and headed out to Asakusa for the day.It is a little crowded but there are many street vendors, and cool things going on in the streets. We took a rickshaw through the streets and the tour guide was really funny. I speak Japanese so I was able to translate for my friend what he couldn't convey in English, but if you are a tourist their English is great and that isn't a problem.He stopped to let us take photos and showed us the best photo ops around. Asakusa also has great street food. We tried black sesame ice cream sandwiches and wow were they good!We got up the the temple that holds a giant lantern in front. My friends explained that a thunder God was trapped inside the lantern.Overall this is a great place that you shouldn't miss!

Nice if you are already in Tokyo. As shrines go, it is very nice. However, you may see more authentic places off the beaten trail because Asakusa is so touristy now. If you are already in Tokyo, it is definitely worth it. However, if you have just seen other shrines or temples, you may give it a pass, although the neighborhood is nice too.
beautiful and crowded. The temple is really nice, but there is also a lot of people, so better avoid weekends if you don't like the crowds

Everything you expect in authentic Japan. If you want to see a Japanese Buddhist temple,Shinto shrine & do some shopping for souvenirs best place around Tokyo is Asakusa.Here you find ancient Buddhist temple Senso-Ji. you should enter the temple after getting your hands and face washed at the entrance.Also you can read your future by shaking a metal container and getting a metal stick with a number and find the corresponding drawer inside which a paper with a reading of your future located.around the street that lead to the temple you can find many shops that sells souvenirs and what not.You can also find very old taverns around the temple which sells sake & hot foodwhere you have to sit on a mat around the table.

A "calmer" Tokyo. This is the place I would advise all families to make their base. Its a quieter, calmer part of Tokyo but with the transport to take you everywhere you need to go in Tokyo. It a lovely place, very busy around the shrine and the narrow streets leading to the shrine, but its manageable. You just have to get into it!! The narrow streets around the (amazing!!!) ryokan we stayed at are quaint with restaurants, many shops, chemists and little izakaya-den's. I found it a perfect base to explore the best of what Tokyo has to offer - I will definitely go back there when I go again.

My best Experience in Tokyo !!. We almost missed this shrine and temple and it would have been a huge loss. It was midweek and it was packed with locals visiting and praying. ( including lots of young teens doing that stupid pose for selfies) but rising above that the noise and colour ( correct spelling tripadvisor) was fantastic. lots of incense burning and prayer stalls made this a feast for the senses.....

A different Tokyo.. This isn't the massive built up area like Shibuya etc. This feels like a older part of Japan, and really brings you back. We loved staying in the area, and it really gave us that "local" vibe!

Lots to see. There is tons to see here. There is little shops and food stands for tourists to try local cuisine. There are also lots of traditional arches and architecture. Very beautiful, there are gardens near here. The Senjoi Temple and SkyTree are in this area. This is a neighbourhood you must go to .
nice place to learn about japanese culture. very nice place to walk around, many little shops that allow you to get any kind of japanese souvenir
to visited place in tokyo.. our hotel is 50meters away from this temple. it's worth your visit. place where you shop for souveniers! the temples are visited by many.. locals or foreigners alike

Sky Tree was awesome. They have a Fast pass for foreign travelers, you need to show your passport and it costs about 2800 yen vs 2100 yen for non fast pass guests. The fast pass takes you to the bag check point bypassing everyone else in line. After you pass the bag check, it's about a 5 min wait till you get on the elevators to take you to the 350 meter level. The elevator is packed full of guests, but it travels so fast that you are to the 350 m point in no time. great views from that level, you can go up to the 450 m level via another elevator and about 1000 yen more. Try to pick a nice day with good visibility to make the most of your time.
Don't leave Tokyo without going here!!. So much history and awesome architecture!! We were around sundown and everything had the most beautiful glow!!

When the past meets the present. The place is nice its historical its just fun to walk around the place and look at the buildings there that was built over 2000 years ago its just crazy, you could ride in like a kart and there is like a guy running he will show you the place this is how the wealthy people in japan used to move around, you could go there by a taxi or the metro no need for a tour to go to Asakusa neighborhood. Hope you enjoy you visit

Power spot. Asakusa area is a power spot famous for Sensoji temple located within its district. It is easy to navigate yourself to the temple by following the signs provided. You can also get souvenirs for family and friends along the shopping streets

Great Japanese experience . This area is a must if visiting Tokyo. This is one of the more popular shrines, as there are several near each other and located near shopping. Many street vendors, souvenirs, and great local food. Be sure to get cash for the shopping, as many do not accept credit cards. We witnessed/participated in many traditions while we were here. Very cool.
A famous historic Temple. Easy to get around and located in an easy to find location this temple is highly revered by Japanese people.
Wonderful . Love this place. . It is must visit when I visit Tokyo or asakusa..... many tourists and shops and it is always pack. I have came here many times and will come back again
Incredible. This is a must see in Japan. Great shoping district. You can feel some real Japan there. Great impression and great place for taking pictures.

Beautiful place, great to observe tradition during New Years. We decided to go to the temple to observe local tradition around New Years.It is a beautiful temple and grounds, much bigger than the pictures do justice to. Unfortunately we did not go inside the temples, people were actually there to pray so we decided not to intrude too much.There was a big food market going on outside the temple on the day (not sure if always or only over holidays) which had one stall serving grilled seafood with scallops the size of your palm; absolutely delicious. I had 4 on my own

Nice place to be. This place has two highlights : the Temple and the shopping street. You will never get bored when you are at Asakusa. The shopping street has lots of food, toys, clothes, shoes etc etc ... you will love this place

Stunning, tranquil grounds. Visited on New Years Eve and it was fantastic! Temple was lined with really great food stalls selling unique local delicacies. Shops leading up to the temple was also great to browse around. Overall, stunning grounds.

Not my first time but still love it!. A place to buy Japanese souvenirs, authentic street snacks and visit shrines. This isn't my first visit but I'm still loving every part of Asakusa. You must try the Mochi Dog(Vienna Sausage wrapped in Mochi) and the Agemanju! I had custard flavor and it is located at the far end of the nakamise street close the shrine. The agemanju is a crispy fried light & airy bun with soft creamy fillings thats not too sweet! I will definitely come back! You can also try sake ice cream or other unique japanese flavor ice cream as well as the famous Melonpan

One of my favorite Tokyo Areas. When friends have a very short time in Tokyo, I almost always bring them to Asakusa. The temple and shopping streets are a must see, plus it's a short walk to kitchen town, tons of great restaurants and even the sea taxi down the Sumida river. Great for kids and adults alike. Although I have never used them, there are plenty of rickshaws for those who are less fond of walking.

Great experience !. During the time I visited here, it was still a holiday for some Japanese where they went to pray in the temple with their traditional kimono. It was great experience with all the stalls selling foods and drinks. Mind you, that you cannot walk and eat at the same time, you have to stay near the stall and finish your food. Yet, the place is full of people, from selling foods to souvenirs to clothes and many more !

area you cant miss in tokyo. There are all in asakusa. Sensoji temple,Sumida park,many kinds of restaurant ex tonkatsu,grilled unagi top on rice,very good steak,good sushi that good price,sweets,soft cream. Big department store like donkihote that you can find everything.Theme park.Many shops on nakamise street.Asakusa rickshaw.You can enjoy with your family here.

Traditional Tokyo. The main temple is great but very crowded with tourists from all over the world. Back streets are great though. So many gems. Kappabashi kitchen street is also great, and there is a trendy coffee shop called Bridge which breaks up the shopping.
Couldn't get enough!. Temples and shrines were everywhere. We loved them all. This one was convenient to our hotel, Edo Sakura.
Must see when visiting Tokyo.. Excellent atmosphere, gives a feeling of old Japanese culture that i didnt feel anywhere else. Alot of people, but very open area so didnt feel crowded.

Great Cultural / Historical Place. This is a good place to see for an afternoon or morning visit. The shrines and temples are amazing and there is a street leading up to the main shrine devoted to a market. One thing to be mindful of is that you aren't allowed to eat any food in this street. However, the food stores have a dedicated area to consume your food. The colours, smells and tastes in this area are worth the visit

Great culturally interesting area - watch out for table charge!. This is one of my favourite areas of Tokyo. Check out the wonderful atmospheric streets at the side of the shrine/temple. If you stay in this area you will love coming back here to the quiet village atmosphere. Lovely shrines and temples and so many fantastic places to eat. On that point - please be careful - if you enter that cute little sushi bar - first ask - 'is there table charge, service charge, must I buy extra' - our only bad experience in the whole of Japan was a sushi bar here - the price was excessive and then at the end they tried to charge us 40 000 JPY for sitting at a tiny table! They also brought additional food and drink and then added the price to the bill. The sushi chef got nasty and we had to leave pretty quickly - an absolute shocker for a little family eve out at the start of our Japan holiday. I noticed the charge was written on the menu right in the middle where you wouldn't notice it. Apparently it happens at expensive restaurants but it's unusual for this area and was a lesson for us - we never had the experience again. I noticed the sushi bar had no name on the outside so I can't tell you which one. However, don't miss this out on a visit to this area as you feel transported back in time particularly at night.

Year end festivities in old Japan. Very lovely place to mingle with locals. You can enjoy typical Japanese down-town lives here. Very colorful, safe and exciting.Recommend to walk around the neighborhood to enjoy old Japan, which have disappeared from many places in Japan already.

Asakusa is amazing. Asakusa is amazing!!! The senso-Ji temple is very beautiful and the atmosphere around it too...and nakamise dori, full of little shop where you can buy everything..don't miss kagetsudo to taste a very good melonpan

Firm grip of Japanese culture is bustling Tokyo. Second time in Asakusa, and did stay in the area for a week in for our first trip. This place is more family and culture oriented as you see more of it on the street compared to the rest of Tokyo.Great place to find authentic kimono, yukata, manekineko, kimono cloth souvenirs or reproduction of popular Japanese artwork be it in craft form or artform.

Nice travel area in Tokyo. I have been to Tokyo several times. Asakusa is always in my travel plan. I love the atmosphere of this place. It has splendid culture scene with nice shopping alley and several delicious restaurants. It is a good place to learn Japanese culture and especially, if you visit during Sanja Matsuri festival around May every year. You will experience crowded and fun festival of Asakusa.

Just ok. If you have seen the temples in other parts of Japan such As Kyoto etc, to be honest this is not comparable. But if you are only visiting Tokyo on your itinerary, this place is a must visit, to get a sense of Japanese tradition and culture. The shopping street attached to the temple area is a really fun place to shop and grab some local snacks.

Nice atmosphere. Loved this place. Went there early to have time to explore the whole area. The temple is quite big if you consider the many sections it has. There are also shops to buy all kind of modern and traditional souvenirs, foods and snacks as well; when we arrived early in the morning we came across this bakery that had just put out of the oven this sweet traditional japanese bread, absolutely delicious. Asakusa feels more traditional than the rest of Tokyo which I think is its main appeal.Highly recommended.

Huge temple. The yemple was huge and full of a lot of small shop along the street just in front of the temple.the sold souvenirs like accessories, clothes , etc. And also several foods and restaurants among them. There were some "alive statue"..kids love them... lol... overall it was a good place to look atound for make a wish or some fortune teller or just shopping and eat. Very recommended!

Amazing historic shrine remenscent of another time. Absolutely loved this shrine. Visited this amazing temple over on 1/4/16. The temple was busy with plenty of food, fish on a stick and a party-like atmosphere as people were still vising the shrine in celebration of the New Year. This temple was even more beautiful lit up at night, I especially loved the mural wall painting on the ceiling and the statues that were reminiscent of a genie in a bottle or was the home of some type of old warrior being.

Good shrine but too commercial. Well i love the shrine. Such a beauty and huge. But beware with the shops along the entrance to the shrines.So hectic and make the place unpeaceful. I have no idea why they let it like that. Maybe from a long time ago. But well dont let them disturb our intent to go to shrine. Hahaha

Great atmosphere. This is a top spot for wandering around with plenty of fun energy / atmosphere. I would recommend staying nerby, as it is really good to have a drink & dinner at one of the many local options, and wander the temple complex in the peace & quiet of the evening.

Nice chilling spot. Nice place to walk around Asakusa neighbourhood. Sunday day was very crowdy, but small streets are still quiet and you can just flow with the current. Nice temple area! Worth of visit!

Cool place. Was a really busy tourist area with plenty to see and experience and I would say well worth a visit! Looooooads of shops and market areas especially around the shrines, 1 must is you HAVE to try the food stalls.. so worth it! :)

The most ancient area for your exploration. You can feel deeply the Tokyo in past decades survives via the street, shops and restaurant. There are many shop stores which sell many tradition souvenirs and local snacks. I am sure that you can buy a huge of gifts for your family and friends and all of them can be packaged in Japanese style for free following your request. The most famous snack is Rice Cracker which cooked in many style. Sensoji Temple is a very popular Buddhist temple, built in the 7th century which is the most attractive place you need to visit in Asakusa.

Enjoyable old Tokyo. We rented kimonos from a small shop called Asakusa Shichihenge and walked around the area, which was very pleasant and had many shops. The trishaw ride was a good experience as well. Although we did feel a bit cheated at a shop that sold yukatas and kimonos for prices that were higher than usual, so do shop around and compare prices. All-in-all we really liked the area.

Charming and cool. We stayed in Asakusa for three nights, within walking distance of the temple and attractions. It's an interesting mix of old and new, and offers a lot to do. Rickshaws, temples, shopping and good food!
Low town, Old Town. My favourite place in Tokyo -- don't miss the old town atmosphere, the temple, the shopping street and the rickshaw drivers!
A must visit place!. Recommended place to visit.Alot of sourvenir shops and restaurants to choose for.Walk freely to capture the moment there.

Insanely busy, not convinced. This was place was sooooo overrun with crowds it was a little hard to actually enjoy the beauty or take it all in...I wasn't convinced it was worth trekking all the way for, but it was beautiful
Second stay in this neighborhood. It feels like the real Tokyo, despite the tourist draw of the Temple. There are tiny shops, interesting streets, and great views.

Old Japan. Easy to get too, just over 10 min walk from Ueno metro station. Nice to be able to see some of the old time Japan in amongst all the skyscrapers. Starbucks is just around the corner and the park is vast.

A very big Temple. One of the must go for the Tokyo trip. You may recognize this temple when you see the big lamp at the temple's gate. It's a very big temple, they provide English fortune here to. If you visit in the morning you may have a chance to see the local temple ceremony. Ready your camera.
morinaga factory. i learn about history, systems. Have tired to check teast of Chocolate lol Oishi!!! dilicious!!! ^_^ .....

Interesting place!. Asakusa is an interesting place - it has lots of places to visit like the Sky Tree and Senso-ji Temple, and is home to the famous Asahi HQ (renowned for looking like a golden turd!) and there are some fun things to do there too - like Escape the Room etc.

A must do in Tokyo. A MUST DO.....thats it. Very crowded...iconic spot.....many stalls selling cheap souvenirs, snacks...Japanese finger food...etc. Take a picture in front of the Giant gate with the red lanterns.
Always busy with tourists and locals. Famous and popular downtown Tokyo area. One of the must places to visit while in Tokyo. Enjoy shopping souvenirs here.

Lovely place. This is a busy place with kiosks, vendors, street food and of course the unbelievable temples, shrines, garden. A place to spend the whole day; than everything gets illuminated and you will not want to leave:-) We were lucky to witness a local festival at this charming location. It is a must.

A taste of Japanese tradition. If you're in Tokyo and have half a day to spare, this place is a must go!Easily accessible via the subway, Asakusa is an urban remnant of Japan prior to western modernization. Although restored, and extremely orientated towards tourists, the experience is still authentic.Great food, good craft shops, and the main temple attraction itself makes this place photo worthy.Must see!

Dynamic place to be. I stayed at a hostel at Asakusa for about 10 nights, and got to see many different aspects of it - the early dawn where a large group of monks were doing their chanting, the bustling day time where temple goers decked in their kimonos make their prayers and tourists buying all sorts of souvenirs at the markets, and the late night where some of the homeless were sleeping outside the closed shops. Overall this is a really dynamic area to be in, and not to mention the wonderful food and snacks too!

New Year Tradition. It's so packed with people, the locals and everyone from around the world that comes together to celebrate the new year. Lot's of interesting traditional food and heritage building. Worth a visit anytime of the year

A Buddhist Temple. Asakusa's main attraction is Sensoji. It is via the Nakamise, a shopping street where you can see a lot of souvenir shops and buy some street foods. Also, there is a shop called "Bunkogawa" that sells traditional handmade leather crafts. It is at the side of the temple, a little pricey if you ask me but it is worth it. I bought one for myself.

busy old shopping street and a great temple at the end of it. this is a busy old shopping street and a great temple at the end of it. On the main road you ll see young people pulling the rickshaw.It was raining when we were there but that doesnt stop many tourist from going there. Shop for souvenirs here.
a must. It's a must place to visited. A lot of souvenir shop, restaurant but crowd. Matsumoto cosmetics shop is here!

People watching. This place was our first foray out into Tokyo and it did not disappoint. It was easy to find from the metro. The Shrine is lovely and there is a great set of shopping streets which really do have the best price for souvenirs so don't hesitate.

Good for brief visit. Very crowded in the afternoon.. Recommend to visit in the morning (8am-9am) since the tourist is not much. You can walk around and take photo freely. Alternatively, pay a visit in the evening is not a bad choice. It open 24 hours.
One of the more 'older' areas. Busy area, but has more of an older feel to it than some other areas of Tokyo (which is very modern). Arrived here using the Water bus service.
A must-visited. It's a excellent district. If you have a plan in Tokyo, it's a good place to visited! A lot of souvenir shop, restaurant, and crowd.

Japanese Temple visit. One of the more active shrines with many locals and tourist. Much smaller then Meiji Shrine but interesting as it is surrounded by many shops and food stalls. Almost a carnival atmosphere. Great for families with kids as there are many food joints available and no restriction on noise or activity.You can easily spend more than a few hour touring the temple and sampling the street food around it.

Great Temple area to visit.. Been here a couple of times and felt different each time, there was some changes in the street layout as there are more exits and entry now. Place is great and is good for those people who wants shop cum temple visit.
Awsome. I like this little town. It has a atmosphere of traditional Japan. It's really close to sky tree. You should go both of it!

A must-see in Tokyo. You have to make the time to take a trip out to this area, not just for the shrine and pagoda, but also for the cute little shopping avenue that lines the road. Little shops of Japanese gifts, tchotchkes, and food abound. Be sure to check out the side streets too! My fave: During the winter, there's a stand that sells hot, unfiltered sake for 100 JPY... perfect for staving off the cold.

Big Temple in the heart of big city. This temple make me surprise cause a big one in the city, you can pray, and you can buy some souvenirs and culinary outside the the temple, if you want go to this temple, you can take mrt, and then you can walk in 5 minutes from station asakusa to this temple, enjoy your trip

Interesting district . Asakusa is a very interesting district as you can find historical temples, little shops selling souvenirs, traditional eateries and bakeries.We only visited the Nakamise shopping street and Sensoji temple due to limited time. While we were walking from the train station, we saw many interesting structures, quaint shops and restaurants. There are many other things to do and see in Asakusa district, so do plan your visit with at least half a day or more.

A strategic place to stay for travellers. First of the Tourist information centre is located here. Train station nearby. Restaurants, Cafes, Bar, 24/7 convenient store you named it! For Muslim there's one Halal Arabian shop that sells Kebab the price is really affordable. Other than that, I guess you can get souvenirs here during your last day at Dempoin Street or Kaminari Gate along the way to the temple.

one trip isn't enough. There are many festivals and Taiko shows all year round. I have seen many and would like to see more.There is an Asakusa Muslim-friendly map. You can find many Halal shops and prayer rooms. Wear comfortable shoes and recharge your camera batteries. There is no entry fee. Buy your souvenirs from EkiMise street in the afternoon. When the stores close in the late afternoon, grab something to eat. In the evening, take LOADS of photos. Sensouji is beautiful in the morning but for photographers, night time is the best. It is always lively, so you will have to wait your turn for photos. Most of the people wait patiently. My sister and I took a 30-minute rickshaw ride. Our tour guide was well informed about the area as well as our culture. Thumbs up.

A Good City to Visit in Tokyo. If your planning a trip in Tokyo area, make sure to drop by Asakusa. Place is full of good shops, great food, souvenir items and temples. Easily accessible as well via train. It is usually full of locals and tourist and can be a jump off point to other attractions such as Tokyo Skytree in Osiage.
Too commercial. Full of tourists so it's difficult to enjoy the aights and sounds. There are, however, a lot of choices when it comes to dining.

A place to visit. As people said, it is 3 in 1 place. Asakusa is the place for buying souvenir, to have meal and a bit of culture visit. It is definitely a place to go to get japanese souvenir stuff, though there are numerous shops but actually it sell almost similar things and the prices isn't much different. There also lot of restaurants nearby and also stalls that sell a 'quick get meal'. At the end of the road, there is a temple, which one could see some culture displays and events. Definitely a place to visit in Tokyo which offer something different than ultra modern things.
New Year Eve Prayer. It was really cool joining the local crowd in a peaceful and pleasant way lining up for your very first new year prayer!

Good for souvenirs. Somewhere where you can buy your souvenirs which can get very, very busy. But this is Japan so it's never frantic! This leads to Senso-ji Temple so you're bound to stumble across when visiting the area.

Best Area in Tokyo. Carefully selected this area in tokyo as there seemed so much to do both in the day and the night. Spot on from temples to little bars that seat a maximum of 6 where you can sing kareoke with the locals (yes I did). Lots of cheap or upmarket eateries and even a street ( bit touristy) where you can have a meal with geishas. Good tip is to visit and photograph the temples in the day and at night. Not only is it ureter at night but they are lit up and look awesome.

A Must while in the City. Very convenient as it is just a few strides away from Ginza Tokyo Metro line. The place was crowded yet manageable when we visited as it was a few days before the new year, so there were a lot of locals and tourists praying and sightseeing. Best to visit at the end of the day before the temple and the shops close before 1900. Need to visit the temple as it gives you a glimpse of Taoism practices while the shops were great for souvenir shopping. While shops mainly sell identicial stuff, one may need to canvass as prices of one may differ from the other. A lot of good restaurants and hole-in-the-wall eateries on the side streets that one can explore, as well. For those who frequent the toilets, there were public toilets at both sides of the temple, parallel to the shops so no need to look for restaurants to use the toilet while shopping/ sightseeing.

Great experience!. it is a great place to visit. When we were there, there were students doing "flag-day", they were shouting in unity for people to donate money. what is the cause, I;m not sure, but i do feel the sincerity as it was pretty cold and they only wore their school uniform. I think it is the principal and teachers were also there with them. there were also a good variety of street food available.
Typical!. The place to visit. Not too busy on winter mornings. Then you can go to the river's embankment for a Sumida tour.

A View of Japan Culture. This is the only temple we went to during our trip in Tokyo. It was nice and you can go inside the temple to see the things people do inside a temple like praying or wishing for fortune and stuff (Though they have a separate place where people needs to pray peacefully). Like other temples, you can also draw your fortune for 100 yen before entering the temple itself. They also have stores where you can buy souvenirs! Keychains, magnets, fans, wallets, etc are some stuff to bring back home.
History & present beautifully combined. Great area of Tokyo to be culturaly enlightened and also have an enjoyful experience with the souvenir stores, food&all
Souvenir Buying. on the way to the main temple there are many stalls to look for different foods and souvenir to buy.

Rickshaw Ride. I took a short rickshaw ride with Ryo Shinodo. I met him at Kaminarimon or the Thunder Gate of the Senso-ji Temple. I chose his company Ebisuya Asakusa since I saw the display of a trip advisor Certificate of Excellence. It was an excellent culture experience. In the very short time, Ryo Shinodo explained the history and sites of the neighborhood we passed by. He studied in the US and speaks excellent English. He also gave me suggestions on how to get to my next destinations. If time allows, you might want to consider a longer ride.

Lots of things to see here. This area is full of things to see: temple, shrine, shopping street... A lot to see, buy, and snack on. If a college student, or group of students, offers to practice their English and provide a tour, do it! One of the best experiences I've had in Japan was our tour hosted by 5-6 college students in an English club that were out practicing their English. They will teach you traditions, culture and religious history of Japan. I cannot recommend it highly enough. Walk through the shops behind the main drag as well, there's lots to buy and snack on there too.

Asakusa should be on everyone's itineraries. Asakusa area has everything you hope for as a visitor. It has one of the most famous temples in Tokyo - Senso-ji Temple. The post card photo spot - Kaminarimon. Most fun shopping and people watching street - Nakamise. Hundreds of restaurants to eat for every budget. You can spend a whole day in this area without getting bored. One piece of advice though - the temple closes at 6pm and stores close around 7pm. This is not Shinjuku.

Best place to find souvenir. Its easy to travel to asakusa from tokyo just take yamanote line to ueno than change with ginza line to asakusa. Take exit 8 than you'll find nakamise street a place where you can buy some souvenir. And traditional snack fresh from the oven. You also can find the famous sensoji temple. You can try your luck there. This time i don't wanna try my luck, because on march i already try it and get an excellent good luck. But if you dare just try it. If you get something not got just leave it at the temple hang it so you will not get a bad luck they believe.You can see Tokyo Skytree from here also. Its nice to take picture there
Great cultural experience of the Tokyo market. Try the traditional tempuraWalk the streets of the market, especially at nightYou might even see a geisha or two

Famous Buddhist Temple with Souvenir Street shopping. Oldest Buddhist Temple in the region, popular with the big red lantern, crowded with locals and tourist hunting for souvenir & local food. Many small shops with big variety of gifts, from kimono dolls to ninja/samurai swords at affordable price. All local delicacies must try but take note that food bought from the vendor must be eaten there itself or for take away, never eat while walking/browsing through shops.

Great place to spend a day . Beautiful old part of Tokyo full of history, culture and colour. We took a rickshaw for 10 minutes and then spend time at the temple, old surrounding streets and geisha town including what we we're told the oldest pub/restaurant in Tokyo. We must've tried 20 different rice cakes. All in all a great way to spend a day
Love this place. Make sure to go to Asakusa Rox - Batting cagesDon Quijote - Open 24 hoursThe Neighbourhood barsNakamise Dori& pls have the Melon bread!
best place for shopping. there are lots of store to buy anything you want both food and other things, such as, souvenir, clothes, supermarket, butcher, etc.
Family trip. Must stop for first or second time in Tokyo. We will pay our respect here every time we ll be in Tokyo. Crowd but not chaos. You can easily walk around and find variety foods.

Very unique area of Tokyo. Asakusa was a standout for me on a recent trip to Tokyo - it has a very long & interesting history & I feel the longer you can spend here the more layers you will peel back.

Huge shopping place. It has rows and rows of shops selling souvenirs and local products. After walking for a while, you will realize that they are selling pretty much the same stuff. Very touristy and crowded in the evening.
Favorite in Tokyo. I think this is my favorite touristic place in Tokyo. There are many little shops where you can buy lot of japanese gifts.

As serene and peaceful as Tokyo can possibly be. Went here on Christmas day. Despite all the tourists and people coming to pray with the coming of the new year, it had a calming atmosphere. Lots of little shops to visit and easy to access. A must see in Tokyo.

Tried lots of delicacies for the first time. . Lots of small shops selling souvenirs, desserts and snacks. Some local delicacies are cooked in front of you. I have tried the mochi and something similar to a hamburger patty. We bought a lot of assorted chips, rice crispies and crackers. They were delicious but I can not name them because labels were in Japanese. It was a good thing that they offer free tastes.
Interesting part of Japanese history. Interesting part of the city surrounded by small shops, restaurants and hotels. Old pet of town. Historic and with atmosphere.

So many things to do for all types of travellers. Asakusa has something to offer for all types of visitors. From souvenir shopping, temple hopping, sight seeing and food tripping. There are also rickshaw drivers who are very enthusiastic to get tourists to ride with them. There are also drinking place where you see working class Japanese who are drinking in the middle of the week.

A must visit if you are in Tokyo. What I liked:- Accessibility; this Place is accessible on one of the Train services (tho not JR Line) and within a short walk from the Train Station- Attraction; The view is glorious; the Street decorated with sparking flowers leading up to the Sensoji Temple really builds on to the overall experience; I also had the honor of seeing a Geisha upfront (shot for a supposed documentary)- Shopping; the street is full of shops with various gifts/souvenir and foods. Off the main street, you can also find many cafes and shops by the sides which will amaze youConclusion:This is a must visit, you will not be disappointed.

Souvenirs, local sweets and desserts and a temple. This visit is what I call as a sightseeing and shopping and eating all in a go!If only it didnt rain, perhaps we could have stayed longer to enjoy the many many shops here catering for locals and foreigners alike. At the end of the long path way where one can't help shifting from left to right and vice versa to get into shops, there is the famous temple Sensoji.But after awhile, one cannot help herself but turned her back on the temple and started to walk back towards the exciting street of shops to end up buying what matters most to her - anpan, snacks, mochi what have you. Until it rained again signalling that one should stop and proceed home before more damage is done to her pocket and obediently walked to the nearest subway station.which is about 100 meters away and dutifully got on the subway.With a happy smile and 10 plastic bags filled with goodies in both hands! What a life!
Very old and classic temple in the city center. Very old and classic temple in the city center. Always very crowded. With a number of shops selling food and souvenirs at the entrance.

Beautiful Temple. I went to Tokyo in April, went to Asakusa, on weekend its super crowded, but its fun to be there. There is a small market full of souvenirs, the temple is big and architucture is beautiful. A must place to be if you are going to Tokyo.

All you need is here!. One stop shop for all your needs. Gift items, food, clothes, leather, house decor, art shops. Suggest you go early around 9-10 as the place gets really crowded. Try the local snack items - different but very yummy. Get those with chestnut flavor.

The tourist souvenir centre. If you like shoulder rubbing with other tourists and are seeking a large variety of souvenirs, then this is a fun place to go. There is also a lovely temple if you have not been 'templed out'.There is also a large amenities block and plenty of places to eat. However, if you are after competitive prices and want to be able to take advantage of duty free allowances, take a trip to Akihabara first. A large number of stores around the station have the same or similar goods and it is also the go to place for Anime and electronic goods.
Interesting place must visit. Please come here early morning. A lot of people here. Easy access via train station. There is halal shop nearby which you can buy your food
Very Nice to Visit. A must see when in Tokyo, but be aware of the crowds. The market stalls outside the temple are unbelievable, if you are a westener on a rainy day, expect an umbrella in the eye!

Full of Rich History and Japanese Culture. The first thing you can see in Asakusa in the huge red lantern at the entrance of the temple. That is the place where every visitor would take a picture to keep as a souvenir! The transport system to come to Asakusa is not that difficult either. Trust me, we used a subway to reach here! (Tokyo Toei Subway Line, please note that using the JR to come to Asakusa is not convenient as not only it is more expensive, but after you go down from JR it takes about another 20 minutes to walk here).Hint: I was lucky because my parents stayed in Japan before. So travelling around Tokyo using the Subway was F-U-N! (Japan is a pretty safe place so no worries~).Anyway back to Asakusa, you can find tons of delicious food and desserts here, souvenir yes, and of course not forgetting the Senso-Ji Buddhist temple as you keep walking further up. You may see pretty young Japanese girls with Yukata walking towards the temple hehe... To be specific, it is to celebrate their 20th birthday here! (the reaching of adulthood age for Japanese)For the rest of what I have seen here? Well you gotta make more research and come here yourself and explore this place.It is totally worth your time (to see the cute Japanese girls as well).

Never go back. We had great memories from 13 years ago but there are far more tourists now and far worse market stalls. We wanted to recreate our experiences and felt claustrophobic from the people around. The octopus balls weren't cooked and everything was 100% more expensive.

Too Crowded And Not For Claustrophobics. I'd cut to the chase: it was too crowded for me. It may be because it was a Sunday I visited but nevertheless I couldn't handle the crowd.After travelling from various places in the countryside in Japan, Asakusa was a rude shock. It was sardine packed and even the shop owners did not have the typical Japanese friendliness. Everyone was harried and pushing each other. :( wasn't the best experience. However, do explore the side streets flanking the main shopping street. They were quieter and had nice little shops :)
A religious place. A big temple with a great view in it..You can see the Japanese pray and respect their God in humbleness.

A must to visity in Tokyo. We took a bus from Ueno to Asakusa. I think it costs a little bit more than using subway but we would like to explore the city. The temple was nice with lots of stalls to attract tourists in front of it. We enjoyed trying few snack there. After visiting Asakusa, we walked towards the river and had a nice view of asahi building.

Crowded and Fun. Went recently, the autumn arrived late so Gingko trees are in its full glory of yellow. Clear blue skies gives a great backdrop for a day of wonderful look around the different stalls. at the end of the stalls if you can get past all the tourists is a temple so its' an interesting mix of culture and commercial. There's snacks along the way as well so keep spare change ready....

Crowded!. This is a very popular location, both for those in Japan and foreigners visiting the country. This place felt so much more crowded than the Meiji temple or any of the other little temples, gardens and shrines we visited during our trip. If you need souvenirs, though, this seems to be the place.There is an entire "village" of shops at the main entrance. Maybe it was the time of day or time of year, but there was a wall of people all the way from the main street, through the gate, and up to the temple. The grounds contain the iconic watchtower (the one that you see in all of the photos of Asakusa), but you should be aware that you cannot go into that building. There is a nice garden and some smaller buildings on the grounds, where it seemed that the locals were visiting, but the main attraction for visitors was the main temple. While there was a huge crowd, it didn't really affect our experience until we decided it was time to go and felt like salmon swimming upstream. Now that I have been there, I know that it is probably best to stop by the shops on the way INTO the temple rather than trying to leave via the main gate. You can easily take a side street and bypass the crowds if you don't care to stop at any of the shops!On a relatively clear day, there is a good view of the Sky Tree, which many people suggest as the next stop on your tour. We didn't have time, and had already visited the Tokyo Tower, so we just caught the subway back to our hotel. There are many subway and train stops conveniently located nearby, and Ueno park with the Tokyo National Museum is within walking distance, depending on what that means to you (I think it is around 2 miles away)

Interesting blend old and new. Took a train from Ueno (subway). I feel the subway has better connectivity than JR lines. The street leading to Sensoji is full of tourists and rickshaw drivers. Plenty of food choices but Tempura and soba seems to be very popular with several popular restaurants like Aoi Marushin and Daidokoya. The side streets are pleasant. We walked across the river towards Tokyo Sky Tree rather than take the train. Great decision.

Beautiful Temples in very Commercial Surroundings. The area is a good mix of the temples and traditions of Japan with a well organized commercial area with plenty of choices to buy souvenirs and local crafts

Wonderful. This temple is a lovely place to visit. Colourful and magnificent in stature. We were there on a festival day so it was very crowded, but the men and women were in traditional dress and looked wonderful. The evening was all lit up and then fireworks. This was a special place this day

Interesting place to visit. Very beautiful! Worth the visit but its very packed even though we visited on the weekdays. The pathway are really cool and interesting, just like anime lol. And you can even see the skytree too!!

Asakusa is one of Tokyo attraction for its tranquility. Asakusa is one of the Tokyo attraction for its tranquility. Arrays of shops on the way to the temple and all the pathway is nicely decorated with beautiful sakura flowers

The markets are fun to explore and the temples are beautiful.. Getting lost in Asakusa late at night after a big night out in Shinjuku is not recommended. You can however use the tallest temple as a guide to make your way back to the train station and get your bearings.
Thanks temple, you rock!

One of Tokyo's shitamachi districts. We were very happy we stayed in Asakusa during our trip to Tokyo. You can walk around and also catch train/subway to other districts. Plenty of good reasonably priced restaurants to eat and the Sensoji temples and the street nearby with all old shops are really beautiful.

Fun temple fix . You don't have to leave Tokyo to see a great temple. Here you can get endless souvenirs and really enjoy your time eating fun foods and buying charms. Careful however. If you're not into crowds I would go during a quiet time. It can be overwhelming. This temple is beautiful however and I really recommend going when it's a festival if you can. The shops and food stands make the experience that much more exciting.

Vibrant at day, peaceful at night. During the day, the area is busy with tourists roaming around and locals selling food and souvenirs. Some people might get overwhelmed but I really love the vibrant Japanese vibe! I highly recommend taking a stroll in the neighborhood at night too. It gets really quiet and peaceful and the lighting is great for some bokeh photography

Tourist centre of tokyo. Tokyo is a crowded city. Asakusa is probably more crowded than most places. From locals who go to the temple to pray, to hordes of tourists, it is almost always crowded. But it is hard to imagine going to Tokyo and not visiting the place. You can find al last anything there. Very vibrant and lively. If you want an excellent aerial view of the area, go to the tourist info centre and take the lift to the 8th floor. Bets of all, it is free!

Best of All Neighborhoods!. Had a great time walking around Asakusa, visiting the temple and going through all of the little shops. Really wanted to do the Tower of Tokyo, but it was too windy, so they wouldn't let us up. :) Spent probably 6 hours here shopping. Great time! You can also rent rickshaws if you would like, but I wanted to be able to take my time in the shops.

It's very crowded on the main promenade nowadays.. I've been here about 7 years ago and the main promenade is now crowded with Chinese tourists. I don't know why they are dragging big suitcases with them. So once you buy your trinkets, visit the stores in less populated areas where you can shop at your leisure. My favorite crafts store is gone. The river still looks nice, but popularity has spoiled this once quaint shopping area.
Go at night if you want to avoid the crowd. it can get pretty packed during daytime. but if you go after sunset, the lighting is quite dramatic (good for photos) and there are less people!

Nice enough, but not worth the hassle. If you're going for the shopping and street food, this is worth the trip. If you're in the neighborhood already, it's worth seeing. I came all the way from Shibuya (about 50 minutes) just to see the temple and grounds. I wasn't that impressed.

If you only have time for one thing in Tokyo. Do not miss Asakusa, you will get a traditional temple, a shopping area and a glimpse on Skytree which is very close by. If you have time spend there some time. There is too many people, but that is the way it is...

Best Moncha-Yaki, don't miss. I heard from my japanese friend that there are most delicious Moncha-Yaki in Japan at Asakusa. About 8 year ago I had been Ofunato and tried Moncha-Yaki, I love it, and try to seek it in Bangkok. A few month ago, I visited Ofunato again, but very sadly Moncha-Yaki shop was gone by Tsunami. My old friend told me that you can find the best Moncha-Yaki at Asakusa, and I found that. There are many resturant in the market near Asakusa temple. If you live in Red Planet Hotel, you will find them in the narrow street around there.

A must go in Tokyo. Started off with street before the Sensoji temple. Nice place for shopping souvenir and street food. Upon reaching the temple, you could catch a glimpse of Tokyo tree tower. Female travelers can rent Kimono for Photo sit around the area.

Love this old area of Tokyo!. So I'm a little biased, as I really love this old area of Tokyo. Lots of attractions are within walking distance (Tokyo Sky Tree, Sumida Bridge/Sumida River, Sensōji, Kappabashi). There's also an Onsen (Jakotsuyu Onsen), near Taito, and it's the only Onsen I've been to where they really don't care of you have tattoos (which is often a problem for foreigners).If you're interested in the older parts of Tokyo, please check out Asakusa. Lots to do around here and lots of sights to see.

amazing temple. amazing temple, with nice traditional architect, with amazing shrine and amazing Sculptures.in the temple complex there is nice gardens and in is entrance there is strip of stands that selling street food ,cookies and souvenirs
Wonderful area!. I have been to this place twice, it's always fun! Though crowded, it's a lovely place for evening sunset photo taking shots of the temples and pagoda.

Wonderful Temple to visit. I had Wonderful memories of this place,beautiful temple and a big market over there where we can buy traditional stuff of Japan, it great tourist place to enjoy,Anyone who visit tokyo must visit this temple.

Great place for shopping and eating.. Went here last month and found many good places to eat. Didn't have enough time to see everything. I think you need two days here. You can ride a rickshaw for around $70.
Landmark temple at Asakusa area. Crowded people to visit this temple if you would like to take a photo with the red giant lantern, you should come here before 8 a.m.

Where old town meets the new. Great place to visit and see both the older town and the newer town all rolled into one. We definitely loved the rickshaw ride through the streets of Asakusa and the views of the Tokyo Sky Tree, the older town, and the Sensoji Temple. This is a great place to visit if you have a lengthy layover and want to experience Japan. We loved it. Wish we did this earlier on our trip so we can spend more time going around.

Fantastic hour seeing some of the quainter parts of Tokyo. This rickshaw tour was turned into a fun and fact filled experience by Kabuki our driver. He not only pulled us from street to street with lots of gusto but he really filled in well with snippets of information and history about the places we were visiting. We got to ring a temple bell, see the Geishas HQ, had plenty of photos taken and learnt a lot in a short time span.It was good to be away from the busier traffic for a spell and this hour made a never to be forgotten highlight of our Japanese holiday.

Crowded but Fun. We visited on a Saturday afternoon and it was VERY crowded. The streets were lined with lots of great souvenir shops and street food. It is a fun place to wander around if you are okay with crowds.

Must see places in Tokyo. Very nice park with famous shops, shrine and pagoda not to mention restaurant variety. Very good place to see the culture and beauty of Japan. The hustle and bustle of this place is very exciting and fun. The shopping is amazing and seeing locals wear their traditional kimonos to the temple is nice and really shows local culture.

Crowded and busy. We visited Asakusa twice. Both times, it was very crowded with tourists and busy, even amidst the drizzle. The streets were lined with colourful stalls, mostly selling souvenirs. I bought boxes of Japanese chopsticks which cost 500y each. Fridge magnets were 200y at the cheapest, but most were 300y - 350y.Many ladies dressed kimonos could be seen strolling about.The wonderful thing about Asakusa is that many traditional restaurants could be found here. On our two visits, we had delicious sushi and sashimi at a kaiten zushi called Maguro-bito and a set of traditional Japanese food at Maguro-soba. Be sure to make bookings before you come though. There're long queues.It's indeed a must-visit place.

The best region of the city. Amazing place, takes you to another dimension. A nice place to also buy some gifts and, you're hungry, a nice place to buy traditional japanese sweet bread :) Nice temples over there.

Fantastic part of town...magnificent temples and fun shopping.. I love Asakusa...you can arrive/leave by train or by boat (the boats come up from near Shinagawa) You will find glimpses of old Tokyo on the side streets with moms on bikes with kids in tow. My son was totally entranced by the main gate: Kaminarimon (THUNDER GATE) with it’s giant red lantern and two scary and crazy wild looking guardian gods: Thunder and Wind. I really enjoyed the promenade of what my husband likes to call ‘ticky-tacky’ shops that runs from the gate to the Senso-Ji temple (a must see and I will review separately). This little street (Nakamise-dori) is festive and fun to walk along. I bought some ‘ticky-tacky’ stuff for my friends (think Godzilla keychains) My husband bought weird food to try. On the side streets you can find some great Ramen and other types of food. My son wanted a bespoke pair of chopsticks and he uses them here in the US all the time! I always visit this part of town every time I am in Tokyo. Love it!!

Lovely place to visit to discover 'Old' Tokyo. Asakusa is a must see place if you want to experience old Japanese culture. It is a short walk from the Ueno station. There is lots to see and do there. There is the Nakamise shopping street leading where you can buy gifts and souvenirs. After walking up and down, we realised that the shops nearer to Sensoji gets progressively more expensive. So if you want to buy simple and cheap souvenirs as gifts back home, you are better off buying from the shops nearer to the Kaminarimon (main entrance).There are places there where you can rent kimonos to wear as you walk along the streets. Some shops even offer Tea ceremony experiences. Hint: If you want to photograph the entire Nakamise Street including Sensoji, go up to the top floor of the tourist information centre across the road from the Kaminarimon.

Very good. Asakusa temple is very nice, can get very busy with tourists. The street is full of people selling snack and touristy souvenirs. But they are still within reasonable price.Explore side street a few blocks away and you can get some cheaper souvenirs and snacks.

So much to do!. This is a great part of town in "older" Tokyo, but there is still plenty to do. Must see is Sensoji Temple. And if your into cooking, or buying stuff, you can't miss kappabashi street!

Nice neighborhood in Tokyo. Late afternoon walk from the Ueno JR station in the small streets of Asakusa. Beautiful temple especially when all the lights are on. Lively neighborhood with a mix of locals and tourists. The small shops and restaurants have a lot to offer and prices are very reasonable, compared to the average in Ginza...

Please visit Asakusa if you wanna experience Japanese culture in Tokyo. Please visit Asakusa if you wanna experience Japanese culture in Tokyo. You can ride the trishaw to go around, the best way to explore Asakusa. You can also get get souvenirs at Sensō-ji temple. There are tons of sourvenir shops that you'll be spoiled for choices.

The more traditional part of Tokyo. Asakusa is fun. There's a train station that takes you right there. I stayed in Asakusa and I wasn't disappointed.There are a lot of random temples here along the streets, including the famous Senso-ji temple and the Nakamise tourist shopping right next to it. It's a great place to get souvenirs.There's great stores that aren't tourist related as well. There's a bunch of restaurants everywhere that display their menus, both Western and Asian food.
Asakusa Station view. Tokyo Sky Tree view from Asakusa Station.August, summer in Japan! Vista da estação de Asakusa, Tokyo sky Tree. Verao O mês era

A must vist. Asakusa is a must see destination if you are in Tokyo. It is very animated, energetic, a lot to see neighbourhood. Visit Senso-ji, lunch around in charming streets, shop for souvenirs. Easy to connect to Tokyo SkyTree as well as take a river cruse.

Beautiful but busy.... I came around this area solely for the Sensoji Temple but got more than I bargain. First of all, Sensoji Temple was gorgeous and beautiful - the red temple was surrounded by modern skyscrapers and the Tokyo tower. The front of the temple was impressive with the 3 huge lanterns with beautiful gold designs on the bottom. Along the way from the subway station, there were lots of little shops and one block away from the Temple, you will see a street lined with small wooden shops/booths with snacks and souvenirs. I had the "Asakusa Ice Cream Sandwich", you pick the flavor ice cream and they pack it between two wafers shaped like the lanterns in front of the temple. Though busy, this is a must visit if you want a step back in time and get away from city.

Tokyo of Good Old Days. The Asakusa side of Tokyo has quite some good tourism spots to offer. Sensoji Temple and the shopping street - Nakamise are not the only one, I'm pretty impressed with the evening sunset view of Sumida River over Sumida Park though. I am visiting Tokyo again next Tuesday (It is mid of Nov at time of review) and I am staying again in this area.

A must visit while in Tokyo. Asakusa should be visited once to get a flavor for what a shopping place for tourists looks like. It's quite busy with large number of shoppers and it is an excellent location for "street photography". There is a large number of restaurants and small food stalls making and selling all sort of food items, including sweets. The Senso-ji Shinto temple is located at one end of the main path of the Asakusa shopping street..

Definitely should come. This is one of the more interesting places to visit in Tokyo. There are a lot of shops before going to the Senso-ji Temple. There were 2 gates that were worthy of pictures. You could also see a very nice fish pond near the temple.

Met a lovely people and good place to walk around. I will definitely come back ! Its in a good location, easy to access and there are so many good restaurants. I went there last march and will come back again next month :)

Good area to walk around. Away from the crowd and buzz of Shinjinku or Tokyo area but still packed with interesting shops and restaurants plus attractions to see. Recommended for visit and even as an area to stay.

The rain just won't stop :). It was raining all the way. We stopped at the tourist information centre, they have a cafe upstairs. Waited for the rain to stop, it didn't. So we just quickly went to the temple, came back and take ferry to odaiba. i still enjoyed the visit though. A must-visit for everyone.

MANY TRADITIONAL AND FAMOUS FOOD STAND. 1. Beside visiting the old temple and do a prayer, you can also visit the food stand2. Many traditional food stand alongside the walkside to the temple.3. Visit the melon bread store right in beside Asakusa (No.1 Melon Bread in Japan)4. Try the sakura soft ice cream ( pretty strange flavour )5. Very crowded place6. After you finish visit this place , you can continue to the gold city of Japan

Old and new . Old meets new, well more old world really. Great little shopping, eating, people watching, massaging etc area. In autumn particularly you can see young kids dressed in traditional gear very cute. Great way to spend half a day.
Beautiful. Part of the Sensoji area of tourist attractions in Tokyo. Very busy and bustling with tourists. Plenty of souvenir shops and food stalls. In easy access of public transport.

Better come in the night.. Sensoji templs is one of the most famous spot in Tokyo. During the day time is very crowd by many visitors. In the night all the shops are close but still you can work around temple to see the property chraming with beautiful night light.

Glimpse at religious roots in Japan. A visit to Asakusa will dispel any thoughts that the Japanese have no religious beliefs. In the midst of very materialistic Tokyo, it was illuminating to see people making offerings at the temple. I recommend a visit to Asakusa for a glimpse at the religious roots of Japan which still appear to be very much a part of the lives of many in Japan.

Don't miss this area!. My favorite area in Tokyo! Beautiful temple area, fun market with lots of souvenirs and local delights and it's just a fun area to walk around in. River cruise is also close by and so is the visitor centre where you can go up to the 8th floor for a free view of Asakusa and part of Tokyo :).
Really nice temple and market!!!. A really fun place to be if your stop by in Tokyo lots to do so a few hour can easily turn into a day!
solo travel to the temple. very good location to get a deeper insight into the local religion and traditions . it s a definitely worth going place

Good taste of old Japan in the middle of bustling Tokyo. Having stayed in and near Asakusa on multiple occasions, I have always enjoyed each time I came here. Sensoji, Kaminarimon, the old style shops, the shopping, the locals, and even the blatant touristy rickshaws all add to the unique atmosphere that is Asakusa. Cheaper accomodation in Tokyo is generally around Asakusa, especially youth hostels. But don't be disappointed that its not near Shibuya or Shinjuku, you can always catch the train there, and quite frankly the atmosphere around Asakusa is more authentic anyway.

Wonderful toruist destination. If you want a real tourist destination and love shopping a lot, this is one place you need to visit while you are in Tokyo. Great shopping with moderate prices. we bought 3 kiminos in the market for a reasonable price as souvenir from Japan. Also, visited the temple. The shrine is really beautiful with great views of greenery on the lane both sides. you can also have great view of Tokyo tower. You should not miss the small lanes next to this shrine, where you can find lots of restaurants and eateries. A word of caution, we were asked to be aware of pickpockets at this places because it is too crowded with lots of tourists.
BEAUTIFUL ASAKUSA. if you come to Tokyo you must to come here, awesome place, amazing people, attractive temple, come here to buy some souvenirs will be awesome

A must see for visitors...at least once. Historical and traditional shrines galore in this famous location in Tokyo. Can get a little touristy, but definitely worth a couple hours of time for first timers. Easy to get to by subway, and the traditional architecture is phenomenal. Nice little shopping bazaar at the entrance.
Very active shrine grounds. Great little shops, street food, and restaurants leading up to and next to the shrine. Giant incense burner, dragon dance, definitely worth a visit. Can get crowded.

HOW BEAUTIFUL OF TOKYO. i arrived in Tokyo in the morning with very cold weather. even though i had expected that the winter here would be very hard but i didn't think how cold of it. The first thing i did was looking for a sweat store and i must say that Uniqlo is very cheap. After already finished all my works, I came back to Asakusa and visited around. This place was so peaceful and i felt like i had just thrown away all of my stress and sadness. The people here were very friendly and helpful.If i have a chance, i will visit this country again

Choose the things that you like. I visited asakusa on october 2015. It is a nice place. there are many foreigner who visisted thi place. I can see that this is one of favorite place for tourist. There are many shops along the way go to temple. You can find any traditional food with Angko (rea beans) , any t-shirt, japanese characters, and others.
BEST district. This is hands-down my favorite district in Tokyo. I cannot spend enough time there! It is Tokyo with a traditional feel.

Visit Asakusa to see Old Tokyo. When you take the Sumida River Cruise from North to South, Asakusa is located just after the completion of the cruise. Asakusa provides a feel for Old Tokyo. It is lined with shops along a pedestrian road that leads to the Sensoji Temple. You will see Buddhists active in incense burning and the purification process. It is a worth whle experience when you visit Tokyo.
Great temple!. Go there and spend some hours looking for the local people.. I was so impressed by their holy culture!

Interesting but a bit of a tourist trap. Fairly enjoyable area with market stalls of food and trinkets. We wandered through for about an hour, most of the markets sell the same merchandise over and over. Good for souvenirs and gifts but overall not the best cultural experience. Worth the visit though as it doesn't take a huge amount of effort.

A must visit place for tourists. I recommend Asakusa for three things :Temple - its a great sight to see, different during the day and at night!Food - the selection of food choices are great; from street food to traditional Japanese dining, from Okonomiyaki to the standard Western influenced cuisine! Be careful though as its quite pricey compared to others areas in Tokyo since this is a tourist attraction. I've had the best Tempura in Asakusa and that is whats its known for as well.Shopping - this what makes Asakusa a nice place to visit, especially if you are short on time while going around Tokyo. My friend bought a Kimono set for just 2,000 YEn! We can't believe it but its her favorite souvenir from Japan. There are other shops of interest around and you may easily lost track of time here.Best time to go is around 4:30PM where you can see a glimpse of the day sight the temple has to offer and then stay until dinner time and walk around the neighborhood.

Tourists must see. You really must see this district. Lots to eat, plenty of shops, grab a rickshaw and have a ride around. The temple is cool. Most things only require a few mins but there are plenty of things to see.

Where Every Tourist Must Go. This is an attraction where every tourist must go. Tokyo can be so busy and crowded that you must not miss enjoying its very rich culture. And that's something you can easily find here in Asakusa.Its main attractions are the Japanese temples. But walking from Asakusa train station all the way to these temples leads you to Japanese-authentic souvenir shops and items you will not see elsewhere. There's this very helpful tourist guide office station just across its street where they have very informative reading materials and staff to assist you. They also have money exchange there because you just can't stop shopping when you're here.The food options are also very interesting. I've had my best takoyoki there so far. Be mindful though of their culture. You must eat the food only in front of the stall where you bought them. Don't eat them somewhere else as it may be a little offensive.This place is overall highly recommended for everyone traveling to Tokyo. Getting there may be a little tricky as it is outside the main Yamanote train circle, but is definitely worth it for exploring how to get there. All thumbs up!
Nice place with easy reach. A must go place when you visit Tokyo. Easily reach via train. Very tradition and do not forget to join the river taxi tour.

A Must see. Asakusa is a traditional neighbourhood with lots of buildings and old fashion shops. Two very different landscape with day light and after sunset, both lovely. During the day it is very crowded but environment is very nice. Also the temple closes around 5 or 5 30 so if you are interested to visit the interior of the temple you should start the visit early in the afternoon. After sunset, all the place turns lights on and honestly it looks totally different.There are many many places to have a traditional diner.

Touristy fun!. This is an extremely busy touristy area that is great fun to see. Just take a walk through and enjoy the experience but if it's a peaceful afternoon you're looking for try somewhere else! Outside of the immediate temple area in the back streets are some interesting shops that are not quite as touristy. All in all an experience!

GREAT PLACE TO VISIT. First visited in 2011 after the Great East Japan Earthquake and Tsunami. It was pretty empty as there were few foreign tourists, It is probably best known for Nakamise Shopping Street and Sensoji Temple and is a great place to check out the many stands and shops selling Japanese confections, and souvenirs. It as also an easy walk to Tokyo Sky Tree and other sites.

Try at night. This is a very nice place with lots of traditional buildings. But during the day it is crowded with tourists. Since it is open all day and night, come after 9PM, so you can see the buildings in night lights. Really nice.
I love this place. Asakusa is a place where you can explore how old Japan is like. Be sure to take one of the rickshaw ride to explore the area.

so much to see. There is so much to see, so much that is unexpected but wonderful and the temple complex is full of beautiful buildings and gardens ... and shops and eateries and people! Loved all of it!
Amazing pagoda set in great location. Amazing pagoda set in a great location, in grounds of Sensoji temple & steps away from Nakamise shopping street. Easy access from Asakusa subway

Fun Sunday Activity. We went on a Sunday morning. It was packed with tourists, vendors and worshippers alike. But like all other places in Japan it was still peaceful and pleasant. We were lucky enough to catch a parade with a dragon. The inner sanctum is restricted to worshippers only but the surrounding areas are worth seeing. Lots of lovely souvenir stores and roadside eating. Must try the candied bananas and pork rolls. Make sure to also write a wish and tie it on one their many wishing trees.
Beautiful, wish travelers were welcomed!. Beautiful exterior but the interior was limited to "registered believers only". Still a gorgeous site!

An interesting area worth visiting. The Senso-ji Temple is the main attraction here but don't forget to wander around the shopping alleys and the side streets. Most of this area was flattened during the war so it is worth visiting the small Storehouse of Gallery ef which survived the war plus they serve good coffee

It's not only Tokyo, it's Asakusa. You absolutely have to see it, bucket list material!!! Tokyo is super-spectacular super-city, a category in itself. And if that wasn't enough, here you have Asakusa, like a piece of the past somehow lost in the time line, ending up in the present time. Despite the thousands of tourists Disney-like, despite the cars and present-time traffic around, somehow it gives you an excellent idea about Japan, crash-course in the very very basics of the culture shock. Enjoy!!!
NIce architecture. very crowded people, because its great destination.. see the way to go there, there's so many shop.. food, souvenirs, and many traditional thing its sell here..

Religious side of Japanese. Well spent 6 hrs being here again with friends this time :) Pictures, laughter, queue and eat, worship, souvenirs, too much to do here. Queue for grilled sweet potato, hot sweet sake & mochi, sweet potato ice cream, imitation crab on a stick and fried meat bun :)Uncertain of what it was all about (mid afternoon, Oct 24), but while the tame monkey was resting on his stool between show, the trainer suddenly pulled the leash and collar choked the monkey. The scream was eerie, frightful and the picture was inhumane.
Not to me missed. Sure it is crowded, but Asakusa Nakamise has the best Souvenir shops. Plenty of variety. The area around the temple is nice. One of the highlights of the trip.

Historic part of Tokyo . Asakusa is conveniently located on the Tokyo metro line. Take the train to the Asakusa station and follow the underground map for the appropriate exit and you will find you are a couple of hundred meter from the buzzling tourist centre of Senso-ji area! Don't pass the street food surrounding the area; stop of some amazing pineapple bun and delicious green tea ice cream!

Great atmosphere, lots to see. My 14 year old and I came on the Saturday to see the Sensoji Temple (amazing, reviewed separately), we also got a lovely surprise of finding all the little streets and alleys with all sorts of shops, food places and gifts. It is touristy but feels very relaxed, the atmosphere is great, not at all like the huge areas like Shinjuku or Shibuya. We bought souvenirs, had photos done where our heads were superimposed onto Japanese characters (a great souvenir and only 1000 jpy each). We also went to the Ninja Experience which was really good fun. This involved a "lesson" in being a Ninja. Our Ninja Master ( great guy, really entertaining) showed us how to use swords, stealth, concealment and how to throw shurikens (ninja stars). Thoroughly enjoyable hour that we shared with other Japanese and Spanish tourists. We ate in a tiny restaurant where we could see an old lady at work in the kitchen (she made our Ramen and gzoyas from scratch). We enjoyed an ice cream (as well as the usual there were some very local flavours (see picture). We saw lots of people in traditional costumes, I especially loved seeing the ladies in their kimonos (who were very gracious to pose for a picture with us). We ended up in Dom Quiote store, a huge multi floor place selling everything! We bought lots of Japanese sweets and green tea kitkats to bring home as well as a huge bag of Panko crumbs that only cost about 50p, would be 10 times that in the UK when you can find them! A fantastic day out

Get there early. We arrived At 9 am and it was relatively quiet but by 10 am it was incredibly busy really nice temple with lots of tourist stalls selling food and souvenirs at reasonable prices look for the small collapsable bags for less than £3 each

Bad tourist trap and annoying rikshas. After visiting temples in Kyoto this area looks like an annoying fair (fair included, there really is an amusement park nearby). The whole area around is also quite let down and filled with tourist trap shops and not so good food. Also tge riksha drivers are really annoing there.If you'd like to go to any temple in Tokyo, then go to Meiji Jingu, but Tokyo is not famous from its temples and you can spend time better.
A neighborhood to visit ni Tokyo. Temple, typical japanese souvenirs shops ( good place to buy tour last minute souvenirs) lots of restaurants, very touristic but worth it to visit
