STREET FOOD outside the temple!. Touristy? Check... But don't pass it up. We have travelled all over Asia and know to avoid 'junk souvenir' shopping. But the huge pedestrian market area before the temple was so worth the half-day spent.Bypassing the trinket shops, we found some fantastic little specialty shops selling fine wares (see pics)... And we had a blast sampling the different hawker snacks. The temple is nothing special, few photos and move on, we didn't even bother to go inside.
Interesting area of Tokyo. I really liked this area of Tokyo. It was more traditional and less crowded than some of the other attractions.

Nice temple, huge lanterns. Very crowded during the day, but if you visitearly morning, before the souvenir shopsopen, you can take excellent photos of thetemple and pagoda, without the crowds.After dark is the ideal time for photographs,With the lights of the pagoda, temple andthe mass of small lanterns, the scene isabsolutely perfect.During the day, it tends to become verycrowded. The shops, which line theapproach to the temple, vary considerablyin price and quality. One or two of the shopssell some very good copies of famous Japanesepaintings, which make much better souvenirs thansome of the rather tacky plastic items on sale.
It was to crowded when I visited Asakusa. There were too many people during my visit. It's even hard to walk leasurely. I can't enjoy shopping though there are many shops.

If you're looking for souvenirs, Asakusa Nakamise is one of the must go to places for tourists for better prices.. If you're looking for souvenirs, Asakusa Nakamise is one of the must go to places for tourists for better prices, diverse selection, outdoor market/street food, and pictures and the temple.You can find various swords, masks, shirts, and a unique umbrella here that beads artistic patterns of water when it gets wet.I wish I could have stayed longer, but was on a schedule. You can easily spend the whole day here.
Highly in Tokyo. One of my favorite places in Tokyo. We were there at end of December and it was just amazing, so full of life, people. Unforgettable.

Asakusa temple tour. This had been the second time i visited here. It is still as nice as before. Many tourists will took pictures of the temple. You can pray to God,tell your wish and ask for a lot,pay a small token of 100 yen for temple. If good lot just keep it,but if not bad lot ,just tied it up and hope bad goes away.
Family in Asakusa. A great area for easing into Japan. Not too busy with great access to the rest of the city. The area around the temple is beautiful.

A great location in Tokyo . This part of Tokyo is great to stay and very easy to get around with all the stations it can sometimes can be confusing but you do get use to it. There is a really nice market place and a fish market very close & a lot of food places around. I felt very safe in this area and comfortable.
Shrine is good, prefer other towns. The sensoji shrine is nice to look around. The town has some interesting streets and the sea flows through which you can get a boat trip. Preferred shibuya town.
Interesting place for foodies !. There's really lots to do in this area. But what I enjoyed most was sampling the variety of Japanese cakes and sweets available. A pity they were so expensive.

Great fun and lots to explore. The whole area is full of lovely little shops and places to eat, which eventually leads up to the Sensō-ji shrine. It's a great area to explore - we had tasty sushi and a Bento box for lunch (from a place with the friendliest waiters and chefs) and stumbled upon a plum wine festival in between our trip to the lovely Sensō-ji. I'd definitely recommend - you could easily spend most of the day here while still only seeing the key things!!

Cool part of town with an authentic vibe!. Stayed here for a few days.A good area for tourists who don't want the super busy shinjuku/shibuya vibe and a more traditional vibe.Good souvenir shopping as well.

Touristy, but still a great deal of fun. Asakusa is one of the places I always try to visit when I go to Japan. Yes, it's tremendously touristy. But it's fascinating and fun, with hundreds of vendors, wonderful restaurants, and the lovely Senso-ji Temple. One of my very favorite things is to get the fresh toasted rice crackers at one of the stalls. If you're a fan of rice crackers, you are going to be BLOWN AWAY at how wonderfully delicious these are. They toast the crackers and then dip them in the soy sauce mixture and hand them to you, hot and ready to eat. Oh, oh...the wonder of it. If you don't speak Japanese, they do cater to tourists (of course). Most labels are in English, and most of the restaurants have English menus. Or, at very least, you can go point at the plastic food in the window... :-).I love walking through the stalls, back alleys and surrounding areas to both window shop and people watch. Souvenir shopping here is a must...if that's your thing. The prices are competitively low. And the people watching is priceless.

Fun and much to see!. Went here with a couple of friends and we truly enjoyed ourselves! Senso-ji temple is a wonderful sight at the end of the many rows of shops. This place is ideal of souvenir shopping and prices are surprisingly not overpriced for a tourist attraction. Make sure to try the fresh dorayaki while there! It is a Japanese pastry pressed with a sweet red bean paste in between. At senso-ji temple you get to pick a fortune, which is fun to do as well!
Great to walk around. There are a lot of things to see in Asakusa. It easy to walk around and get lost in the amount of culture there is. It is beautiful traditional Japan. I really enjoyed it.

Touristy outside, plenty spiritual inside. Did not like the hustle of the tourist shops outside the temple but loved the experience of the incense burning, and prayer as one looked into the temple center area. Around the temple area seems to go back 30 years or more in time including an abundance of rickshaw drivers hawking rides.
Nice traditional town. I love Asakusa! Love the temple, the foods and the shops.It was a bit different from other place in Tokyo.But that what makes it more special.
Nice picture, more recommend at night view. I arrived this area at the night time, its very nice view especially at night time i thought, but becareful the shop almost closed at 20.00 hrs.
pretty little place. Very pretty little place and a very busy tourist area. Asakusa is more traditional Japan so it's a nice place to visit away from the big city.

Spectacular and peacefulIn the middle a a massive metro. I had hoped to see a little of old Japanese culture and Asakusa did not disappoint. Despite significant crowds it still managed to be very peaceful. The water fountain, shrine, and gates are definitely worth a look.
I loved the statues.

Experience a different, more traditional side to this vast city.. The Asakusa area is a must-do for all those staying at least a few days in Tokyo. The area has a fantastic temple complex (Senso-ji), traditional shopping streets and artisan producers, great restaurants and street-foods. You are also a stone's throw from Oshiage and the Sky Tree and access to the boat cruises along the Sumida-gawa.
Traditional Tokyo. A nice temple, in the hearth of Tokyo. The market street leading to it is full of interesting stuff. Also good to stroll to the Sky tree nearby.

Asakusa. Love this place. It is busy but full of culture. Can buy cheap souvenirs to take home as well as second hand silk kimonos for 1000 yen!!!
A must have is a rickshaw ride to learn about the culture.

Historic shrine. Built around 637AD, this is a great example of Shinto and Buddhism religions. The main shrine is beautiful and people come here from all over world to see it. There is also a purification fountain and incense burner on site to help worshippers. The multi-story pogota Is something to behold. Leading up to a main shrine is a street lined with shops.

Nice place for a walk but very busy and commercial. Lots of small shops selling everything from hand made knives through to fans and footware! There are also nice open spaces around the historic temples (Kannon Temple or Sensoji) and some beautiful old gingo trees. But be warned, it is very commercial and lots of people go there. Some nice small restaurants with outside tables on one of the main side streets serving inexpensive food. Seems to attract alot of younger Japanese. Worth the visit.

Nice tour. Busy main street with only souvenir shops. However, this area gives you a right idea on typical Japanese souvenirs such as yukata and folding fans, various traditional local snacks etc. The shopping street leads you to the beautiful Sensoji temple who is absolutely a must see.

Busy but fun. We really enjoyed visiting here, the temples were great and made for some excellent photos and the streets were busy but interesting, teeming with souvenir shops! Would definitely recommend a visit and its very close to the subway station.

Go at night for the lights. We visited late so all of the souvenir shops were closed and consequently there were less people at the temples too, the temples and pagoda are lit until 11pm at night so a visit between 9:30pm and 11pm was good. Great for street photography at night too, very photogenic area of the city

Great area to discover. Asakusa a great area just to take off and traverse. All sorts of things to see from the riverside park to the large temple complex. Shops temples, restaurants, foodstalls. Cross over the bridge and go visit the Tokyo Edo museum of just vist the vistors centre, on it's own a fantastic piece of modern day architecture. The atmosphere in the area is fun, relaxed, busy just something for everyone can be found. Worth a whole day just to take time out and explore all there is to see. take off into the side streets this can offer you little hidden gems of shops etc or just nice little old fashionend buildings great for getting an idea of changing tokyo
Must see in Tokyo. Next to an old temple and has a wonderful area where you can possibly feel how Japan was in old days. I would go there any time i am in Tokyo

Holy Hyper Commercialized Batman!. One of the less interesting stops in Japan. The temple itself is beautiful, but the entire road leading up to it is chalked full of cheap souvenir shops. As a result, the atmosphere is less reverent and really caters more to tourists. I recommend the Heiji temple.

Asakusa Rickshaw Tour. Stopped in Asakusa to specifically ride a rickshaw. Tokyo Rickshaw was a short walk from the metro just around the corner (pass the pub built in the 1800's) on the same street as the new like-boxes-stacked-up tourist info building. We chose the first rickshaw company around the corner. It was a bit expensive but worth it for a very unique experience. Our driver Kazuki made sure we were in safely, then took us down a street of cherry trees which blossom beautifully in the spring. We also had a great view of Tokyo skytree where Kazuki stopped so he could take pictures of us with our phones. Kabuki gave us interesting historical information along the route. Kazuki was a friendly and enlightening tour guide and it was a great rickshaw ride. The traffic is very busy, as well as the pedestrians, however Kazuki did a great job navigating through all of this.

Busy but interesting. Very old site that was rebuilt after being bombed in the war. Lots of people and a walk from the temple to the thunder gate is packed with interest as you go past the street stalls. Two temples on site a Bhuddist and Shinto , good to donate and get your fortune from the drawers , if it's a bad one you can tie it up and leave it behind !!
Great!. One of the tourist attraction shrine that must go for. There is fantastic traditional area with great shopping, restaurants.

Just perfect. You can get souvenirs from shops inside in front of the Kaminarimon gate.. It got access to anywhere.. Can get a perfect view of the Skytree from Asakusa.. Access from subway Asakusa line and Ginza line..

nice small walking tour. in a 0.2mi sq area, you can see a small crafts museum, sennso-ji which has several food stalls, awning covered streets filled with small shops & restaurants. we watched a street entertainer with his monkey at the temple. the temple was packed with people as it was silver week. the masses of people alone were interesting to watch. Note:the categories for type of visit is too limiting. i traveled with an adult son. so not family as defined. not couples. not friends. not business. not solo. i marked family (teens) for lack of other.

First time exploring Asakusa. We have though lots that should we stay in this Arawak because we think it is quite far from Shinjuku. However, we have explored the area and found that this is more simply to access. Close to Tokyo Sky tree and famous Zadayu building. Life here is more ease than Shinjuku. We can reach there in 35 minutes by metro.

Do your research and avoid the tourist traps. As others have said, Asakusa is touristy but has some real gems hidden away. The Sensoji temple is always crowded, even at night but I would actually recommend you visit twice to get the atmosphere at different times of day. Personally I enjoy the walk up Asakusa dori from Ueno JR or Kesei station past all the religious goods stores - but it is a bit long for some. Just remember there are two subway companies going there and the tickets are not compatible. The backstreets are really worth exploring, but do your research if you are interested in specialty shopping. I for instance, stumbled across a coffee specialist shop but too late in the evening so it was shut. Same goes for food. Many places serve tourist slop but there are nice little places, sometimes serving European food of excellent quality (San Gusto Pizzeria springs to mind). Overall a vibrant and interesting part of the city which is good for relaxed wandering

One of my favorite districts of Tokyo. Asakusa has a beautiful shrine, amazing shops, an interesting Donquijote, a free Japanese crafts museum, an uncrowded Game(arcade chain) and is near the Tokyo Skytree where you can get a nice view of the city.

Touristy but a must see. Foreign visitors to Japan, as well as Japanese visitors to Tokyo all stop by Asakusa. Yes, it's touristy and very crowded at times, but it something you just have to go see. Lots of great restaurants but research beforehand.

Asakusa is virtually my backyard. This is one of the most popular tourist spots in Tokyo. We live right behind the Sensoji Temple in Asakusa.Things to watch for: Restaurants are of lower quality as tourist rarely ever come back to the same restaurant. There are a few top quality restaurants too, but very limited.Lots of shops and stalls selling tourist items. Some interesting antique shops on the side streets. Two good shops that sell Japanese pottery. Allow at least one hour just for window shopping. You must browse as there is a myriad of shops selling everything you can imagine. Please watch out for your belongings. This is a tourist spot and although the Japanese are extremely honest and law abiding, there is certainly a mix of many nationalities in this area. Sadly, shop-lifting, bag snatching and pick pocketing is not at all uncommon.Nearly all shops close at 6PM when the temple doors close.There could be a long line to enter the main temple hall.

A place worth to see. We have had fun experience in there from the train. One of the tourist attraction shrine that must go for. There has shops (food, things to bring back) along the Asakusa as well as outside.

Fun Place to Eat and Shop. So much fun to walk around here! Shops selling everything imaginable at great prices, and also lots of food stalls with good things to eat--(not just odd things made of fish parts!!!). There are good ramen and yakitori restaurants as well. Definitely worth a morning or afternoon when you are in Tokyo.
Really liked this area. We visited very early in the morning due to jet lag but was a great part of Tokyo to walk around. We had breakfast from street vendors and viewed the temple

Worth seeing as an introduction to Japan. It's an area of Tokyo that contains temples, old style buildings, Japanese culture and crowds of people. Yes, it's the number one tourist stop in Taito, that means lots of tourists.Go see the area, but then escape to the less touristy areas to get a real feel of Tokyo. If you are up for a walk, leave Asakusa and walk towards Ueno park, mixing back streets with the wide boulevard of Kotobuki.

A great way to start Tokyo trip. Going to Asakusa is a great way to start your trip. Take some time to try Japanese street-food, then go make a wish at the temple.You can go there by metro, Asakusa station. Using google map to navigate is the best way. There are 2 metro lines that go there, so try not to get confused. The tickets can't be used together even if the price is the same. :)There are many local food stands along the way, i found the ones near the entrance were slightly cheaper than the ones near the temple.Also there is a delicious melon bread shop here.(heard from local. Yes they sell only melon bread) Facing the temple, keep an eye to the right for the shop somewhere along the way.

Great escape and shopping. Great outing to shop for local arcticrafts , and touristic items . Has plenty of restaurants and a great massage parlor .At the end of the shops is the asakusa temple which is great to view and take pics .A nice place to visit . Has a great quite garden next to it .

Asakusa - Must visit in Tokyo. Been here a couple of times and I don't wonder why this is the no.1 attraction in Tokyo. A true depiction of culture, history and what not. This is a beautiful temple with a great surroundings. Only problem is the amount of crowd, but it has to be so, right? There are shopping options also around the temple for food, souvenirs, etc.. Must visit in Tokyo.

Tourist Town. Asakusa has plenty of shops and foods along with the Senso-ji Temple but it was a little touristy with lots of shops selling cheap tourist merchandise. Not bad prices though if you need to grab some gifts before you head home.

Felt like a tourist trap........ Asakusa on it's own is great. The problem is that there are lots of temples and shrines in Tokyo (many of which are nicer and quieter than Asakusa). There are a plethora of stalls with tourist merchandise so it's a great place to pick up a few souvenirs and worth going to sample the atmosphere as the place is packed with people all the time but don't make a special effort to travel here (the location can be awkward for those staying in Western Tokyo).

Tokyo must visited. If you visit tokyo, this place is must list in your program. Mostly people come to take a photo in front of the temple. Recommend to come on early morning or evening because it has lots of tourist.

True Japanese Culture. You can see Senso-ji temple which is Tokyo's oldest temple here. True Japanese culture you can observe here. There are lot of small temples inside. First time i am seeing whether entire Japan crowd is here :). Also heard around 30 million visitors from throughout Japan and abroad visit the temple every year. I will definitely recommend any tourist to visit this place without fail. Best place for shopping Souvenir,Crafts and delicious cakes both sides of the street.Also you can view Tokyo Sky Tree from the temple. Also very famousAlso Five storied Pagoda is another attraction here. This pagoda was founded in 942. Also a bone relic of the Budda presented by Srilanka was place in the top most storey of the pagoda. Only Members allowed in side this PagodaGo and enjoy this Historic place with your friends and faimily
Good food and local souvenir . Foods great, but sometimes there's a lot of tours and the place can get very crowded. Otherwise, beautiful site and many things you could look at.

Silver Week!!!!. Dear All, It was Silver week, Japanese get 4 days off and the place was pack but nice weather and still good to see. Very traditional, great for some good picture and memory,could be better during a week day.Go around the place and you will find some good Japanese restaurant for more or less 500 Yen for a great noodle with beef and fun shop.From Asakusa, you can walk to Ueno, more or less 30 Mn and only one road.

Asakusa, temple visit. The temple suppose to be one of the large in Japan. In and around the area is more tourist area and many restaurants that offer Japanese food. Ramen, and Chow Han , a Soup kind of meal with meats and noodles with fried rice is a super meal. Cost would be nothing more than 15$ in a standard restaurant.There are days that the temple is closed, so get the opening time wine right before u visit Asakusa

Lovely area - and a change of pace to the rest of Tokyo. Twice we have staid near Asakusa and really like the laid back atmosphere, smaller craft shops and busy markets. The food and drink is cheap and there are some really interesting small shops to see (in addition to the very busy but impressive Senso-Ji). Always worth visiting in Tokyo for a change of pace, a whole world away from Shinjuku and Akihabara.

One of the best neighbourhoods in Japan. Asakusa has a very interesting story, which is visible during walk arounds in the streets, shrines and parks. Modern and traditional live together in a harmonic way. A must see in Tokyo.
Good for food. Many good restaurants around there. It is very close to my hostel. You better wake up early to find nice breakfast around those area.

Try the food!. This is actually a fun place to visit even though we are not into temples. The colorful Nakamise Street have vendors selling every kind of wares including some interesting snack items. We like to try out local food so we bought a few things to eat, like the animal-shaped waffles and some fried mochi. Not a good place to shop for souvenirs though, a little on the expensive side.
Must visit when you are in Tokyo. Don't miss out the big red lantern in front of the temple and there is a shopping streets with souvenirs and local snacks leading all the way to the temple.

Great haunt for local souvenirs. You will never get tired of this place... Great haunt for local souvenirs... Foodstuffs.. I recommend to keep it as your last stop before home as u gonna lots of stuffs back

A Great Area To Shop. The Nishiasakusa area of Taito-ku is an excellent shopping area particularly if you are looking for kitchen items (Kappabashi Street) . One of the best is on the corner of Kappabashi and Asakusa called Den-Gama and they have an excellent range of Japanese pottery. For a little fun visit the shops in Kappabashi to see the wide variety of plastic food used by restaurants to promote their offerings. Take the Ginza Line to stop 18 and it is a block away.

Less frantic than some areas, but very interesting area. Stayed in this area and was less frantic than Shinjuku / Shibuya but well served by the Metro and was a great choice. Appeared a little older / quainter and lots of little streets to explore with attractions such as Senso - Ji temple / Flame d'or to view. Plenty of small restaurants. The many stalls near the Temple are very touristy and chaotic at times but the adjoining covered shopping areas interesting to walk around.

Culture Trip. This temple is an ancient Buddhist emple, Tokyo's oldest and one of the moste significant ones. Formerly assiociated with Tendai sect of Buddhism. It became Independent after World War II. Big "Bazaar" for nippes.
Nicel Old Part of Tokyo. this is the old part of tokyo. old buildings but very nice and polite people. visit senso ji, it is a very nice temple.

Magical site. Although very crowded, this place is a worth seeing in Tokyo. The big impressive lampoons at the entrance of the area, the markets around the temple and of course the shrine itself. Next to the shrine a pagode rises up to the sky. When in Tokyo don't miss this place.

A compact version of Japan. Asakusa has everything most tourists expect to see in Japan.
There are Shrines, Small alleyways, plenty of tiny restaurants and Kitchen Street.
You can get there via the river bus or the train.
I've stayed in the area previously and visited twice this trip.
A great place to stay in Tokyo. Fantastic traditional area with great shopping, restaurants, good transport links as well as the Senso Ji temple.
love the city. really love this city, so many tourist attractions such as Kaminarimon gate, Nakamise street, Kappabashi town, Senso-ji temple, Ueno park and Tokyo Sky Tree
perfect for souvenirs. excellent place to buy souvenirs,see a lot of people and hang around.also you can eat at small traditional places outside!

Very Cool and Amazing historical place to visit while in Japan. A very good place to visit while going around Japan, I had seen similar Temples in Kyoto but this was still great to see. Please add it on your things to see and do while in Tokyo.
Sakura. Brilliant could easily spend a couple of days just in the temple area, never mind the outlet shops, who said Tokyo was expensive???
A must-see place in Tokyo. If you like Japanese temples and shrines, this is a must-see place in Tokyo. There is not only the temple, but also many shops and places to eat.

Amazing Sensō-ji. Eventhough this place is too crowded, I can't help but adore Sensō-ji;s architecture. The street market leading to the temple is also a great place to find trinkets and souvenir items.
Nice neighborhood. This is a very pleasant neighborhood with easy access to most other places in Tokyo. Many restaurants in the area, a Don Quixote for discount shopping, and the temple nearby.

Great District, many things to see and visit. Asakusa is one of Tokyo's District. To get there take the Metro Ginza line until the terminus. After easy visit on foot. In the area many temples as the famous buddhist temple is a must to visit (called Sensoji Temple). Otherwise lots of shops, and busy place. I enjoy to visit the Don Quichotte, a shopping "temple" with everything to purchase.Also nice to see or do the Sumida Park and the Sumida river cruise.Really recommended area!

Cool Area To Visit. We stayed in the area for a week while visiting Tokyo. Much quieter & less crowded than the other areas of Tokyo. Sensoji Temple is nice to visit. Several shops and restaurants in the area. Kitchentown and the world famous Kamiya bar is there. Although touristy, we had a great time and the restaurants were quite good.
Gotta Go. Wonderful friendly unique area to taste and see some great artisan food. Buy your gifts home here lots of choices. Try tge various homemade specialities here

Nice zone. Asakusa is more calm then Shibuya or other places in Tokyo, but then you can enjoy this district for the nice shops in narrow and tipical streets around the Senso-ji sanctuary. The district is well linked to the others of the city, and then Asahi head quarter is set there!

Great shopping for the tourist.. awesome touristy markets here with a fabulous view. I got all my gifts for the family back home here. Easy enough to find, we actually walked down from our hotel in Ueno, not knowing these markets were here, we were walking towards the Tokyo Sky Tree Tower and came across these suburb markets.

great neighbourhood. This was the lower town where the peasants lived there are still some remnants visible. The main attraction here is Senso-ji temple. The street market leading up to the temple is fun and different, offering anything from Tshirts to snacks to wooden sandals!
Street food stalls were he highlight.. This is a historic neighborhood with amazing temples and food markets. Atmosphere is reminiscent of the Edo period.

good place to roam. Asakusa is a good place. You will get good products and souvenirs which you can buy from asakusa market. You can also visit the shrine or go the river side in the evening when sun is about to set. its a nice place to go.
been there last month. My friends and I been to the temple and it was so amazing. I enjoyed shopping and eating alot. love it

Most interesting. If you haven't much time in Tokyo this is probably one of the better temples to visit as there is a great traditional shopping street to stroll down. You can buy swords of all sizes, kimonos, masks or anything. Try the snacks. If it's hot the ice cream is a necessity! You'll need about half a day and I'd recommend not going on a weekend if possible as it is super crowded.

Shopping Galore, Seno-ji Temple and Samba Festival. We went there during the annual Samba Festival. Getting there is easy, the temple is a short walk from the Metro. We spent a lot of time on the shopping street leading up to the temple. The street was crammed with people. Once you get to the temple, the crows thin out. The temple itself is neat to see. Most of our time was spent shopping. Besides the shopping street, the surrounding streets are filled with shops. Tokyo is shopping overload. Then we went to the Samba festival. There were school marching bands, and a few Samba clubs dancing. Only a few of them looked decent. In general, the Samba festival was not very good. At least it was free. It was crammed with people.

Great culture and a lovely charming place with lots to see and do. Visited the famous Sensoji Temple and other Asakusa must-see places. Which include the local charming streets. You will find many stalls, lots of local shops and eating places too. Many of the places here feel very rustic and like they came straight out of a Japanese TV drama... a great cultural experience.
Tokyo. Asakusa is one of the many neighborhoods that combined form the formal Tokyo. Is very calm (out of the main centre) and there's a lot to do around! Easy access by metro.

Beautiful temple . This is worth to visit Asakusa would busy during day and silent in the night . I did stay this area coz near to Narita airport , late night supper and beers at back street nearby sakura hostel . Asakusa is a great place for praying , a place for gift / souvenir and great mochi and sushi prepare by great chef , you may saw Sumo fighter having big bowl ramen , walking distance to sky tree is 35 minutes if you don't mind walk .

Skytree and Nakamise!. went to asakusa for a very limited time, so I went to skytree since it's the landmark there and also nakamise to buy souvenirs. Nakamise is the best place to buy souvenirs, though one store with the other one next to it might have different prices for an exactly same item :D

Great Place. I visited here as part of my 24 crazy hours in Tokyo and I wish I could have stayed longer. The temple is beautiful but busy, it was the school holidays when I visited so other times of year may be different. I spent a lot of time in the markets that lead up to the temple there is so much beautiful stuff be sure to bring lots of cash! If you are in the area it is definitely a must see, in fact I would go out of my way to check it out!
Beautiful. The temple area is packed during the day, I recommend going at night, you will be alone ! I find it even nicer with the lights on. Don't forget to eat and snoop around the galleries ;-)

Interesting temple. One of the oldest temples, with plenty to look at. Like most temples, however, there was no descriptions if you didn't already know what to see. But a nice little photo spot, with a great avenue of shops geared to tourists and souvenirs!

The ancient temple in Tokyo I know. We stopped and went inside Asakusa from the entrance in the left of Asakusa (near with parking place). I like Nakamise str so much, because of variety of local food and souvenir which are satisfied my budget. I bought come hand-fans for my friends, they are really sophisticated as Japanese attitude. I remember that, Asakusa has a water well with a fresh water which all visitors want to try. I were introduced that I had to scoop water out my hands and drink this stream as clean me clearer.

This was one of my favourite places in Tokyo. We'd toured Tokyo on the hop on hop off bus and hopped off here at Asakusa. It's a great area to explore - the temple is great and the cute little shops here are fab to wander round and hunt for souvenirs,

Great Area. I was pleasantly surprised by the area. Great shops, beautiful temple and great eateries. If you are in area right near the shrine there is a stall that sells these little deep fried dumplings/buns that are a little slice of heaven they come in lots of different flavours. Do yourself a favour get some! Great place to pick up a random souvenir.

Exceeded expectations. Take a free guided tour.. This is a very tourist centric place. But it does not feel like the tourist trap I had suspected it would. This is the place to get well priced and good quality souvenirs. Just heading one block off the main drag delivers better deals.I'd suggest heading there on a weekend if possible as you can get a free walking tour at 11.00 or 13.15.Head to the Asakusa Culture Tourist Centre on the corner opposite the main entry way for the temple near the metro station. Our guide said to watch our pockets. Given our sense of safety here it was perhaps a good reminder as we just never worried about pick pockets!

The best shrine/temple in Japan. Brilliant shrine and traditional passageway of shops leading to the temple. My favourite shrine and temple in Japan. Not blindingly busy but many great photo opportunities and gifts to buy.
Great area to visit. This is a wonderful area to explore with shops, temples and restaurants. This is our second visit to Tokyo and we still found more places here to see
Beautiful visit!. You cannot leave Japan without visiting this place. Temples existing from Edo period, right in the heart of Tokyo

wonderful day shopping. Spent lovely day exploring the little shops, and alleyways. the temples were great but very busy. really recommend this place for those holiday gifts and treats. lovely places to eat.

Amazing cheap souvenirs and impressive temple. If you love cheap souvenirs, there are a million stalls here selling all sorts of tat for your loved ones back home! I loved them all and spent a good couple of hours here. The temple itself is very impressive too - Asakusa is a must-see location in Tokyo!

You have to go, it's wonderful. This is a beautiful and busy place to visit. The walk up to the temple is crowded with stalls selling food and all sort of things, it is a good place to pick up that gift to take home. The temple is great, full of locals and tourists and has a great atmosphere. When you have finished at the temple be sure to explore the streets around it as these are full of interesting things to see. This is a place that everyone visiting Tokyo should go it's brilliant.

Traditional Japan. Asakusa temple is hidden somewhere in the city. It is the big traditional gate that attracts tourists and when you get there you realise there is a bustling traditional market behind that gate, with Japanese snacks and souvenirs on sale. The market leads to a beautiful and serene Japanese temple. A must do for every tourist visiting Tokyo.
Lovely place, not to be missed. . Really enjoyed visiting. It is very 'touristy'. Great place to pick up some souvenirs. I lit some incense for some friends and sent it to them as a postcard.

A bustling area yet fun to visit. The place is packed of things to must try. From local restaurants, souvenir shops, rickshaw rides, food stalls to their temples.
A feast to the eyes for a tourist. Armed your self with full battery cameras and hand phones to capture the moment.
Touts and tourists. Big shrine very busy lots of touts, tourists and tat shops. There are hundreds of little shops that are geared to tourists the shrine is well a shrine and very busy.

Nice tourist/historic site.. This was a nice site that has a lot of shops and restaurants. In addition a nice historic landmark that is flooded with tourists. Happy we visited but nothing too spectacular.

Busy and underwhelming. If you are big on seeing all of the "sites" then you'll make your way here anyway. But if you've done a lot of traveling and seen a lot of beautiful places you might consider skipping this. It's busy and bustling in a very touristy way--quite distinct from the smoother flow of most other parts of the city. The payoff did not feel worth the effort on this one.
Great!. I stayed in Asakusa and had a great time. Easy to find food and a lot of shops. Very crowded around the Senso-ji Temple but you should still go and check it out.

Temples, street vendors, festivities!. Asakusa is a home of quite numbers of famous and big temples in Tokyo. It also has some gates which are pretty and huge. There are a lot of vendors along the road but remember, you cannot eat on this road! If you happen to buy something (ice cream for example) you have to finish it at the store.
Great temple to visit.. The area around the temple may be very built up and grey, but the temple itself is very nice indeed. Often crowded with tourists but what else can you expect.

A visit to Old Japan. Asakusa allows you to step back in time. The temple and surrounding area is steeped in tradition and history. It produces a sensory overload for the visitor with the noise of the visitors and the many vendors selling their wares and souvenirs as you approach the main entrance, the smell of incense burning and the odd glimpse of Japanese ladies dressed in yukatas and kimonos. It is a place that is worth visiting if it is your first visit to Tokyo or indeed on any visit to Tokyo.

Everyone Happy. I tihnk it is just so cool to see everyone smiling. I mean most of them, doesn't matter where you from, you just enjoy this wonderful atmosphere. It was so cool walking around in night time, place is lively but not noisy all good. What made it better was how I didn't see much English or Chinese explanation on certain items. Some places.... they got translation for over 2, 3 languages on board or on wall and I think that just takes away the spirit. For that, STUDY before you come and you might enjoy even more.And night time seems much better then day time.

amazing temples and quiet nights. we went as a young family and asakusa was the perfect place to stay at night. we had easy public transport access to explore through the day then when we were ready we could come back, grab something amazing for dinner and the street was quiet enough that the kids easily went to sleep.There was still bars and things for friends to go to so was the perfect place for everyone

Busy but worth a visit . Really busy with both local and foreign tourists but with a good vibe. There was a tourist oriented market for souvenirs and a mixture of larger and smaller streets to explore. The temple area was hectic but worth seeing.

Good place to experience traditional culture.. Here you can experience traditional culture in central city!!! I had tried Kimono (a kind of Japanese traditional clothing) and Caricature when I when Asakusa. If you wanna experience traditional culture but Osaka is not in your travel plan, you should go Asakusa.
A must-go if in Tokyo. Beautiful, big, a classic if you are in Tokyo, it's particularly beautiful at night, with the orange lights on!

Great little spot in Tokyo!. It's right off the station and getting to the main temple area is quite easy. Lots of stores on the way. Lots of nice photo worthy places too - streets have this very classic old Japanese charm - a sharp contrast to the hustle & bustle of Shibuya. It also help a lot that you'll find people in traditional clothing roaming around as well. Overall very nice!

A good target in Tokyo. Asaka area hosts many nice restaurants, a tourist oriented shoppnuíng street, a tourist information center and a port for river bota tours. It is not a bad start if you have not prepared anything specific.

Temple Experience of Japan. From the entrance of Asakusa, there is a traditional Japanese pathway with shops along the road. The temple was good-looking and I was able to experience the Japanese culture in their shrines and temple. It was fun to test our fortune and Asian Culture is always fascinating.

Loaded WIth Attractions. This area is loaded with many attractions such as Sansouji Temple, Sumida river, Tokyo Cruise Centre, the Japanese rickshaws, Asakusa Culture Tourist Information Centre and so on. There is also an Edo vibe in this modern area.

Old Tokyo. We visited Asakusa with a friend, who was in Tokyo for the weekend. This is a very different place comapred to the other side of Tokyo in Shibuya and Roppong as in its 'known' as Old Tokyo and doesnt have that crazy edge to it. There were some great little street markets and stalls set throughout especially around the Shrine. It has a more laid back feel to it but does get very busy.We visited some great little bars around there but you must go looking for them. Can be hard to find. I will say though we did get refused entry to a few places because we were western...It was a Sunday night and I would like to give them the benefit of the doubt that they were just over tourists...(Happens more than you think though) There is a large canal near by where we caught a ferry to Odaiba. This turned out to be a master stroke as we go to see a lot more of Tokyo than we thought. The trip on the ferry was about 45 mins and the transport back into Tokyo from Odaiba is just as easy...Great day out or can spread over a couple with the Skytree etc being so close.

Packed. A must see land mark that makes Tokyo..Tokyo. But be warned this place is PACKED. The typical tourist trap for all things tourist such as food and souvenir. If you want to buy random things to take back to your friends and family this place is loaded. As for the temple itself I only managed to get to the entrance and all the way down to the main temple gate. It was insanely packed on a really hot summer day and I didn't want any part of it. Take pictures of the giant red lanterns as these are what this temple is all about.

Must see when visiting Tokyo. Love this place! Not too far from the city.Temples are not too big so won't take up a big chunk of time for visiters who wants a quick visit. They have small boutiques that sells traditional snacks and goods that are great for gifts. (The stores closes around 6pm) Depending on how long you want to look around, it can be a 10min stop for a quick photo snap or could be 1-2 hours looking around and trying the food. They also have rickshaw infront of the temple, they explain the history of what you will see during the ride. Didn't try it but I believe it's around 9000yen.

Cultural part of Tokyo. This tourist area has theme parks, many restaurants, stalls, cafes, museums, temples, shrines.
It is located near to Skytree and Ueno.
Recommended.

Traditional. Gorgeous, undiluted culture . Gorgeous place. Pretty little market in from with some great food. Hostels nearby are also of good quality. Really worth taking a few hours to look around the whole area and soak in the sights

Worth the visit. The temple and surrounding buildings are a delight and a must see. It is wonderful to watch tours of Japanese and Chinese visitors/ families enjoying all the charms of this area. We loved the fortune tubes and whilst we had mixed "luck" it was great fun. Loved the smaller buildings and gardens and wish I had more information in English to understand more of the meaning of various aspects.

Asakusa temple is way too crowded. We visited during the peak season mid summer, so probably that's why this place is too crowded. So many tourists and way too hot to visit during mid day. So so so many people i didn't really enjoy my time here. Tho there r lots of shops selling kimonos and japanese gifts.

Maybe the biggest outdoor shopping market in the world. This is an enormous outdoor shopping market (there are some covered stores as well) where you can find restaurants and endless stores that sell souvenirs and all sorts of stuff for tourists. To give a sample, we bought some small trinkets for young kids, wallets, porcelain cup, and some hanging art. The number of stores must number in the thousands. You should plan to spend several hours here. It is family friendly. There is also a temple at the very end that is popular.

Don't miss a visit to Asakusa. This is a vibrant and busy area of the city both during the day and night. It is full of restaurants and street vendors plus temples and shops. You can stay days in this area and all is very safe.
Must see. This is an essential place to visit. You can bathe in the incense for luck or touch the statue with the part of the body you wish to improve . Beautiful

Asakusa Temple. Wonderful place buzzing with local shops selling kimono, novelty items, food etc etc. Dont forget to know you future here. There is also a pleasant boat cruise nearby a must do activity to explore the city.
great place to souvenir shop. Great architecture - but was surprised by all the shops on "holy" ground - however they shops did have a wide variety of things to buy
Another temple . I found the temples in Kyoto much better than the ones in Tokyo! If you have plenty of time in Tokyo you can visit this one otherwise not recommended.

Amazing, must see. Asakusa was an amazing sight to see, the markets leading into the temple were very immersive and the temple itself was the temple that gave the most culturally accurate feel out of all the temples we attended. You must go!

Put on "must-see" list. Asakusa is an interesting area in Tokyo where ancient and modern collide. There is of course the beautiful temple with its interesting architecture. Then there are the many streets of vendors and shops selling all sorts of goods and treats. It was very hot and humid, so we found a nice cafe with shaved ice which was very refreshing. A fun place to spend an afternoon.

Must visit there. I went there on July 24 evening.It was nice Japanese style architecture and many souvenir shops.There were very crowded with tourist and local travelers.My daughter love yummy ice-cream shop there.It was really tasty.Even Tokyo summer was humid and raining,Asakusa still beautiful and amazing place for me.
Wowwww. A good hotel to spend time with family..good place,good food,quality service...Nice environment!!!!!!!

Great Place.... An interesting place to visit with lots to see from old japanese temples to small souvenir shops and restaurants. Its easy accessible via train and metro and try to spend sometime around the shops around the temple for small souvenirs and don't forget to try some of the local cheap eats there!!!

Stunning Photos of Japanese architecture. Wow this place is amazing. You need to go in the morning and in the evening. Its quietest early morning, around 7am still very little people there, so you can get great photos, and in the evening its all lit up, and most of the tourists are gone home. Avoid mid day if you can, but here are great little market shops around. Stay in the area if you can, but its a bit of a pain to switch train lines around Tokyo from Asakusa, but I suppose thats everywhere in Tokyo. Absolutely worth the visit.
Beautiful. Japan is a country full of temples and shrines - all must-sees. Asakusa is stunning, I spent a whole day walking around and taking hundred of pictures. Love it

Lots to see. Lots of things to see here! You could spend a day in this area visiting little shops and restaurants. I suggest, if you have time, walk around and visit before deciding on little souvenirs to buy. Some shops are all the some but some have better prices and more unique pieces. You'll also find a plethora of food booths that serve traditional food and are bound to find something that pleases you.

Another must visit of Tokyo. Loved walking through the small shops which lead to the temple. The temple is beautiful - bright red which stands out against the Tokyo cityscape. Enjoyed sitting on the side and watching locals use the incense and say their prayers. Felt apart of the Japanese culture by watching and learning. A local explained to me how to use the incense - once lit and in the burner wave the smoke towards and over your body as it is thought have healing capacity. Was a great experience and the surrounds of the temple are immaculate.

Must visit. We went to Asakusa by subway Tobu line, arrived at Asakusa station. First visit was Asakusa Culture tourist information. It located just 2 minutes walk from Asakusa station exit, and in front of Asakusa Gate. There were many information in all languages on the front desk and the staffs were very helpful. We can go to 8th floor for free. It was observation terrace to see Asakusa view with background the famous Tokyo Skytree and Asahi Beer Building. After took some photos, we walked to Nakamise shooping street to buy its specific rice crackers, and to Sensoji Temple with its giant lantern. I wished to go to Denbouin street to see Japanese crafts, but didn't have time.

Historic area in Tokyo. I was staying in Asakusa area during my Tokyo visit and so happy to realize that I have made the right decision. Asakusa is the area for the famous Sensoji temple. Recommended..

Most traditional@Japan. Asakusa's atrractions in the area include one of Tokyo’s most historic temples – Sensoji, and the impressive Kaminari Gate that marks the entranceway to the temple. You cant miss the numerous shops along Nakamise-dori Street, which runs along the approach way to Senso-ji Temple, carry a variety of small articles made of Japanese-style paper and other traditional goods such as folding fans. It is a lovely shopping street that attracts many foreign visitors.

Don't forget the temples amid all the shopping. Asakusa is a great place to see a variety of temples at once. Unfortunately, many go for the shopping that lines the path to the temples. Nothing wrong with shopping for souvenirs, but don't forget the main reason for Asakusa. This is a good jump-off point for visiting other key attractions in Tokyo. Plot your time accordingly!

Japan as Imagined.... This is the old Japan one would imagine seeing. Although Kyoto was on our itinerary, we enjoyed Asakusa and its old world charm. A complete delight to walk around the complex, and stalls with food (especially seafood) and wares. Fresh rice crackers are worth seeking out and trying. One practical tip while traveling with kids is to have enough water on hand, it gets hot during summer. Plenty of attractions to keep even the young ones entertained.

Typically Japanese. Great old temple architecture in Tokyo area (if you do not want to travel all the way to Kyoto/Nara). Easily accessible by metro/subway, and no entry fees. Traditional food stalls and souvenir shops along the way to the temple. Bungee jumping next door and great views of the Skytree tower as well.

A must visit place. Visiting Asakusa is like going through a time tunnel. We can see the old style Japan located in the middle of modern Tokyo. Sensoji temple is a must-visit. Try to visit this temple both in the day time when it's fully crowded, and at night when it's very quiet. The lights make the temple much more beautiful. Especially with Tokyo Skytree in the background. You have the old and modern beauty in one frame.

Fun Shopping District. Yes, Asakusa boasts a Temple complex dating to the 7th century (around which, by the way, had some of the most interesting array of booths with all manner of merchandise. The street food vendors were terrific with squid, octopus, crab deep fried & on a stick!), but the adjacent shopping was the most fun. The extensive covered mall had terrific local shopping, and the small restaurants were great as well.

"Step back into the Edo Period". A must place to visit to get a taste of Old Tokyo. Here you can find many Japanese items and traditions still carried on from the Edo period. Take a look at the surroundings.

Definitely Worth a Visit. This is a wonderful neighborhood where the sense of past Tokyo remains. If Kyoto is not on your itinerary, don't miss Asakusa in Tokyo. Kyoto, having escaped bombing, has much of the atmosphere of old Japan; however, Tokyo does not. Don't miss Asakusa, particularly if Kyoto isn't on your stop.

Amazing Asakusa. In my opinion Asakusa is representation of old style or ancient Japan. Combination of old and modern era in Japan will attract many people to come to this country. When visiting Asakusa, going to Sensoji temple is one activity you have to do. You will find big temple there. You can also find souvenir shops there.

Interesting for the cultural knowledge. Just make up your minds before going if you don't have better usage of your time. It's beyond a long market of old goods or tourist junkyano. Then you reach the pagodas and holy statues. Light a candle, if you will, and pray for world peace.

BEST AREA IN TOKYO. We simply loved Asakusa: we spent one month here and everyday we discovered new things... it's a neighborhood full of story, culture, food and things to do. If you visit Tokyo you can't miss it!

Join the crowd. It is a very crowded place, but really worth to visit. The temple is spiritual and peaceful, many people ask their fortune, must be really accurate.
Lots of small shops, there is a hand-made udon restaurant at the side way, really delicious. And the red bean pancake (木村家跟龜家的人型燒) is so tasty. Have to try all of them.

Worth the time. Get off the train and walk around endlessly in small covered side streets that have all the nic naks you want as gifts before your return home. We didn't actually spend much time at the shrine bur a lot in the immediate vicinity. Very crowded on a Saturday in July. Wear some good walking shoes, this day we put on 24km walking in a mass herd of humanity.
Lots Of Things To Do Here. There's a lot of thing to do in Asakusa. Visiting the Temple, doing Shopping, eating and sight seeing. The metro is also nicely located. Just a few steps from the temple.
Great!!!!. Fantastic place !!! Definitely recommend , spiritual and peaceful place ! Great view ! Not allowed to enter inside the temple

A walkers paradise. Everything you should see is within walking distance or just a short train ride away. The historical Sensoji Temple grounds are great and the shopping at the Nakamise Shopping Street is absolutely wonderful, you can find souvenirs to take home and share with your family and friends. There are many places to eat...we found several good places tucked in alleys or along shopping areas by just exploring.

Old school Tokyo. Asakusa is a wonderful neighbourhood that comes to life early. It has to be. Even their Don Quijote branch opens at 7am. Asakusa has many temples with Sensoji Temple being the most well known. Many train/metro lines serve Asakusa. Among them being Ginza, Toei Asakusa, Toei Oedo,Tobu Isesaki and JR Yamanote. This is a good place for first time visitors to Tokyo who want to be in the thick of the action and who dislike taking many trains from the Tokyo suburbs to central Tokyo.

Definitely a worthwhile stop when in Tokyo. We always come here when visiting Tokyo, not only are the temple and pagoda worth seeing but the shopping street leading up to them is filled with little shops selling all kinds of souvenirs. The gate at the entrance is very impressive with a huge paper lantern providing a nice photo-op. If you are looking for a quiet out-of-the-way experience it may not be for you, but if you really wanted that you wouldn't be in Tokyo anyway.

Very touristy. Asakusa has some lovely gardens and buildings but can be overrun by tourists especially during the day and on weekends. The public toilets are gross and the tourist market shops are pretty tacky. A short visit at dusk is perfect.

Lovely Old Temple. The surrounding area to the Temple comprises of rows of small tourist type shops which were very interesting with plenty of places to get good and drink. It was very busy at the time of our visit but well worth the trip to see such an ancient temple.

Enjoyable night walk. I went here a bit past 8pm and the temples were lit up. It's quite a nice walk at night. There's also a strip of stores close to the temples but it was closed at the time I was there. Other side streets still have restaurants and stores open though. You also get a nice view of Tokyo Sky Tree in the distance.

Asakusa Rickshaw tour guide. yesterday we took a rickshaw ride in Asakusa, Tokyo. the ride was or one hour and we got to see Mimeguri Shrine, Sky Tree, Geisha Town, Asakusa Engei Hall, and so many more I don't remember the names. Our guide Akitaka Otsuji was super friendly, spooked english very well, and he provide us lot's of formations thru out the tour. Also he took some pictures for us to main places. This was my second ride - first one was in Kyoto in May of this year. Awesome service I will recommend to everyone... you don't have to walk so thats pretty easy. Thank you so much for you service!
Old charms. Asakusa is on of Tokyo's must-see sights, offering beautiful religious buildings, and many big (and small) shops that are a big fun to explore.

A must see in Tokyo.. Asakusa is a very fun place to visit that offers a little bit of something for everyone involved. It is a very touristy area and gets very crowded, especially in the summer. In the summer it get ridiculously hot with everyone packed in so make sure you got some liquids to keep hydrated. I find it more fun to visit in the later evening, it gets a little less crowded. It is also pretty cool seeing it at night.

Asakusa...Old Charms. My family of 5 stayed at Asakusa the entire one week we were in Tokyo. We love this place....Asakusa area is quiet and peaceful. It was a mix of old and new that is very attractive about Asakusa. We visited Skytree at night (but didn't go up) . Infront of the Asakusa temple...there are many small shops selling Japanese souvenirs. It's a great place for shopping yukata, T-shirt, key chain, fridge magnets, Japanese sweets and rice crackers etc....lots of choices. The price is reasonable...though for T-shirt..the price and material are better at Oriental Bazaar. As we visited Asakusa during autumn the surrounding ginko and maple trees near the temple were all in their autumn shades...it was beautiful...Japan is really beautiful in autumn. If i were to visit Tokyo again...Asakusa will surely on my list.

Must visit in Tokyo. Asakusa is a shopping street of over 200 meters, called Nakamise, .It's great place to find souvenirs, arts and crafts with bargain and reasonable price. Quality for the arts and craft was good. At the end of the street, you can find one of the oldest temple in Tokyo, it is Sensoji Temple

Another intersting place in Tokyo. Overall, this town feels like Edo atmosphere. Sensoji Temple is famous and very historic, but there are lots of places around it. There are 100s of shops going towards the temple. A must go without fail in Tokyo

So much to see and do. The place is bustling with locals and tourists. Many shops and eateries. Besides the obvious shopping street there are side roads worth exploring with different kinds of shops full of curiosities. The walk up to Senso-ji temple is full of souvenir shops and snack food stalls. Good place to go! Quite a walk to the closest JR Station.

Very Touristic. Asakusa is a very touristic area. There are a lot of souvenir shops at the alley leading to the asakusa kamon temple. Plenty of eating places and atmosphere is good. I recomend to try ROX Spa if you are in Asakusa.

My favourite neighbourhood in all of Japan. Asakusa is definitely the ideal neighbourhood for backpackers, with loads of cheap eateries and such a vibrant community. Really sad I won't be able to visit during the Samba festival this August, but I'll be in Asakusa again next April, fingers crossed!
Cheap food, affordable accommodation, friendly neighbourhood <3
busy street district. From the street, we can view the sky tree tower stands tall and it's nice spot to take a picture from there. The street is in the Asakusa Senso-ji temple

Where tourists flock. If you are looking for the kind of souvenir-arts-and-crafts market tourists usually love, this is the place to go. It is probably one of the best places to buy souvenirs, although less traditional than other less crowded places. Prices are mostly reasonable and you have plenty of options.

Lovely place for a few hours wandering. Quite old style Japanese area
It is a touristy though, but that's fine.
Lovely temples to wander through.
And lots of little shops that sell everything.
Plenty of places to eat as well.
On the outskirts of Tokyo by train. And well worth a visit.
Crowded temple. Very beautiful but very crowded, full of small shops, there is a beautiful handpainted leather wallets shop near the main street.

THE SHRINE IS FINISHED!. The last time I visited in 2009 the sensoji temple was still being renovated. It's complete now and although full of tourists is still quite an attraction. Tons of shopping in the area as well if you are into that sort of thing. :)

Skip the tours. We had booked a tour but it was cancelled the morning of our tour, so the concierge advised to do a self tour with a day metro card! Very glad we did. We saw the same thing included in the tour while experiencing the local culture of the subway system and going at our own pace!

Great shopping opportunity!. The main shopping area in Asakusa is the street leading to Senso-Ji Temple. Even though it is packed full of people, it was still a great experience. Plenty of variety of stores available, one of our favourites was a food store that sold fish shaped pancakes with sweet fillings inside - yummy! An item to tick off the bucket list and a great place to buy souvenirs for yourself and loved ones back home!

Magical place. Although you go there to see the magnificent temple it's the streets surrounding it that capture the imagination. Lots of stalls and shops selling all manner of goods. It's a place you can wander around for hours.

Cheap goods. Near the temple street, there is a row of shops selling very cheap bags and watches (around 13000YEN). I manage to help my friend to find his limited edition Pikachu stuff toy here (which he couldn't find it elsewhere in tokyo). I would say that Asakusa, is a place worth to visit, because some of the shops really sell cheap stuff!
I really like this place. I enjoyed shopping along way to get inside the temple. The temple is very nice. I been there three time during my trip. I will come back again

Old Tokyo. So many people come to Tokyo and wonder where the Japan of the picture books went. It is in Asakusa. There is a covered walkway shopping area where you can still buy traditional kimonos and food. Step outside the covered area and you can find the fake sushi you see in all the Japanese restaurants outside of Japan.

Nice street stalls and temple. Asakusa is a nice area with lots of street food stalls and market streets, and a lovely temple, but if you are pushed for time then there are better neighbourhoods to visit. Nice but not a priority
Busy, but nice. This place is sort of a tourist trap, but it is worth the trip just to see the interesting temple and the arcitecture of it and the surrounding buildings.
real nice area. has amazing night life at the weekends not to sure about during the week as we were only there at the weekend. it has lovely temples. lots of shopping markets really great area.
Worth seeing. Great site to visit. There isn't a ton else around so I went there specifically to see the temples and that's it. Also it was metro accessible which was great.

Beautiful little shops along the street!. It is great, a must visit in Tokyo. Best time to visit this place is in the morning so it's not very crowded. When i was there, there were lots of food stalls selling japanese street food, worth trying! Don't forget to walk along the streets where you can find many little shops that sell souvenirs and also foods you've never tried before.
Local feeling. We used to live in this area for two weeks close to Minami Senju station. It is charming in a way indeed. Thrift stores, small food joints and tiny bars. It feels very local.
Central and Buzzing. Food outlets, markets and easy access to transport short walk to both tube and train. Variety of foods reasonably priced.

Fun tourist trap. Pagodas and temples, shopping and restaurants. Approaching the Senso-ji temple though the busy (and touristy) Nakamise Street gives you a sense of the old Tokyo and is a real highlight of a visit to Tokyo. Tons of tourists and expensive souvenirs are not able to ruin the experience, but keeps it from getting top marks.

A lovely stroll in the oldest shrine of Tokyo. It's a beautiful shrine and above all- a great place to see a lot of young girls in kimono. The shrine is surrounded by a great numbers of stores in the streets around it.

Favorite spot for a day in Tokyo. We had very limited time on a short trip to Tokyo and the Asakusa area was a great place to spend the afternoon. Aside from the large temple, there is tons of little shops and bites to eat.

A Definite for Your Tokyo Visit. Probably a bit too commercial for those wanting a more 'cultural' activity, but a must see tourist spot. We take groups of visiting students here on every tour to Tokyo and they enjoy a good couple of hours. Visiting the temples and learning about the culture and traditions, and then the rows of little shops. Something for everyone here. Head into the side alleys as well for more shops and small restaurants The students buy their lunch from the street vendors and enjoy every mouthful. For those with kids, worth a couple of hours..

Tons to see. This place is great. Very touristy though, if that isn't something you're into. They have tons of little shops and the temple is interesting. Inside, you can pay ¥100 and get a fortune (I got a bad one, boo!) Plenty to do around it. Makes for great pictures and memories.
Famous tourist spot. You can come if you are first timer to Tokyo. The temple itself is of a good exemplified of traditional Japanese culture. Very crowded all the time with tourists.

Worth to see. I came to the asakusa shrine & found it interested with the water also fortune teller. It's gave me a peace & happiness after. Worth to see & find your own explore with the shop in the alleys
crowded. This was a distance from the center , best form of transpiration is by ferry . Though it was very crowded , i did enjoy the local merchants and also the temple .

Just ok . Traditional looking outdoor market fronting Buddhist temple. Reminded me of Chinatown in Singapore. Market stalls sell all kinds of souvenir type stuff. It was just ok for me. Don't know if I'd go out of my way to experience it again.
Old Japan . Lovely area. Temples and shopping. Quite crowded but that is Japan. Lots of souvenirs and small food stalls. Well worth a visit.
Faith, tradition. A mix between faith and tradition. Moving place. Nice to get lost in the streets around the temple, buy some souvenirs, sample some street food.

The old temple with the new city as a backdrop. Lovely atmosphere all be it as little touristy, the temple is wonderful and the shops and stalls are all geared up for the crowds As always in Japan the food stalls are clean and the food is good so no need to worry, the whole scene has a backdrop of the new Tokyo tower which also adds to your photos A nice way to spend a couple of hours maybe even an afternoon

Early morning. We were visiting the temple and the surroundings at 6am on a Saturday morning.Due to the timing , was really nice and quiet but we have missed all the shops on the way because of the early hours, they are open from 9ish.The place was really relaxing,you could feel the energy, the peace and the uniqueness.It was a private ceremony inside so visitors were not allowed after the main entrance.Huge building with the red painting it is just so impressive.The garden are around is also lovely, with the waterfalls and koi carps and with all the small places to pray. Most probably the place has different atmosphere when people around but this was just what we needed to relax and experience a little bit of heaven in the middle of a 12 million population capital.

A touch of the real "Japan"?. I actually found this place interesting, giving a feel of ordinary Japan quite unlike the modern high end shops of Harajuku or the crowded ambiance of Shinjuku. I enjoyed browsing the small shops and walking around the blocks. Here, I discovered the sweet potato sweet and enjoyed our tempura meal. I will definitely come back when I visit Tokyo again.
Nothing too special. Compared to the hundreds of amazing things Tokyo has to offer, this is not on the top ten list. If you're in the city for more than a weekend, i would still take a visit though.

Nice temple to visit, free entry but expect big crowds.. On arriving at the temple area, the entrance will be filled with people having their picture taken with the big colourful lanterns in the archway. It can get very crowded but all part of the experience. Once through the entrance there are two lines of souvenir shops selling all kinds of gifts, but many of these can be bought cheaper elsewhere. Walking down to the end of the shops you find the main temple in front of you, with another to the left side and the Tokyo Sky tree towering above the skyline to your right. Take your time and enjoy the whole scene. The inside of the temple is a glorious colourful scene, make sure you enjoy the murals on the ceiling. Be prepared for a bit of crowd jostling though as it does get very busy inside.This is an impressive temple, but Kyoto has many more impressive temples to offer. There are some nice areas to shop just a short walk away and plenty of places to eat. If you are lucky, like I was on the day I visited, you could see some traditional costumes being worn by some visitors. All in all a nice, but very commercialised place to spend a few hours.

Cultural and Shopping. Good place to shop for Japanese souvenirs though a bit on the expensive side. I found the same items at Narita Airport stores for the same or lesser price. Good place for sightseeing and watching all the Japanese families enjoying the local street food. Lots of options for shopping and eating for all kinds of budgets. Many premium brand stores are also there. Good connections with other parts of the city by the Asakusa Metro Line and also the Toei line.

A nice neighbourhood. Asakusa is a nice neighbourhood. A lot of shops and restaurants in the covered streets, some old streets near the Senso-ji, the Senso-ji itself which is one of the most beautiful temples in the country in my humble opinion. We spent our very first day in Japan there and it was a great idea in order to get used to this magnificent country. Asakusa can be quite crowd, but its older style contrast quite a lot with Shibuya, Shinjuku and all those crazy places :)
old fashion Tokyo. like the Nakamise street with all the stalls selling different kind of souvenirs and snacks... ice cream is GOOD

Nice shopping area and temples. This is a nice area with lots of shopping and restaurants. There is also a temple that is well designed. The shops close at 6:00pm so make sure you get there early. Most of the prices are average among all of Tokyo. Some deals on the Mochi are cheaper here if you can find the right vendor.Restaurants are plenty and there is everything from Japanese BBQ, Mos Burger, Ramen, Udon, Burger King, Gyu Kaku, Denny's, etc. Easy to take the train to the main areas of Tokyo so save money on the hotel by staying around here. Also a good view of the Tokyo Skytree.

Not the highlight of my trip. I visited Asukusa on a Sunday and it was extremely crowded and is not so special when compared to some of the temples and shrines in other parts of Japan, like Kyoto. I guess if you are only visiting Tokyo it is an interesting place to see, but I would recommend avoiding the weekend. Location is handy because it is also close to the Tokyo Sky Tree if you want to battle the crowds there. There are plenty of stalls if you want to buy souvenirs.

Serene temple in midst of busy street. Undoubtedly I found this temple the best in Tokyo, nice architecture, serene environment, friendly priest, it has big compound and nice small park, one of the good place to do photography, lot of good shop for souvenir but extremely expensive
Recommended to take short walk around temple and if you are not in hurry then walk bit further for shopping

So many people!. After the museum we took a taxi to have lunch and check this area. There were so many people we could not even take a decent picture. We found a belt sushi place and rested our feet while we piled the plates. Fun time!
A must see in Tokyo. We visited Asakusa on a sunny and were not diapointed. A bustling place with lots of people and culture. Plenty to see and lots to buy if you want to sped money.

Japanican- Cityrama Tokyo Morning Tour. My husband and I were only in town for 48 hours so we wanted to see as much of Tokyo as we could as quickly as we could. We signed up with the Japanican Cityrama Tokyo Morning - Meiji Shrine, Imperial Palace Gardens, and Senso-ji Temple (Asakusa) tour. Our tour guide gave us all the information and history we were looking for at each spot and the tour spent just enough time in each destination except Asakusa. Asakusa was my favorite part of the whole trip and despite being given the option to stay and let it be our final stop (instead of being dropped off in Ginza), I was told I would have to tell them ahead of time. Since I had not seen what Asakusa was like I had no idea that I would want to stay there longer. I really wish I was given more time to browse the market so my advice to any travelers contemplating this tour, take it! But make sure your final stop is Asakusa instead of Ginza.I loved Asakusa because of all the little shops and cute trinkets available for purchase. I bought all my souvenirs here and was happy that they weren't chintzy, cheap toys like most tourist gift shops offer around the world. These aren't your typical name-written-on-a-grain-of-rice necklaces or postcards and whatnot, these are unique, quality gifts reflective of Japanese culture.

A nice complement to Sensoji Temple. After visiting Sensoji Temple - 10 minutes walk from Asakusa station - be sure to take a walk around the surrounding area. There's a street, about 15 min's walk away, called Kappabashi Street. This is where you can find shops that make and sell fake food that looks as good as the real thing. Great place to buy something different as a souvenir. Skytree Tower also isn't so far away. Great if you like exploring on foot.

Lovely tour of Ueno Park thanks to a local Goodwill guide. http://www2.ocn.ne.jp/~sgg/introduction.htmlI had seen an entry on Lonely Planet about the Tokyo Systematized Goodwill Guide (SGG) Club, whose main office is in Asakusa (hence, this review falls in that section) and whose link I include above. I had read that they offered free 90 min. tours of the Ueno Park area on designated days/times and on the last Fri. of May, on a rainy afternoon, I set out to find the meeting place for the tour. I met Mr. Isao Watanable - a very kind and affable gentleman, exemplary representative of the club. Since I was the only one there, I had the pleasure of his company and knowledge for a couple of hours strolling through the sites and also visiting the wonderful Tokyo National Museum on the grounds of the park. I recommend that you seek out SGG's services and enjoy!

Great place to go. I was there during the golden week and boy was it crowded. Nonetheless it was a nice place to visit. Has a rustic feel. You may offer prayers, ask about fortune there. The nakamise street leading to sensoji temple has many gems to uncover from unique gift to good food. A different feeling from the more modern shibuya or shinjuku.

Good place. Really beautiful place, there are the Senso-ji Temple and Kaminarimon Gate, the place looks like a old town. An approximate walk of 20 minutes will take you to the new landmark, Tokyo Skytree.

Nice shopping area but busy with heaps of tourists!. I know being hypocritical knowing that I'm a tourist but it was really busy and I saw it was hard on the locals who live in the area. But regardless asakusa is good to buy those little trinkets, souvenirs and heaps of rice crackers and senbeis!
Great area away from the madness of CentralTokyo. If you go to Tokyo you have to visit Asakusa, it has temples, shops restaurants and a cat cafe which is a must if you are a cat fan :-)

Culture, religion and a bit of shopping. Asakusa is where you can find Sensō-ji, a Buddhist temple. There are several other temples in Asakusa also. The place is always full of tourists who want to visit the temples and go shopping in the souvenir and food lane. Aside form temples, you can also see old houses from the 50s and 60s as well as traditional ryokan homes here. An amusement park, Hanayashiki, is also located here. It is said to be the oldest amusement park in Japan. Be patient as sometimes buying can be such a challenge for foreigners and the lines in shops and eateries can be long and slow.

beautiful, traditional and lots to explore around. The main attraction has both the Asakusa Shrine and Sensoji temples next to each other. So be sure to cover both when you go,Getting there: take the Asakusa MRT (Ginza line) and walk along the crowded, but very local alleyways to get there. There is so much happening in the alleys that its worth spending some time to look around.How to explore: Start at the main gates, hire a guide if you can (but we found it very hard to find English speaking guides at the venues. You are better off reading about it early or using a tour operator). Then walk to the 2 main attractions and then the gardens on the left. Once you complete the gardens, continue walking till you exit. Outside, you will find more alleyways and eateries that are absolutely amazing!When to go: I would advise that you complete this early in the day, as most tourists then head off to the skytree right after (its a longish walk away). Even if you arent planning on seeing the sky tower or are afraid of heights, you should complete Asakusa in the morning (there isnt a night life scene anyway).

Touristy, but cute. The Senso-ji temple is the big draw for this neighborhood, however, there are many shops immediately surrounding the temple that are also fun. Lots of souvenirs and snacks. My advice, don't buy souvenirs here. While they are cute, I found the same stuff cheaper elsewhere. Also, other reviewers have mentioned that there is street food available for purchase. There is, but it is mostly snacks and sweets. If you are looking for a full meal, this is not it. There are several restaurants and sweet shops on the street immediately across from the temple area that looked promising.

A quiet corner of Tokyo. Asakusa was the first destination of our first visit to Japan. It is a beautiful part of the city with key elements of Japanese history displayed amongst a vibrant street food scene and specialty shopping areas such as 'Kitchen Town'. Asakusa has easy metro links to other parts of the city and an enchanting ferry ride down to the Tokyo fish market area. A great base for your stay in Tokyo where you can return to relative calm each night.

Experience the history of the Temple and Old Tokyo. Not doing research before visiting may leave you not as impressed. It was built in 645 and deserves a nod of respect. Wear comfy shoes for several hours of exploration. Avoid peak "bus tour" times as it gets really crowded. Typically thats roughly 10am-3pm.
