Also note that Sundays are quiet but there is a reason-many shops may be closed. During the week typically you can shop between 9am-8pm. Visit the Asakusa Culture Tourist Information Center before you begin your journey to get oriented.

Great place to spend the day. Many stores around the shrine. Kaminarimon is always full of people. You can enjoy the "man driven cars". Cool experience that you gotta have at least once. Take a few walk and you can check it out the Skytree.

Pretty amazing how old it is but.... It was neat to see how old this temple was as well as how close it is to downtown Tokyo but honestly I didn't get the reason for the large crowds. Definitely a must see but don't think you need to spend much time here.

busy temple place. I love this place because there are alot of stores outside the temple place. Slthough there are alot of people walking around, you can get your own bench and just seat around appreciate the view and people praying.

Temple + Old Tokyo + Shopping. One of the best districts in Tokyo where you can see old Tokyo, very busy shopping alleys, wonderful old shrines and temples, the pagoda, views of the skytree tower from the bridge, ...My recommendations:- Go there on a Sunday. Sundays tend to be boring in Tokyo, except there! It's crowded but fun- At the shrine, put/donate a 100Yen coin in one of the slots then shake a box while making a wish and randomly pick a stick where a number in Japanese is engraved, then find the drawer with the same sign/number and take your good fortune paper. If it's good, keep it :) If it's bad, tie the paper on one of the hanging lines. Just watch the others and do the same, it's fun!- Walk around, there are plenty of side streets with loads of shopping for souvenirs, kimonos, sticks, ... and great food as well. Don't do only in the main street leading to the shrine.- Go at the visitor center across the main street / Asakusa metro station and take the lift to the top. It's free and from there you have very nice views of Asakusa and also the river and the skytree tower.

Shopping and wishes. Of course you have you have to go there! It was the complete tourist visit! The amazing shrine , the traditional Japanese wares , the native sweets ... From low end to high end dining and shopping! Jump on the subway or take a train ! You wont leave without a parcel or two from this place... Even a snack or a full meal! Simply amazing!
Great Location in Tokyo to see it all. A brilliant place to stay while in Tokyo - it has temples, market places, food markets and is close to transport. I would definitely stay here again.

Great area, visited twice. We visited during the day and at night. If you only get chance to go once, go in the evening. The atmosphere is great and all the little stalls will be open if you go before 8pm. Bear in mind that the temple closes at 5pm though so go earlier if you want to include this. The temple and lanterns are lit up and you don't want to miss this if you're into photography. Great for souvenir shopping.

I like the Asakusa area with food, temples, shrines and lots of people. This is a great area for tourists. I enjoy the shrines and temples and all the restaurants and all the souvenir shops. There is also an excellent toursit information center here. They have helped me a lot. I also enjoy the crowds. Both Japanese and international tourists come here.

very very busy. we went on the weekend and it was so packed you could hardly walk, especially around the temple and main shopping street. Once you get away from this area, it is less crowded and there are still great shops. A good place to buy ceramics, paper goods and sweets.

Good area to visit. Make sure you locate the shanty area just to the side of the shrine as this is worth strolling through, We bought Kimono's for the girls here best prices in Tokyo. Good shopping mall Tokyo style, can get busy on weekends Food choices were also plentiful so can easily spend a few hours here

Traditional Japanese experiences. Great traditional experiences with the beautiful Senso Ji temple (even saw Geisha), walking along the river, trying lots of different restaurants and loads of quaint shopping.
Halal food can be easily found here!. Walk down the streets n you'll find halal cafe and restaurants here! lots to see n shop. Mainly souveniors.

Crowded mix of historical significance and tourist-centric vendors. We visited Asakusa on an organised cultural tour of the city during our week-long stay in Tokyo back in mid-April. As is the suggested route for first-time visitors to the area, we entered via the Kaminarimon ("Thunder Gate") and quickly found little room for maneuvering. (Kaminarimon is the outermost of two gates leading to Sensō-ji, a Buddhist temple.) The crowds were immense during our visit; we arrived about 1pm on a Thursday. We essentially followed the flow of the crowd towards Sensō-ji. Along the way were vendor stalls selling various food items and of course the ubiquitous souvenirs aimed at tourists. Passing through the inner gate, the Hōzōmon ("Treasure-House Gate") we arrived in front of Sensō-ji. After visiting Sensō-ji, it was a short walk to the Sumida River where we awaited a river cruise.

Hot and crowded...nothing special. Envision yourself stuck wall to wall with people...tourists and school age kids in uniform, all heading in one direction in hot and humid Tokyo. This after spending time in a crowded rush hour train from your hotel to get there. Enough said. If you want to stroll down a "traditional" Japanese neighborhood to visit little shops and restaurants, this is definitely not the place. Personally, I would skip this area. The temple is nice, but there are other nicer ones in Tokyo to visit.

crowded. the temple is a mishmash of tiny shops selling for the tourists.However amongst this mess there are several shops selling bonafide good stuff. just need to look.This temple is just too crowded but it is one that attracts tourists and seems to be popular but really, there are so many other temples in Japan, this is not the place i would take guests.

Great place to experience old traditional Japan. Asakusa is a great place in Tokyo to be explored on foot. Go to Asakusa via Kaminarimon (Kaminari Gate) and the Nakamise shopping street with small shops selling tourist souvenirs. The main attractions in Asakusa is the Sensoji Buddhist temple with a five storied pagoda. From Asakusa, Tokyo Skytree is a 20 minute walk across the Sumida River.
Little town. The architecture of houses and building is very unique, quiet lively for a little town. A bit disappointed with the kitchenware street, not much of the kitchen stuff as the name stated!

See it as u r next to it anyway. Most visitors to Tokyo will come to the nakamise street. At the end of it is the sensoji temple and next to it is the shrine. Just drop in for a brief visit and pay your respects

Always a Delight to Visit. Asakusa nakamise is always enjoyable to visit. It is quite crowded very often but it is a MUST if you visit Japan. The place is known for the big red lantern at the entrance to nakamise. Many people always take photos with the lantern behind. Remember the leaning tower of Pisa? Wasn't used to be but now you can't eat and walk nakamise though there are many food being sold. A new surprise.

Festival time. On our first day in Japan we were lucky enough to experience the festival that offered hundreds of eating options from a McDonalds Teriyaki burger to Octopus balls. There were shrines and festival floats showing religious deities to add to the experience.Vanilla and Green Tea or Sesame were but two of the flavours of ice cream available.
Good to go. Asakusa temple is touristic place in Japan so you can expect a lot of people there however I still recommend you to go and enjoy the Japanese architecture which was stunning.

Great place to experience a condensed version of traditional Japan.. This is definitely a place in Tokyo to visit if you are looking out for a bit of cultural experience. There is a large buddhist temple, Sensoji temple, where you can read your fortune, and take in the atmosphere. There are also many roadside store, some selling souvenirs and some food. Do remember to try the popular red paste pastry here which has its origin here. There is a small amusement park near the vicinity, and as for lunch, you can consider having Okonomiyaki, self-cooked pancake, at Sometaro, which i would strongly recommend!

Fabulous neighborhood. Great attractions, great restaurants, great shopping, low-scale buildings and with seriously good views, a major shrine complex, easy to reach from both Tokyo airports, and good subway service puts it within reach of all tourist neighborhoods in 30 minutes or less.

Festive feel. Visited the temple during the Sanja Festival.It is an amazing experience. The traditional festival celebration in an urban city, both old and young dressed in their festive attire celebrating.There are many stalls selling food like grilled fish, takoyaki, fried noodles etc for the festive season. There is one stall which we tried "catching" gold fish using paper scoop. Many shops selling mochi, cakes, ice cream in various flavours, gifts infront of the temple.The landscape in the temple is beautiful.

Backed full of views and shopping on your way in.. Expect crowds but lovely avenue going into the temple with places to shop for small gifts to take home. Loved the garden too and views. It was nice to walk there and then return to our hotel via small side streets to get a feel for how people really live in North Tokyo.

Nice district! You should visit it!. Two main attractions are located here: Sensi-Ji temple and 650 m high Tokyo Sky Tree tower with its' astonishing Sumida Aquarium. You can also find here the Drum Museum, as well as other interesting points. It's absolutely worth visiting. Just must be here!

Historic temple and shopping street for souvenirs. Very busy...locals and tourists. A combination of temple visit and street long shopping stalls for souvenirs and delicacies. So much things to see and great feel of the community spirit. Very much alive and abuzz!

One of the oldest sections of Tokyo and busiest. Asakusa is primarily the home of the major Buddhist temple of Tokyo but is much more. As we walked toward Sensoji, we shopped for souvenirs along the Nakamise. Once we visited the temple we walked to the right and visited a Shinto temple which very few people know about. We went to the left of Sensoji and found an amusement park with many exciting rides. When we left the Temple area and walked down Kaminarimon Street we found many different restaurants all serving various types of delicious Japanese food. Make sure you see all of Akasusa.

Temple, shrine, food, shops. Bustling streets and crowds but narrow backstreets take you into old Tokyo with shops selling curios, food, etc. Worth it especially if you're going to the temple and shrine nearby (a must stop). Watch out for pick pockets.

Unique atmosphere in the midst of a city. Although part of the huge metropolis that is Tokyo, Asakusa has retained its individuality and charm. With the oldest temple, streams, gates and characterful streets it is a joy to wander around but also has easy transport links to the rest of the city. Well worth a visit.
Asakusa. A temple you can't miss. Walk around the temple find a special Japanese souvenir. Enter the temple to feel the spirit of the religion and enjoy the amazing garden.

3 in 1: historical, religious, traditional with a lot to experience (but very busy!). Asakusa should be in your trip (even if it is one day in Tokyo). In there, you experience historical streets with Japanese wearing traditional customs (many Japanese tourists rent kimonos there), visit the Sensoji temple while walking around tiny streets with a lot of Japanese candy and souvernirs shops. Also, find there a ninja shopping where you may experience some ninja art. The Asakusa Culture Tourist Information Centre is closeby and worth a visit: go to the top floor for a free nice Asakusa and Skytree view. Access through the Asakusa station quite easy. Go to Asakusa!

Traditional side of tokyo .. . Visit this place if you want to experience a blend of old traditional & modern setting of Tokyo. The moment you reach here you see a group of Rickshaw pullers ready to give you an old style sightseeing tours in Asakusa. They, enthusiastically, give enough information about the place while giving the visitors a beautiful Rickshaw ride. Definitely, an experience one must have. The area is full of small little shop selling souvenirs, daily wear and other consumable goods. The area is very crowded with locals & foreigners and it has a good vibe too. If you love spending time shopping, you can spend really long hours here. And if you love taking photo clicks, get ready to get surprised with some amazing takes you gonna have. Overall, a good place and definitely asks for a visit if you are in Tokyo.

A prominent piece of the Tokyo Jigsaw. This district has a wealth of exciting and historical attractions to witness. When walking down certain streets I really felt as though I was in authentic, real Japan. Nice temples and sights also. Well worth a visit.

If you only have 1 day in Tokyo, please come here !!!. Really, if you have only one day in Tokyo just come here to experience Japanese Culture, come and visit to Sensoji Temple and wander around into all the souvenir shops. We take a stroll at the back alley of the shops and we found a very affordable small shops and bought all of our friends souvenir shops. We came in the early spring and there is small shops selling Sakura Ice cream ! yay ! What an experience. There are a lots and lots of eatery that you can try for an authentic Japanese Foods, we ate at one of the Tempura shop and happy and satisfied. He he !!

Ricshaw asakusa tour. That was the most romantic tour we had in Tokyo .university students are pulling these carts around Asakusa and giving you an amazing cultural tour around the geisha neighborhood. Very enjoyable and informative . Our guide was waiting for us with a nice big poster with our names and a very nice welcome from his colleges Mr Tsuji our guide was so nice and very friendly . I definitely highly recommend this tour on rickshaws and it was one the highlights of our trip to Japan.

Good for an hour. This temple is easy to get to and the approach is lined with lots of souvenir shops. It's pretty popular and always busy with lots of visitors. There isn't any temple garden to talk about here though so it is good for about one hour's visit.
Interest to see. It is crowded street and popular. We have a great time to explore and learn new things how Japanese pray.

old and new. Lots of little shops and stalls leading up to the temple. Crowded street. Fun atmosphere. The temple is beautiful with lots of photo opportunities. The parallel street has more modern shops, but still reasonable prices. You can find souvenirs, local food, and anything else you can think of. Easy to get to from subway. Fun half a day or just a couple of hours.

Place to see. That is a good place to see japanese tradition and atmosphere; but as well a nice district to wander around and look at people daily life; good for shopping; Also you may find there not expensive places to eat some traditional food; this place is on every map and definitely worth seeing.

Wonderful. Had a great time visiting this area, and the Senso-ji Temple. There are lots of stalls and shops selling kitschy things. Enter through the main gate and walk down towards the Temple. Super busy, we went on a Saturday. Maybe try for during the week.

Amazing night view of the temple. If you are addicted to the night view shooting, it's a great idea to visit the temple in the evening. In addition, there are many traditional stores and restaurants around the temple, while many of them will close around 6 p.m..

One of the most visited tourist attraction in Tokyo. It's famous for its crowded streets leading to the temple, you'll find lots of small shops.Pay ￥100 and you can get a fortune from the booth: 1. pay the coin into the slot, 2. shake the box until one of the stick comes out3. the stick has a number (it's not arabic number)4. take the paper from the box matching the number. Your fortune is written on the paper, it does has English translation on the back, but less detailed than the Japanese version on the front.There's also Kimono rental shops next to the temple, so you'll see quite some ladies in Kimono around the temple, mass majority of them are tourists myself included :)
Loved it...... Great introduction to Japan and what it has to offer. Everything you could wish for and more plus very few non-Japanese. Super for exploring ....a surprise round every corner.
One of the best sights of Tokyo. I visited many sights in Tokyo and this was by far on of the best. A great area, a nice shopping street and the whole place feels like old Japan. Definitely visit.

Apart from the main attractions, the neighbourhood is not so impressive.. We have been in Asakusa twice during our holiday and found the neighbourhood all-right even though by itself it is nothing special. The presence of main attractions like the Senso-ji temple, Asakusa Ferry-station and the metro line for Tokyo Skytree makes it a point of convergence. Apart from the 3 or 4 main attractions we did not find walking around Asakusa so impressive. There are many restaurants available and during the cherry blossom there is a dedicated and very suggestive festival.

Our home neighborhood in Tokyo. We stayed in Asakusa during our trip to Tokyo. Our hotel was just across the street from the Kaminarimon so we spent a good amount of time in the area around Sensoji. During the day Asakusa is a bustling place, full of both tourist with selfie sticks and locals going about their daily lives. The Asakusa visitor center is a great place to pick up some maps of the city, and the building has a free observation deck overlooking the Sensoji complex and the neighboring Sumida district across the river. The obvious highlight of Asakusa is Sensoji and the Asakusa Shrine. Take some time to explore all of the side streets radiating off the main Nakamise market street leading up to the temple. The area has a lot of good food options, interesting shops, and great people to meet. At night many of the tourists disappear and the temple complex and surrounding streets are a wonderful place to stroll. The illuminated buildings of Sensoji and the glowing Skytree towering overhead are such an amazing juxtaposition. It's an area of Tokyo that's definitely worth a visit, and if you're planning to stay in Asakusa there are convenient transportation options that allow you to get anywhere in the city with relative ease. I'm very happy that we chose this area to stay in while we visited Tokyo.

Nice although touristy.. We had a great time shopping at the market in Asakusa, however it is very touristy. If you want more of market the locals frequent take the subway to the next neighborhood to the west Ueno. It is a true Japanese market.

Great district for exploring. I stayed here during my visit to Tokyo and absolutely loved it! All the main sights are within walking distance or a short train ride within the prefecture, including the Tokyo Skytree and the Asakusa shrine. There are great restaurants and eateries, and shops selling all kinds of things, including traditional artisanal Japanese goods. The maze of side streets are the best for exploring because you never know what you'll come across, and almost all of them are in the traditional Japanese style shop fronts making it all very pretty and charming.

Nice District - Great Places to Eat.. This is a very busy district but is a lovely mix of old and new. We enjoyed the mix of temples, restaurants and little shops. There were some lovely shops with handmade items such as screen-printed textiles etc. It was very busy when we visited on 1st January 2015 but really enjoyed the atmosphere.
Nice district of Japan.. Places you can visit while in Azakusa: Tokyo sky tree building. Sensoji shrine. Don Quiijote. Good food. Nice people.

Beautiful. A beautiful place to visit while in Tokyo. We went to Asakusa shrine about a few weeks ago and decided to take the rickshaw tour which started not too far away from the shrine. After that we spent some time at the market starting from the kaminarimon gate and walked all the way to the temple.

A must see when in Tokyo. We went on a sunny but not too hot day and strolled over the market, bought souvenirs and other stuff and ate a lot of snacks and sweets which are sold around this area. The temple at the end is good for checking your future :)

Scenic. This is a Buddhist temple that has become a tourist attraction. Once you get out of the Asakusa metro station, you will have to walk along a long stretch of shops selling souvenirs and snacks before you finally reach the temple. The temple is beautiful and at the entrance, there's a big red lantern. Nearby, is the restaurant called Daikokuya. This restaurant serves Ebi Ten Don or Prawn Rice Bowl.

Perfect mix of the old and the new. This place is simply amazing but when we went it was incredibly crowded, the surrounds are full of modern shops so it provides a great experience of the old Japan and the new Japan, great location and great temple

Very busy and tourist area. Blooming around the Senso-ji temple and Asakusa station this entire area is very busy and touristic. It has hundreds of restaurants, shops, department stores,...
Riksha rides are offered through the area, but with ripping off prices of some 100 USD for half an hour.

Street with pricey souvenirs. This is a crowded street heading to the Senso-ji Shrine, there are many little shops lined at the street. You can all sorts of souvenirs and street food here but it's pricier here compared to other places (in my opinion). But the atmosphere is definitely a good one to experience. View at night is very beautiful with the lights on.

Favorite part of tokyo. Out of all the many touristy and popular sites to visit tokyo, this has got to be my favorite! I love how old and traditional asakusa can be in the midst of a modern world. The temple and shrine are beautiful and makes for great pictures. Mornings before 9 are better, less crowd and more space to walk around and really take in the beauty. The food and shopping stalls are crazy, I don't recall which streets we went down (because there are soo many!) but there are food stalls in the main street leading to the temple and then on the side streets there are tons of restaurants that you can choose from. come here for traditional souvenoirs and depending which stall you go, pretty cheap. Can't wait to come back!

Popular shopping area. Taking the Sensoji Temple as the start, one can go around the block and find many department stores. Our group visited the ROX building where they had a Daiso 100-yen shop, UNI QLO and many other shops. Just a few doors down was a big Don Quixote department store which had many interesting things.

Amazing temple. A great part of Tokyo... The mixture between tradition and modern world could be seen here... No comment about the temple, cause it was just so amazingly beautiful. But we also had a culinary experience since there are so many street food stall.. You should try the street food of Japan
Crossroad. Here for short time. Come to see crossing, especially in the afternoon when there are a lot of people. Don't forget to take picture with Hachiko, the famous dog.

wonderful garden. this famous temple can be very very tourist crowded. avoid afternoon visit especially on weekends and holidays. it is however a wonderful place to see classic japanese architecture and garden in the heart of modern tokyo.

If you have only one day in Tokyo, go here. Granted, there are a lot of other better places to see in Tokyo and its surrounding area. But if you only have one day, you should go here. It has a nice mix of old and new. It has a nice temple with a small garden. It's close to Skytree, so you can snap a picture of yourself with the tallest building in Japan. It has streets full of souvenirs. There are several streets in the vicinity that has buildings that look like they're from the Edo period. Lots of restaurants. And it's close to Ueno Park, where you can go if you're done exploring Asakusa.

Interesting place to visit. If you like to buy some cheap souvenir and food Asakusa is the right place to visit...the price is reasonable and so many things to see. There are many people wear kimono around the street too

A wonderful part of Tokyo. We didn't have time to head down to Kyoto this trip so we stayed in Asakusa instead and so glad we did. This area has the same old world charm of Kyoto - the stunning temples, quiet streets, lovely little restaurants. Proximity to Ueno Park. Definitely worth a trip as a contrast to the bright lights of Shibuya or Shinjuku. We loved it.

Excellent Place to Shop and See a Temple with small japanese garden area. Really enjoyed all the shops even though it was crowded. It was nice to see the temple area. What I enjoyed best was the small garden area with a waterfall and koi pond to overlook as you went past a bridge. Oasis in the heart of the city, Easy to get everywhere from here and plenty of food options.
Awesome Place. Nice place and you have many snack shops around if you are a food freak. Temple is crowded though. A must place to visit in Tokyo.

Nice to walk around. We came here based on the reviews this area was like 'old tokyo' with a lot of its old charm. In some ways that was true, but it was also very touristy. One half of the city was like a mini vegas, with lots of gambling places, and the other half a street lined with shop snacks ending at the temple. We walked to the front of the temple but didn't feel inclined to fully explore it. Because it was cold, we instead searched for a local bar to get a drink. It was hard to find one with a good vibe, but eventually we stumbled upon this small bar (big enough to fit 5-7 people) where locals and the owners were very inviting! I think this would be an interesting area to stay in an explore more of.
Beautiful mix of old and new. Loved the markets with all the (albeit fake) cherry blossoms lining it. Saw many women in kimono and the temples are very impressive.

Snacks heaven!. My friends and I ate a total of 15 snacks here. You can find some f best japanese snacks here. Expect takoyaki, melon pan, dango, shave ice and many more. BUT Make sure to research for the best shops that serve all these snacks or you could simply look at the shops with the crowd. The visit to the shrine was good but a lot crowd kinda make it hard to capture any picture. I simply found the food and shops more enjoyable:)

temple, street fair, shopping all in 1. the beautiful Sensoji Temple is here, it's 1 of the temple that I loved the most among the few i visited in Japan.there's a street fair leading up to the temple, and if you decided to try the local food offer by them, most of the shops have a policy that you must eat the food within their premise. i supposed this is to keep the place clean.to the side of the temple you have a covered area with shops and restaurants.
Beautiful Sight. Tokyo Skytree from the Asakusa Crossing, and Senso-ji itself is BEAUTIFUL. Many snack stands in Senso-ji area, really delicious.

Sensoji Temple. Worth visiting for the Sensoji Temple. We then had a walk to the river for a cruise. The cruise is a good break from walking and a different view of Tokyo, worth doing if unspectacular.

nice area. a great little area to visit, heaps of shops to look at and different restaurants. not to mention cherry blossoms and the Sensoji temple to see. There were lots of people when we visited so it was quite busy!

Beautiful neighborhood in Tokyo.. So much to see in this part of Tokyo.It hasn't changed that much from the Edo period (~1600s).The shrine is beautiful and there are hundreds of little traditional shops all around it.If you want to visit all the little streets around the shrine area, you must stay there a complete day at least.It's a very quiet place, even if it's ever crowded.You must avoid going there with big luggages or with strollers.

A must visit for all tourists. Asakusa is a must visit for me every time I visit Tokyo. I will also go pray at the Sensoji Shrine. This is also a great place to shop and eat if one is not here to pray, Hundreds of shops can be found around the shrine. There is a very established tempura restaurant located on the main road. One can find all kinds of souvenirs, Japanese snacks and other stuff in the shops here.After walking around the area, take a boat ride down to Odaiba and enjoy the view along the river.

My favorite place in Tokyo. I come to Asakusa nearly every time I come to Tokyo. I love walking the streets, visiting the shrine, and eating in this part of Tokyo. I particularly love visiting Sensoji Shrine at night when everything is lit up. Also if your are taking Tobu Skytree line its easy access to an express train to Haneda Airport.

Shops galore. The shopping is good for souvenirs from Japan. The crowds are better in the morning. You can eat well in the area. There are many other streets worth looking at, not just the main one (Nakamise).

Definitely worth a visit. If this is your first visit to Tokyo, I recommend going to Odaiba first then taking the boat cruise to Asakusa. From the pier, stroll along the waterfront then turn off to Asakusa. Good to have an appetite when you go, besides lots of stalls selling Japanese goods and souvenirs, there's a whole heap of food variety too. At the end of the street is a temple. Make sure your camera is charged, lots of photo ops.

Spring festival is a good time to visit. Temple visit during the spring festival was very rewarding, as there are additional vendors selling traditional foods and treats. The market and temple were bustling with tourists and locals paying their respects. Lots of young ladies and gentlemen in traditional dress and if you are polite they will pose for you. Many attractions are nearby, for example Tokyo Skytree, Kirin Beer Building, Kappabashi Street, Nakamise Shopping Street and Sensoji Temple. You can easily spend a full day in the area tasting local foods, visiting local sites and shopping.

Eclectic Shopping. great shopping area. Kind of a farmers market sort of feel with lots of booths, some covered, some open-air. Lots of funky things to see, plus a fantastic temple/garden. Was one of the highlights of our trip to Tokyo

Asakusa is the best of Tokyo. Asakusa is a must visit for anyone who wants to get a good look at a more down to earth life in Japan. Tons of old school restaurants and shops selling everything you could imagine. While other parts of Tokyo have a modern futuristic look and feel, Asakusa preserves the past in a wonderful way.

Fun Place - All encompassing. You can find culture, shopping, food, gardens, everything in Asakusa. You have Nakamise and Kappabashi to shop to your heart's content for everything right from quirky souvenirs to awesome crockery and kitchen equipment. There is Sensoji and its set of shrines to engage in the cultural and spiritual side. There are crazy number of restaurants and stalls as well for the gastronomical experiences. Asakusa is a fun half to full day experience.

Perfect Place. This is the perfect place to be at during the day. There is so much to see and do. Lots of shopping (streets upon streets of it!) and food to try. The Temples and Shrines in this area are absolutely amazing and is something you would need to see.Easy to get to by metro, and the sky tree is just a few blocks down.

Crowded and busy . After getting dropped off by our tour bus, were ovehelmed by the number of people that were eager to see this temple. First, you'll have to walk through a crowded market area where they sell souvenirs and food. Our bus guide warned us to stay away from these vendors because they'll charge a premium. We just browsed and after some squeezing through other tourist just standing around the path of this market area, we finally saw the temple. What a beauty! You can't come to Tokyo and pass up on coming to this place. Must see on your bucket list in Japan!

Still finding new sites after more than 30 years!. The area around Asakusa is a delight! From the main gate, through the parade leading to the temple, the gardens and adjoining buildings this is a centre of attraction for so many domestic and international tourists. Over 30 years I've followed much the same route when visiting but this time was diverted through the quieter areas and what treasures - Whilst always calling the site 'Asakusa Jinja' (Shrine) I blindly just went to the Buddhist buildings including Senso-ji. This time I visited the shrine too and almost alone could spend some time in the quiet.
asakusa. a great tourist area to be located, where everything is conveniently located, shopping and food, oh so much food....lol

Lots to do and see. We'd been to the major tourist locations of Asakusa before but this time we stayed there (Hotel Hatago) so we spent more time around the many attractions. The cherry blossoms were just beginning so a walk along the river was very pleasant.
Great place to stay. Lots of things to do. Many choices for food, and supermarkets and trains very close. Easy to get to anything you want to see in Tokyo.
Asakusa park. Very nice Japanese traditional park full of temples and shrines. It was very romantic wedding ceremony during my visit. One minus - overcrowded!

Nice temple & surrounds but tourist trap & expensive. The temple was great but if you're spending time in Kyoto, then it's nothing overly unique and if you're picking a few destinations in Tokyo, I'd put this lower on the list. (There's so much to see and do in Tokyo!!) If you're not going to Kyoto, and want to see a few temples then sure, you should check it out. The markets have a great atmosphere as it's very busy but it's also extremely overpriced so I wouldn't do any souvenir shopping here.There's heaps of hidden, tiny restaurants around the markets, so I'd opt for eating in one of those gems.We were actually trying to find a pet cafe that was allegedly in the area but never did discover it.

Explore further. Beautiful cultural and compact. Easy to navigate and explore around other landmarks such as the theme park, skytree and rickshaw guys. amusement park is beautiful at night. There are many snacks along the way. Custard puffs is a must to try. Delicious!!!

Arriving in Asakusa Not sure what to expect. A Japanese friend told us to go there and direct us to this place. First visit was the tourist info and then as the day went on. There are rows of shops selling mainly Japanese souvenirs and goods. Inc foods etc. Leading all the way to the temple at the end, Very interesting place and lots of tourist hotspot there,
Main attraction in taito. Shop along the temple, crowded, all people wishing to take picture in the gate. 1 minute from asakusa station

japan breeze. Asakusa is the famous place in Tokyo..where you can feel ..'like in Japan'it's open market...and close at 5 or 6 pm. There are many stalls here, ice cream,cookie,and many souvenirs..especially hello kitty.. but quite expensive..if you take JR line, just stop at Ueno station.. walk straight and go outside the building ( if I didn't forget..it's exit 9 ), you must go the open air and go down by escalator and go to another old and small building, there is Ginza line...buy a ticket to Asakusa.There are many exits in Asakusa...and huge area..if you confused, just ask the people there..go to Sensoji temple..so you can find Asakusa market street in front of the temple, or just go follow the other people...cause all the people there go to Asakusa.

Olde worlde Tokyo. Great neighborhood of Tokyo. Although set of for tourists this is a great alternative part of Tokyo to visit. So interesting to see all the various dedicated streets to vendors selling their wares. Thoroughly recommend visiting this part of Tokyo as the contrast with modern Tokyo is huge. Great venue for families, couples and singles...has something for everyone.

Buddhist shrine and Shinto temple. Both are on-site. It was interesting to compare and contrast. On a Saturday, there were lots of food vendors with a great selection (try the octopus cakes!). Wander of onto some of the side streets to get the true flavor.

The only place u can feel old fashioned Tokyo city. Huge temple and shrines, the only town u can feel old fashioned ancient Tokyo city. And many traditional japanese food restaurants and shops for souvenirs. Early April or end of March, beautiful thousand cherry blossom trees are lining up by Sumida river. And every month there is a festival held around temple.

great outdoor to soak local and tourist flavour. Spent relaxed 3-4 hrs on a sunny weekend at the shrines; also shopping souvenirs, sitting at river front, sampling local savouries, watching the faithful pray, enjoying endless army of selfie clickers and just idling. I was not in a rush. And I got a lot out. I liked Dempoin Dori for browsing and picking small stuff. Vinayak - Thanks for making a great suggestion.
A taste of Japanese history in some minutes. Super temple in the middle of Tokyo. Well connected with the metro network and with hundreds of shops in the surroundings selling souvenirs, food, etc.

Good temple in tokyo area. if you are traveler who has no plan to visit Kyoto, then this should be must visit place to see temples in Japan. Usually very crowded. Lots of shops while walking from Asakusa station to main temple area.

Best of Tokyo Experience Here. We came here via Asakusa Subway, walked towards the outer gate of Sensō-ji Temple called the Kaminarimon or Thunder Gate with a giant lantern, perfect for photo op, then enter the Nakamise stree full of Japanese wares, food, drinks, etc before reaching the Sensō-ji Buddhist Temple. One can try out the traditional Buddhist practices and kimono wearing.There a lot of streets to explore here either by walking or by rickshaw (jinrikisha, literally "man powered vehicle"). We also dined in one of the Japanese restaurants, very traditional delicious and cheap. We proceeded to the Sumida River part in the evening where we viewed the Skytree with its rainbow color, standby the river for a cold evening, public toilet was available and clean. You can also take the Sumida River Cruise. The Sumida River Park is also a place to go when Sakura (Cherry Blossom) are in bloom.One whole day here may not be enough to experience old Japan. We would like to return for some more fun and adventure.

A nice part of Tokyo to spend some time in. I visited the area on a recent trip to Tokyo and spent a few hours wandering the streets and shops. There is a lively market street with perhaps a few too many cliché shopping items like chopsticks, silk slippers and Japanese prints. The surround streets held more interest with some great speciality food shops, leatherworks and I found a great little spice stall where they mixed the spices in front of you to your specification. The temple area was busy and very pretty even though it was the dead of winter. Overall there is a nice feel about the place which makes it a worthwhile visit.

Lots of People, Beautiful Temple. This was a must tourist destination and we availed of a afternoon tour that included this temple that has a long strip of shops. It was truly an enjoyable experience to see the contrast of culture and tourism. I enjoyed doing what tourists do here: take pictures, eat, shop and be amazed at the beauty of the temple, the tradition and the surrounding area around it.

A great day out.. Asakusa is a short distance from the centre of the city and well worth a visit. We were there on Sunday and the place was filled with locals enjoying the sunshine. They are so friendly and will do anything to help you if you need them. It is all about the temple here. You can walk through the small streets from the main gate and you will see many things about Japanese culture. There are people praying, getting the fortunes told and many of them eating. On a sunny day it is a really great day out.

Nice place to stay. I like this place to stay because very close to access around Tokyo, near by everything. The people here very welcome and polite, i cannot find my hotel, and everybody willing to help. even they cannot speak english, they wanna help with many way.
Nice temple. It's a nice temple to visit. It's a good place to watch the traditional rituals of the shinto religion.
Good complex don't miss any of it. make sure you do all parts including the shrine, a beautiful complex & the tacky shops on the way in are good fun too

My favourite of the temple complexes in Tokyo. I think this was my favourite of the temple complexes in Tokyo. It's free and there are a number of very large and impressive temples all on the same square. There is also a market nearby which also sells lots of interesting little things from cheap suveniers to lots of tasty food (there is a really great bakery nearby, just look for the queue). This is definitely worth a visit. The sky tree is also nearby if you want to combine the two.
Sensoji Shrine and Nakamise Street. There is a pharmacy in Shin Nakamise that sells chocolates and cup noodles tax free. Just bring your passport.

Plan to Spend a Full Day and Evening Walking Around. This was by far our favourite area in Tokyo. Shops you can actually afford to buy things from, a fairground (the original in Japan) to spend a few hours going on rides, a famous temple, a riverside walk, a covered shopping street, street food and a great night scene for sitting around in street bars serving delicious food. The kitchen street is also nearby.We also hired traditional dress and spent three hours walking around the temple and riverside area. The Kimono shop also arranged a photographer who spent an hour or so with us, taking photographs (we got 250!) and being an excellent local guide at the same time. Just Google << Asakusa sakura kimono hire photo >> and you will get six or so choices from where you can hire the gear. remember it is going to take 30 minutes to put on the Kimono and the make up and accessories. But it is really fun to do and with the photos a lifetime memory.If you only have time for one place in Tokyo then this must be your destination. Make sure you do the evening and night when the place really comes alive. We did the Kimono walk from 2pm until 5pm.

Beautiful place with several attractions on the side. We stayed around this area and was it fascinating! A hybrid of the traditional (temples and shrines) and modern (souvenir shops and restaurants) Japan that's should be on any traveler's to-go places when in Tokyo.
Underrated. A lovely part of Tokyo, especially around the Senso_ji temple with its narrow streets with numerous food places at bargain prices
Kamakura - Budha and Beach. i loved to see big budha and i beach also so good. worth to go.i am sure you will definately enjoy this place.

A Must Do!. We enjoyed a great day wandering around the beauty of the temple and the lovely lanes with shops in the surrounding area. A cultural experience for sure and very easy to get to on the Metro. Probably best to go week day as the crowds on the weekend were pretty full on!Probably allow half a day to take in all the surrounding sites,

Nice temple if this is the first you visit. The pros : lots of history surrounding this temple, as long as you have someone to explain it to you:
The cons : became so much focused on tourists, from the restaurant staff calling you when you exit the subway till the very long alley full of souvenirs shops.
Interesting but don't allocated more than 30 minutes in your schedule

Wonderful place. I absolutely loved sensoji ji. and the surrounds. The sky tree is also pretty cool and especially loved the shopping centres attached to it. And if you have the money be sure to get a rickshaw ride! our runner was the best, he spoke some english and had a pretty good conversation with is and took plenty of pictures of us too!

Nice but tacky. Asakusa was a pleasant place to be at times, and we enjoyed wandering around the shops and temples, however we also found it to be a bit tacky and falsified. The main 'ancient street' leading to the temples is just full of tacky stalls and swarming with tourists, while we were stopped a few times by adorable little Japanese kids and their teachers as they attempted to practice their English with us.A nice place for an hour but annoying thereafter!

Best place to stay in Tokyo. Asukasa is probably the best place to stay or live if you're visiting or working in Tokyo. It's really quiet, especially at night, even though there's probably just as much of vibrant nightlife as anywhere else in the city—it's just more hidden and spread out. There's Senso-ji temple, which is a great place to meditate on your thoughts, and plenty of little shops and restaurants.The neighborhood feels more representative of the east part of Tokyo in that it is traditionally Japanese. Even if you're not staying in the area, visit Asakusa at least once when you're in Tokyo—especially if you're an avid shopper! I bought a great handmade cooking knife from a store that was on the corner of one of the alleys.
Perfect!. This place is great! So many things to do, nothing I disliked. Lots of shopping and attractions! Just simply an amazing trip.

Beautiful temples.. I got here around sunset and it was such a beautiful temple. I spent some time walking around it but I was more engrossed in the little markets and shops around it. There were shops that sold everything and I managed to get two old traditional looking paintings of Japan that are hanging pride of place at home.

great mix of old and new tokyo. Asakusa can be crowded and touristy by day due to senso-ji and other temples, department stores and restaurants. At night as the crowds thin out it can be somewhat quiet but authentic due to the locals and it does have a couple of music venues and good ramen noodle houses and sashimi restaurants. It does offer good transportation with short distances to other parts of Tokyo and walkable to kappabashi (kitchentown) also nice to explore the side streets and older areas and very safe.

Get there early. Asakusa, a must visit for all travelers. Plenty of temples, history and little shops. Although it was refurbished (by fire?) it still retains outstanding. There are many charming gift and snack stalls before the temple main entrance. For young kids, there is a small fun park with rides nearby.I would recommend an early visit as it can get very busy eg. school field trips etc.A great experience!!

Beautiful does not even begin to describe. Old school Japan with history and temples. This whole area was beautiful. A perfect mix of modern with Edo sensibilities. Lots of temples and shrines strewn about, and also home to the older theme park in Japan. If I stay in Tokyo again next time I'm in Japan it will most definitely be in Asakusa

A must-go when in Tokyo, been here plenty times, love it. Beautiful architecturePretty old and nice streetsLovely shops I enjoy this place and been there several times A must-go for every tourist to Tokyo

Old Tokyo in the lap of new. If there is one place cuddled in the lap of the new that is Asakusa. It is old part of Tokyo always crowded with tourists. There is a temple and around the temple streets are lanes full of souvenirs shops. Whether it is Japanese doll or T shirts or Kimono, you get everything here. No negotiations. In some of the shops kimono is available for rent. I dont think any new comer to Tokyo can miss this place. One visit is worth for feeling the vibes of Tokyo. First day, i had 1 hour. I could just cross 100 mts in one hour. No you can gauge how much time ypou need to plan for Asakusa visit. Plan generously especially if you are a woman.

A Place to Get a Taste of Tokyo. Asakusa is located in the Taito District in Tokyo. Asakusa is famous for the Senso ji Temple. It also features many hotels, restaurants and shopping places. This is a real happening place not to miss especially if you do not have much time.
Crazy busy, but well worth a visit.... Crazy busy here - lots of tourists, but definitely worth a visit - especially the temple here which is beautiful...

Too Crowded on Weekend. I was hoping to climb the pagoda tower, but sadly, it's off limit.If you seek tranquil, peaceful, and quite temple; avoid weekends.You can take omikuji (fortune forecast) with donation of 100 yen. No one will judge you if you don't donate, but I think 100 yen won't be hurt.It's really helpful they put english translation in omikuji, and unfortunately I got bad luck. Bad luck fortune should be hanged on iron thin bars to cleanse it.You also can smoked your hair and drink from fountains. Also the famous coin tossing shrine. They sells omamori (amulets) varied from 500 yen to 2000 yen. Many small shoppes sighted nearby sensouji temple that sells garments and various things like keychain, accessories and even matsuri mask. But don't expect cheap price since it's famous tourist attraction.

Funny! But I Keep Returning.. I have been here on numerous of times and keep complaining about the crowds but I keep returning. Funny as it is. Asakusa definitely is a good place for street photography and that the reasons you may find many of them (photographers) here.

Scenic, historic and lively. A very enjoyable experience wandering around 'old' Tokyo, surrounded by the new. Nightime brings street performances, market-style indoor streets, light shows and a beautiful glow on the temples.

Wander for an hour or 2 and ENJOY!. You will inevitably see the Asakusa neighbourhood since you simply MUST see the Sensoji Temple. Once you pop out of Asakusa Metro Station, you will wander through this delightful semi-residential, semi-business low-key neighbourhood on your way to the temple. Some very interesting knick-knack & food shops. Be sure to get over beside the Sumida River too for some stunning views of the Tokyo Skytree.

A spiritual treasure and shoppers paradise. The main focal point of this area is the Senso-ji temple. Today was the Winter solstice. In Japan, the year's shortest day and longest night is traditionally celebrated. It is celebrated yearly on February 3 as part of the Spring Festival and is accompanied by a special ritual to cleanse away all the evil of the former year and drive away disease-bringing evil spirits for the year to come. We were witness to the bean tossing ceremony (roasted soybeans) that were thrown from the temple by special guests. As part of bringing luck in, it is customary to eat roasted soybeans, one for each year of one's life plus one more for bringing good luck for the year to come. I was lucky enough to have caught/received 3 bags of beans containing just the right amount of beans! If you have a chance to go next year it was well worth it. Note, many other temples conduct these ceremonies. Once finished, we spend the rest of the day shopping in the many small streets and shops. Worth walking to is Kitchenware Town (a few short blocks away) for all you foodies and chefs alike. Another store not to miss is Den-Gama, a Japanese pottery shop found on Asakusa street.

Charming neighbourhood. Old style city, many suvenir shops and some curious shops too. There is a very nice place where Japanese old women go to have afternoon tea. (But, I don't remember the address, sorry)

Great place to get lost (in a good way!). Seriously though, you can't really get lost because there are people everywhere and eventually even if you are walking aimlessly, you will still see the subway (this is a main stop and you can see the temple area easily or follow the crowds). There are also tourist police you can ask for directions. This is a beautiful temple area along with the side markets on the streets.So many things to see (cultural temple area, shopping, restaurants, vendors) and great for safe walking. It is busy but not overly congested. The only challenge I had was the lack of translation since this is a very popular visitor area. I wish I had been able to understand the signs and read more about the cultural significance here. There are several areas near the temple where you will see obvious common spiritual rituals but without knowing exactly what they mean, you only are experiencing part of this beauty.After walking around, you will undoubtedly be hungry. Pretty sure everything here would be great since there is such a wide variety. Vendors display their prepared meals in glass cases to give you an idea of what you might order. Snacks are also available for purchase in the street market area. The vendors do ask that you eat in front of their stalls though. I'm sure this practice keeps the area very clean too. Try to find the green tea "ice cream burger" - so cute and tiny (hits the spot after all that walking even on a cool day). The vendors have lot of little trinkets to purchase for reasonably priced souvenirs.

It's a nice walking area!. Comparing to the fast steps in other areas as Shinjuku or Shibuya...., Asakusa gives you a whole lovely afternoon to enjoy the traditional view of Tokyo. And it's 15 minutes by subway to Ginza, that your night in Tokyo carries on from here!
Lovely. The market is really great for presents and the temple is serene and beautiful. We were lucky to witness a wedding whilst there, stunning! Very busy place but well worth the effort.

Busy place. There is so many temples in Japan. And our tour allowed us to visit many of them.
This one is at a location that is really crowded with people. There's a lot of shops and some local pastry that you can buy leading up to the temple building itself.
Pretty place to visit. Lots of interesting gimmicks to find, clean location, nice people and of course food ... do not miss this place when you visit Tokyo ...
Shopping and Dining in Asakusa. Big choice of restaurants and shopping opportunities for low and medium budget. Both Japanese and European restaurants.

Great place to walk. Visited the district on a weekend. It's pack with people. A lot of nice street food near to the temple. There also a lot of souvenir stores and restaurants around. However, I feel that the prices of some items like kit kat chocolate are slightly pricier than town. Overall a good place to visit and walk around. It's also within walking distance to the new tokyo sky tree.

Temple, Shrine, Shopping - great day. This place has it all. The Nakamise Shopping Street (as it's known) is wonderful. Loads of tiny stalls selling wonderful souvenirs. It takes a while to go through them all and along with that, there are many great restaurants and food outlets to eat. There is something for everyone. It gets very busy but that's Japan.
Great place to visit. One of the best shopping areas in Tokyo plus the magnificient temple as well. Always busy and crowded.

Great place to walk around!. Many nice street with great restaurant and shops, just around the beautiful temples. Also the oldest roller coaster in Japan in the small amusement park. (which is mostly for kids!) You can eat at a good price and local food.
Interesting place. A tourist spots with lots of stalls and outlets selling different types of things from food, souvenirs, clothing, accessories, etc. And also a temple too. Go pray if you want too.

By far my most favourite part of Tokyo. We spent two weeks Christmas break in Tokyo. The first few days, we walked round the most frequently recommended part (Imperial Palace, Shinjuku, Shibuya, Ginza), we only discovered Asakusa a few days later. Apart from Sensoji temple and the souvenir street, we really enjoyed the shopping arcade where we can buy a range of products from made in Japan and other imported products that accommodate different budgets as well as Kappabashi where you can buy anything you need for your kitchen, especially things to make Japanese foods. And do not forget to check out Don Quixot - an interesting 5-storey shop for nick nack. However, the most memorable experience was with Asakura studio where we were dressed up in Japanese traditional outfit and taken pictures around the area by a professional photographer cum tourist guide. I would highly recommend it to any tourist who is interested in history, culture and shopping. Wonderful experience.
Unforgettable trip. Asakusa offers a different picture of the city with traditional activities , souvenier shops, women in kimonos and cheap and reasonable shopping options. Must visit.
Energentic. Was one of the first temples we visited in Japan, it was very busy however I believe we went at peek time. Lively and pretty! The markets outside are very nice to.
Another Lovely Shrine. It's a nice place, was quite packed when we visited it but for sure you have to visit it if you have some extra days in Tokyo

Sight seeing, shopping and dining. This area famous for it temples especially the Sensoji temple. Many shops here selling local crafts product or souvenir. You may finds many restaurants serving local foods and delicacies. If your are lucky, there are many festivals happen here around the year and as fro me it was a new year. This area was throng by Japanese and foreigner for visit or pray at the Sensoji temple.

Favorite section of Tokyo. I love this section of Tokyo. I usually stay in this section as a base for travel around the city. Asakusa is less hectic and there is more everyday life here but still plenty to see and do, lots of good restaurants and easy access to trains and underground. The train to Nikko starts here as well.
Great part of Japanese culture. Surrounded by the new buildings this part of Japanese history is a nice change to the rising sky scrapers and is well worth a look!

Unique in its own terms. The major factor to the shrine at the place is its architecture which is a mixture of modern and traditional architectural skills making it unique and one of the biggest and popular shrines in Tokyo. Apart from the shrine the place has a lot more going for it. The restaurants or food stall are perfect to check out Japanese snacks and souvenir shops are good for memoir shopping. It basically has something for everybody
Good area to explore Japanese culture.. All in one area - culture, food, shopping and relaxation while exploring Asakusa. Stroll along the back lanes to find more interesting shops.
Excellent. Anyone going to Japan should already know about Asakusa. Just an excellent place to see the sights. Great way to start a vacation, by seeing a big temple.

I keep coming back!. Of all the places I visited in Tokyo, Asakusa is one of my favourites.
It's Edo Tokyo meets modern Tokyo, with fantastic historical spots as well as restaurants and karaoke bars and everything in between.
Asakusa is also central to trains, making it a fantastic spot to stay if you want to travel around Tokyo.

Fun and Buzzy. My favourite part of Tokyo, Asakusa has something for everyone. There is the shrine of course, which is full of people and the incense burner is not commonly seen at other shrines. Unusually for Japan there is also a public area where you can sit down next to the shrine, and I even saw people eating there, which is unusual in Japan. Probably tourists.The market stalls sell all kinds of interesting things from cheap souvenirs to toys, clothes, kitchenware and food. On some days there are also temporary food stalls next to the shrine itself. There are also lots more shops in the side streets around the area. One of the best things about the shrine and torii are the girls (and guys) wearing traditional dress who promenade in the area and seem to enjoy posing for themselves, their friends and tourists to take photos.Across the road from the torii is the tourist information centre at the top of which is a viewing platforms that gives a great view of the whole area.
Great neighborhood with shrines and little shops. A taste of old Tokyo, with terrific stores, historic sites and a great contrast of old and new. Great access to the subway is also a plus.

Nice japanese architecture!. We went all around Asakusa, and we were surprised by the amount of stuff there is to do around the temple area. The temple and shrines are beautiful. Access to Asakusa is very easy using the subway I don't read or understand japanese and i found it just fine, the merchants are very helpful and nice.
Nice part of town!. We actually had our hotel here and it was a great choice for atmosphere. A lovely neighborhood with the rickshaws and old buildings.
A charming and lively place. Besides the Sensoji temple, Asakusa area has lots of attractions. Best time to visit at night, have dinner at one of the local restaurants and shop for fun.

Area with lots of attractions. The area is very crowded as it's where Sensoji temple is located. There are lots of hostels around the temple to choose and choices of souvenirs and street foods in the area. Try to visit the temple once at night, it's different from the day.

Touristy but great!. It was raining and during a weekday but it didn't stop the crowd to come here. Many people gathered but you can still enjoy the area. My most favorite part is the shopping street. There were so many souvenirs (some are cheaper than other places like Akihabara or Shibuya) also great traditional snacks. We tried a green tea mochi for 100 yen only and it was the best ever!

Be prepared for the crowd. Asakusa is where Tokyo ' s most famous temple Sensoji is located so expect to see hordes of people here. Nakamise street that leads to the temple is lined with small shops selling all kinds of souvenirs and street food. This street is jam packed with tourists. Around the temple are side streets where you find traditional shops and houses. A few blocks away from the temple is Kappabashi street. It is lined with shops selling all kinds of kitchen and table wares. I found beautiful ceramic wares at very affordable prices.
Better to visit Asakusa Temple at night. Incredible place to see in Tokyo. Lots of choices of souvenirs too! Highly recommended especially for first time Tokyo tourists!

Beautiful temple, great shopping. This temple was amazing and definitely worth a visit. Plan to do your souvenir shopping here. Lots of cute trinkets at pretty decent prices. Don't forget to try the green tea ice cream!

A nice place that retains the traditional Japan feel but it's quite touristy. It's a popular temple in Tokyo with a shopping street that sells Japanese souvenirs, Yukata and local snacks. This is the place in Tokyo which still maintains the traditional Japan feel. But it's quite touristy.

Crowded but worth it. We really enjoyed our walk through the stalls/shops in Asakusa. There were so many different stalls selling a bunch of different items. It's a great tourist stop. We arrived at the Asakusa subway stopped, walked through the stalls/shops and then to the Sensoji Temple and then back, which ended up working well. If you're going to visit one, I'd suggest visiting the other since they're so close.

2nd visit and still mesmerized. I love going into the shops in asakusa. Maybe it's the tourist in me. Just love sampling the japanese street food. The vendors were very polite and ever so willing to let us sample their food. However asakusa is getting very crowded now. Better to come during non peak season

A massive temple, fun people watching and custard fish - what is not to love!. The temple is a must do. Powerful image. Fun to tell fortunes there. A great view of the shopping arcade from the stairs. I am not a big shopper but people watching in the shopping arcade was fun. Towards the end of the shopping area a left turn into a side shopping street headed towards the river direction is a window shop that makes fresh baked custard fish. Worth every calorie - eat it hot standing on the street

The stretch of stalls before reaching the temple has many interesting shops.. Asakusa has a stretch of stalls before reaching the temple. It sells a wide variety of traditional snacks and goods, as though you step into old Tokyo.

Nice walk to shrine and sky tree next. 2nd day of Japan which is also my 2nd time in asakusa, as always the small shops while walking in is a heaven for? Yes! Snacks!! Icecream, biscuits, buns and many more authentic Tokyo snacks for take away or just have it at the corner of the shop itself. Further in are the souvenirs although not cheap, it's still worth the time and effort to find something which you might not find as where like lu my charm, phone accessories, personal chopsticks etc. Walking into the shrine you can do 3 things, get a divination, take some smoke for luck outside the shrine:p, do a lucky coin toss in front of the shrine and lastly get some lucky water at the side :)Short and sweet and you can go on to walk to sky tree :)

Wonderful for souvenir shopping! . Asakusa is a little market like area next to the train station. We went on a Saturday so every man and his dog was their praying at the shrine next to the markets so it was extremely packed. However, it was still a wonderful place to buy nick-nacks and presents for loved ones to remember your trip. You could spend hours here looking in every shop and there is something for everyone.A great samurai sword shop is here too. My partner bought himself a replica sword and they gave him a certificate to assist getting back through customs. Defiantly worth the trip out.

A must see place. Well, it was spring and everythings here was so pretty (the shrines, the temple, the shops, the atmosphere). You can found a lot of interesting things. I do had a lot of fun. Just for walking around, buying souverniers or tasting their local food. Perfect place for sighseeing of course. Never try to overlook this place while you're in Tokyo.

Must visit cultural heritage.. Lovely and sacred complex filled with cultural and religious heritance. This gives an insight to old japan and how cleaver, accurate and artistic they were even some centuries ago. The place is to be respected and honoured in everyone’s behaviour. You can take photographs but locals didn’t like when someone tries to lean on to statues or show full “Backside” to statues of worship. Therefore it is advisable to stand by the side of those statues than posing in front of them.Complex is very crowded and possibility of children getting lost is very high. Better to have own control measures in place. If anyone planning to visit, get a very GOOD camera to enjoy the quality, creativity and artistic values of the place.

Check out a matsuri here. This is the coolest cultural visit you can make in Tokyo. Try to go when the festival is on. You will be in for a treat. Lots of traditional food and costumes. On any regular day it is very worth the visit too.

Wonderful slice of old fashion Japan. Must see for any visitor in Tokyo, worth a detour I suggest the backstreets for food and get to the temple for a walk. Get the boat and stop at the Tokyo bay garden on the sea after the fish market (Tsukiji)

Lots to see and do. We went here on our hop on/hop off bus to see the shrine and Skytree Tower. The gardens are gorgeous. Lots and lots of shops around the area. They do rickshaw rides around. This was so enjoyable. We tried to go up the Skytree tower but too many people and too long a queue. Try to come early or late to do this. Wonderful day out.

Something old, something new, all together. This old area of Tokyo is a fascinating place to visit, with ultra modern cityscapes and street artworks backgrounding extensive alleys of traditional and tourist-oriented stalls. The grand and colorful temple complex is adjacent to a small, serene garden. Just blocks away are numerous clusters of street cafés with very keen staff and simple food that is quickly served, but a long, long way from 'fast food'.The evening night lights on the Sumida River are well worth the subway trip themselves.
old town mixed well in tokyo. maybe the only place in Tokyo which still has an ancient atmosphere, a very different feeling than other places in tokyo

Cannot miss this.. This area was recommended by Japanese friends and I'm grateful for their advice. It's a beautiful little area including pretty gardens and amazing traditional architecture. There's large temples with the amazing Sky Tree in the background making for fantastic photos. Even now (December), there's still a lot of beautiful yellow and red leaves contrasting beautifully with the red buildings.There's plenty of food and heaps of little stores with souvenirs that didn't seem too expensive to me.I've been in Tokyo for several days now and this would have to be one of the highlights.

Worth a quick visit. Worth going to check this area out for sure! A great area for shopping and picking up local items from food to chop sticks. The temple/shrine won't take very long to visit. You can get a couple nice pics looking at the shrine from the outside. Its easy to walk around the courtyard and take a few extra pics of the area. Be sure to check your fortune...see if you have good luck or bad luck by shaking a stick out of the "jar"and finding your fortune amongst the numbered drawers. An hour is plenty of time to spend here. Have fun!
Must visit. You can visit a temple along with shopping experience whenever you are here. A must visit attraction in Tokyo. The local Japanese shops are located just adjacent to temple.

the art in every little thing. Asakusa gave me a different experience of Tokyo metropolitan city. I came here twice on my visit to Tokyo, November 2014. Everything you see, you eat, and you buy will have the touch of Art. My suggestion is for those who don't have time or budget to visit Kyoto. then take times to stroll down and browse Asakusa. I remember coming here in the afternoon where stores are open and they sell unique Japanese souvenir, snacks, and clothes. Then on the next few days, I came again at night where almost all stores are closed in Shin Nakamise Dori, Nakamishe shopping street. I was a bit disappointed because I was planing to buy some souvenirs . But surprisingly, I experienced another cuteness of Japan where all the closed door of every stores are painted, and every store paints different pictures. I do buy some souvenirs, what I love buying souvenirs in Japan (also in here) Beside that they are cheaper than other places in Japan, they still care in their packaging. They will wrap whatever we buy in sweet little box, gift papers, and paper bags.

Mix of the quiet and city vibe. Asakusa was a good mix of crowds and solo walks -- majority of the side streets are not crowded and it was easy to walk around and just get a sense of the place, while on the Nakamise Dori and up to Sensoji temple it was very crowded, both with tourists and locals alike. I happened to be there during the Golden Dragon Dance and it was a very interesting procession to witness.
Temples and shops. Great group of temple, pagoda and small gardens. A stroll away from the river with Olympic flame and tokyo tower views. High ranking sightseeing if visiting tokyo.
A great Sight!!. This was by far the biggest excitment of seeing the true Japanese in thier culture. The buildings and area is a must see!

More than just the shopping street and Temple. Be sure to wander some of the back streets. Certainly the temple and the approach to it along the street jammed with sellers' stalls are a must- see but there's also a covered retail street one block away and some charming old-school buildings.We visited Asakusa by boat and walked from the landing. Lot's to see so allow time to just explore.

Great area of town to stay in, enjoy. First trip to Tokyo, and it's a challenge in many ways. But, we chose the perfect place to base our adventures. This area has character and convenience. Great subway, great food, everything you need and away from the madness of Shibuya and Shinjuku. (Be sure to see our review of the Gate Hotel - highly recommended.)
Nice typical japanese neighboorhood. Very nice neigboorhood to walk around, do some shopping, see temples, buy self made cookies etc. This is a mist do in japan.

Best whisky bar in Asakusa. Hands down the best bar in Asakusa. Shunya is the best bartender you'll ever meet. Great spirits, great jazz records. Thee hold thing. Whatever part of Tokyo, travel here for a incredible drink. Cash only.

Also explore the surroundings. Of course you must walk and spend some time in the street that leads to the temple, it has lots of different things, good for souvenirs. At the temple if you see people shaking a metal container and getting a stick out of it...it's find out about your future, get one stick it has a character, then get a paper from the drawer with the same character (don't worry, it is also in english), remember to put the stick back ;)Besides this it is also really nice to walk around the area, I found a small street where apparently lots of people go for breakfast after a night/early-mirning shift.. place looked awful but it is the best stew I've had in Japan, people was friendly too.
“Senso-ji Temple” - sacred site. Place you have to see when you first time in Japan. A magical place! Very peaceful. Excellent cultural experience.
quaint but crowded. an ever present crush of bodies swarming towards the Sensoji Temple. Be prepared for the noise and crowds
Traditional area in Tokyo. Tokyo is a very modern city, Asakusa is the traditional district of it. There is a big temple and local stores and restaurants to visit.

Much Fun to hang out there. I like everything beginning from the beautiful، product colorful market, passing by the temple, and going through the branched out lane and neighborhood. We stumbled with a street performance of Japanese drum, performed by ladies, was awesome

Great for short sightseeing break in Tokyo. A place to visit if you want to see some more than Tokyo city district. Easy to get by subway. From Asakusa station it's about 400m away to the main street leading to the temple. It's full of tourists and stalls catering to all tastes: fake, original and curious. Suggest keeping toghter otherwise it's easy to get lost between shops and throngs of people. If in hurry do not walk main street - there are a few parallel offering shortcuts and some cheaper shopping options. When in for a lunchtime take left from the main street (when facing the temple) there are all possible restaurants there and some are very popular.

Local is better than main. Asakusa is a good place to visit if it is your first time to come to Japan. many travellers just go to the main spot around Sensoji temple. of course it is good to see. but you should go to more local spots in Asakusa. you can experience more Japanese.
Edo Feel. Really Nice & we actually found a kissaten really cosy, with really nice yummy meals, the owner is friendly too!
A must!. One of the most famous temple and district in Tokyo. Nice souvenir shops along the entrance of the temple. The temple is huge and beautiful.

Lots to do ~ diarise in your Itinerary. Asakusa is a beautiful town with loads to do for tourists. We recommend you start with the Drum Museum, Kitchen street (Kappabashi), Nakamise Shopping Street, Shin-Nakamise Street, Senoji temple then walk to Sumida to the Sky Tree Tower. Then take the cruise to Odaiba (from Sumida)
Senso-ji Temple. A wonderful Buddhist Temple in a fabulous garden. A magical experience! Very peaceful, very contemplative.
Asakusa. Great place to visit. Glad I went. Market was clean and vendors were friendly. Good prices. Temple was lovely.
A must visit attraction. Asakusa's main attraction is Sensoji, a very popular Buddhist temple.A lot of local F&B and beautiful souvenirs can be found at this area.
Must see area. Sensoji temple was stunning. Surrounded by a stalls/market where i felt some shops boarded on tacky, but that did not detract from this amazing area.
Lovely old area. Very interesting area near Kaminaron Gate. Lots of small restaurants, general stores etc, Sumida River with cruises to Obaida. Easy train & subway connections to Central Tokyo

Great visit to the temple and surrounding shopping street. If you're only visiting Tokyo, here is your chance to see a beautiful Japanese temple and 5 story pagoda.Upon entering the temple grounds, there is a line of souvenir and food stalls that are worth browsing through. Here is your chance to pick up any Japanese souvenirs and any special food or cakes to take home.Very close to Tokyo Skytree, you can walk 20 minutes or take a 3 minute train ride.Highly recommend Asakusa area as one of your main stops in Tokyo!

Lovely Tokyo neighborhood. truly lovely part of Tokyo... full of little shops, restaurants... Sensoji temple is here... dont miss Asakusa Tourist Center - one of new architecture landmarks of this part of Tokyo... Just across the river is iconic Asahi Brewery building and not far from here is another Tokyo attraction - Tokyo Sky Tree... so try to make a plan to visit all this while you are in this part of the city...

Lots of little shops. I love shopping!! This was a great place to find little Japanese items. I bought a lot of souvenirs for my family. It had a beautiful street and a lot of little shops. There was a big temple at the end
fun place to walk around. This area is fun to walk around and see all the interesting shops. Food is great, try to find a place off the main road

A cultural experience, with some souvenir shopping on the way.. The gates that lead to the historic Buddhist temple have giant lanterns and statues. They are visually impending and great for a photo. The lane ways that lead to the temple have lots of souvenir shops, selling a variety of things, for example; chop sticks, yakuta, swords, magnets, key rings etc. if you don't have a lot of time in Tokyo, you can check out a sight and shop at the same time, very tourist friendly. The temple is also open to the public for prayer and a short walk from the station.

A "gentler" part of Tokyo. I spent a Saturday morning in this area, visiting the temple, shopping for souvenirs near the temple and on Kappabashi street. I found this area to be a great change from the towers and noise of Shibuya and Shinjuku. The temple is the oldest temple in the city, and the whole region represents an older part of Tokyo. The temple was busy but well worth a visit. The vendors on the street to the temple sell a wide variety of goods and foods. Some goods appear to be relatively cheaply made, mass produced souvenirs but others are much more interesting and unique. There are also some interesting shops on the side streets There are several small places to eat throughout the area. Try the Japanese sweet bread loaf in the small bakery to the right of the temple). I did not go to the Asahi beer building but it is easy to see from the Subway exit. Kappabashi street was a mass of local people with a few tourists intermixed in the crowds. There are great functional kitchen related items on this street that make great inexpensive souvenirs or Japanese gifts (knives, wooden bowls, baskets, hand cut class, and plastic food samples). Overall, this is a great part of Tokyo to visit for a morning that will provide a very different picture of the city (take the Ginza line subway to Asakusa).
Sensoji Temple. It's a nice and beautiful temple and culture. There are lots of food and souvenir stalls that you can enjoy shopping.
