Crowded but still maintain wisdom. It's always great to visit and pray. Too many people as we can expected from any tourist attraction. Visit in the early morning so you experience nice and peaceful temple.
Great cultural spot. Nice temples and gardens. Very well maintained and with good history explanation in English. Great nearby market street. Not very easy access...

Plenty to See. We took the waterbus up to Asakusa from our hotel near the Shiodome. I would recommend this as a good way to arrive. We walked up the Nakamise to the temple. The street is popular with tourists but none the worse for that. There were plenty of stalls selling various gift items and also some interesting foodstuff (which I enjoyed). The Senso-Ji temple itself is impressive and worth a visit.
Sensoji temple is here. Mostly packed with tourists all day and night. Rows of shops selling souvenirs, Japanese cakes and pastries.

crowded. it is a tourist attraction but a must to see and experience. lots of shops and trinkets. some really nice things also. the temple was interesting- according to the old ancient writings on the door frame banners - you were not suppose to turn your back to the idol god to take a picture- even though everyone was- not many there i guess could read the writing. But we thought that this shows that their god is only in this room and to turn your back to it would be disrespectful…we are thankful our God is everywhere- not just in a little room.

Better known for Nakamise Shopping street. The place is easily accessible from Tokyo and one of the most culturally active places throughout the year. If there's some kind of a celebration going on in the city like fireworks or parades, chances are it's around here... Nakamise shopping street is the best places i could find in Tokyo for getting great and reasonably priced souvenirs.. do check the prices in different stores before you buy since they vary..

Very touristy, but nice souvenir shops and sights. I had booked a kimono experience here and really enjoyed myself. My grandmother was Japanese and she met my grandfather who was an Aussie soldier so my mother was born in japan and I have been here a couple of times as a kid and dressed once in a kimono but this was 20+ years ago. Was lovely to be able to have this experience again and walk around for a few hours in a kimono. Even though it was extremely touristy we were still able to find some space around the temples and gardens to get some great photos. Loved shopping for nick nacks as well. Overall it was a great place to have that kind of experience as it felt like quite traditional japan. There was a few people doing the same thing and everyone especially the older generation seemed to like that you would want to dress in their traditional dress.

Very Busy!. Nice and easy to get to via the Ginza line...we went on a Saturday which probably made the crowds even thicker...particularly in the main access alley. A tip is to take either alley on each side of the main one and you'll be at the entrance in no time at all!Once inside theres really no queues for anything you may want to do or photograph.If you are not going to Kyoto dont miss it!

a must see. sensoji temple & nakamise shopping street is a must see. easy metro access. you can walk along the streets for souvenirs and red bean cakes. the atmosphere here is exiting. one can see the red lantern gate from far far away. yet the main hall, the tower, and the gardens showed us the history of this oldest buddha temple in tokyo.

Get lost in translation in Asakusa. Sensou-ji, Nakamise and Kaminari-mon aren't the only attraction of Asakusa in fact. There are quite a few authentic/interesting shops, restaurants, bars and cafes on the back streets. All you have to do is that you walk away from the crowds on Nakamise and simply get lost.I personally think that the very best way for sight-seeing Asakusa and dodging those ongoing waves of tourists is to go and check out Sensou-ji and Kaminari-mon super early in the morning, have breakfast at one of the Kissa-tens (Japanese-style cafes if they are open), and then you begin wandering through the back streets. Otherwise, do vice versa (wander thru the back streets and check out Sensou-ji later on at night.) You'll be amazed by how uncrowded Asakusa is early in the morning and late at night.Additionally, don't be afraid walking into a restaurant, bars, etc,.with little or no ability in speaking Japanese as most local people and staff in Asakusa should be used to dealing with tourists. Get lost in translation. That's fun :-)

Great area. Asakusa feels like a smaller town within the big city. A visit to the temple is a must. If you are willing to spend some extra money, rickshaws can be hired for a tour around the area. They are located near the Temple and around the metro exit. Cost was 3,000 yen.
A Must-See. A visit to Tokyo would not be complete without a visit to Asakusa where you find the famous Sensoji Temple & Nakamise Shopping Street.

A must for your Tokyo trip. I'm having my Panasonic internship at the time of visiting. The iconic red latern and its gate is donated by Panasonic founder, Mr. Konosuke Matsushita. Souvenir shops and japan street food can be found along the street. Remember to try out the fortune-telling at the Senso-ji.

Nice and not so expensive neighborhood. The center of Japan is Shibuya and Shinjuku. But some of the best places are in Asakusa, a place where you can take a cruise through the Sumida River, visit the biggest Tokyo Shrine, a cat café, the Tokyo Sky Tree, and also find some of the cheaper hotel and hostels.

Asakusa /Sensoji Temple. Asakusa Kannon Temple is a Buddhist temple located in Asakusa.
It is one of Tokyo's oldest and most colourful temples.
you'll marvel at Nitenmon gate, bedecked with huge red paper lantern. The alley lined with souvenirs and hand made crafts can be purchased in Nakamise-dori.
It is a beautiful temple surrounded by gardens.

The past made visible. Just walking around the temple complex is an education in the cultural life in this ancient suburb, and some streets have been preserved to reflect how life would have been conducted centuries ago. The shopping is leisurely, personalised and the items we took home all the more precious to us

A necessary visit while in Tokyo. Easy access by Tokyo Subway.
Enjoy the small souvenir shops and food stalls enroute leading to the shrine.
Different from Shinto Shrine this is more of Buddhish Temple.
Lots of people come here to pray.
Visit this place any time and it is always busy.
Quite a sight
A must visit wile in Tokyo

Busy but a must see. We were on a Grey Line tour and only had 30 mins to visit which was enough for us as were dropped v close to the temple & so missed out on the souvenir shops other tripadvisors mentioned. Lots of good photo opportunities and nice it was free sight to visit.

Don't just visit Senso-ji - spend a half-day wandering around the neighborhood. Senso-ji! We make a pilgrimage to Asakusa each time we visit Tokyo. Don't head here just to visit the temples though. There is much to see throughout the district.A walk along the river and a visit to Sumida Koen to view sakura is a pleasant diversion.A carnival like atmosphere often pervades the streets: sometimes there are street performers and buskers to entertain with puppets, musical performances, miming, story-telling... Girls wander around dressed in kimono trying to look like Maiko, muscular men pull rickshaws for tourists, souvenirs shops, snacks shops, restaurants... It is all very touristy and a bit tacky, but such fun.We were looking for a yukata sash and found several for sale in the various kimono shops but they were quite expensive. Then we walked down Nakamise-Dori, lined with stalls selling souvenirs and religious items, the main approach to Senso-ji. Here we found several stalls at which to purchase the sash and we could bargain there and got an even better price.For some this whole area may just seem like Disneyland in the suburbs - it is definitely a tourist dominated site. Nevertheless, there are those who come to the temples to pay their respects.

Relaxing attraction. Asakusa is another famous district in Tokyo.One of the most popular destination in Asakusa is Senso-ji or people just simply call it Asakusa Temple. Asakusa temple is very crowded. Most of the people will go there pray for good luck I supposed.and also there are so many shops selling souvenirs and snacks along the Nakamise-dori Street, the street that run along the way to the temple.Once you see a large red lantern..that's the Kaminari-mon gate, Kaminarimon is the first of two large entrance gates leading you to Sensoji Temple. Hope you will enjoy the peaceful & relaxing walk around Asakusa.

The most famous Shrine in Tokyo. Asakusa is one of the most famous place in Tokyo. The big red lantern is a japanese icon. The Senso-Ji temple is a big temple with many souvenir setores around. It's a must see.

Beautiful tourism attraction . Had a great day walking around, enjoyed shopping for gifts and different types of foods, and loved the cart ride !! Its close to skytree so you can enjoy the night view from a distance then go there for dinner ;) A full day well spent

A quiet environment. Asakusa, unlike central part of Tokyo, is a bit quiet. You will enjoy walking around the neighbourhood. But then again, it has Sensoji temple, Nakamise street, and Sumida river cruise located nearby, which you should not miss!

Pretty, lots of great shops, kinda crowded.. We went out to Asakusa just to see the shrine and temple, but there was so much to do here! Lots of traditional craft and souvenir shops on the road leading up to the Senso-ji Shrine and around the area.It was very crowded. However, I still had enough space to enjoy some of the surroundings, including very beautiful paintings on the road's wall leading up to the gate. The gates are massive and quite impressive, with bright hues of reds. The shrine itself (as most Japanese shrines) is closed to the public, but offers many options to show your appreciation with fortunes, wood ash wafting, and monetary donation.I bought a few things around some of the shops nearby and a couple traditional Japanese treats which were very good. I would suggest looking around the streets adjacent to the shrine before you set off on another destination. Also, I wouldn't go at peak time. It really was more relaxing around sunset when less people were around.

Do by Day and Night. Asakusa is wonderful day or night, but the difference in atmosphere is significant, and warrents going twice or staying from mid-afternoon to post-twilight. The temple complex is beautiful and historic. The Sensou-ji Temple is Japan's oldest for commoners. The Asakusa shrine next to it (toward the river) dates the Tokugawa shogunate (built in 1649), as does the 300-year old gate leading to it. Other shrines, heat and small, are on all sides, in a small Japanese garden. The great gate leading to it, as well as the towering five story pagoda to the west, scream "photo op.". There are hordes of tourists answering that call. The lanes leading up to the great gate, and leading away from the area, are packed with stalls and shops, but you shop if you want; you're not harassed by hundreds of peddlers and "guides" as you would be at, say, the Mughal attractions of Agra or the Khmer ruins of Angkor Wat. With any luck you'll see kimonos a-plenty. November is the best time to see mothers in kimonos taking their three- and seven-year-old daughters to the shrines to give thanks for their good health, but I saw one mother and toddler daughter in Kimonos going to the Asakura shrine yesterday (perhaps thankful to have survived the typhoon that Tokyo earlier that day). I also saw a group of 20-year-olds. (3, 7, the 20-year coming-out and marriage day are the four traditional times Japanese women wear kimonos.)At sundown the merchants roll down there shutters, the tourists thin out a bit, and the Japanese lanterns all come on. Sensou-ji, pagoda, great gate are all illuminated, and the atmosphere is less animated, more serene. By the way, those storefronts don't lose their appeal when the shutters are down--they're all beautifully decorated with different Edo-period images. I'll post images of some main attractions by day and night, a typical Asakura storefront shuttered for the night, and an example of the Japanese lanterns at night--these were hanging over, of all things, the entrance to a parking lot on a side-street.To get there, go to Asakura station, exit A4, go around the block to the tourist center, take the lift to the 8th floor rooftop view to get your bearings, and off you go. Highest recommendation!

A highlight of Tokyo. We visited Asakusa as part of a Tokyo Tour, and probably would not have visited the area but for the tour. A long, colourful open market leads to the Sensoji Buddhist temple that was built in the 7th century. The foods on sale in the market were a highlight.
interesting. quite interesting place made even more precious thanks to the amazing temple. free entrance and very recommended

Grows on you. I was a little wary of the crowds and noise when I first arrived, but after 3 days I am sad to be leaving. It's a great area, temples and a slight air of seediness, cheaper shops and stalls, but some very good food shops and restuarants. There's also the chance of seeing Sumo wrestlers waddling down the street in full Japenese regalia, really atmospheric.

Don't go.... We started our trip in Tokyo and pumped up as we were we went to see this place. It was surreal, but the bad kind. So crowded, so commercial! It felt fake, like a Disneyland attraction. I would advice you not to go, but to go to Meji Jingu, way better!
Best temples of Tokyo. The atmosphere is really good in Asakura, even if it's a bit crowded ! We can find local food, nice souvenirs
asakusa. i saty at asakusa longer than the other place.. i love asakusa, many cultural place like a temple, shrine, souvenir shop, etc.. i can feel "japan" in here :D

Japanese version of Fauneil Hall. This is the Japanese version of Boston's Fauneil Hall, with lots of food stalls, souvenirs, and street performers. Gaijin won't feel out of place but it was nice that the crowd was mostly Japanese. It is a contrived, but gives a nice feel of old Edo.

The door to Japan tradisonal culture.. I'm surely you couldn't miss the big lantern icon on the front gate. Behind that gate, there's all sorts of Japanese snacks and souvenirs. It's a must visit place in Tokyo.
Other must visit place at Tokyo :
http://alwaysmissmandy.blogspot.com/2014/10/tokyo-2014.html
Heart of Shitamachi. Low season, and still full of people. Sensoji Temple is a must see and in front of Kaminarimon there's the best tourist support station you'll find in Tokyo. Good place to stay.

not to be missed. Sensoji Tenmple is not to be missed. There are shops, restaurants and all manner of unique places to see and experience. It is crowded in the mornings and early afternoon. Visit late in the afternoon to early evening.

The Holy Grail of Traditional Japan. Since I wasn't able to visit Kyoto, you'll be able to find a lot of men/women wearing Yukata and visiting Asakusa shrine.
Plus, find the best traditional Japanese souvenir (fans, yukata, slippers, keychains, etc.) here in Asakusa.

Fun Tokyo Experience. We spent a whole day walking through the streets and shopping stalls. It has a very relaxed atmosphere and an old "Asian" feel. It was fun watching different foods being made and trying new tastes. The better prices are on the side alleys off the Main Street. Some bargains can be found if you hunt for them. Many things made in China, so read the tags. It was a very pleasant experience.

Souvenir hotspot. Came here as a recommendation from Tokyo colleagues - it's an extremely busy place with lots of tourists!The temple itself is relatively newly built - not as old as the ones in Kyoto, but equally as interesting. The walk up to the temple lined with rows of souvenir shops which makes it the perfect place to pick up fridge magnets, teacup sets and other miscellaneous souvenir items for family and friends.We went on a Saturday afternoon and it was absolutely heaving - don't know if it would be better on a weekday.Worth going once, but doubt I will return to this area if I go back to Tokyo.
Asakusa. Took the train from Ueno to Asakusa. About a 5 minute walk from the train station. Great souvenir shopping, great little food kiosks, though it was very, very crowded.

Not Kyoto...But Pretty Close!. When we arrives at Asakusa, we quickly realized that there are still some small parts of Tokyo that have an older Japanese style feel to it, kinda what Kyoto makes you feel like with all of its temples and shrines.The area is about a 5-10 minute walk from the metro station and buzzing with tourists from all over the world. Asakusa is well known for all of its shopping on each side of the alley leading up to the temple and the shrine. There is so much going on from vendors, restaurants, shops and colorful Japanese banners hanging down everywhere you look.This place has to be high on things to prioritize on doing while on a short trip to Tokyo as you will find everything you need to bring back home as far as culture and food. This was definitely one of the highlights of our trip to Tokyo!

Busy temple/shrine area. This is probably the busiest and most typical temple/shrine complex in Tokyo. We arrived at the information center and took a free walking tour of the temple/shrine street. We then walked around in more of the area with shopping and restaurants everywhere. It was a fun afternoon.
Beautiful. Just walking around the area makes us feel very good. It's beautiful and 1 of my favorite places in Tokyo.

Touristy but love the area. Love the little shops and restaurants. You cannot go wrong with any of the restaurants, so just walk into any one that looks good! Also a little culture here with the temples, garden, etc. A fun little place to visit.

Souvinirs. I needed them. . I bought them. I'm glad. Vibrant. Extensive. Food. Fine gifts. Children's gifts. Nakemishi district. Best for me. Ricksaw rides. I even haggled with an Afgan for hand carved wooden elephant.
Great area for sightseeing and food. It's a very lively area with many shops and restaurants around. You could watch the city skyline and landmarks from the bridge which is spectacular.

Beautiful temple, lots of souvenir shops and tourists - but great experience. Asakusa is a uniquely Japanese experience you can't miss. It's a nice experience in that you enter and walk along a series of stores and shops and restaurants before you reach the temple, which is among the most impressive in Asia. This is an exceptionally well-maintained temple, a source of great pride for Japan, and it shows. If you're fortunate enough to visit during one of the Japanese festivals, you'll remember it for a lifetime. two tips - there are plenty of great local restaurants in and around the area - eat there, not somewhere else on the next leg of your tour. And, if you have kids, there's a charming but certainly well-aged amusement park right next door to the temple. Nothing fancy but great fun for an hour or two with the kids.

Nice Area !!. Touristy area in a lively neighbourhood of Tokyo. Lots of shops, Shrines Temples, and places to eat. Roasted chestnuts with warm sake on a cool November day is just what the doctor ordered. Bought a couple of very reasonably priced Kokeshi Dolls.

2 temples, 1 pagoda, lots of touristy souvenir shops, good to start river cruise!. I hate souvenir shops, so for me this place immediately ranks low as you have to go through/past several 100 shops to reach the temples.Quite interesting, this place combines a Buddhist temple and a shinto japanese religion temple in one location. Felt like the place was primarily visited by japanese, Korean and Chinese tour groups.Many lunch options there, so good to do temple plus lunch and then take the river cruise near the bridge going to Tokyo bay.

a beautiful street ~. This street looks beautiful with lots of shops at the sides selling snacks or souveniors. Tourist attraction as usual, overcrowded and hot during the afternoon time! Really impressive to have so many shops and even behind this street. Able to find some magnets which are only available here tho the price is a little higher. Try the snacks, looks good. Located right outside the entrace of the subway with a few walks away.

Tourist area, mainly. This area is worth a visit, but do not expect too much. It's sort of Brick Lane meets Camden Lock, with temples. There were quite a few traditionally dresses folk wandering about and you can hire a man-powered rickshaw, which might be a laugh. Lots of trinkets and "gifts" also plenty of food and drink. The temples are lovely, but the crowds detract from any reverence there might otherwise be.

beautiful but overcrowded. One of the few places in Tokyo with an ancient and historic aspect. The temples are impressive, but it is a tourist area. Overcrowded, it is a bit difficult to walk aroud among the shops and people. It is a living but congested neighborhood. Really impressive. It is a maze of restaurants, bars and shops.In the stores, there are all kinds of souvenirs, local food and beverages .. Take your time and look around

Sweets, souvenirs and other knacks. It is a great place to try some of the famous sweets of japan. Some you can bring back home and some you can eat while exploring the place. Nakamise shopping alley is not that huge so you can actually linger and visit each shop to look for souvenirs. But dont expect for cheap finds since price for magnets are usually 300-450yen. Tshirts are even higher albeit poor quality. We bought some daifuku here and try on their taiyaki.

Fun place to visit. Perfect place to spend a few hours wandering around the shops getting a few souvenirs and visiting the temples. It is also very close from here to catch one of the riverboat rides . Super easy to get to by subway.

nice!. Not as naturally authentich like kyoto, still a very nice place for strolling in tokyo. The gallery shops are worth a visit as well. Don't miss the food stands with inexpensive local food on the way to the temple.

Love this area!. The area is vibrant, close to Skytree and museums yet very cheap. Shops here when there are branches somewhere (like Don Quijote) is much cheaper here in asakusa. If you need to but something, better buy souvenirs here. its cheaper when you go out to Shinjuku and other area. Very safe as well

Old Edo. Asakusa is one of the best places in Tokyo. It brings back the old feeling of Edo, before Tokyo just became a massive metropolis. Stroll around the back streets behind Sensoji temple and you will find great little shops and restaurants.
A must visit . A beautiful place, cannot be missed. Experience Japanese culture and markets. The shrine and pagoda are gorgeous with a lovely river side walk nearby.

Don't waste your time unless you like tourist traps. Don't bother to come here. It's brimming with a sea of tourists and cheap trinkets. It is quite an unpleasant experience. Take the time to go to Kamakura about 45 min away. It's charming and the crafts you can find are made of better quality.

Best Place for shopping!. Buy chopsticks in bulk and then divide them amongst your family and friends back home! :D Also, look through the wonders of Japanese dolls and take one home! Swords, food, keychains, magnets, everything unde rthe sun is available here!

Best district in Tokyo and a bit touristy.. Well, if I can recommend this it's the top district in the city, I chose this area for my hostel a little 'by chance not knowing what I would find, but after coming here I realized that the choice I made was outstanding. A neighborhood alive even till late evening, congested with tourists during the day, perhaps because of the presence of the top shine and temples here in Tokyo Asakusa. Really impressive both day and evening with the lighting, this is also open at night and you can walk through the streets of the different temples. From here there is also near the river and the famous Sky Tree Tower. Beyond that is a tangle of restaurants, pubs and shops so much more. Absolutely a must-see Asakusa!

Great Place to Walk Around. There is a lot to see and do in this area. I highly recommend going to this area if you have time. There are a number of shops, restaurants, as well as the shrines that are worth seeing.

Nice and Quiet. Compared to many other areas of Tokyo, Asakusa was a nice and quiet area to stay. There are no huge buildings and no giant bustling shopping/electronics areas. It doesn't have the easiest access to the rest of the city on the metro (usually, you have to transfer once to get to where you want to go). As with the rest of Tokyo, there is plenty of places to eat in the area. Overall, a great place to stay if you don't care about being in one of the more popular places of the city.

Souvenirs. Good place to buy cultural souvenirs and to try local street foods. Also, nice place to take pictures with local people wearing kimonos/yukata. The place just seems so crowded with tourist and locals so I did have a hard time having a great picture with the temple.

Asakusa: Shrine experiences in urban Tokyo. Asakusa has a big temple shrine and very popular destination for Hanabi in Summer. The Sumidagawa Hanabi one of the popular Hanabi (fireworks) can be visible from near the shrine. Apart from that it is a wonderful experience to visit the temple during the New Year Prayer ceremony. Though it is super crowded but the midnight prayers are worth an experience. Moreover the shrine and its vicinity will provide you with a great shopping experience. Omeyage (gifts) especially Japanese Kimono/Yukata, a traditional Japanese umbrella, Japanese fans, lanterns, et al. You can always find something for yourself.Yup for a about 2000Yen you can get a Rickshaw ride all around the vicinity.
It's a place you want to visit again！. Many nice restaurant here，a place full of Japanese culture. You must visit when you are in Tokyo！

One of Tokyo's best attractions. The Asakusa temple is a must see when in Tokyo. The area is packed with good restaurants, small shops with local food and souvenirs. In addition, there are multiple restaurants in the area that serve great Japanese food.

Shrine, Souvenirs, Food all in once place. It is one of my favorite places in Tokyo. It is a must visit and I recommend half a day. After that a ferry can be taken to Odiaba for some shopping near the Asakusa station.

Busy Touristy Temple. Very busy temple in Tokyo which was rebuilt in the 1970's as the original was flattened in WW2. Reconstruction is excellent throughout from the temple gateway to the 5 story tower and the main temple. Lots of both Western and Japanese were there on the afternoon we visited. There are lot of small kiosk based shops around the temple, particularly on the way in from the Metro station selling all sorts of items from clothes and shoes to biscuits and ice-cream. At the temple itself you can have your fortune told by choosing a numbered stick and then receiving a piece of paper with the appropriately numbered fortune- it was very popular with the Japanese. I am glad we went but enjoyed the Hasadera Temple in Kamakura much better.

Asakusa Temples. This historic site is a taste of old Japan with original site being over 1,000 years old. several temples and peaceful Japanese gardens are a haven in the modern metropolis. This is also an ideal place to buy souvenirs for your friends and family back home with the prices and choices as good as anywhere. Easy to get to by metro rail.

Hustle and bustle of Tokyo. Asakusa is a cultural smorgasbord of food and souvenirs. The main highlight would be the temples. There's lots of cute Japanese stuff like charms, pouches, kimonos that are great to bring home. Do try the street food. I bought a green tea soft-serve ice-cream and we were not allowed to venture beyond the shop area. Customers have to finish their ice-cream first before moving on. This is a good way to maintain the cleanliness of the area!

Beautiful grounds and peaceful retreat from the City.. We stayed in Asakusa one night during our visit to Tokyo and were just around the corner form this temple/ shrine. The grounds and atmosphere are peaceful and an pleasant retreat from the business of the city. I also recommend the many shops and vendors located adjacent to the temple. This was a great start to a fantastic trip through Tokyo and Kyoto. Loved it!

Lovely small shops in front. This is one of the most important temples in the city and worth the trip. There are lots of small shops just in front of the temple where you can buy traditional souvenirs and food stuff. The temple itself has two big statues standing at the entrance, with lots of those red lanterns hanging around. All in all it will take you 1 hour on the site itself to see everything. Good for families, all flat.

Interesting, but touristy. Asakusa is a great place to stroll around. The areas surrounding the famous Senso-ji Buddhist temple are interesting to explore and are filled with fun little shops and restaurants, but they are kind of touristy. For me, that was ok, but not everyone will like it. The temple itself is nice, but during the high season extremely crowded as well. I would recommend coming here in the evening or at night as well to walk around. Everything is closed but the temple grounds are deserted and lighted beautifully.

A glimpse of old Japan. Interesting place to visit where there is the famous Asakusa Temple and rows of shops selling souvenirs and snacks (which i enjoyed trying =) Lots of eateries but do try learn some common names of the food. I couldn't eat at a particular eatery bec the owners couldn't communicate in English at all.

A bit of historical Tokyo. A great place to get a taste of historical, if touristy, Tokyo. The temple is impressive and the shops are charming. An added bonus is the fact that the public bathrooms are clean! It was lovely to see young Japanese in traditional yutaka walking around. Tokyo is encouraging people to dress traditionally with a series of promotions. I appreciate this effort to preserve and showcase Japanese culture.

Great place for sightseeing and souvenir shopping!. Asakusa is a beautiful shopping arcade that is great for buying souvenirs although after awhile, you will notice that each stand sells more or less the same gifts or same snacks. The place is usually pretty crowded but the entrance to Asakusa and the temple at the end are beautiful and great for taking pictures.

Tourists take note!. Another beautiful cultural part of Tokyo amongst the hustle and bustle. Great array of souvenir shops along with little tasting shops of different Japanese foods. The nearby Japanese gardens and temples make this a wonderful opportunity to see the old cultural Tokyo.I would certainly recommend spending a few hours here if you aren't going to have the opportunity to go to Kyoto.

One of my favourite neighborhoods.. I love Asakusa, all of the people are very friendly and there is so much to see and do and eat! There are lots of little areas to explore and buy souvenirs. Definitely worth a visit.
Great!. A must see in Tokyo. Wander the streets, and make sure you see the Sensoji Temple, too. Bring a fan if it's summer time - it will be hot!
Good for souvenir shopping. Fun way to find all those little items you want to bring home in one place. A good wander through endless streets.

Amazing Temple/Fun Shopping. We went to this temple early in the morning and we were not disappointed, the grounds were large and there were many great monuments and things to see. There are many signs in English which helped us understand the history behind the site. It is by far the temple I would recommend seeing in Tokyo most. As you are leaving the temple there is a great shopping street connecting to the main road, it has great souvenirs and at really good prices!

Amazingly culturally rich destination in Tokyo!! And you can see the Sky Tree a Tower from here!. I love Asakusa. It feels vibrant, energetic, crowded with both international & domestic tourists. Culturally enriched destination to experience Japanese culture, history and food. It is close enough to see the newest addition, the Sky Tree Tower from here! Must see!

Very nice place. This is exactly the place you would call TRADITIONAL for the city, very reflective of the Japanese Culture. This is a place you will see ladies in KIMONO and people wearing traditional clothing from Japan. We visited the area and witnessed a procession and traditional warrior parade, unique experience.
It is worth visiting. Nice shops and neighborhood.

Very nice place, highly recommended tourist attraction. Asakusa is a beautiful place with a beautiful temple,loads of shops and eatery places in here. Try to visit here on a weekend or on any special occasion day and you can find a lot of KIMONO clad ladies, the sight is beautiful to see people cherishing the tradition. In Asakusa, there is a shop which sells paintings, dont miss this place, though a bit on the expensive side but really worth memento to bring back from Japan.In the eateries, you can get a lot of different items here, like freshly pan fired cookiesThis place is a must in your travel list.

A Must Visit!. This place is a must if it's your first time in Japan!From the entrance all the way up to the shrine, there are rows and rows of shops selling an array of interesting itemsGive yourself a couple of hours to explore all the shops, to look, eat and buy.Good place to go souvenir shopping as it has the largest selection of interesting trinkets. You may or may not find your item cheaper elsewhere in Tokyo, but for the sake of convenience and variety, I would get it here. Ended up coming back again before I left Tokyo to finalize my shopping list.

Neat shrine and shopping spot. Pretty cool area. The shrine is very decorative and there is plenty of reasonably priced shopping. Close distance to the Sky Tree Tower so you would want to do both on the same day.
Lovely area. Shopping , souvenirs and food! Got the try the shaved ice! So good for a hot day especially after temple seeing!

Interesting area to wander around. We were staying in the neighbouring Ueno area and decided to take a look at Asakusa after a (rainy) day trip to Nikko. Nakamise shopping street area was nice to look around and see the different things available for sale. We enjoyed the restored 'old' streets and it was a nice area to soak in the atmosphere. There are lots of restaurants but we didn't notice many places with English menus.At night (we visited just before it got dark) the streets are lit up and look very pretty.

Great souvenir shopping with a shrine to boot. There were many tourists here when I came here on a weekday in July 2014. As expected of a tripadvisor locale that has a near 5-star rating. The souvenir shopping avenue that leads up to Sensoji Temple had a unique array of buyables I hadn't found things that I saw there from little shops elsewhere in Tokyo or Kyoto.

Amazing area!. Very cultural area. When you imagined Japan, this is the place you imagine. The whole area around the pagoda and temple is gorgeous. There is good shopping and eating in the area. The atmosphere is fun and lively. Be sure you get to this area!!!!!!! Stroll up and down the random streets.

MARVEL AT UNKNOWN CORNERS. Many tourists simply gravitate towards where the crowd gathers. Try to visit the periphery; there are many enchanting corners and little spots worth a photo and a respite from the long walk. The old trees are romantic, the little ponds so fascinating and signages so helpful. Asakusa does not always have to be a photographer's nightmare because of the crowd; there are little pockets of tranquility if one explores farther left or right. We were led to quaint shops and found interesting bargains there too.

Good but crowded. It is one of the greatest attractions in Tokyo. And it is really crowded during the daytime. I suggest you visit this place again in the night. It is calm, and lighting adds more aesthetic to the temple.
food and local snacks attraction. it is their food and local snacks that made me wanna visit there again. they have very nice and exquisite snacks that you don't get to get hold of it in town area.

Great old fashioned shopping. Wish we had started the day earlier in our visit to Asakusa and the Sensoji Temple. The shopping opportunities were endless with the many streets and alleys surrounding the temple. We ran out of time here before moving to next planned activity for the day. I would love to return to explore the city further. We visited the information center across the train station. People there were very helpful and spoke English.

Beautiful temple and interesting shops. This is a busy temple and shopping area for locals and tourists. Plenty of places to eat/drink in the locality as well as sit and relax in the shady small 'park' under the trees.

Shrine with marketplace. Quaint streets with various sellers made this historic site interesting to us. This is probably one of the more ancient yet must-see places in Tokyo. Check out the bottles with marbles in them, sold from carts!
Great to walk around and soak in Japanese life. Little lanes full of traditional japanese shops, the temples, and just observing life in this amazing city. The food choice is great as well.

good temple... day time i walk here a lot people and a lot shop for souvenir. you can walk to Donki department store very close.At night time you also can walk here.. it's sooooo quiet and romantic... i walk here with my girl... and feeling so happy..

Too crowded to be a pleasurable experience. The shrine itself is an amazing example of Japanese culture, but the whole experience is more like being at a state fair. Between the main gate and the temple lies a long row of food and trinket vendors hawking fried food and key chains. We wouldn't make the effort to go back, as there are so ma.y other landmarks to see without feeling as though you're being herded through a tourist trap.
Descent Place. A good place for walking around good shops also around! Place to visit if you are in Taito Area. There are many narrow roads going around which takes you to many hidden area too!
Old Tokyo Feel. I can imagine this was how all central Tokyo must have been like before urban development and skyscrapers. Beautiful little area to wonder around to shop, eat, drink and explore!
Metro Takes You Anywhere. Excellent location to take the Metro. Many small market like shops, and small streets to walk around in tranquillity.

a little bit of old Tokyo. I was reading about old Edo and wanted to see it for myself. Well, you can see a little: the old temple Senso-Ji, other religious sites, and all the market stalls around it, are very beautiful and well worth a visit. It may be a bit disappointing though, as so much of old Edo has been burnt and destroyed. So, this is mainly a late twentieth century area, in terms of buildings. But, you do get a sense of Japanese tradition, and the area feels very Japanese in spite of the many tourists. It is also a very good place to shop, with a good range of Japanese goods.

must visit temple in tokyo. when we get here..the weather was so rainy. so if you want to go here around may.. prepare your umbrella. the area consist several building. one of the main temple is like pagoda buildingyou can find many souvenir shop in this area too. the most i like is buy dorayaki cookies.so my advice visit this temple when its rainy..becouse when rainy there are not many place to stop

Experience of Edo time. In Asakusa, you can see and probably feel the amazing Japanese culture when passing by different temples and traditional buildings.Its also excited to draw a stick (Kind of fortune telling practice in China and Japan) from the bucket by paying 100 yen. Then we could get a written fortune according to the number on the stick. I really like the content written in Kanji (Chinese character) being a Chinese and a Japanese learner. But for non-Chinese and non-Japanese speakers, they may also refer to English translation.There are many lovely souvenirs and local snacks selling on the main street and visitors can also have a taste of traditional tempura for which Asakusa is famous.

old japan heritage. Asakusa is a perfect place if you want to feel old japan and what they believe in.also if you want to buy souvenirs there are a lot of shops selling there traditions.a good advice try not to visit if it is rainy.

Favourite Area of Tokyo. Asakusa is definitely a must visit area if you're planning to go to Tokyo. The temple is a little busy but has a great atmosphere. The markets are definitely a great place to visit for food stands (ice cream, rice crackers, taiyaki, shaved ice, etc.) as well as decent priced souvenirs for friends and family. My dad ended up bulk buying ¥500 boxes of mochi and daifuku which he had to carry around while we walked around the area and also later in Odaiba which we went to via river boat cruise.

hmmmmmm, another temple,（Sensoji temple. another temple and a very large one but, not really worth the trouble of going to, its not the most beautiful,, it has the feeling and look of disney land, if you like to be stuck in a slow moving mass of people then this is the place for you,
Pure japanese culture everywhere!!. Amazing Japanese culture,everything in walking distance and local people are friendly and helpful a must see for first time visitors to Tokyo!!

My favorite destination in Tokyo. Been to Tokyo many times for leisure & work and always ensure I make a trip to Asakusa. Sensoji temple and the beautiful stalls lining along the path make the place unique and special. You can also see Skytree from Asakusa.

Stunning Temple. Beautiful temple with surrounding grounds to explore. Lots to see and do here; one end is the temple with cool areas surrounding the main building which few people seem to check out. Have a walk around the outside of the main building to find lots of interested things to look at. Walking away from the temple you will find shopping. The only downfall is that it's really touristy with bus loads of people here so it was very crowded, don't let that deter you though.

very traditional feel in tokyo. Asakusa was my favourite part of tokyo - yes there were a lot of stalls selling tourist focussed gear. But it seemed like Japanese shopped here just as much as tourists. Also in Tokyo/Japan, tourist stalls are far less obtrusive than in other countries. Here, there are important shrines and temples, traditional buildings and ryokans, as well as proximity to transport for other parts of tokyo.

Tokyo souvenir shop. People tends to go to Asakusa first thing on the day of the tour, i think it'll be great if this could be visited at the end of the day, as you will shop a lot in here ^_^ for they have cheap prices and so many things to buy #shopaholic alerts!

A good taste of Japanese culture. In Tokyo it is easy to get distracted by the tall buildings and neon lights - so it is nice that this temple and area is more Japanese-y, albeit tourist orientated. A must-see if you are in the Tokyo area.
Great to wander. Tokyo is full of interesting neighborhood. This area is close to cruise pier. It is a good logistics to stop by before or after the cruise. But will not pay specific visit.

Senso-ji shrine, pagodas, shopping, sweet bread and rice cakes. Asakusa has left a very good impression on me. There were a lot of nice picturesque spots. You have shopping all the way to senso-ji which is the temple located in Asakusa. Traditional sweet bread was great along with the freshly cooked rice treats! Best of all, accessible within the Tokyo Metro subway.

worth a visit. my last temple i've seen in japan, ofcourse there too much temple more worth a visit but next time.there are too much shops selling japanesse traditional souvenirs at the entrance of this temple.. You can buy souvenirs at reasonable price while you're in the temple visit. touristic place, peoples praying in the courtyard of the temple..old city Asakusa. shops,souvenirs,foods side by side.. and very easy to transport.. enjoy your holiday

Asakusa - must visit when in Tokyo. I love Asakusa bcos of the slow pace here compared to d other part of Tokyo. The shrine is beautiful n if time, explored side track n u can see more things. If u r thinking of buying those souvenir at those side stalls, let me tell u this - the duty free shop at Narita airport is much cheaper there. Whatever they sell here, u can find it at d airport duty free shop. So just head straight to d shrine. Sumida river is nearby - having a stroll along d river is also quite nice.....it will lead u to d Asakusa subway.

Easy to Find. By train, it's an easy walk from the exit. Place is well spread out and not cramped. There are guides who might ask you to hire them and you ride in their version of tuk tuk. but otherwise, it is an easy stroll. Go in the early afternoon when it's not so hot. There are souvenir shops selling japanese must haves on your list. A few food stalls are also there and on the right side is a big covered shopping/food area. Touch the big slippers for good luck and light a candle for more luck. A must.

Ok for a stroll. Went here for one afternoon as I had one day free during my business trip. It was Saturday and really busy... I think it was too crowded. The tempel was ok, I liked the outside more than the inside. Gardens are nice to stroll. Also the neighborhood is nice to walk around, although I didn't like much of the shops, it's all the same.

Quiet and traditional. Asakusa is the place to be to enjoy quiet and traditional japanese culture. People speak just very little english, but are helpful with all you'll ask them. it won't be easy to find a restaurant with an english menue, but go for the adventure and try something new!!!

Great area. Asakusa is one of districts that I preferred in Tokyo. My guesthouse was located there, and I enjoyed staying in this area. It is a relatively quiet one, and a good mix between modernity and tradition. There is plenty of Japanese restaurants (sushis, ramen, tempuras...) and souvenir shops. I liked the little streets around the Senso-ji temple. It is easy to get around from and to Asakusa, to the extent that there are a couple of subway lines that gets there.

Worth a stroll through the crowds... Tons of little eateries to be had, a green tea to cool off on a hot day, snacks to sample and purchase, just follow the tourists..tons of people and stroll through the little shops!Too many people?Just go on your own and discover what the natives has to offer and you can take pics. Of sky tree from the streets nearby while site seeing....Cheers!

perfect for sightseeing and shoping. Asakusa in one of my favorite tourist destination in tokyo. It has a traditional atmosphere, perfect for sight seeing. And also a place to buy souvenirs with reasonable prices

Dream Come True!. I read about Asakusa in my sophomore year and was amazed about its magnificent review. So I said to myself I'd like to visit this magnificent temple if I ever get the chance to go to Japan. So when I went there, it was like a dream come true! It was as great as the review and even better! You will find amazing Japanese temple combined with their authentic culture. Also, you will find lots of mouthwatering food stall along the way. Its a must visit place!

A traditional place in a 22nd Century town !. When I first started traveling to Tokyo in 1989, I decided to live (for months on end) at a ryokan (a kind of rough "inn", tatame as a mattress and no pillows. Rooms divided up by rice paper walls and you're up at 5am , no matter what. It's because of the carps screaming (and they do scream loud just as cocks and hens), or because of the ryokan owner or manager is chucking out of your room. Then, it's quickly down to a Japanese breakfast (rice, salmon, seaweed, pumpkin and NO SIGHT of coffee) and, right after that, into a hot / boiling bath. And you MUST be out by 11am. The place is NOT a hotel so, you're encouraged to find things to do all day long.Asakusa is a Shinto district of Tokyo - not that far from Ueno Train Station, and it's traditional costumes and customs and eateries are notorious. This is the beauty of Japan: the old and the new, the super old and the super new, living side by side.Enjoy your stay.LOVEGerald Thomas

Best tourist shopping in Tokyo. This is my 2nd time to Asakusa temple with 3 friends in May 2014. Overall I would highly recommend this place as one of the best places in Japan (along with Kyoto centre) for tourist souvenir shopping. There are an array of things you can buy, for example: traditional Japanese clothes, swords, porcelain Maneki-neko (cats), saki and tea sets, chopsticks etc. There is also a Studio Ghibli store here. At the end of the street of shops, there is the Asakusa temple which is reasonably nice with both traditional prayer sticks and traditional hand washing facilities. The park area on the left the temple is worth a visit as well.

worth a walk. I guess most people do come to Asakusa and visit the Sensoji temple. It is quite a touristy district due to popularity of the temple, but the area is quite pleasant to walk around. There are numerous small temples, various shops and some old-world stuff around.

Really overcrowded! . I went to Asakusa yesterday based on some of the feedback from people I've met. However, I felt that it was really over crowded with people arnd souvenir shops, which made the trip there less than pleasant. Perched on top of the steps just before entering the temple, you'd get a good view, but other than that, half the time, you'll be trying to make your way through the crowd. In my opinion, it was really tourist oriented, but for me, I'd prefer one which is quiet and give me time to look around! And I felt like this place had lost it's authenticity to the overcrowding and commercialization

Worth the hype. It's near the top of most to-do lists in Tokyo and is worth it. The rows of souvenir & snack stands are fun -- take cues on what to buy from kids that swarm here after school. The temple is worth a visit - look for other small shrines along the sides and the pagoda as well.

For That Old Tokyo Feel. Asakusa is both old and modern. Streaming with tourists by day, quite by night. This is where the famous Sensoji Temple is, and of course, the Nakamise Shopping Street, where you can get souvenirs a lot cheaper that in souvenir shops (ex Tokyo Skytree, Hello Kitty, Sumo, magents and key chains, and almost everything else!) You can also shop for inexpensive shoes and clothes on the adjacent covered streets. It does't matter that this is very touristy, it really is a great place to go, shop and eat.

Great Area with Nice Shops. We stayed here for about three days an explored the area quite a bit. I think one of my favorite things about this area were the small shops. There were quite a few little stores that were very cool and a lot of them had a lot of neat things about them. There were not a lot of food vendors (actually common in Japan from what I found) but there were a lot of vendors with many small unique gifts. Be aware that these shops don't open until around 10 and start closing around 4ish

Worth the Visit, Awesome Shopping. The shrine is amazing! Your photos will be the envy of your friends when you return home and show them your pictures. What I didn't expect was the awesome shopping right in the area. This is THE place to do your souvenir shopping, promise! Think Christmas gifts, no matter what time of year you visit.

OMG. This was so full or culture and beauty, exactly what i was looking for on my trip across the world. It was crowded but that definitely was not a distraction in being able to see the beauty and learn so much from these gorgeous temples, and shrines. Lots of suoviners shops

A combination of shopping and calm. We loved this place, a lot of people, in the Nakamise street, that provides the visitors with traditional snacks and tourist souvenirs..
The main attraction is Sensoji,a very popular Buddhist temple, we highly recommend to take the one day tour with Japan Gray Line Co, Ltd,(reservation@jgl.co.jp) they are amazing

Crowded but beautyful. Packed with people, many of them praying, many tourists as well, lots of them both.
Stunning shrine, huge! Bright colors!

The crowds, the shops, the food---all mingled with the scent of incense.. The idea is to walk slowly and absorb what you see. It's also satisfying to buy and eat everything that catches your fancy:) Good place to buy stuff for the people back home.
busy and calm together. Although it can be quite busy around Asakusa there is a calmness to be enjoyed. This applies not only for Sensoji temple but for the quarter itself.

Worth the visit . I visited the temple on my way to skytree building , it was a regular Japanese temple but what really made it special is all the stores around it selling all kinds of traditional Japanese clothes and some restaurants .

Lovely Neighbourhood. A beautiful temple, a variety of Japanese restaurants and tasty treats in street stalls and little shops selling everything from masks to tea sets. We loved getting lost in the many little streets around Asakusa, discovering all sorts of special treasures that we brought back as souvenirs of our trip. The dumplings, the tempura . . . take advantage of all the wonderful food and just try it.
Large Temple teeming with visitors. Very attractive site in centre on busy tourist area (it was there first!). Well worth a visit. Quite a few aggressive touts trying to get you into a rickshaw.
Great place to visit. We went there for the recent festival and while it was busy it was a great way to see the culture and local shops

Asakusa Temple - Worth A Visit. Asakusa temple is beautifully designed, and involves multiple buildings. While a major tourist area, it is a functioning temple. If you visit Tokyo, it's definitely worth a visit. Asakusa temple is surrounded with little eateries, and shops with beautifully crafted traditional Japanese merchandise.

Must see in Tokyo. I absolutely love visiting Asakusa. As you walk up to the temple, you walk through Asakusa's shopping street. There's a variety of goods you can purchase - from wooden, hand carved or hand painted Japanese dolls or masks, to clothing and accessories. There are also some great food vendors -- ice cream on a hot day, and I'd recommend the red bean cakes which are delicious. There's also a great senbei shop towards the last half of the shopping street. The temple itself and the grounds are peaceful and nice to walk around. There are a lot of food vendors out on the weekends. It's almost always busy, since it's a huge tourist attraction and a popular place for the Japanese to visit as well. There's much more shopping and more restaurants on the side streets branching off away from the temple too. It's a great place to visit.

Great Fair. I went to Asakusa after check in at the hotel in the evening taking subway from Shinagawa. It was a little bit challenging taking a subway coz there is no English when buying a ticket but it was so fun...finding through the number. Finally we got to Asakusa and good luck there was a fair, very traditional with many local Japanese food venders, parade and many local people. I really love that atmosphere! And i didnot miss to take pictures under the big lantern.

Nice temple, shrine and pagoda plus souvenirs galore. Nice area in the midst of market style shops and very busy too. Temple is one of the few you don't need to take your shoes off and can photograph. Garden area ok but nothing special. Good place to move on to the Sky Tree from. One stop across the road at the Asakusa station.

We were positively surprised!. Asakusa has a lot to offer. Me and my girlfriend stayed there for 10 days and it was the central point for our adventures. From Asakusa station, we travelled everywhere in Tokyo. It had everything we needed and it is lovely to explore the temple, shops and restaurants. We are going back to Japan this year and we are going to stay in Asakusa again!
One of our fav's. This was one of our favorite "districts" in Tokyo. Loved strolling the streets, found great restaurants (on Trip Advisor), really loved the flavor of this piece of Tokyo.

A city of contrasts. A city of contrasts: locals walking their dogs at night, old temples, noodle shops, KTV's, even an English pub and brewery, 24 hour department stores selling sexy clothes, boutique restaurants ... this are has it all. A good place to be based to see Tokyo.

Really nice place to visit in Tokyo. The temple complex is a nice place to visit, it is so interesting and you can spend a lot of time looking around and soaking up the atmosphere. You can take loads of pictures, look at the temples and statues and shop in the little souvenir stores. I would recommend to anyone visiting Tokyo!

one of the best Experience of Tokyo ~. One of the best attraction ~ it is just near to the metro station as well just follow the attraction board Sensoji Temple ~ it have offer a rickshaw ride tour by 2Person in 1 rickshaw by strong young man~ they will park their rickshaw nearby and do stand and asking you have a nice tour~ i feel you might try it , that's great experience at Asakusa~ as well you also can rent with Kimono Experience at Asakusa that is offer visitor back to oldest Japan , it make you unforgettable visit~ it will via a shop street to the Sensoji-Temple ~ it offer alot of Food , Souvenir , some old toys as well ~ you can do some bargain for the souvenir you to buy ~ not much but you can get 1 extra for free as well~ it very close to Tokyo Skytree (By View Only)

Handy if you are short on time. Asakusa provides a lot of experiences and sights that are typically Japanese in a nicely compact area. It has good train connections to the rest of Tokyo and sits at the end of Ginza metro line. A short walk brings you to Kaminarimon (Thunder) Gate - which is the famous one with the giant lantern hanging over the entrance. Inside is a narrow pedestrian street Nakamise which is lined with shops selling kitsch trinkets and snacks. At the end is one of Tokyo's best temples Senso-ji. It's a busy temple with people trying all sorts of good luck and fortune telling activities. Back near the metro station a bridge crosses the Sumida River from where you will have a great view of Tokyo Sky Tree and the unusual Asahi Building with the gold swirl on top.
Worth a stop. Good place to get away from the shopping and hustle of the rest of tokyo. Make sure you arrive early enough to miss the school trips.

Should be your first stop on your first visit to Tokyo.. If Tokyo is your only stop in Japan, or your first time in Tokyo, this is the must-do for the experience and the souvenirs, especially if you have not visited many temple complexes. Here you will find working temples and their grounds crowded with tourists, patrons and pilgrims. Spend a few yen to pull a fortune (don't forget to tie it to a tree or line if it's bad to keep it from coming true), learn how followers purify themselves before entering the temple, and get in line with the Japanese and eat whatever they're having.Spend an easy three hours taking photos of the temples, gates, shrines and gardens then shopping and dining in the stalls that line the street to the temple or the arcade just a half block away.

Nostalgia of Asakusa. After reading about the history of the Asakusa's oldest temple, Sensoji, and then taking the sunset stroll walking from the street vendors to the temple, a movie scene plays around you as you can see/feel the goddess of Kannon's spirit in the air. What did the spirit see when she returned to this beautiful spot. The night lights of the temple and the light rain falling made it so much more nostalgic

A must see precinct in Tokyo. Clean, safe, un-hurried and pollution free - make sure you vist the many atractions in Asakusa when in Tokyo. Great shopping, great food and excellent transport options make Asakusa a popular place to stay.

Great start of my Japan trip. This was the first stop of my Japan trip. Such a typical Japanese place with all the buildings and temples, very traditional.Good place for photo opportunities.You can also see Tokyo Tower from the temple.And most interesting spot is the shopping strip. From food to souvenirs, very wide range.

Simply Beautiful!!. Go early, best before 10am to avoid the major crowd!!Good place to get some souvenirs.Nice small food stalls incase you are hungryKaminarimon is the gate at the beginning of the area and its close to Asakusa station making it for easy access.Sensoji temple is definetely quite a spectacle, must see are in Asakusa!

AWESOME. I felt in Love with Asakusa!The temples and architectures are amazing, not even mentioning the stunning nature and sculptures around.You can find so many shops salling traditional japaneses things like theater masks, kimono, getta scandals, fans, and. And also food food food!You absolutely need to visit it if you can and take the time to soak yourself in this strange but fascinating atmosphere !
Pleasant visit. Go early in the morning before tour groups start pouring in. After walk-around temple, just in time for shopping

Nice neighborhood to shop and visit the shrine. Nice place to spend a couple of hours. So many stalls with different and interesting foods, temples. Shopping is defnetly cheap here but irecomend going not on the main street for it.

Nice shopping street. It's easy to move around, just by a cross, with the Thunder gate as main and SensojibTemple at the end.Go the Tourist Center Tower and get a free nice view of the cross at it's rooftop.
Nice place. There's a cool market just beyond the torii gate entrance. You can donate done change and day a blessing.

kimono experience in asakusa. Wonderful experience ...we walked around sensoji temple. All the tourists were clicking our photos we felt like some celebrities !! If you are visiting Japan then you have to take this kimono session.
http://www.sakuraphotokimono.com/

Interesting town...love it. We stayed at Shinjuku and It's quite easy to get to Asakusa by Subway. It's an interesting town with lots of traditional eateries, souvenirs shops and beautiful temple like Sensoji. It's an old town in within the modern Tokyo. It;s worth a visit, make it the first destination when you are in Tokyo.

lively tourist town. lots of souvenier shops and eateries, there is a trishaw ride in old Japan style and you can even see Tokyo Skytree and Asahi building. people we met is friendly and the shop keepers are honest with their pricing. Amazing place to visit

Old Town. We walked from Ueno Station into Asakusa. it was quite different to the other commercial areas of Tokyo…more like old Tokyo with traditional shops and houses. Once off the main streets it was good to amble along narrow lanes and stumble upon temples and shrines. Kappabashi Street has an enormous variety of kitchen/cooking related merchandise at reasonable prices.Sensoji Temple is there and the Nakamise shopping street leads from the temple grounds.

Loved this part of town. I was amazed by Asakusa. There was beautiful temples, nice gift/souvenir-shops, an older feeling to the time, you could see Sky Tree from there, a nice little park and a wonderful atmosphere. The restaurants are very nice too!!I can only recommend everyone to pay Asakusa a visit. :D

Feels like old Tokyo. If you are tired of seeing all the modern attractions Tokyo has to offer, visit Asakusa and get a feel of how Tokyo was during the old days. Asakusa has a very traditional feel and you can visit both the Sensoji Temple and Asakusa shrine if you want to soak in and pay respect to Japan's religious beliefs. Lining the street leading to the temple, you can shop for souvenir items (found a store that sells samurai swords) and dine at the local restaurants nearby (we ate at Daikokuya known for its ebi tendons "tempura rice bowl"). If you love takoyaki, you must definitely try the Gindaco stall located in a road leading to Sumida Park. For those with a sweet tooth, the place also has numerous sweet shops selling traditional sweets you can only find in Japan.

Second time. Second visit. Its a good place to get your souvenirs for friends. A lot of souvenir store selling key chains, decorations, Japanese snacks, Tshirts and even yukata. There are quite a numbers of restaurant in this area too.

Beautiful but busy. This is a really lovely area of Tokyo and the shrines there make it a great alternative to the bustling and modern areas like Shibuya and Shinjuku. Besides visiting the shrines to pay your respects (which you must!) there are great little cafes, bistros, and novelty shops. A great place to bring just about anyone. One of my favourite parts of visiting there was being able to sit in on a ceremony of the blessing of objects. It was a wonderful insight into the world of Japanese traditions and a rare opportunity.My only complaint is that since it's such a large tourist area it can be very crowded and difficult to take photos. I'd try going during the weekdays when it's not quite so crowded.

not too crowded. we like stay at asakusa, the place so peacefull and not so crowded like in shinjuku or shibuya. One of the best shopping market in town (Nakamise shopping street) just next to the sensoji temple

First Stop for my Guests. Whenever I have people visiting, I make sure to take them to Asakusa for a little bit of the flavour of old Japan. Ideally, we get there on the water-bus, travelling on the Sumida river. The big red lanterns of the Thunder gate, the Kaminari-mon, are very impressive and it is fun to stroll down the avenue towards the temple, with old boutiques on each side. Lots of kitsch, lots of food and a few lovely shops. Please be aware that not every item sold there is actually made in Japan, however. The main temple at the end is interesting, for sure, but there are also several other beautiful temples and statues in the surrounding area. All in all, although Asakusa is full of tourists, I rate it as one of the best Tokyo attractions. Nearby: Ueno and Kappabashi.

A great place. This is a bustling and fun place to wander, try a very local restaurant, visit the shrine pick up a souvenir or two or some fresh baked biscuits. Has to be high on any visitors list. Very easy to access on the metro.

Not to be missed. Just when I was thinking that Tokyo does not have anything extraordinary to show to me, I came here and was floored. The place was full of people with children and elderly people having a great time. You can shop souvenirs till you drop, keep snacking or just stroll around. The whole place has a very festive feel to it. The temple in the end is also quite crowded but still exudes a lot of peace. Loved it

pefect place for western beginners to enjoy Japanese temples. this is what westerners expect and where we take foreign people who come to visit us in tokyo. (i would never come here with my wife - we would go to more quiet, less travelled temples). if you come here, come early when it is not inundated with tourists. also good place for souvenirs...

Our #1 place to take visitors to Tokyo. We live in the Tokyo area and often take our visitors to the Asakusa area. Besides the incredible Sensoji temple, there a great Japanese clothing (yes, clothing), and a fun drum museum that is a hit with kids and adults. It's right on the river and has great fun stuff shopping too. Highly recommended!

My favourite visit in Tokyo. This was my favourite tourist site in the entire Tokyo trip. It has everything - history, good snacks, good photo opportunities and easy access. First thing on arrival is to check with the local tourism office for maps of the area. Then head across the road towards Sensouji Temple, through the Kaminarimon Gate and via Nakamise street, with its local snack and souvenir stalls. Do also visit the surrounding streets and other sites such as Asakusa Shrine and the Edo Shitamachi Traditional Crafts Museum.If you have the time and inclination, head west towards the Kappabashi Kitchen Ware Town (about 15 minutes walk), a kilometre-long stretch where you can find all things kitchen related, from baking ingredients to utensils, cutlery and plates. One of the notable sights are the shops selling life-like plastic food. Alternatively, head east to Sumida Park and Tokyo Skytree.

Great Souvenirs and Treats. If you want to buy Tokyo souvenirs, and see a temple this is the place to do it! The temple is beautiful and you can participate in the local traditions, such as burning incense or pulling our your good or bad fortune. I am still kicking myself for not buying a kimono at the shops nearby, so definitely shop here. Make sure you buy yourself a treat, such as a steamed bun with red bean paste (local specialty) or one of the small cakes you see them making via some metal molds, delicous!

Buzzing, and best souvenir hunting ground. The shrine does look great, but I went hunting for souvenirs, which I had found challenging in some other parts of Tokyo. There are loads of stalls on the main drag up to Senso-ji, but some of the best shops are just off to the side. I bought some typical souvenirs, a very cheap bag (for hold luggage), and a cool furoshiki.

Famous are because of Sensouji.. Came here to see Sensouji temple. But there was more here than expected. We decided to walk from here to Tokyo skytree. We found a river cruise, nice park along the river with cherry blossoms, street vendors selling all kinds of snacks and souvenirs. Most importantly Sensouji temple, which was extremely crowded. Plenty here to keep you busy for several hours. We left here by cruise in the evening to go to Odaiba for a night viewing over the harbor.

Really interesting area. There is a lot to do from here. Make your first stop the Asakusa Culture Tourist Center which is signposted from Asakusa metro station. They will help you with maps and directions on where to go. On the list should be the temple complex that is Sensouji Temple. the kitchenalia street that is Kappabashi, the boat ferry that is Tokyo Water Cruises ... Drum Museum, World Bags & Luggage Museum ... the list goes on and on ... All very safe, all very easy to negotiate - definitely go for a great day out
Great area, great views. we went down to Sumida Park and Senso-ji Temple and it was a great place with a very relaxed atmosphere

Lovely place. If you would like to experience the old traditional Japan but have limited time to spend in Tokyo, this is the place to go. Traditional Japanese town like Kawagoe is a few hours ride from Tokyo, so alternatively head to Asakusa. Getting here is easy. Just take the Metro Ginza Line (Orange) and stop at Asakusa or you can take Toei Asakusa Line (Pink). At the station, take exit number 1 and in a few steps ahead you will reach the grand Kaminarimon gate, you won’t miss it. There’s a lot to see, from the temple to pagoda to other surrounding buildings. Nakamise street leading towards the temple is souvenirs haven. You could even buy samurai sword or Shuriken and bring home (if it’s allowed :D)A very nice trip indeed.

What I imagined Japan to be!. Well worth a visit. Easy to get to. It was exactly what I imagined Japan to be like. The buildings are beautiful! Really enjoyed seeing women in traditional dress. Spend 100Y and pick a fortune from a box.
A must see in Taito. very well preserved, one of the best place to buy japanese items and souvenirs. this is one shrine where you can go inside to check it out

A must see in Tokyo. Take the time to visit Asakusa. Walking through the temples is a very Japanese experience. Spend the time to visit the shopping arcades and have an adventure trying some of the food.

Calm but central. Asakusa is a part of Tokyo where you don,t have to feel stressed as a westener. There is plenty to see. Take a look at this to get a feel of how this part of Tokyo is: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=14gKm53zgt4
Nice and awesome pedestrian street. . A lovely pedestrian street. Definitely worth going to have a look. Well recommended yo all. Selling lots of souvenirs and snacks.

Souvenirs Galore. If you need to buy souvenirs with little time left, this is the place. From expensive kimono to keychains, rice cakes and candies, traditional Japanese items – all in that tourist packed pedestrian street, Nakamise Street. Some are slightly more expensive than those I found in Kimakura or even the boarding lounge in Narita itself (buy those rice cakes in the departure launge). But, for varieties, this is it. I got what I came for, no, not the temple; fridge magnets, keychains, fancy rice cakes – typical Asian bring-home souvenirs. It is quite a distance from Tokyo (with transfer too) but I figured it was worth it February, with a photo taken with the Tokyo Skytree in the distance – snow and all.
Worth seeing. Swwn this on a tour while is was snowing.. very nice and worth seeing with small shops at the front. Overall 4/5

Calm amid the chaos. I've been to Tokyo twice, both times for business, so we typically don't get a chance to get out to see much. Maybe this is why I enjoy Asakusa and the Temple area. Traditional Japanese with beautiful colors and details. The temple was closed when we got there around 6pm, but the some of the shops were still open, selling sweets, toys and touristy items. There's a garden close by as well and just walking down this quiet area was a great way to end the day. A few blocks over are plenty of restaurants and we tried all sorts of dishes - sashimi, yakatori, local beer. It's a great area to see True Tokyo even if you only have a little time to spend.

Nice for a walk but busy. The temple itself is nice & much more elaborate than the others I've seen in Tokyo. There's a market that goes along the entrance but it feels like it's mostly a tourist trap. Stay off the main area & get your souvenirs somewhere else.

Stay a night here..... I recommend staying a night in asakusa. You can store large suitcases at your next hotel and just bring an overnight bag.Asakusa has many places to eat and shop, so apart from the shrine, take a walk around the place. Visit the shrine also in the evening when all the lights are on also. There is another place called akasaka, which is a different place. Asakusa is the last station on its line.

Asakusa - Great base to explore Tokyo. After doing a bit of research on Trip Advisor and other sites I decided that Asakusa would be a good base for a short stay in Tokyo. I stayed at Ryokan Kamogawa, a affordable Japanese style hotel in a great location in Asakusa. It was very easy to find, coming from the Asakusa (Ginza line) station.The Asakusa temple is one of the most popular tourist destinations, so there are the usual crowds. The Nakamise shopping street is crowded from the Kaminarimon gate to the temple with shops selling foods, souvenirs, cards, and stuff. The surrounding streets that parallel Nakamise st. have nice restaurants, nicer shops, bakeries, and a great place to get a massage. Across the street from the Thunder Gate (Kaminarimon Ave) is the Asakusa Tourism Cultural Information Center in a very modern building. They have English speaking help for tourists and a lot of local information. Very Helpful! They can tell you more about the 3 buses that run around Asakusa and have stops at attractions. I think they are free??? Tourist buses. I walked along the street that is the southern border of the Temple to Kappabashi Dogugai street (Pottery, restaurant equipment, kitchen wear) through the entertainment district, past 'Don Quiote', (a 6 floor food/department store), down narrow streets lined with residences and shops to Kappabashi. The Asakusa area I explored had enough English words to get by. I never had a problem communicating. The subways were easy if you paid attention. I'm going to stay in Asakusa my next trip to Tokyo.

Great area. You have two metro lines connecting at Asakusa and it is easy enought to move around. The area is very nice and less chaotic than many other parts of Tokyo and it has what left of the old city. With an amazing temple and a great makert it's a must visit area

Asakusa. Bought my fair share of tourist tat down the streets in the stalls, but it is a great experience. The temple is breathtaking, huge, and great for photo opportunities.Compared to some of the newer areas of Tokyo this felt much more of a traditional area, and as my hostel was so close I was glad to be in the middle of it all!
you're looking fo Tokio Souvenir? here is the place. took Asakusa line to reach it, there was an elevator up to the main street near Asakusa temple..just few walk from the place for Souvenirs stuff

Something really special. I arrived to Asakusa from Chiyoda district. It is really an other face of Tokyo. Near to the Asakusa metro and train station, it is much more authentic then any others district. You are always in the shadow of the Skytree, that symbolizes the modern Tokyo, but here, here is different, it is like an other world....First, you find here the Sensoji temple with its 3 gates. The Buddhist temple was built in 645 A.D with the finest Japanese architecture. It is the oldest temple of Tokyo. Then you'll find the Five Storied Pagoda, built only about 40 years ago. It’s about 50 meters high, a mixture of concrete, steel and a pillar of Japanese Cypress tree woo. Around is the Nakamise shopping area, it is principally for tourists, but still with a lot of special feelings, especially when you enter to the area from the magnificent Kaminarimon Gate. Alongside in the small streets, something diffrent is waiting for you, a real feeling of older Tokyo. Small houses, local shops, and a lot of stuff for kitchen. That's an other story here, the Kappabashi Dori, the so called "kitchen street" is a long main street with stores lined up on either side. You find everything here you could ever imagine about japanese kitchen...You have a lot of nice and sympahtic restaurants in this area, just behinde the Asakusa station building, you find really japanes restaurants with good prices. Just take about 15 bucks, 12 euros. you have a fantastic dinner/lunch. I even don't remember the name where I was, without English menu and any English word,only langauge of signs, with local draft beer and typical "Tonkatsu" served with shredded cabbage, boiled rice and miso soup. It was a bit down from the Station, but in the same street as Starbucks. Excellent chioce!!

Old part of Tokyo. Excellent place to experience some old part of Tokyo. Those little shops are slightly for the tourists but you can buy some interesting souvenirs too. Different from going to places like Shibuya, Roppongi etc!! If you are visiting Tokyo for the first time then this place is a must. Perhaps not very good place for very young people(?).

nice neighborhood in down-tempo Tokyo. There's a lot to see and do in this area of the great metropolis of Tokyo.There are lots of more traditional shops specialising in furniture, flowers, knives, kitchenware. The perfect alternative for those who grow tired of the giant shopping malls.DonOf course, the Senso Ji sanctuary is a big POI in Asakusa too. There are many shops around it with souvenirs and fair-style food.
