Loved Asakusa. Asakusa is a lovely area. It's a bit more traditional looking around the streets near the Kannon Temple and just has a really nice atmosphere. The street markets leading up to the temple are fantastic - lots of interesting things to look at, buy and taste! We stayed in the area as well, and really enjoyed it. Lots of restaurants and eateries local.

Welcoming Temple and Neighborhood. This was one of two places we visited on a lay over for ten hours in Tokyo. We chose it on the recommendation of several people who told us it was a nice place to walk around. The Sensoji temple and surrounding buildings were lovely. We especially enjoyed walking around the neighborhood. Many of the streets are pedestrian only, making it very pleasant for strolling. As first visitors to Tokyo, we were surprised by a couple of things. One was the huge number of bicycles that were in use. The other was how friendly and helpful local people were to us when we obviously were having trouble figuring something out such as the right subway or train to take. It made us want to return for an actual destination visit!

Explore!. This is a great neighborhood for exploring. Yes, the shrine is neat, but the backstreets are even neater. The entire neighborhood seems to be dotted with little hole in the wall shops and restaurants. I love this place.
Nice place to see. There is very nice Buddhist temple with nice surrounding. Plenty of little shops where you can buy food and souvenirs. Although it is quite crowded place, it is worth to see it.

Older part of Tokyo to explore on foot. The main attraction in this old district of Tokyo is the Sensoji Temple. Nakamise, the street leading up to the temple is basically a touristy street lined with all kinds of things Japanese. Granted there are wonderful snacks aplenty and the temple with their giant lanterns at the gates are great for photos. But the real old Tokyo are the sidestreets around the temple with a myriad of shops that seem more untouched by tourism. A short walk from Nakamise street will take you to the river where you can see the distinctive Asahi building. From there, I slowly walked my way to the Skytree tower about 15mins away. A nice area to explore on foot if you have a few hours.

Great area in Tokyo to stroll, shop, dine, drink, and have fun.. I liked everything in this area which I visit almost every time I go to Tokyo. It has a nice old-Tokyo feel to it, while having up-to-date infrastructure. In addition to all the touristy things everybody knows about (mainly the sensoji temple), it's also very beautiful in spring with all the azaleas blooming (2nd half of April). It's near Sumida River with its lovely promenades and Tokyo Sky Tree view --- very romantic at night. The Tobu Station provides easy access to Tokyo Sky Tree (just one station away) and the Nikko/Kinugawa area about 200km to the north of Tokyo. The Matsuya department store (same building as the Tobu station has a nice open-air rooftop with nice views of the surroundings, and on my last visit (Dec 2012), the rooftop had a Christmas tree and a free footbath, very pleasant experience under the bright winter sun.
Well kept old neighborhood of Tokyo. Asakusa is great for a walk. Here you'll find street-markets and temples with a feeling of old Japan even though you are in the middle of hectic Tokyo
Good place to stay in Tokyo. From Asakusa you have very good connections to the Tokyo Metro. Just 3 stations to the Ueno JR Lines. There are many good restaurants, we loved that place.

lovely place with traditional Japanese feeling. Crowded street full of locals and tourists, lots of stores selling delicious Japanese snacks, souvenirs, sth like that, they were quite good in quality and price! Asakusa is an awesome place to learn more about the traditional culture, beautiful architecture. And it is convenient to go, all the main spots are near the metro, many lockers you can find in metro station and on the streets, a good news for ppl like us who buy a lot.

Nice Temples and Structures. Asakusa has very nice temples that you can walk through and take pictures of, but I don't think it really takes that much time to see everything. You can walk through and see a lot of the souvenier shops. There's a lot of those shops in one place, but again, it won't really take too long since most of the shops sell things that are very similar to each other.

to make absolutely. lovely typical pedestrian area with temples, typical shops and souvenir shops (lot of japanese tourists making relegious path), and not far from the kitchen street (to make as well)
Beautiful. Great place, really nice looking, with a busy market nearby. Really easy to find, and lovely food. It's a bit touristy, but that's to be expected.
Must go. Great atmosphere! It's an older side of Tokyo. Traditional Japanese snakes are yummy. You mush try the "Ningyou Yaki"人形焼. It's my favourite. There are also pretty souvenir shops around.

Tourist trap - expensive food and extremely packed. If you want to experience what sardines feel like in a tin - come here. It was ridiculously crowded. Even trying to exit the train station is a challenge. You cannot see ahead so you just follow the crowd - or the person in front of you. Everyone doing the same feels robotic. We got sick of this so broke away when we could to walk the side streets. So much better. The main drag walking towards Sensoji temple has food and souvenir shops on either side. Everyone was just walking along and some did not even bother looking at these shops. Others that were, just held up everyone else. Japanese are used to queuing so some eateries were not even open but the queue was already long. You queue for everything - even the fast food stall! The prices are also for the tourist - too expensive 500 yen ($5) for a grilled corn on the stick!!We asked one of the guards to let us out of the barriers as we just did not bother going into the temple. The view of the temple from a little distance was better.

Must visit. Asakusa is an easy visit using the Metro subway, and a Must Visit for gifts for home... We visited here on the end of our trip and it had everygift type for those at home... even a kimono outfit for the dog! It is a serious setup of Market stalls in every direction, we were lucky enough to be there during the battledore festival so scored ourselves a paddle to display at home... I'm not much of a shopper but this was very interesting...loved it

Great for souvenirs . Good place to buy any little souvenirs for friends and family back home. The temple here is beautiful and has to be seen if you're in the area. On my visit there were a lot of local Japanese children in the market asking if I could help with there English homework which was very sweet.

More than visit temple... A place filled with crowds, snacks and food.. other than visiting the temple I will always go to the traditional dessert shop - ?? didn't know the English name but it's a shop that must try!! Its not along the Main Street that selling souvenir and snacks . They are at a junction ..It's not difficult to find just look for the signature. They traditional toasted mochi n in a bowl of red bean ... Wow -- highly recommend !! The texture of the mochi is so yummy!!!

Popular...for a reason.. There is a reason why this set of shrines are so popular. They're enormous and plenty. Several of them are rebuilt following WWII, but they all impress an ancient feel. My only wish is that we could go up the pagoda! Step through the gates initially and get covered in purifying smoke. Wash your paws in a water fountain with a cup. Walk up to the golden shrine of extravagant symbols, throw in ur money, clap your hands, bow and pray. Mission accomplished.I liked the souvenirs at the shops. Bought a rising sun flag and other things I did not see at many of the other locations we visited.

Good but a bit crowded. The temple is very impressive but could be very crowded with tourist. I actually preferred the temples in Kyoto but if you are in Tokyo, you have to come and visit this temple.

Downtown Tokyo. The place is completely the true Tokyo in its full bloom. The whole appeal and the character of the place are quite different from the rest of the places. The area is popular with its temples, restaurants and shopping centers and is a good place for quick and cheap shopping spree in Tokyo. The place can provide you with both high end stuffs to cheap shopping and along with lots of places to try out Japanese cuisines in many of the restaurants that are aligned in the place.

A great place.. I stayed in Asacusa for 4 weeks whilst in Tokyo and loved it.I stayed in 'Khoasan Tokyo Samurai' which was a great place to stay and also spent time in a capsule hotel which was interesting.The temples are beautiful and worth a visit!I went up the 'Sky Tree' and the view over Tokyo was incredible.I found a great 'Kyokushin' Karate dojo in the area too.I'd definitely recommend paying Asacusa a visit!

Beautiful Area for Visit. My husband and I stayed in the Asakusa area for our recent trip to Tokyo, and we were not disappointed. First of all, it is a quieter part of the city than some-- say, Shibuya or Roppongi--which is a benefit for sleeping. But there's also quite a bit to see-- not the least is the Senso-ji Temple, which is worth any stop on any trip. There's also great restaurants, more sightseeing, and wonderful shopping. I'd recommend "Kitchen Town" for any ceramics or food goodies that you might want as a souvenir.
Asakusa is a shopping haven. Good for cheap souvenir shopping. Love the stuffs there, but it can get too crowded, which I don't really enjoy much.

Interesting place - lots of tourists. Asakusa is a part of Tokyo's downtown Taito district best known for its many temples, including the popular Senso-ji Temple. It is located just west of the Sumida River (and you can visit this part of Tokyo by taking one of the River tour boats). It is also about a half mile west of the giant Tokyo Sky Tree.I visited this area on a Sunday afternoon in mid-November and thought it was interesting. The central part of this area is the Nakamise Street shopping arcade and the Senso-ji Temple and I spent almost my entire 3 hour visit here. While I only spent a few hours here and think it would be much better if I stayed overnight here so I could check it out after dark and walk through the back streets. If you are looking for lower priced souvenirs, Nakamise Street is the place to go. This street is directly in front of the Senso-ji Temple. There are lots of booths to buy souvenirs and snacks from. There are guys nearby that will give you a rickshaw ride for a price. I saw a young local couple that just got married getting a ride.Overall I thought this place was interesting and recommend it. It is a must see attraction if you are on your first visit to Tokyo (not sure if I would go back unless I was looking for cheaper Japanese souvenirs). Senso-ji Temple is in the center of this area and is the main attraction in Asakusa. The only issue I had with this area was the large number of tourists that made it feel like an amusement park and not an old part of Tokyo.

Shopping Street, Food Street, Culture Street. Asakusa never disappoints any traveler dropping by Japan. Asakusa is beautiful and unique in terms of the varieties it offer along the shopping street and the main Asakusa area. Once you have burn thousands of yen, head over to look for some good food around and burn another few thousand yen perhaps. Just spend half a day here would do you good with shopping, sight seeing and eating, preferably come during the weekend to see more things.

Awesome!. We based ourselves in Asakusa when we went to Tokyo this summer. It's a bit far from the action (Harajuku, Shibuya, Shinjuku etc) but they are only about 30mins away by train. Ginza and Akihabara is only 15 mins away (you can actually go there by bicycle! we did, but it took longer obviously) there's a lot of cute little eateries in Asakusa. Sensoji temple is great too, I actually love it a lot more at night, the lights make it so pretty.

Must see in Tokyo. Asakusa is a must see when you're in Tokyo. A nice blend of tat shopping and sightseeing with some good eats thrown in too for good measure. I went during the day time but I can easily imagine at night when its all lit up its incredible

Amazing Asakusa!. Asakusa is more than just Sensoji and Nakamise-dori, it is a wonderful area of Tokyo to explore. I stayed 5 days in Asakusa during my most recent trip to Tokyo and loved walking around at night and in the morning. Imado Shrine is a great small shrine to check out. It is a bit of a walk but if you walk along the Sumida Park whcih runs along the Sumida River you can enjoy a wonderful setting see some joggers, wild cats, birds and other interesting things. If you are curious about Maneki Neko or love cats this is the place to be.Kappabashi-dori is sensational if you have even a tiny interest in cooking. Kitchen town as it is known has great shops all dedicated to cooking. You will find very unique items for gifts or for your own Kitchen. Bandai, the famous toy maker has their home office in Asakusa and out front they have a lot of statues of some of their better known characters which is fun to see.Walking across the bridges can also be enjoyable as they are rather short and distinctive. Each bridge has its own cool style and they look great at night.Taking the Waterbus from Asakusa to Odaiba is really great as well. I really enjoyed it most at night as you can really see the beautiful city lights as you sit in comfort inside the ferry. They offer several different styles of ferries at different prices. If possible you may want to consider a visit during a festival or event. Asakusa has several famous ones and these can be great fun. I went to see "Tokyo Jidai Matsuri" and "Shirasagi no mai" both were great fun though busy.Of course the star of Asakusa is Sensoji and that is well deserved. It is a fantastic temple and Nakamise dori is a lot of fun to shop at you can get some great deals and delicious snacks walking along this area. Don't be afraid to walk the side streets though as there are tons more shops and places to eat as well as smaller shrines and temples around the area.

Favourite place in all of Tokyo!. Senso-ji is beautiful and Skytree is breathtaking but go a little further away from these things and just explore the alleyways. It will remind you of why you wanted to visit Tokyo in the first place. So beautiful and charming, the people are so friendly and welcoming. We spent hours just walking and cycling through the back streets and alleyways of Asakusa and I can't wait to do it again!

Shopping!. Lots of great shopping here for tourists as it seems like there are more of the traditional style Japanese trinkets that are available for purchase. The prices are reasonable however the crowds we found could be very overwhelming! It can also get very hot we found in this area.

shops and restaurants to suit everybody. Not to mention Senso-ji park and temple. We spent 6 days in Tokyo and kept returning to this area: because we liked the atmosphere, the restaurants for all tastes (not only the usual Japanese ones) and budgets; specifically, we loved a set of shops in a closed, supermarket-like area just below the station: incredible and mysterious (for us) sweets and fruits, small fish, fried on the spot, French bread... From the station you can walk to the Skytree tower, more than 600 meters high; an experience in itself. We do not mention the Senso-ji park and temples, because they are already described by guides and by other travellers, but they are worth seeing as well!

Traditional shopping in Tokyo. You probably go to visit Senso-ji Temple when you go to Asakusa, but the surroundings are even a must see. There are many small shops, ones that you cannot see in the futuristic Tokyo made of tall buildings and department stores. Here, you can get in touch with traditional craftsmen and merchants, descendants of Edo Period, the native inhabitants of Tokyo.

A sea of people. This is our second visit to asakusa and it is well worth it. After seeing the shrine one walks down along road of Japanese souvenir type shops and unusual food stalls and great ice cream. Walked to kappabashi and saw all the Japanese knife shops and found a real gem of a restaurant that required the removal of shoes and sitting around a huge hot plate we made okonomoyaki or tasty Japanese pancakes - great experience
One of the must visit places in Japan. You can't miss visit to orange street, shopping from low end to ver high end shops plus good restaurants and shrine of the big red lantern
Great experience. We visited last 3rd November and it so happen that they have this parade so we get to see Asakusa Shrine with additional "flavor". The structure itself is an architectural marvel.

Functioning Shinto temple. We walked through the grounds of this temple on a daily basis while in the Asakusa area. When you see the old abandoned temples on some side streets, you appreciate what must go into the maintenance of such remarkable buildings and their gardens to keep them beautiful. Lovely by dark as well.

What a wonderful area!. The first stop in Asakusa was of course the Senso-ji Temple. It was super crowded during the day but it was so much fun! The great, big red lantern was so cool! After viewing the temple, we wandered off to the Nakamise shopping street. There is so much to look at there and you can definitely find some cool souvenirs! Don't forget to visit Asakusa!

Excellent place to stay. There is nothing to dislike about Asakusa! Flat area easy to walk, full of life by day and beautiful by night - especially the Senso-Temple and Nakamise markets when they are lit up. There are great views of the Tokyo Skytree from Asakusa as well and you will get amazing photo's of Old vs New Japan. You can eat at one of the hundreds of restaurants, hire a bike or ride a rickshaw, catch a train to the Tokyo Skytree or take a cruise on the Sumida River and back. Asakusa is a sightseeing dream come true!

charme of old tokyo. great location to stay in Tokyo if you don't need busy night life a la Shibuya. walk around to see the old Tokyo with Edo period spirit. small shopping places and Japanese restaurants, big market with clothes, 2nd hand kimonos, fabric shops,antiques, japanese kitchen- and household items and numerous other interesting stuff around senso-ji temple. worth to leave the beaten path and walk all the small streets to discover new things!

Must visit by everyone. The best area to visit in Tokyo. There is an oldest temple in Japan and also streets of souvenirs to buy and places to eat on the way. You'll be able to see a Sky tree from there, as you won't be able to see it outside of the Asakusa station. We walked to the Sky tree and it took around 40 min.

Very nice tourist area. We enjoyed walking down the lovely market street all the way down to the Senso Ji Temple which is also very beautiful. It´s one of the best places to ger souvenirs from Japan, from food and snacks to kimonos and the typical miniatures from the country. There are also many restaurants in the area.

Overrated.. Lots of tsochke stalls and a decent shrine. One of the main gates was being refurbished. Very touristy--which could be a good thing if you want to try street food or buy souvenirs. Be sure to look for the racoon-dog shrine outside the main complex.

Sightseeing in Asakusa district. Walking away from Asakusa Kannon temple grounds I headed for the narrow back streets of the district. Many arcades, with little shops laden with souvenirs of dubious origin, but nice to look at. I walked towards “Kappabashi”, Tokyo’s main wholesale district for kitchenware, curious to find a reasonably priced sushi knife to bring home. This I did and to my amazement the shopkeeper had been to Greece (hitchhiking) many years ago. He also proceeded to declare his admiration for Alexander the Great! On leaving Kappabashi the rain had started again quite strong. Clad with my rainproof overcoat I walked back to the arcade area in search for a decent spot of lunch. There are numerous sake bars and eating places to choose from but I was looking for something with character, so I opted for a little corner place (‘kapilio’ as we would say in Greece) run by two ladies. It was fun! By contrast to other street food places this one was quite unique; behind the bench the ladies were busy boiling various meats for the traditional stock. I chose to have grilled shiitake mushrooms and tofu with my beer. To my amazement and dismay the menu included whale meat sushi at an exorbitant price! All in all the district offers plenty of interesting things and before I headed for the train I bought a pair of authentic Japanese wooden clogs.

Go the back-street way. The main boulevard should be walked only once, and either early in the morning or after dusk - the rest of the time, it's a screaming, pricey, worthless tourist trap with throngs of people blocking any potential enjoyment of the history and artefacts.The back streets, however, are a different story altogether - beautifully crafted mini-shrines, mini-parks, mini-eateries and curiosity shops (including semi-porno, bondage and tattoo shops frequented by yakuza gang members), street shows (try to catch the "ninja duo" if you can - hilarious, spectacular acrobatics act that never goes out to the Main Street), and old-skool traditional charm.

If you love a quiet, go there at night. If the weather is nice. and you love taking a photograph, go at night. It's so quiet. I also go there on daytime too, nice matcha green tea ice-cream there. A lot of souvenirs. First enter, on right side the have a place to clean your self before go in to temple. Nice place for a first-visit tokyo to go.

great location for shopping and sightseeing. Asakusa is famous for its pedestrian streets with an uncountable number of souvenir shops, coffee shops and other shops. At the end of the main pedestrian street, you can find the Sensoji Temple, which is a must see in Tokyo. If you don't like crowded places and shopping, I recommend you to go at night. Shops are closed at night and the temple has a lot of lights, which makes it more beautiful, than during daytime.
loved it. I stayed in Shibuya and a friend brought me to Asakusa to see the shrine and walk around. It was wonderful, so many shops with little trinkets and gifts and the shrine was beautiful.

Fun to walk around!. There were lots of shops and places to eat here. It was fun to walk around and see the different types of food available for purchase. The shops had various trinkets, woodblock prints, and Japanese fabric available to purchase. It was very busy -- I held onto my husband tightly so we would not get separated from one another. My husband said if we went again we would go earlier in the morning. We went on Sunday around noon-ish and it was very crowded. Before going to Japan with me my husband came here for business and stopped by Asakusa earlier in the morning, and it was not nearly as chaotic. So, maybe check it out in the morning! Despite it being crowded we still enjoyed ourselves very much and would recommend going if you are in Tokyo.

Great area - culture, shopping and food!. This neighbourhood is hugely popular. It's one of THE tourist spots to visit. Even though it is so touristy, it's still very much worth to visit it.The Temple is the main attraction here. But the (Nakamise) Shopping street leading to it is great too. Lots of products and souvenirs. And the prices and quality are actually very fair!Be sure not to miss the side streets too with smaller shops and good food options. There's also a shopping arcade with more regular shops and a bunch of dining options.It can be pretty packed here...especially on weekends. Be here on a weekday or quite early to avoid the big crowds. It's a great area, lots of great foto ops. It's fun and surely should be one of the first places you visit when in Tokyo. Wanna know more about me and my travels? Check my profile (with a link to my website).

touristy but a must see. The stalls of independent shop keepers line the paths away from the Shrine. The wares are perfect to bring home as souvenirs. People watching here is plentiful. Bring your camera. Food choices galore. We loved the ice cream burger. Venture a couple of streets over and you'll find covered malls with an endless array of shops.

wondeful neighbourhood. Just forget about what most of the tourist guides say about Asakusa. Try to get lost on the streets, on the movement of people... You will always have the Shrine to guide your way back and the river is just nearby. Tokyo is so complex but getting around Asakusa is so simple and fun.

Interesting district. Asakusa is a more traditional Japanese district.
It has a number of attractions, plus Tokyo Sky Tree is not that far, 15-20 minutes waliking district. It also easily connects to Ginza line. There is a perfect hotel to stay in Asakusa - The Gate Hotel Kaminarimon, strongly recommended.

Awesome place. One of the things I loved about Tokyo is seeing thousands of years of history and culture in the middle of a large metropolitan city. Asakusa is a shrine in the middle of the city. The walk to the shrine from the gates has a lot of shops where you can find souvenirs, pastries, candy and other stuff, we're sure (we don't read Japanese). There are two main buildings-one big shrine and to the left of it, I 5-story pagoda. This is definitely a must see in Tokyo.
Interesting area. Roam the little alleys and small shopping streets. The shops and small eateries are fascinating. I didn't see anything else quite like it on a 2 week trip to Japan.
Nice area to visit. Its one of the "must see" places in Tokyo.. The small shops nearby are also nice and interesting.. Get ready to take a lot of pictures

A nice city. We went there during our last day in Japan. There are a lot of souvenir shops here ( I don't know but it seems so hard to find a proper souvenir shops in Japan. at least they are not everywhere like Carrols in Ireland)
Food alley. There is a great pedestrianized street of open air bars and restaurants in Asakusa, a few streets to the west of the temple complex.

Must-See. We went to Asakusa on the weekend. It was late in the afternoon. We enjoyed the temple, it was bigger than the temples we already saw. There are shops lined on both sides. We bought souvenirs, and we tried some of the local food. There are many restaurants around. So, that would be a good place for lunch or dinner. If you are tired, or prefer not to walk in the crowd, they have pulled carts. Rent one, and you will be ready to go!
Entertaining and busy. We went in the evening and found the area to be vibrant and entertaining. We spent more time looking, because the shopping wasn't anything special.

The temple to see. We couldn't get into the Tokyo Palace, so we went here instead, to visit Sensoji temple. Large and busy temple, good to see and walk around. From the entrance gate to the temple, really busy shopping street (I think called Nakamise), absolutely the place to buy souvenirs from Japan. Tokyo was the last city we visited, so we have collected massive bundle of souvenirs from the other cities, still we managed to scooped up a couple of bag full. Absolute collection with best price.

A sumo wrestler on a bicycle. The huge red lanterns hanging from Kaminari-mon Gate and Senso-ji Temple Gate are really captivating and fantastic to travellers from overseas like me from George Town, Penang. . I bought some souvenirs from Nakamise shopping street , a tad too expensive though.On the main road outside the temple I saw a tall heavyweight sumo wrestler on a bike waiting to cross the road. As soon as the light turned green, he sped away in lightning speed even before I could say , hello !
Love the place. We just notice on the last day of our stay that their is a local market on the left side of temple where many nice, low cost food provided.

A must see in Tokyo. As you enter there are a row of stalls/shops that is approximately 1km long with the typical traditional Japanese tourist merchandise. The temple itself is very dominant and is picturesque but does not have the speculator gardens compared to other temples in the city. It's ideal to combine seeing the Tokyo Skytree tower as it's only 2 stops further down on the metro.

Just walk around and walk some more. See and smell and taste. What a place to be. You can spend there hours and figure out what souvenir to bring home. Buy something to eat and drink but don't eat on the street. Go to that temple at the end of the street. Sit there and eat while looking around and resting a bit. and when evening falls, the place has a different look. Go back the same streets and see and smell and taste again.
Amazing place. This is what you expect when you visit Tokyo, loads of history and traditional buildings to see, amazing temple, loads of shops to buy all your souvenirs too

Must do. Very folkloric and typical; you can get a good impression on how a very Japanese place looks like. The temple itself is beautiful, but it is all around it what gives you the biggest impression.

Impressive temple and massive crowds. We thought it was worth seeing this mammoth temple, with its huge gate, giant lanterns and extensive market selling everything from food to souvenirs. But the whole area was packed with people, both tourists and locals.

Worth visiting but there are better places. It's a temple! Not really my cup of tea but it is quite nice. It reminded me of Blackpool - one thing worth seeing surrounded by trashy shops trying to take the tourists yen from them.Interesting, if you can't find anything else to do.

Worth Seeing. Asakusa is one of the best temples to see in Tokyo however because of this there are a lot of tourists. If youre not going to Kyoto it is worth a look. However, if youve already visited Kyoto or plan on it, Asakusa could be skipped.

Tradition and modernity side by side. Nice and pleasant place as it has both the traditional side of japanese society and the typical modernity. Easy access via public transport and great variety of restaurants. Also, there is a bulding specially for tourism information.

Loved wandering around this place. My daughters and I loved spending time here. Great shopping in the alley ways and side streets. Loads of friendly and helpful people and just a relaxing place to go despite lots of people around. Heaps of places to eat as well with a wide variety of choices. Deserves an afternoon here.
Great place to spend a day in Tokyo. Lots to do and see here. Everything from great shopping, to ancient temples, to good food, amusement park rides, and people watching.
Love the market. This is an old market and so extensive you can wander for hours. Easy to get to and easy to start buying!

Historic and cultural, Japanese khan el khalily. Been there in oct 2012Again made lots of shopping and was struggling to buy more stuffI'm a shopping maniacBought three kimonos for me and my family and some Japanese made tshirts for friends and familyIt felt so much like Egyptian khan el khalily areaLater on my Japanese friends told me I should've negotiated for the prices, which I didn't know could work in Japan tooThe place is nice for those looking for historic places to seeU can also buy souvenirs there, but I'd recommend u buy from Tokyo sky treeI also found a good Turkish kebab small shop there which I was incredibly happy to find and it tasted gr8But only chicken was halalGood over all experience

Just an average temple. If you've never been to a Buddhist temple, then I can see the appeal. After seeing numerous temples and shrines across Japan, China, and Thailand, this certainly stands out as one of the LEAST interesting. It is extremely crowded and overly commercialized. If you are in the area, it's worth poking your head in, but it's not worth making a special trip to this area from elsewhere in Tokyo. Way more interesting things to see.
visit japan. very nice and good to see many thing together at the same place. Sky tree,river park. temple and many beautiful peoples. music i am sure u enjoy a lot after visit\it this place.

One of my favorite places in Tokyo!. Asakusa is one place you cannot miss in Tokyo. I am Japanese and am originally from Tokyo. I still love to visit. It reminds me of old days (and hundreds years ago). It has a temple (Senso-ji), a gate (Kaminari-mon), shops that have been there for generations. It offers many unique, classic restaurants with reasonable prices. I love it all! One caution: I just left a hotel and wanted to leave a suitcase in or near Asakusa station. However, all coin lockers (a few dozens) were all taken even in the morning. Fortunately, mine is small so I just carried around with me.

Great place to find a restaurant. As the title says this place is an amazing place to take a stroll and find somewhere to eat. We went pretty late in the evening and thought that it would be difficult to find somewhere but there were lots of places to eat. After dinner take a stroll to the Asakusa temple and you will be rewarded with a beautiful sight. The local's are also very helpful, so if your worried about stumbling into somewhere that you won't know what to order the server's will help you out.
Great izkayas. Check out the Izakayas at night - its a great atmosphere and lots of fun. Definitely one of the most unique and interesting places in Tokyo

Traditional Japan!. It is in asakusa where I felt truly in Japan! There are streets in which traditional Japanese items are sold: key chains, fans, chopsticks .. And it is not very expensive. There are also temples and old buildings (with the traditional Japanese roof! :))All in all, asakusa combines both : shopping and culture!

A lovely launch pad to old style Tokyo...in a good way. Cruise locale, easy to get around, perfect of bike adventures. There is allot to see from the Sensoji Temple and the neighbouring markets. Great selection of bars and places to eat in authentic Japanese style.

Fun area. This was a very fun area to venture into. There are several notable shopping streets and a nice tourist center. You can get a nice traditional feel in this district. The highlight would be the Senjoji Temple, Asakusa Shrine, and the Nakamise Shopping Street.
nice place!. There's a lot of souvenir shops and tourist destination. They even have a Information Center Building for tourist!

Lovely Asakusa. Asakusa is a not to be missed stop in Central Tokyo. A charming Japanese suburb with many shops and eating places and near the famous Sensoji temple.
Nice to visit any time of the day when the shops are open.

Interesting temple and markets. A great spot to see traditional Japan in Tokyo, there are many market stalls, though got there a bit late in the day and they had begun to close up.
Get your fortune in the temple for a bit of fun.
Great mix of culture and shopping. Such a lively place full of nice quirky shops with cheap finds, and also a lot of picture-worthy temples. Must visit for tourists.

Best day trip. Luvely pace for a day trip. We loved the shrine there with all its ancient tradition. The amosphere was magical. Luved the architecture of the shrine with its curved roof and the ornate huge doors and there are small shops all around where you can find some really unique stuff. Beautiful japanese dolls and charms and wonderful variety of food everywhere. The people were so friendly and it was a pleasure to be there. Didnt want to come back...

see it at night!. The lights of the temples are fantastic! And it is not so crowded, though all the shops are closed in the late evening. There is a market there, prices are different, so you can search for a best price! We bought nice umbrellas there, which were made in Japan, not in China. Quite expensive but beautiful.
Very beautifull and attractive place. definitely a good place to visit. temples, shops, small road with no car alowed. many japanses and tourists poeple.

When traditional and modern Tokyo colorfully clash. We had a wonderful three-night stay right in the heart of the Asakusa area. We thought Asakusa was such a perfect blend of modern and traditional Japan, and even Japanese kitsch. It remains a major tourist destination as well as a shopping heaven for those who enjoy walking streets and browsing small shops that sell everything from factory outlet shoes to exquisite hand-crafted gifts.Nakamise-street is wonderful for shopping due to the number of shops and its covered walkways. You can spend hours and hours checking out each store and dropping in quaint coffee shops. Shopping here is fun, and I found most shopowners and staff to be very pleasant to deal with. There is a definite tourist-service culture here.Of course, the highlight of Asakusa is Sensoji. It is a reflection of the strong Japanese culture that makes this country probably the most distinctive on earth in terms of a national identity. It is a vast complex that tourists descend upon throughout the day. Do a night visit and you will be amazed at how peaceful and magical the temple can be.I would choose to stay in this area as it is also very convenient to get to other places because of its two train stations. Take a walk a bit further and you find Sumida River. Not the most beautiful river scenery when compared to the likes of the Seine or the Chao Phraya, but refreshing nonetheless.

Skip this area of Tokyo. This area is quite and feels run down. There is a tourist trap of a shrine here and not much in terms of interesting shopping or eating. Your time will be spent better elsewhere in Tokyo.
Alot of fun. The little streets and side alleys, the shopping, the quiet of the streets at night. It has a lovely feel to the place.
Packed. Very crowded. Doesnt feel like its sacred with all the activities going around compares to meiji shrine. Lots of shopping stalls for snacks and souvenirs.

Hot weather. August is not a good month to travel there for those who do not like hot weather. When I was there last week, it went as high as 38C and it was really hot and to do outdoor shopping, you will need a good umbrella. Visiting Disneyland was not good too as the weather did spoilt the mood, not to mention the summer holidays where it's extremely crowded with holidaying locals.
Pretty temples. Alot of temples,pretty crowded,was there during April so the sakura made the whole place better!,but the shopping streets around there are pretty pricey.

Enjoy the crowd!. This place was very crowded, but the atmostphere was great and I enjoyed it. The Sensoji Temple was beautiful. Can go inside throw coins and offer a prayer.The opening hours of the main hall is from 6:30a.m to 5:00p.mThere is a shopping street nearby which sells Japanese popular traditional items, foods and drinks.Took a bath at bath house, walked to the river, so nice!Really want to visit this place again!!!

Least Favorite Site. This was probably our least favorite site of our entire trip to Japan. In the grand scheme of temples and areas in Japan, you are much better off going to all of the other temples and save the crowds and tourist vendors. The only thing that we enjoyed was the intricate ceiling painting inside the temple part where you can get your 'fortune' for the year.... but it isn't enough to draw us there in hindsight.
Great area for night life and evening drinks. Very busy place as you can imagine, loads of places to eat and drink, loads of shops. Great atmosphere.
The temple with a local color. It is not a spectacular wonder of the world, but when you are mingled with innocent native visitors from every corner of Japan , you may feel a touch of local spirit.
Crowds!. Lots of tourists, lots of cheap shops and lots of finger food. The temple itself is at the far end and it is nice but this is a tourist place. It was part of our tour.

Surprisingly good. This was toward the end of our trip and all I could think of was another temple and shopping area. The temple was nice as expected but the shops were numerous and diverse. Shops with food, souvenirs, pictures etc. We spend a fair amount of time and money there.We walked around and found some pottery shops. Bought numerous pieces there and essentially did all of our shopping for those items there. Reasonable prices as well.There is visitor center across the street from the Asakusa Sensoji Temple entrance. If you walk to the top level you get a great view of the area including SkyTree. There was no elevator though so it is about 5 sets of stairs. Nice bathroom break as well. Would definitely do again.

Not that great. If you've been to temples and shrines elsewhere in japan, i would recommend skipping it. About as far from an authentic temple as it gets, insanely crowded as well. There are a ton of shops selling souvenirs, so if you feel like paying a lot for made in China items, i recommend doing your shopping there.It can be beautiful at night, 2300++ when the shops are closed and there's no one in sight.
A tourist Mecca. I found this place to be a tourist trap. The mix of shops and temple don't quite fit. There were some good samurai swords though.

Don't forget the tempura!. Great neighbourhood, a welcome relief from the sky scrapers. Good shopping too, especially if you are looking for poignant, tasteful knick knacks as souveniers... Make sure you check out the shopping streets surrounding sensoji temple... the farther away you are from the temple entrance, the better deals you get! And don't be like us and forget the tempura....
Gorgeous & historic. I go here everytime I’m in Japan and it is always filled with crowds of people, but it is gorgeous and a lot of little stores that you can eat and purchase souveniers.
Historic. Lovely little area of Tokyo. Very historic, with a great little market for buying souvenirs for friends and family and also the Temple.
Crowded but great. Lots of people. Lots to see. Even more to eat. Best pastries ever....even compared to Paris. Relatively safe if you're not stoopid. Great shops. Go for it.

Amazing place but be careful on the weekend, too many people.. No question it's one of the highlights of any trip to Tokyo, but I'd reccomend going early as possible if you are there on the weekend, the crowds can be unbearable. The neighbourhood is so charming and the the shrine itself is a joy to behold, as is the shopping street that leads the way. The views of Tokyo Sky Tree are also amazing! Well worth a visit, and don't forget to pray!

Great place to get lost in!. Besides the quintessential Sensoji and Nakamise dori, the streets surrounding the area are choke full of interesting streets and hidden treasures.A definite must visit especially if you would like to experience "shitamachi".

Good place to spend half day. Nice neighbourhood with lots of shops and restaurants, where you can also visit the Asakusa Shrine. You should walk by the market which has a big variety of products, including food and souvenirs.

Asakusa. Wonderful place, traditional Japanese restaurants, plenty of local shopping, local cuisines, colorful and vibrant but quite crowded. It was drizzling and partially cloudy and amazing place. A must try is the traditional Japanese cakes and rice crackers.

Very Crowded but GREAT for Shopping and Site Seeing!. Loved this and bought a lot of things. They take credit cards as well but, be mindful of extra charges. Took great pictures and nice things to buy and take home. Just great place to visit overall. Just take walking shoes and make sure you are ok with crowds as there are a lot of people.

Very authentic experience. Although it's very touristic, Asakusa is the place to go if you want to see the old Tokyo and its traditions. Asakusa's main attraction is Sensoji, which is a big Buddhist temple.We took the train and walked towards Nakamise, a shopping street that leads to the temple. It has stalls side by side for about 300mt selling traditional but popular Japanese items like sake sets, sandals, kimonos, magnets, etc. and traditional snacks, which by the way, you cannot eat while walking but have to eat it right there a few steps from the entrance of the shop you bought it until you finish.It's a lovely and vivid walking you don't want to miss. You can spend there about 2 hours easily and then you can keep walking to Sumida river and then cross the bridge and go up to the sky tree.We went on late March when the cherry blossom was in full and the river looked absolutely magic with all those beautiful trees alongside and a few people walking or riding their bike. We had such a great time there....
Lots to see and experience. Well worth taking the time out to visit and walk through the market area. Plenty to buy if you are that way inclined or just window shop

Crowded. Tip: have lunch in Irokawa. Delicious grilled eel.Cons: crowded.Its an astonishing temple with lots of beautiful details.I would enjoy it better if it wasn't so busy. Tons of people trying to take pics and trowing garbage almost everywhere.

nice for tourist. It's the best place for tourist looking for 'traditional Japan' Interesting street stall, awesome presents for friends, lively atmosphere.I visited the shrine on special holiday and saw people wearing Kimono. maybe Feb?also I had help from kind people
Sensojii temple. Beautiful temple and pagoda, it closed at 5 and we were the last ones in! Very pretty and interesting. Market leading to the temple was full of souvenirs and was cheap.
Very interesting shrine with food stall and shopping.. Check out the back alley lane, the small shops is more interesting. There is also a few good restaurants around the shrine.

Fine Japanese Culture. This place is situated in heart of Tokyo city. Most of the tour operators shall visit this place for sure. There are some good luck charms available which could be bought by tourists. Time should be spent in appreciating the various aspects of the place.

Loved the Area specially Sensōji temple and the bazaar in front of it. Beautiful Area in the massive and busy Tokyo .. you could simply go there, visit Sensōji temple, buy amazing stuff from the bazaar in front and then walk for 20 minutes to reach the Sky Tree (long queues but worth the wait )

Absolute must. A first time visitor in Japan, i was warned the area around Asakusa temple would be packed with people since the Sanya Moritsu Festival held every third week of May, was on its first day. I never regretted coming that day! The festival was colorful , vibrant and exciting and noisy. The clans came in different colored yakutas and there were men, women and children bearing on their shoulders their miniature shrines in groups. The sun was out. We were all sweaty and hot but the smiles on the faces and happiness to be able to perform this ritual was apparent! This is Japan.

Fascinating area. Not only the superb shrines but a delightful little fun park, magnificent souvenir shopping, great little restaurants everywhere - literally hundreds of them - a must see part of Tokyo which is quieter, highly recommended, easy to get to everywhere, and more "real" than the more commercial districts.

Vibrant atmosphere. The temple is surrounded by stalls selling souvenirs, snacks and local food and is adorned by lanterns, trees and statues. You'll see many locals visiting Sensoji Temple to pray for good fortune. Some people may find the place a little touristy however it does not reduce the appeal of the place. Allow yourself an hour to check out the temple's surrounding fully.

Marvellous older district. Unless you just want nightclubs and neon, you must see this area, which is tourism central for anyone interested in how real Japanese live and to experience the shrines. Fabulous restaurants abound plus great little shopping malls and even a small fun park. Despite the tourist attractions is is mainly a residential area and it feels really nice, lots of locals going about their daily business.
Temples, bath and river cruise.. For a VERY full day of sightseeing, enjoy the temple and shops, take a bath in a bathouse and then cruise the Sumida river to Odaiba

Lively Neighborhood Especially During Festivals. I visited Asakusa on the first day of the Sanja Maritsu festival which happens on the third weekend of May and it was amazingly alive. There were small shops all around the Sensoji temple selling wonderful foods, candies, and souvenirs. There were neighborhoods preparing their wonderful floats, lanterns everywhere, and a general party atmosphere. Even when the festival isn't on this is one of the most fun areas of Tokyo. Don't miss it.

A Tad Too Touristy. Located at Taito area (alight at Asakusa station), this shrine is a must go if you are a tourist in Tokyo. The path towards the shrine filled with all the shops selling souvenir and Japanese street food like Takoyaki (octopus balls), Taiyaki (Japanese fish-shaped cake filled with red-bean paste), Senbei (Japanese rice crackers) and many more. So if you are looking to buy some gifts and taste those yummy Japanese street food, then this place sums up everything. The shrine itself s a little disappointing in my opinion.

Great place to experience traditional Japan. I spent 2 hours in Asakusa on a recent trip to Tokyo and it was time well spent, I highly recommend a visit.If you are short on time and unfamiliar with the area, I suggest going to the Tourist center across from the subway station and from the outer gate of the Senso-ji temple. Here you can get a detailed color map of the area and ask the friendly staff to point things out for you. The Tourist center also offers a free 1 hour tour twice a day which is a good way to get someone local to take you around.I had 2 hours in the area, I spent 30 minutes eating at the Tenya on Kamikarimon, then 1hr 30m wandering around the Senso-ji temple and the surrounding shrines, this was just barely enough time, I would suggest budgeting 3-4 hours to fully enjoy the area (including walking on all the side streets, lunch, etc.).
What a buzz!. Great views of the Skytower, rickshaw rides and the excitement of the bazaar-like market stalls leading up to the shrine and in sidestreets and arcades.

Enlightening afternoon in Asakusa. On a recent business trip to Tokyo, I ventured out to Asakusa on the northern fringe of the city. I wanted to see some of the older buddhist temples, and take in a bit of history and local flavor.Outside of the temples, there are not too many of the old buildings and architecture left as this area was hit hard in WWII. But on a Sunday afternoon, I found the area to be relaxed and a great way to observe Japanese life and customs. There were religious ceremonies happening with families and children dressed in traditional outfits. And I was mesmerized by the Asakusa Shrine.There are rows of vendors selling various wares at Kappabashi market... some nice souvenir opportunities and local dessert treats.I probably did not take full advantage having done minimal research on this area, but found it to be a very enjoyable and relaxing afternoon. It is also very convenient to get to by metro via the Ginza line.Highly recommended to enjoy local culture... especially on weekends and when the weather is pleasant.

Nice temple, fun shops. This is a great little morning or afternoon place to visit. There is a well preserved, historic temple (free to visit) and lots of small shops. Interspersed among many shops selling tourist trinkets you still find traditional food vendors and a few artisans--makes it worth the trip. This is a different pace than just visiting Ginza!
Quiet neighbourhood with great attractions. Hana matsuri at the Asakusa shrine, Kappabashi market, Sumida riverside parks, Rin project bike rental.

Well-preserved Corner of Old Tokyo. Asakusa is a famous hubbub of old Tokyo, representing a way of life that brings people in close contact for souvenirs and food. The center architectural attraction is the Senso Ji temple, Tokyo's oldest; the original structure was built in the 7th century. The adjacent shrine is a Shinto Buddhist shrine, the Asakusa shrine, built in 1727. The temples have been maintained beautifully. It is difficult to imagine the ideal Buddhist tranquility in the throngs of Asakusa, but all temples have an air of transcendence, and there is reverence and respect amongst the tourists here. We came in April on a day celebrated as Buddha's birthday. The cherry blossoms were riotous with fragrance and color, and volunteers handed out orchids to passers-by. At Asakusa, as in Ginza, people watching is a great sport. Ladies in fancy kimonos and young adults in manga clothing are commonly seen. There are a great variety of street vendors selling small eats, like octopus dumplings, red bean cakes, roasted chestnuts, mochi, ramen. The food is not cheap, to be sure, but it is great fun. There are stores selling vintage Japanese toys, Hello Kitty, postcards, candy, swords, handbags. The stores are close to each other and the lanes narrow, and it is crowded. Kids can get easily separated. There are some good restaurants as well. We had sushi and homemade tofu in one of the restaurants in a side street. The tuna was good quality and fresh. In all, Asakusa is a must see when in Tokyo.

Japanse style temple. The temple resides inside an old Japanse town. I like the temple a lot with the famous tower. The local food there is delicious. I dropped by a ramen house and order a local ramen with a shochu in a rained day. Other local food stores also provide a wide range of Japanese cake. They are really delicious. Highly recommend.

Cherry Blossom & Senso Ji. The main attraction of this place is the Senso Ji temple and thousands of people come here to sight-see and shop at the four blocks of concession booths along the arcade. During peak seasons and sunny days, this place gets really crowded.My favorite time to visit this site is during cherry blossom seasons (mid-March to mid-April) and the winter months (less crowd).Accessibility: The site is wheelchair accessible. The majority of the path is paved in concrete and there is an elevator to the main temple (hidden on the left side of the building).Cherry Blossom: When you finish viewing the temple ground, I highly recommend you walk along the pedestrian path near the river (about 6 blocks east). From here, you can see Sky Tree, Asahi Beer building, and many sakura trees.
Must see, but can be crowded. The crowds come here and the side streets are a relief. Some of the shops are high quality. I am sure if you go when there are no crowds it would be outstanding.

The Oldest Temple in Tokyo that you must visit. I have visited this temple on August 2011 with my brother and his friends.My brother and his friends decided to go to this place, so do I.From web that i have readed this place was very interesting.The location of this temple is very near from Asakusa station.You just need to walk a little bit to reach the temple or you can ride Jinrikisha (Japan becak), about 30,000 yen each person. The Jinrikisha riders are very friendly, he explain all the place that we cross and tell the story about the temple. He with pleasure will help u to take a picture of you while you on that vechile. Nice to try.When you decided to walk, u can see so many store that sell souvenir here, also some foods and drinks. The temple always croweded by the people who wants to pray and sightseeing.I recommended this place to visit. This place have a nice atmosphere.Operating hoursHours: Main hall: 6:00 to 17:00 (from 6:30 from October to March) Temple grounds: Always openClosed: No closing daysAdmission: Free

Great area for tourists. Lots of great tourist market stands here for souvenirs and the Sengoji temple was also really nice and well worth visiting. It is Tokyo's oldest Buddhist temple and a great place to go if you can't make Kyoto.

Beautiful old school charm, hidden gems waiting to be found. Quaint, old school, touristy but with hidden gems around. Seek and you shall find! Yonyoji spice shop mixes the Japanese togarashi spice to your specifications!

Nice sky tree, parks and senso Ji. Make it a day worth trip to explore Asakusa, from senso Ji temple which is apparently the main draw of Asakusa to parks and the newly built sky tree. It's more than one could ask for in Tokyo.If you are traveling on metro, do drop by the park just beside the river for a breath taking view of the Hanami and sky park, that is if you are visiting in Sakura blooming season

like another planet. my hostel was here, i stayed for a week and totally fell in love with the place, its soo clean, the people are really friendly. plenty places to eat and shop on a budget, nothing to dislike although transport and accommodation can be bit pricey!

So crowded. A nice spot to visit thereafter walk to sky tree which is only 20mins away. Although busy but I kind of liking the busy environment, great to people watch here. Shopping at their Nakamise market is great fun too, prize differs from shop to shop, suggest to do a little quick survey before putting down your purchases. Plenty of food stuff sold here, many queues too! Landscape and architecture at the Sensoji temple is great stuff to take a slow stroll around.

Busy but welcoming. A large plaza welcomes tou with countless stalls offering souveniers and other local goods. Eventually you reach the Temple which you can see through the distance. There are multiple temples within the same area a well as the main temple and well worth a view round the park and soak in the atmosphere.
wonderful. wonderful old buildings among the modern buildings, Great place to walk and explore alley ways. Lovely temple. Fun shopping and great little tea shops.

Wonderful neighborhood to walk around. We arrived by boat on the Sumida river, and there is a great view of the Tokyo Sky Tree and Asahi building from the river bank in Asakusa. The Sensoji temple is fascinating, and the shops and surrounding neighborhood were fun to explore.
Excellent. Family friendly location can be similar to a market but the outlets are shops not stalls. Lots of specialty shops everything from fan shops to tea. Shouldn't be missed.

CHARMING AND PROFOUND. The temples, pagoda and shops in Asakusa are a must for any trip to Tokyo. Start by the Buddhist temple, then contemplate the wonderful pagoda, visit the Shinto shrine, and then walk through the shops' street (lot of things to buy) to see the giant lantern and the guardian-god statues, which are imposing. Then return all the way, non stoping, to the temple. Take your time...

Old style Japan a stones throw from all the modern stuff. Asakusa is a dream destination, especially for first time visitors to Japan but its my third time here and I still love it.It is old Japan in architecture, food, temples, history, cultural significance etc etc. it's a very beautiful place, great for photos and you can enjoy it day and night.There is a couple of public bath options, hundreds of restaurants and all variety, great shopping, both touristy and just good shopping as well as having lots of street food.The place is very busy because its very popular with Japanese domestic tourists but there plenty of room for everyone.Probably the only down side is that its not on a JR line so you can't use you JR pass for the train from the station for a couple of stops but its only a couple of dollars each time.Location to greater Tokyo is easy with Akihabara, Shibuya, Shinjuku, Tokyo, Harajuku, Ginza all easy by train. The Sumidagawa river is right there as well so you can take a ferrie.The new Tokyo sky tree is in Asakusa as well which is a great view point and shopping centre.It's certainly not a party areas but there are some izakaya for a drink. It can be a great place to stay but is a destination for a day trip in its own right if staying somewhere else.

Enjoy the Crowd. We just went straight to the Senjosi Temple. But it was a very busy place and we had to go through a sea of people in the alley just to get to the temple. Don't get me wrong, the Japanese are very polite so there was no pushing or shoving from them. It was a very good experience.

Crowed but fun and loads of tiny little shops. I visited Tokyo with my 2 older kids and they LOVED this place. It's the only part of Tokyo we went to twice. They enjoyed seeing the temple but loved the many tiny streets crowded with stalls selling all sorts of things. My son even found a sword shop selling replicas- he'd been hunting all over Tokyo to find one.Yes the main area is really crowded but it's a fun lively group of people all enjoying the experience.Take time to explore the area- off the main street to the temple are many side streets with interesting items for sale.
Lots of stalls selling food, souvenirs. Popular place to visit, stalls very busy.Senjosi Temple at the end of the stalls - extremely popular with the Japanese and tourists.Lots of history.

Lots of shops and stalls for buying gifts. Asakusa was recommended to us as the old-style part of Tokyo. It's seriously busy but there was lots to see and loads of shops and stalls - it's a good place to find traditional presents for friends, everything from ceramics to kimonos.

One of the best attractions in Japan. Asakusa is a place where you will not get sicked of going even for how many times. The place is the actual representation of Japan (since this is the oldest temple in Tokyo). Before reaching Sensoji Temple, you will pass through the Nakamise-dori. It's a street full of omise (store) selling different stuffs like Kimono (Japanese traditional garment), okashi (Japanese sweets), and lot of souvenirs that you can only see in Asakusa. After passing through Nakamise-dori,you will easily see the Sensoji Temple. There's an incense urn where lots of people are gathering.Japanese believes that the incense smoke from the urn will make you smart. Also there is the dragon faucet,where people either drink or wash their hands (it is a belief that it brings luck and prosperity). Then the last is inside the Sensoji temple,where you can offer your prayers and respect. You can throw coins before offering a prayer.When going to Asakusa, don't forget to bring your camera or video camera. Don't worry because the place might be crowded (especially along the Nakamise-dori) but when you are already there,you'll feel that you just have to enjoy the crowd. If you plan on buying something, bring extra money since the prices are quite high. Foods? There are lot of food stands inside but also the prices are quite high. The best day to go to Asakusa is during weekdays since the place is not that crowded. Although I've been to Asakusa twice,I'm not getting sick yet of going again especially during events and festivals. I'm sure I will come back to Asakusa some time.
lots of foreign tourists. There's lots of foreign tourists there, and lots of interesting souvenir stores and food stalls.

The heart of shitamachi. Asakusa is the heart of shitamachi, the lower town of Tokyo. If you want the latest in fashion boutiques or designer goods go to Ginza or Shibuya. If you want to see the traditional side of Japan in Tokyo go to Asakusa. Wander the back alleys check out the specialty shops have a beer or sake in an isakaya. One nice thing for foreigners is that you are always welcome in Asakusa. In some other areas people may not want to bother with serving foreigners but in Asakusa its never a problem.

Senso-ji temple and Tokyo Skytree. I like to visit the Senso-ji temple here with its big gates and pagoda. It is a short walk from here over to the river, a good place to take pictures of Tokyo Skytree.Asakusa subway line connects the area to both Narita and Haneda airport.
Wonderful. Lovely structure and certainly worth a visit to enjoy the views.Plenty of photo opportunities and can wash in a buddhist fountain which is nice
Old Edo charm. Lots of gimmicky Edo style shops, but lovely all the same. More laid back than Shinjuku/Shibuya. Especially loved walking along the river from the Edo museum towards Damonji gate.
Wonderful. Sadly it was being renovated when I visited but worth a visit. Also the area around is a nice eye opener. I even went into a small theme park and just watched everyone. Highly entaining.

Excellent local attraction place!. The place is big with lots of chances to take pictures on the local/authentic Japanese feel. The place has lots of shops to buy Japanese stuff and the best rice crackers too! There are many cafes/eateries along the alleys so one must explore then decide.

Pretty temple - busy market. We went to visit Sensoji temple in the afternoon 12am, the temple is really nice very pretty architecture and although the area is bustling with people the temple is quite nice.Me and my partner washed our hands in a little bhuddist fountain which was, i think a blessing or somesort. We got a fortune from the main building which is great. Also there is a garden surrounding the temple with lots of ponds and koy.the markets surrounding the temple where nice but we thought the selection of things to buy was a bit boring - mainly key rings and clothes. Nice atmosphere we also had a funky ice cream with an odd flavour - but very good. There are also rickshaws and runners who offer to take you around the whole area and see the sights. Although he was very friendly we didnt have enough time or money to jump on.All in all good day :)

Perfect place for souvenirs. If you are having headache of buying souvenirs, this is the place for you to buy souvenirs from Japan. From the Kaminarimon to the Shrine, rows of shops for you to buy souvenirs. Prices are reasonable, souvenirs are of plenty of selections. Other than the souvenirs, its a nice place to visit and photo taking. I think this place is considered as one of the landmark of Tokyo.
I love Asakusa.. Very touristy area, just as many as Shibuya crossing area. Tourists flock around the temples and the red bridge! Great views from the Skytower and food is pretty cheap :)

Busy but manageble. This is a city where you can walk round without to many crowds and take in the atmosphere of Tokyo. Restaurants are reasonable and most have picture menus.This is not the area to go clubbing (Shibuya or Shinjuku), even though they do have some really cosy bars.

Nice neighborhood. Really nice neighborhood to walk though once you go visit the shrine in the area. I went to the shrine super early and then walked around looking for a breakfast place and there are tons more nice areas than just the shrine.

a smorgasbord of japan. We had a day in Tokyo and visited Asakusa for a few hours during a weekday. It is well worth a visit and if done leisurely you could spend the better part of a day there with lunch in neighbouring surrounds.There are lots of food stalls serving snacks with restaurants nearby, almost any Japanese souvenirs and some temples and gardens thrown in. Great spot for some photos and easily accessible from the Ginza subway line.Nearby, there are some old shop houses with owners in traditional dress. Would love to go back and visit at a more leisurely pace.
Lovely!. When we went there were a lot a lot of people, but the place is nice and has all the feeling of tourism attractionThe principal temple is gorgeous

A must see!. This temple is easy to get to and costs nothing when you get there!There are many temples on site but the largest of them is quite a sight! The gardens are lovely too and I came in the winter!!!Around the temple there are LOTS of things to buy and I felt you could look at your leisure without pressure to buy!Go and soak the atmosphere in!

Wonderful place to stock up on gifts. The open market is very large and stocked with tons of colourful, locally-made gift items. Also some very interesting items to look at such as wigs that are worn with kimono, face masks etc.

Nice neighbourhood. I loved Asakusa, it's a quiet neighbourhood. The most I liked to wander at dusk. The Taito Kannon Temple at night is a lovely as in the day light. Near the temple there are some small streets where I spotted some good kaiten-sushi. There's a street full of shops settin homewares, and I regret I didn't buy a couple of Japanese kitchen kinves there. so, I'd better come back there one more!
Must Visit Area. It has it all.. Be sure to make a stop here. See the temple, the great places to eat and buy your gifts

Top Tokyo Tourist site + tips. Sensoji Temple in Asakusa is almost featured in every travel brochure to Japan. Because everyone wants to take a picture in front of the Thunder Gate (with the lamp). It is advisable to get there early, there are multiple lines which can reach Asakusa station, from time to time there are English interpreter there to help the tourists.Enjoy ! Who knows you might be able to find a bargain in one of the stalls there !

Nice amble through a more rustic side of Tokyo. Delightful streets, mixture of old and new buildings, interesting shops... definitely had a good time walking in Asakusa. Would recommend it definitely, such a refreshing change of pace from downtown Tokyo.

Touristy traditional. I always like a little stroll through Asakusa, or a brief peruse their long market stalls, its very tourist oriented but sometimes thats fun! You can get some nice snacks, cheap gifts and can hitch a costly but fun riksaw ride - personally I was happier with looking at the drivers than the views about the city but thats just me XD
Must see in Tokyo. All about old Tokyo, good for any Gaijins visiting Tokyo whether for thefirst time or return visits.

Bustling and full of life. Asakusa is a must visit when going to Tokyo... in fact its a place we have been to several times, and still enjoy. During the day its so busy, with all the little shops open and all the visitors to the Temple. In the evening there the temple is so much quieter, but looks stunning all lit up. There's also plenty to do round there in terms of eating etc, and if you feel like a walk the Sky Tree isnt too far.

Old Tokyo. The markets in the surrounding street are quite cool, full of souveniers and snack foods. The temple gate and giant lantern is a great photo. It's a good place to get gifts and souveniers and didn't seem too overpriced. Walk along the main shopping and market street will take you from the gate to the sensoji temple. Surrounding streets look awesome at nighttime with lights, lanterns, shops. Many rickshaw guys are available to take you around, I didn't use them but saw quite a few people who were. You won't see this kind of area or get this atmosphere many places, this was the only place I found on my visit in Tokyo. You can also see and photo the Skytree from here. :-) You can go and not pay a cent, or you can shop and eat. Freedom is yours, enjoy your holiday!

Amazing jam packed tourist markets. Obviously tourist stuff but one or two streets back from the shrine are fantastic second hand kimono shops. Plenty of restaurants and accessible by two undergrounds. Cool spot.

Kimonos, temples, and so much food. Miso flavoured ice cream, rice balls with miso paste, shopping for kimono, Studio Ghibli store, Kappabashi-dori kitchenware and "fake food" street, and ukiyo-e prints - we spent a day just wandering the streets of Asakusa and were much delighted by what we found. A bit touristy perhaps, but take some of it with a grain of salt, and it is lovely to behold. The tourist information centre is very good, plus they have a wonderful viewing platform which gives you amazing views of Tokyo Sky Tree and the street leading up to the shrine.

Can't get enough of this place!. Asakusa is one of the most atmospheric areas in Tokyo and an absolute must see for anyone who only has a short stay in this amazing city. The main attraction is the Senso-ji temple however the whole area is bursting with things to see and do. Yes, it is very touristy but isn't that the case with most popular and well loved places? I have now been here on 2 occasions, once on a weekday and another just last weekend. Go on a weekday if you prefer less crowds. Even on a cold winters day, Asakusa was teeming with people on a Saturday and progress up the Nakamise-dori shopping street moved at a snails pace (although this may only be because it was the week after New Years Day when 1000s of locals visit the Shrine for their New year blessing). However the advantage of going on a weekend is all the additional food stalls surrounding Senso-ji Temple that aren't there on a week day creating a really carnival like atmosphere. These stalls sell an incredible array of food I don't see at home like skewered whole fish on hot coals, multicoloured choc coated bananas and amazing omelette styled dishes full of goodies cooked on a huge grill.Explore the backstreets and you will find heaps of restaurants to suit all budgets including street stall like operations packed with locals.There are also a lot of artisans selling their crafts.Not far from the Senso-ji Temple is a small amusement park. Opposite the huge entrance gates leading to Sensoji is a funky and modern design wood and black steel 8 storey building which houses a Tourist Information Centre and won a design award in 2012. Take the time to go to the 8th floor to get a more aerial view not just of Senso-ji and Nakamise-dori shopping street but also the impressive modern architecture to the right including the Phillip Starke designed building with the unusual gold formation on top . At sunset, this is magical with the sun bouncing off the gold facades of the buildings (see photos). There is a small cafe on the 8th floor.Also in Asakusa is a Drum Museum and the reknown Kappabashi-dori street that sells kitchen gear and all the plastic food models you see in Japanese restaurants.So in short this spot has something for everyone and is easily accessible by subway.

Senso-ji is filled with lots of fun shops. They were lots of shops on the way to the temple grounds (the temple itself is a must see). Also the drum museum was sinteresting and the sushi restaurants are excellent on Sushi Street
traditional neighborhood. we loved this neighborhoods traditional feel and its proximity to the riverside park, however, the area around the shrine was extremely touristy.

A Little Late. After a nice walk at the Hama-rikyu Garden, we took the last ferry from there to Asakusa. The boat ride was wonderful, passing under all the bridges in between and made the stop at Asakusa. We found a small restaurant nearby and had a wonderful meal. Too bad I forgot the name of the restaurant. Unfortunately, we were there a little late, especially after dinner. Most of the vendors were closed or closing as we were walking through. We still had a nice stroll of the area and trying out little sweets and snacks. Had a great evening there but would go there earlier next time.

One of my favorites in Tokyo!. I was lucky enough to be within walking distance of this very cool village. I had no idea how much I would like it. I recommend renting a bike there, which is extremely cheap(a few dollars for the day) . The bike place is located near the boat tour building, but you have to go down a ramp where they have hundreds of bikes. They don't speak much english, if any. Bikes are a great way to get around Tokyo since its so spread out. I took mine over to Akihabara(Electronic City. I really liked Asakusa because of the flea market type setup called Nakamise Street as you walk to the temple. There is a ton of cool and interesting sweets to buy. Also, they have just finished building the Tokyo Skytree across the river. It is one of the tallest buildings in the world and will offer amazing views of Tokyo, as well as many new restaurants and shops. Be sure to get over there is you are in Asakusa.You can also catch a nice tour boat from Asakusa. I recommend taking the boat to Odaiba which is an island full of shopping, restaurants, and the Toyota showroom, and a giant ferris wheel. The boat itself is amazing and well worth it.

Regular Visitor. Asakusa is a wonderful place Sensoji and Nakamise Dori are great but dont miss the Kamiya Barright near the excit of the Ginza Line Subway if you want to meet friendly Japanese..Also head twards the Temple and just before you reach it turn left and find the back streetsanother great area to meet friendly Natives.. Very safe Night or day, Last Saturday in Julybig Firework display Kamiya bar also has extensive Menu, and cheap

Must visit!. This is tourist must visit stop. I went here several times and still find something new to try or even buy. From the traditional sweets to the sumptous food stops, i would easily spend more than half a day here. The rickshaws were a bit pricey but a fun experience. There are so many things to look at and photos to snap. The beautiful temple and the wonderful shops really transformed me into a hyper active touristy frenzy each time i visited the place!Best of all, i get to bargain. Please visit this place!
Sundays!. You must go there on Sundays.It has a lot of awesome food and sweeties!Check the tents with Yakisobas and ice cones! They're the best!

Old tokyo. Very popular with locals and tourists, can get very crowded. Visited mainly for the Sensoji temple but it's also a nice option to stay if you want a taste of traditional Tokyo with lots of food options as well. Lots and lots of touristy shops.

Must do. Asakusa is a cool place and it's really not hard to get to. The big temple here with its shopping street is something to experience. I've never taken a rickshaw ride around the neighborhood, as I'm not sure how many (if any) of the driver speak English.

Beautiful Shrine and Kitchentown. Travel to the Asakusa stop of the Ginza line and all within a stone's throw, you'll find 'Kitchentown' which is a whole street (Kappabashi Dori) of kitchen ware, and the fake food that you see sitting in the windows of japanese restaurants in japan and in the US. And you'll also find the Asakusa Temple, one of the most beautiful in the city of Tokyo

Old Tokyo. Quite a fascinating area of Tokyo, and definitely worth a visit, although it is a bit of a tourist trap.If you want to see a little bit of the old Tokyo "preserved", you could do worse than spend an afternoon wandering around the streets of Asakusa. Beware though, the area is very much geared to providing the tourist with a version of what they expect Tokyo to be like ("just like the movies!") but it is definitely worth it as a starting point. You might be better off going to Kyoto though for more of that "authentic" Japanese experience.Anyway, do come, check it out, but just be on guard in terms of buying anything here, but it is definitely carrying a tourist price tag.

For a great day out!. You only need an hour to get around this wonderful complex that mixes worship and commerce in a single area. Come here to get:1. Shrine action with a smattering of pagodas.2. Shopping for food and souvenirs.3. Monuments.4. Lovely Japanese gardens and koi swimming in a pond.Really close to the dock where you can catch the ferry to Tokyo, Tokyo.Best experiences with a walking tour app, if you are a tourist and want to get some information on what you're looking at.Tip: When you exit the train station, make a right and keep going along that main street. Asakusa will be to your right on that main street. If you go left, you'll end up at the dock.

Beautiful and peaceful neighborhood. It is definitely another great neighborhood having a beautiful shrine, many quality restaurants, lots of souvenir shops and a lovely old atmosphere of past times of Tokyo.
