Try to wonder around the streets away from the temple for reasonably priced souvenirs and restaurants.

typical tourist attraction. Tried the rickshaw near the temple.. its expensive 3000 yen and an experience to remember! the surrounding street are rather unique.. nice place to pop by. Its 15 minutes walk to sky tree. to pray to the deities, please proceed to the fountain to purify yourself before purchasing some joss sticks from the counter at 100 Yen and pray. if you have gotten a bad fortune slip for whatever you had wish for, please do not bring the slip of paper home. tie it at the stand and the monk will burn it for you at the end of the month. Bringing the slip home is believe to bring bad luck.

Feels like a festival every day.. So much to do with all the traditional shops, restaurants and attractions in this area. Definitely go to spend a day seeing all the sites and sounds of this old area of Tokyo.
Nice place. Catch the boat to Odaiba! Have a walk, watch people... Shops are cheaper far from the shrine. Tokyo is amazing

Try the Rickshaw!. Very touristy, but great fun. The surrounding streets are really interesting too, not just the row of stalls on the lead up to the Temple. The rickshaw is expensive, 3000 yen for barely 15 minutes, but it's good fun and the guide spoke English giving us some interesting info along the way.

Nice but too much touristic. The temple is beautiful and its interesting to visit and to observe. Peaceful and very coloured, traditions and Japanese flavour. Surroundings are pretty touristic for my taste. A small bazar before entering the temple itself selling souvenirs, pricey of course.
Beautiful shrine and great shopping. Easy to get to by train and fun to walk around day or night. Lots of sights, shopping and reasonable restaurants in this area.

Afternoon in Askusa Tokyo. Definetely nice place to visit in Tokyo to see tradition and "old fasion" market. Lots of things to see and taste, great food and souvenir shoping.Not far away to walk from Ginza or come by Sumida river boat.5 strories pagoda, Kanon Temple-Sensoji, oldest Budhist temple in Tokyo are there just few steps awayDefinetely recomended to vist
Lovely area. Brilliant area, still very neighbourhood like, with good restaurants and very atmospheric at night, especially around the shrine area.
Asakusa Area. Really fun lots of stalls and things to buy - we were there in the New Year so lots of stuff happening and loved all the food and bustle and bits n pieces to buy.

Very touristic place but the temple is nice. This is a highly touristic place, full of many Japenese shops proposing various items from food to toys, shoes, or souvenirs. The street going to the Temple starts by a huge red lantern and at the end,you will find the impressive hudge old Asakusa temple from the 17th Century.It's interesting to see that despite the important touristic activity it's a place of pray for the Japanese people.

Asakusa area and Tokyo Tree. A place to visit when you have the time. The senojji temple is said to be the oldest temple in Japan and gets very crowded during the days. If you visit during the night 6 pm to around 9 pm it gets quieter but the souvenir shops would be close by then.After the temple head on the to the Tokyo sky tree which is just another train ride away on the Tobu sky tree line.

Tourist attraction, Souvenier Street. Easily accessable via subway, 2 mins walk from subway station. Follow the crowd, can't miss it. Lines of shops selling snacks, touristy gifts but price not cheap. You can donate Y100 and get a fortune telling slip which has English translation. Great place for photographs.
NIce area. This area has a quiet side and a lively side to it. Shrine and park are nice and some good places to eat.A jewellery makers mecca if you head down Edo-dori.

Great photo op. Asakusa is a great tourist spot, lots of shops & temples. Check out prices closer to the station first, they are cheaper than they are right on the strip. Food is available on the side streets off the strip.

Asakusa is a place you must go if in Japan. You can find some great gifts while shopping the strip, it's very busy on weekends so we went on a Monday & it wasn't that bad. Check out the prices near the station first, I found cheaper prices on the same items. The airport has gift shops as you are leaving the country as well with great little gift like book marks, refridgerator magnets, etc. Great food on the side streets, we ate on a street that had a Theatre on it with a Kaboki man statue sitting on a roof if front of the noodle shop. We had the best chashuman noodles, they cooked them right in front of us. You can see the new Sky3 tower from the strip which made for a great photo op, the temples are beautiful for photos also.

Worth seeing. Like most reveiws I agree, this can get crowded and a little kitschy. That said, the temples are beautiful. Be sure to look at the smaller shrines and walk the side streets. I didn't have a lot of time and it was raining lightly but it is a worthwhile taste of Tokyo.

Fascinating. Amazing temple and surrounds. Very busy, mainly Japanese tourists, so go there early to have a quiet look, but by all means return later to watch the crowds. There are lots of shops leading up to the temple, which are of course rather touristy, but some of them sell quality stuff. Lots of food stalls, too, and they are surprisingly good value for money.While in the area, go down to the river bank as well for a pleasant stroll and view.

Heavily touristic area with expensive food. The asakusa area is a very touristic area. There are a lot of souvenir shops at the alley leading to the asakusa kamon temple. However, it is really not worth going all the way there to buy the souvenirs there as you can actually buy the same snacks in any part of Tokyo at the same price since you don't bargain in Japan and the price for all the food items in packaging are the same anywhere. In fact you can buy these snacks at narita airport at 5% less at the departure area as it is tax free( Japan has a 5% VAT tax). The food is actually expensive there and is the most expensive in Tokyo- you can get much cheaper and nicer food in Shinjuku or shibuya. Hence will not recommend going there.

If you are wondering where all the tourists are.... We had spent 3 full days in Tokyo and hadn't really come across many tourists. We found them all in Asakusa! It is an interesting visit and we saw a different part of Tokyo, but be prepared for crowds. We did go on a Saturday, and got the benefits of seeing all the market stalls. I would recommend that you wander down the side streets and explore - more interesting than staying on the mail streets.

Been here five times. This area of Tokyo is filled with history. Senso-ji is located in this area as well as Nakamisa-dori that leads up to it. The whole area really is the welcome you're waiting for when you first come to Japan. It's what you always see in TV and movies when you think of Japanese temples and shoji screens. The little shops on either side of the covered arcade of Nakamisa-dori are quaint and you can find some nice gifts here. A must see, period.

Touristy but Great for Photos. Having visited the Asakusa neighborhood twice, in 2012 and 2008, I have to say the Nakamise - the pedestrian street leading up to the Senso-ji - is now a lot more touristy and commercialized. Simple street snacks now cost a fortune and the traditional kimono and Japanese goods have been replaced with cheap and garish Made-in-China products. The Senso-ji and the various temples and shrines surrounding it are beautiful examples of Japanese architecture, and still worth a visit. Do spend some time exploring the tiny streets surrounding the temples. There are some interesting finds to be found. A fantastic and affordable lunch option we read about on Foursquare is 中華そば つし馬 (no English name), a coin-operated ramen house along the covered shopping arcade by the Asakusa subway station.

A great spot, go for the side temples. Alot of clustered shops and odd attractions. The side temples are great and well tended. The main temples very loud and taking a photo of yourself is impossible.

What a great place to start off a trip in Japan. Like other reviewers have said - Asakusa is a great area, a lot of fun, interesting to see, full of life, beautiful temples, and a great introduction to Japan.I visited Asakusa on my first day in Tokyo, and found it so enjoyable to stroll the shopping street, Temple, and laneways and food stalls... I loved taking in all the people and sights and foods and goods for sale - touristy enough to enjoy, but still a real Japan experience with the most amazing Temple to take in, and some great eating places too.A fantastic start to the Tokyo experience, and a good 'warm up' before heading to those big areas like Ginza, Shibuya and Shinjuku.

Small touristy slice of traditional Japan. A nice area to visit - it's a big break from the lights and sounds of Shibuya or Shinjuku. The streets surrounding and leading up to the temple are lined with tourist shops (designed like old Japanese merchant houses). It's a fun place to go shopping for gimmicks, regional delicacies and green tea soft serves. Throughout Japan I was trying to find a novelty solar powered Manekki Neko cat for my colleagues in the office, and this place sold them, and other tourist type items in abundance.If you are after something more 'real' and historic, then try Kyoto's Higashiyama district or Hida-Takayama and the merchant houses there.

Asakusa Trip. One thing about Asakusa that I love is that it’s quite a nice introduction to Japan if you’ve never been. Jumping straight into living in the major populated busy areas in Tokyo such as Shinjuku, Harajuku or Shibuya could be a bit overwhelming at the beginning.Asakusa provides a touristy feel, but allows you to mingle with the locals at a slower pace. Sensoji temple and the markets surrounding are a great place to visit. Souvenirs can be bought and delicacies such as Taiyaki are available. Be sure to try the pineapple cream cheese ones as well as the red bean original ones. I can’t express how good and different they are in comparison to ones we have in Perth.There are a couple of 100 yen stores around where you can find all sorts of goodies. It’s similar to the $2 shops in Australia only 100 times better, with quality products and gifts. If you’re looking for Tokyo fashion such as harajuku styles or people dressed similarly you won’t find them in this area.Since Asakusa is well located, you can jump on multiple train lines to Ueno, Akihabara and Shibuya (30mins).

Tokyo Temple & Market. This was a fun area to visit, even though it feels tourist-y. The Temple, which has been rebuilt many times since it's found in 645AD, is a great place to visit and take some photographs. The surrounding market is full of many interesting stores and shops, selling food, tourist oriented goods and souvenirs, as well as a larger variety of items on the side streets. There were lots of local school groups visiting on Friday. Very close to the Asakusa metro stop; across the street, you can transfer to the SkyTree line, to go and visit that.

Great Area - Its touristy, but it feels more traditional and less like just another big city.. I loved the Asakusa area. Not only was there a temple with gates and gardens to explore, but the surrounding areas were charming and full of arcades to shop in and local stores and restaurants to pop into. I would definitely recommend this area to anyone visiting Tokyo!
Shopping. There is a great area of shopping here. Lots of craziness, but also some very neat stores (check out the side streets).
Temple. Asakusa temple and market is amazing. I return here every trip. Beautiful. It has great shopping on the temple grounds and around the temple as well. So many amazing sites and sounds

Go for the smaller side temples. The Akusa area, has, besides a nummer of realy local shops, a lot of impressive temples. We advise not to take a tour but go there by taxi or underground, because you need more time to visit the smaller temples and parks around the main temple. The smaller temples and parks are much nicer and quieter than the main one. And thus will give you a far better experience.

A must for tourists, plus Sky Tree. I've been dozens of times and it's always the same... magical, with lots of old Japan. A 20-minute walk to the uber modern Sky Tree Tower for a completely different experience. You can do both in a long day, but better to give them a day each or you'll be cheating yourself.

Easily the Highlight of Our Trip!. My girlfriend and I visited Asakusa on the last day of our Japan trip in February this year.Other than Sensoji and the Kaminarimon, I originally did not expect much of this area and was greatly surprised to find out how much there was in store. You get immersed in local culture pretty much immediately upon leaving the station (in my opinion, more than Kyoto) and you'll find the atmosphere very relaxing and welcoming. The shopping streets, like Nakamise, are also filled with interesting local goods. All that easily made Asakusa the favorite part of my trip.Duration-wise, we spent about 4 hours in the area, including a 60 minute rickshaw ride and 2 - 2.5 hours in the Sensoji area at a comfortable pace. I advise allotting more time (about half a day in total) if planning to explore more of the area by foot.Good points:- Great cultural feel- Numerous shops selling traditional food and souvenirs in the area- Interesting juxtaposition of the new (modern buildings) and old (traditional temples, etc.) especially when they're often side by sideBad points:- Casual tourists might miss smaller but still noteworthy places of interest (e.g. Hanayashiki, a theme park; taikokan, a drum museum, etc.)Others:- If your budget allows, try the rickshaw ride near the station exit. It is pricey, but the experience is amazing and the guide is friendly and informative (they speak English too) - we got to learn a lot more like the old Japanese theme park, the area's history (and a lot of those statues around that we probably wouldn't have noticed otherwise). The guides are humorous too!

crowded with tourist as usual. went there everytime I went to Japan, I can only say its crowded with tourist as usual. if you have more time, go around the area and not just the nakamise shopping street

Great area!. July, 2011. So clean, so filled with ancient wonder and fun little shops! Great food, very good vibes and overall, just charming! Great temples, parks, energy everywhere. Wonderful silences too in the sacred areas. Fabulous!

a must-do. a beautiful example of the contrast between tradition and hyperfuturistic architecture that you can experience in tokyo. A beautiful old temple, and a set of nice traditional stores where you can buy nice souvenirs. My wife loved a stre that sells traditional japanese dolls. By the way, this is a real temple, not a museum. People go about thier religious business and one needs to be respectful. A great experience

Highlight of my Tokyo trip!. This area of Tokyo has so much to offer in both a tourism and cultural aspect. When you first walk into the alley that leads to the shrine it's literally a shock, tiny stalls lined with usual tourist goods as well traditional sweet stalls and craft shops, all reasonable prices if you want to buy gifts for friends or relatives. I would recommend doing the temple first before browsing the stalls! When you first walk into the shrine there is a huge urn burning a smokey intense, which fills the air, as well as chanting, girls in kimonos, and monks. In all my travels I've never seen something as unique. The Temple is a gasping red colour with lanterns on every corner, and there as lots of separate pagodas and outbuildings as well as floral and statue displays. If you go into the main temple you can see the monks performing Buddhist rituals and chants, which is fascinating! After leaving the temple I felt somewhat enlightened and was by far one of the highlights of my trip! Do this first as it will get you excited for what else Tokyo has to offer!
Nice section of Tokyo. Wonderfully quiet and unique part of Tokyo. Lots of history, festival-style decor, traditional food.

Nice market. I visited during new year and the place was packed but the atmosphere was amazing. The main temple is a must see during this period as many go to pray (more so than normal). A large market is situated right infront of the temple and you could spend a few hours looking around the normal tourist tat and some stunning items that you could take home as gifts.Very easy to find from the main train station (about 5 mintues) that links direct to most places on the subway.

Edo Period Markets!. Check out the huge Edo Period Market, which is around a 5 minute walk from Asakusa station, it's located just off of the main road (turn left down a side street or follow a rickshaw man). They have so many traditional Japanese wares, and the market itself is so beautiful, covered in cherry blossom lanterns and ebony stalls.Take advantage of a rickshaw ride around to the River, they are hand pulled by the men with ninja shoes and dressed in black. As the river is located across the road from the station, you could also go and check that out, there is a company that runs a river cruise service all the way to Rainbow bridge. There are many bridges to see on the way too!

Vintage Kimonos! Temples! Plastic Food!. This was one of the most interesting neighbourhoods we visited in Tokyo. I had a plan to buy a vintage kimono and a 'window sample' - plastic food like you have never seen before! We got close to Senso-ji temple by subway, then walked through delightful streets to the area around the temple, which had some very nice market stalls. The shop I had researched for kimonos didn't have great stuff, but just around the corner, next to an ice-cream shop was a store that makes new kimonos and there was a wee sign in the window that they had vintage ones upstairs. 90 minutes later I was having an ice-cream and the proud owner of two beautiful kimonos (one hand-painted), with obi, zori and some hair pieces - all to hang on my wall at home. The lady was wonderful and her prices were ok - competitive I would say. We communicated in sign language and through the APP on my smartphone! Next we visited the temple, which was the most crowded of any I had seen in Tokyo (we hadn't visited Kyoto at that stage so hadn't experienced the crowds there!). It is gorgeous though. After that, we used the guide book to navigate through a busy narrow laned area to Kappabashi Street, where you could buy anything in the world for your kitchen or restaurant. We finally found the three or four shops selling window samples - they are perfect replicas of Japanese meals, made entirely of plastic. You simply cannot understand why your nose can't smell the food! They look so REAL! Pretty pricey, but we bought a small piece. A great afternoon in Asakusa.
Be early ;). If you come early to the Nakamise you will have enough time to browse through the little shops before all the tourists come

Worth a visit. We went to Asakusa primarily to see the Sensoji Temple. This was the only temple we visited in Tokyo, so I don't really have anything to compare it to, but it is very beautiful and has the biggest lanterns I have ever seen! The temple was small and busy with lots of people burning incense and getting fortunes. In the area immediately around the temple had cute shops and on your way to the temple from the station you can see their version of the Hollywood stars.

Favourite place. You may like a full day here or an over nighter. My favourite thing to do out of all activities in Japan was to have the rickshaw ride around Asakusa with Yusi. It was the best. Eating at sushi go round was a great cheap cheap experience - highly recommend. Wander the streets after your rickshaw ride they are gorgeous. Great shopping and great tourist attractions. Love this place. You won't see Geishas but you will see their district and training school.
Very nice! But.... ... an awful lot of tourists. If you want to find a temple ground with not to much people, Asakusa is not the place. But it is of course a must see in Tokyo.
Shopping galore. A lot of restaurants and shopping available in Asakusa. Great for little knick knacks or souvenir's. Interesting place to shop is outside the Sensoji-Temple.

Old & Fun. Excellent place to go to if you like temples, parks, pagodas, traditional shops and food. Absolute must see in Tokyo. What I especially liked about the place is the quietness compared to Shibuya, Roppongi and so on. It's a very peaceful place. Bring your camera!

Amazing culture. Love the Sight and the culture experience here. Bought quite a no. of stuff and ate a no. of foods. It's not a place to be miss. The negative: wasn't able to bargain about the prices.

Asakusa. If you are in Tokyo, one of the places to see that is not 21st century is Asakusa area. However considering how many temples and ancient japanese areas exist, I would rather recommend other places to visit. The thing that struck me first was how many foreign tourist there are. One second you are in japanese only filled metro, the next you dont even feel like you are in Japan. However what this place does offer is a perfect blend of old and new Japan. Here you are admiring the ancient temples and across the street you can clearly see a visible Sky Tree Tower that has just been open to the public. Whoever collects magnets and tiny souvenirs here there are plenty. If you really want to experience ancient Japan, go to Nara ;)
Senjo ji temple. Very nice to walk around, enjoy the shops with japanese souvenirs and the temple

Great temple experience. I was lucky enough to be here at a flower festival. It is very crowded with both locals & tourists but you do get the spirit of japan here.It was great to see so many children learning about their culture

Back for a second fortune from the temple. The temple here really is beautiful. Make sure you get your 100yen fortune! We were here pretty early, around 8.30am and had the place to ourselves. We then caught the river cruise down to the Fish Markets and got to see Tokyo from River View. Worth a look for sure.

Asakusa - Great place to experience traditional Japan. I was recently in Tokyo on business and had one free day. A colleague suggested Asakusa. It was definitely worth the trip. Take subway. From Shibuya station, take the Ginza line to the last stop. Great little shops and restaurants along alleyways that lead to the temples, shrines, and the five-stored pagoda. There is even an amusement park there. I would recommend spending the day or even a few hours in Asakusa.

Nice but crowded. Asakusa had beautiful temples and a nice market street but it was so crowded with tourists and people trying to sell different things. On the other hand it was a great view of the tokyo sky tree!

Favorite. Asakusa became our favorite place, especially the area around the temple.We liked the small market like atmosphere and we were lucky to find the Gyu-Kaku restaurant between the market and the metro. Don't miss it.Grill at the table. Can't beat that. Note, there are other Gyu-Kaku places too. We stopped by one in Shinjuku that also was nice.

crowded, full of tourist but worth seeing. like many other grand temple of the world is always full of tourist, this temple is not an exception. always full and crowded. they have some store on the way to the temple selling souvenirs, cloth and food for sure. its bit expensive but Tokyo are expensive any ways :p Many local still pray in this temple so please respect them and the temple by not too disturbing them when photographing etc. Asakusa is very easy to find, even with yamanote line :) best come not in the weekend !

old and new japan. old temples, small walkup eating houses (cheap good eats) subway to everywhere. 13yr old boy loved the indoor baseball batting stadium. very friendly locals, only too happy to help just ask.Dislike- very crowded on weekends at temples
Udo atmosphere. Nice lanes to shop more traditional Japanese ware. A street dedicated to cooking ware. Nice coffe shop Bridge

A must go in Tokyo. Nice Nakamise shopping street just on the way to asakusa. Lotsa souvenirs and Japanese snacks you can buy home you can see and buy, immerse yourself in jap culture and food here. I loved this place. The temple was a photo stop :)
Old Japan. Nice temple, garden, shops and food stalls and restaurants
I love asakusa. We were there around 20-22 May and there was a really amazing festival on. Wonderful place!
nice place, great shops & restaurant around there. must-visit tourist attraction, lots of people, really enjoy shopping along the way to sensoji temple

Fantastic!!!. I knew literally nothing about Asakusa before my visit. It quickly became one of my favorite places in the world. So much to see and do. So many great places to eat. So much unexpected fun and so easy to get around. I highly recommend walking around to enjoy the sights. So much to see and possibly miss if you are in a car. The people I encountered were all incredibly friendly with the exception of one lady in a coffee shop that I witnessed yelling at some school children that were passing by. I don't know the story behind it but I think that lady was just grouchy :) But don't worry, everyone will treat you with great hospitality.

souvenirs. this is one of the best place for sightseeing and to buy souvenir, you can find several choices along the way to the temple. this place is also nearby to the tokyo cruise. the nearest metro stop is Asakusa by Ginza line.
always a pleasure. not so much a sight as an immersion experience. You might well wonder what all the fuss is about, but let it grow on you. chill.

Great fun.. I love coming to Asakusa. I love Sensoji. The shopping is fun with a great ice cream seller in the shops near the large toilet block.Do try and go there for a festival, it's really worth it. We were there for Setsubun and it was AWESOME!I do try and avoid the bar area of Asakusa as I'm a non-drinker.If you like japanese kitch for old old theatre and shows from the 50s then there are bars for you in Asakusa too. Also there is a street decorated in Tanuki, pics, statues (metal and ceramic) and a pose as a male and female tanuki with your face in the hole stand for anyone to use. lol It's on the way from the temple to the ROX 3 building.

Nice place to walk & shop. Great place to shop in Tokyo. For small things like keychains, pencils, magnets etc, don't expect to get lower price than other place in Tokyo, but some other things are cheaper than other place in Tokyo. They won't allow you to buy things cheaper than their price, so it's a good idea to look in other shops for the things you want for cheaper price. And near the temple, there's a place near a kindergarten where you can have a nice photo with Sky Tree tower as background.
Must see in Tokyo. Very interesting to see such a large Temple! Lots of touristy shops (filled with locals) around the Temple. Nice that is there is also a Shinto Shrine to visit next door.
such a pretty place. we were seeing the sky tree all the time. while exploring the place, we realised bandai head office is at asakusa and took some photos with doreamon haha
sanja matsuri!. visited it during sanja matsuri. great place to be during then!

Endless alleyways of shops. In Tokyo, this is one of the places I enjoyed the most. It has an older, but more pleasant feel in contrast to the other busy areas of the city. I didn't find it to be too crowded at all, but then again, I visited on a Thursday afternoon. There are endless shops here, ranging from clothing to food to souvenirs. However, I have to disagree with some of the other reviews in terms of the prices here--I went around quite a lot of cities around Japan and I found the prices for things in Asakusa to be significantly cheaper than what you can find elsewhere. Just keep in mind that if you see something you like, keep walking a little bit further and you might just find it for a few hundred yen cheaper. If not, then walk back! I also found the area quite easy to navigate since it all seems to lead to the same main street. Lastly, the shrine and temple complex is gorgeous, of course. Great photo opportunities.
Breathtaking. .. I love it there. You can see both temples side by side, the Buddhist one and the Shinto one. . .
Too many people. The temples were well worth a look but there were too many people and too many shops selling over priced tat!

Shopping, food and a great temple. While the temple buildings are very impressive the shopping and food on the way to the temple were the highlight for me, lots of freshly made local treats to try and a huge variety of things for sale made this a great place to visit.
impressive. Very unusual experience, like the views, especially the modern tower bihind the ancient buildings

A must in Tokyo and even better with a free guided tour. We joined a Volunteer Guided Tour of Asakusa during the blossom period in April . We spent a bit more than 2 hrs walking with the guide in one of the old and different areas of Tokyo . The gardens were beautiful , the temple amazing and it was a different contact with the Japanese culture . My wife and I were the only participants on the tour and we really got the attention of our wonderful guide . This volunteer used to be a liaison officer with the U.S. army in Japan so his English was excellent and he also knew his history and did not hesitate to communicate to us the characteristics of the Japanese culture . The tour starts at 11:a.m. or 1:15 p.m. at the SGG Club at the Asakusa Culture Tourist Information Center right across the Kaminrimon Gate of Sensoji Temple . no reservation required

Fun walk and great temple. The walk from the gate to the temple is great and full of shops that have tons of interesting goods and food. It was a great way to spend a few hours, find some souvenirs, and try some Japanese snacks. A lot of activity, a lot of fun.

A Shopaholic and Bargain Hunter's Haven. They say Japan is one of the most developed economies and we were forewarned that everything is going to be expensive. So we brought along small luggages. When my aunt from the US and I went to Asakusa, we were curious of the place. We didn't realize we will shop. We did with gusto...we got 3 pants 4 blouses, 2 shoes, 3 bags. Of course we did have a very good lunch of Udon in one of the side streets. So to the tourists...bring some cash...you will really find good bargains and good food.

Loved it. A short walk from the subway station, this is such a great spot to walk through. The shops in front of the temple draw a lot more attention than the temple itself, though the temple is not to be missed. Such a large variety of items at the shops, especially interesting to the kids were the plastic food, and lanterns & bells that come in all shapes and sizes. Some good snacks too.
...if only it was bigger.... great little side trip, you walk down this street where people sell fresh food and gifts, then the temple is at the end, would be great if there was more vendors
Old-town Tokyo tourist trap -but why not?. Great shopping area for little presents of retro Japanese knick-knacks.

Interesting atmosphere. Asakusa is famous for the Sensoji temple. This temple was destroyed in WWII so the buildings are new. Nevertheless you can meet there local people (and a lots of tourists of course) and feel the atmosphere. On the way to the temple and surroundings you can buy quite good souvenirs.

central asakusa. the great atmosphere when you step out of station -like going back in time -rickshaws and littlle sidestreets with old world charm -interesting shops on main street and temple nearby -plenty to photograph good sushi restaurant opposite asakusa hotel and convenience store at hotel entrance

Do not miss. Asakusa area is a must when visiting Tokyo, it's quite different from the modern Ginza or Shibuya areas but worthwhile the visit. Senso-Ji temple is an obligated stop while in Asakusa. You can then stroll around its alleys and small street with its wooden houses and try different kinds of japanese food.

Nice temple to visit. If you are in Tokyo, then one cannot miss the Sensoji Temple at Asakusa. This is a must visit if you want to see a japanese temple. The surrounding area is nice too, lots of shops and restaurants. This is an old part of Tokyo, nice place to stroll around and spend a few hours here.
a great place to shop. Worth exploring if you like shopping in the Japanese markets and seeing a more historic looking part of Tokyo. The ambience is great.

Asakusa - Vibrant and traditional experience in Tokyo. I have visited Tokyo twice, and Asakusa both times. I love to experience both the modern and spiritual contrast of Japan. If you are in Tokyo for a short stay and have interest in traditional aspect of Japan, then you should visit here.There street upto the temple has many interesting small shops. Rather that a quiet meditative shrine, this place is vibrant with lots of people. Make sure you take some time to check out the complex around the central temple and the side streets - there is a lot of good spots for pictures.
A must see. Very interesting and unique historical area of Tokyo, but it all shuts once the sun sets.

Traditional Japan in the midst of busy Tokyo!. It can be crowded (even on a rainy day). If I went back I would try to do so midweek instead of a Saturday! You can find traditional treasures here as well as the typical Japanese trinkets like charms and souvenirs highlighting the neighboring attractions.Try pushing past the main drag to the smaller shops where you can find tea sets, sake sets and hand painted fabric and paper prints. You can also find traditional rice crackers in many different flavor (sweet or savory)

A cultural icon, but very touristy. The Asakusa temple complex is a great example of a typical Japanese style temple, and it's nice that it's located so centrally in Tokyo. The downside of this is that Asakusa is the token "Japanese temple" for most tourists. You will walk through the long row of sales booths with typical tourist items before you get to the temple itself, but if you've never been here before, don't let it deter you (in fact it can be fun looking at the items). Asakusa is definitely worth visiting, but I haven't been back on my many trips to Tokyo.If you want to see something interesting nearby, walk about 10-15 minutes to the west to Kappabashi street, which is where restaurants go to buy their supplies - signs, cookware, serving ware, and....plastic food for display! You can find great prices on cheaper lacquer ware or bowls, but I always go to look at the artistry of the plastic food (and buy some!).
Fun time shopping. The stalls in front and leading to the shrine are varied and fun. Easily spend a couple of hours checking out the inexpensive treats, knick-knacks and souvenirs.

Great cultural experience in Tokyo. For those who are not going to Kyoto this is a must see, For those who are going to kyoto and have enough time i reccommend seeing Asakusa anyway.Not only is this the sits of a great japanese temple, but it has an amazing shopping area, so many nice souvenirs can be purchased on the road leading upto SensoJi temple, prices are good too :)Dont miss the Ningoyaki !!!

Must see!. Asakusa was definitely a tourist trap with all kinds of vendor stalls, cute shops and little streets but it's old Japan with great architecture! You can try all kinds of treats as you walk around (wherever you see a crowd, stop and see what they are buying to eat and try it!) We did that 3 times and enjoyed each of the treats we tried. Definitely spend 1/2 a day here and get your souvenir shopping done.
fantastic night views pf sensoji. looks fantastic at night when it is all lit up/ in the day it is a very busy area esp near sensoji

Cultural Experience of Japan combined with shopping madness. Asakusa is easily accesible via Ginza MetroHighlights include:-a) Sumida River - If you have time, please take the boat cruise to Odaiba. If not, just stand by the river banks and take a good shot of the Asahi Building (with a Golden sculpture on the roof) and the Tokyo SkyTree (to be opened in May 2012) which is near the exit of the Ginza subway lineb) Kaminarimon - facing a busy street with trishaws pulled by locals at the side. If you can get a good shot of Kaminarimon during a weekend, then you are truly blessed. The highlight is of course the infamous red giant lantern which hangs outside the Sensoji Templec) Sensoji Temple - beautiful temple with locals praying. Before entering it is advised to follow the local custom of washing your handsd) Nakamise Dori (Street)- in my opinion, the highlight of Asakusa. On weekends, it is jam packed with locals. This is where you can have the local delights such as tempura, small cake with red bean paste and even ice cream. This is also the best place to do your souvenir shopping as every stall offer different, eye catching are the souvenirs that you can purchase such as various trinkets, key chains, sculptures, masks, figurines, yukatas, T-shirts and so on. All in all, a must go if you are in Tokyo.

Very busy but nice place.. If you do not mind crowded place and you search for a nice temple go visit Asakusa. It offers beautiful complex of buildings in the traditional Japanese architecture, plus there are many shops and restaurants nearby.

A quick taste of Japan while in Tokyo. If you are in Tokyo on business or pressed for time and can not get to the Nara/Kyoto/Kamakura areas, this is worth finding via the subway. Enjoyable walks, pleasant surroundings. Obviously rebuilt and surrounded by modern buildings, it still was a decent view of a temple/shrine and some genuine activity going on. Market was a bit kitschy, but the food vendors were delicious, particularly the pastry ones. If you are looking for genuine souveniers, I prefer to go to the Oriental Bazaar in Harajaku.

Vibrant place with a feel of old Japan. We stayed just across the river (over the red bridge) from Asakusa station. The area around the temple was very busy and has a real buzz to it. Sensoji is impressive and the stalls around it are fun too. The Sumida riverside walk with cherry trees was also great, we did this again in the evening when the lanterns and trees were lit up. The Tokyo Sky Tree dominates the skyline here, and the Asahi "golden poo"! If you go the other way from the temple (away from the river) you get to a main street which is lined with shops selling kitchenware - we enjoyed a browse here to look at pottery and ceramics, knives and all the enormous variety of utensils etc used in Japan. Great fun!

Do NOT miss it. Asakusa is such a beautiful area presents everything japanese in may ways...the temples are magnificent and market is a deilghtful experience.from there you can also take a cruise on the river to the hamarikyu garden ....this was an awesome experience

Must see in tokyo. the temple is good,very few in tokyo, the market alley has good choice for souvenirs but expensive ,no bargaining,but the best authentic restaurants good for the locals and adventurous travellers. you can literally window shop a restaurant ,you know what they serve with plastic dish presentations in the window.many sushi bars and good food clean and reasonably priced .go there to eat , check the back alleys ,they are safe. for Japanese style hotel check Ryokan Asakusa Mikawaya Honten

place that offers some traditional views of tokyo. go to asakusa to experience some traditional facade and culture of old tokyo. the place is well worth a visit with the senso ji temple and nakamise dori providing lots to see and do. the shops and restaurants around the area offer plenty of souvenirs and local goodies for every one.

A charming neighbourhood. There a two sides to Asakusa - the very touristy area immediately surrounding Senjo-ji; and the homely old-school areas only a few metres further away, where old men ride bikes and stop to help lost tourists - be sure to check out both.

My Afternoon in Asakusa. As soon a we stepped of the train we loved this place..its a vibrant, happening place still steeped in traditional japan..so much going on there! lots of market stalls, food stalls and shops everywhere, we saw some beautiful geisha girls as well...

Funky great place. Asakusa is the traditional "shitamachi" or "downtown" (even though it's actually uptown geographically!) traditional working class area of Tokyo. Something like the East End of London. Go to the shopping street near the Shrine and be amazed by the variety of Japanese objects, restaurants, kitchy souvenirs, interesting characters and lots of people. Wander the side streets around the Temple too with little stalls of things being sold, from old prints to clothes, to "takoyaki" or doughy balls with pieces of octopus in them covered with a sweet sauce (really good!). And lest you think that all this commercialism is a product of the postwar Japanese economic growth, it's been an uber-commercial lower class area for 500 years.

Lovely Temple and great Souvenirs along the way. The temple itself is great to see - remember to "look up" and see the beautiful artwork on the ceiling. However, if you are looking for souvenirs to take home - then this is also a must do venue. The walk to the temple is lined with great shops full of goodies. Behind them are some great little restaurants as well.

One of the Most Delightful Places In Tokyo. Not only is the Temple gorgeous, there is a place in the temple grounds where you can get "your fortune" on a piece of paper- on the honor system! If it's bad, you hang it and twist it up on the standing lines provided so that bad fortune will stay tied up there. The tourist shopping area can be overwhelming with all the stalls and colors and people, but it's a wonderful experience. If you go a couple of blocks away, there are very good noodle shops and authentic shops as well. The whole place was a treat to visit, and as I was fortunate enough to live in Japan for a year, I frequently went to Asakusa. Good memories.
must visit for visitor!. great place for a feel of the older part of japan, also dont miss the exploration in the small shops scatter around, great discovery.

Good shopping off the main road. The other reviews already mentioned the congested tourist shops in front of the temple, but if you get away from that a bit there are some really great shops and noodle houses. The crowds are very low in these shops as well. There are public bathrooms which are clean.
Neat area to stay. There are a few attractions nearby, lots of local food in shops and has access to many subway stations. Out of the most popular places for cheaper, quieter and less hectic.
Must Visit. The shrine is *the* thing to do here. There are some tourist trap stores but I liked them. And you can haggle for prices if you buy lots of things.

Really cool tourist trap. Asakusa is a tourist trap, but is still worth a visit because of the temple. There is a long street leading to the temple that are lined with shopping and food vendors. It is a great place to buy omiage and other small gifts for friends back home. The surrounding area offers a wide range of restaurants where you are sure to find ANYTHING and EVERYTHING to eat!

Get most of your tourist shopping done here, and get to see great architecture.. This is one of the better known cultural sights of Tokyo. As a result it will be very crowded, but it is worth fitting this into your itinerary. It is also close to other attractions you may want to go see. The photos you will get of the temple and statues will make it well worth your trip. Also try some of the snacks on sale from the various street vendors. It is a great way to sample traditional snacks as they were served back in the day. One more advantage is the string of tourist specific stalls all along the walkway. You can get a wide selection of "japanese style" presents here for your loved ones, and most will be quite affordable. Mostly, Japan is not a country that promotes haggling, but you may have more luck here at getting a better price since so many tourists come here. It is a famous attraction to both Japanese and Non japanese. Get lunch before or after coming here...that, or wait in a long line, since most of the restaurants around here are quite famous and people line up from early on to get in.
Typical, tacky,temple.. Very touristy and tacky but typical of that type of temple.Plenty of eating places and atmosphere is good.

Old Edo in the modern metropolis. Asakusa is one of the last remaining part of Tokyo that exudes an old Japan atmosphere... A lot of interesting things to see and doPros: cheap eats available around (monjayaki) river cruise available for Sumida River to Tokyo Bay (Odaiba)Con: there are a lot of people, tourist trap

Edokko (Tokyoites) have been living here for generations. Behind the old and rusty facades of 1940-50s Tokyo, there are faces of hasty and a bit brusque but trustworthy Edokko (Tokyoites) seen around here. Craftsmanship has been passed on to generations, and it's not rare to find soba or sushi restaurant, sweets shops, or ningyo doll shops dating back to the Tokugawa shogunate era. Regardless of earthquakes, fires, and bombings, tradition has somewhat survived. The more deeper you get to know the area, the more you are impressed with what it offers. This is not Tokyo in slick suits and ties but neighborhood of stubborn kind of grannies ("I want my sushi to be eaten properly") and energetic bros and sis that might perhaps appear on Takeshi Kitano's films. This is TOKYO IN DEEP. Try some traditional Kaminari-okoshi and Uguisu-mochi sweets at the Nakamise Market before the Sensoji. If you love hot springs, check out the old Jakotsu-yu onsen-sento bathhouse near the TX station.

One of my favorite Tokyo stops. Great area for food, shopping, and sites. Really cool shrine, great ramen, fun little side streets. My only complaint is the throngs of tourists and the goods that flood the streets aimed at those tourists.

The only place "Japanese" in Tokyo. Yes it is kitschy, yes it is full of tourists, yes they sell all the little junk souvenirs, but it IS what most foreign visitors think Japan is all about. On a serious note the area around the temple hasn't changed much since the war, and has a flavor of times past. This is the "traditional" center of the town, and you can still see a few kimono being worn, and get an idea of what Japan used to be like. Every foreigner I have taken there loves the place, once you work your way through the road block of jinrickshaw vendors outside the gate. Food is good IF you DON'T go to the tourist traps with the big lines out front. Long lines in Japan do NOT mean it is good, only "famous" or recently on TV.
Good spot for buying souvenirs. Good spot for buying souvenirs.A bit crowded though.The temple is not as beautiful as the temples in Kyoto, but this is still worth a visit.

An escape from the busy city. Arriving at Asakusa station I wasnt sure where exactly the temple district was. I stopped into the very helpful tourist information centre and they provided me with a map, explanation and suggested walking route - as well as directions to the entrance. 2 minutes later and quite by surprise you come across the entrance gate with its large red lantern. What a surprise this was. A long strip of small stalls selling everything from fans to chopsticks, toys and street food to exquisite (although expensive) traditional Japanese dolls. I took my time sauntering down the stirp of stalls towards the main temple and pagoda. The main temple is very interesting, although not as peaceful as Mejii Jingu - this district of Asakusa should be top of any visitors list.
A must see in Tokyo. Visited a shrine at night, everywhere was so nicely lit up, souvenir stalls, plenty of places to dine. A must see in Tokyo!
Most famous temple in Tokyo. A million Japanese going there on the New Year day, guess many of them only go to the temple once/year.

A nice Tourist Object in Tokyo. as ordinari Tourist object everywhere, this area was crowded but I like the Nakamise Shopping street where you can find many things about Japan. Souvenirs, snacks, key rings etc
Spirituality within the reach. I love this place and go there often when I feel like resting and having a peaceful day. The most visited temple for me is this and Narita San.

Worth Visiting. The Gate called Kaminari-Mon is photogenic. You can enjoy shopping along the Nakamise Street after the gate. The end is Sensouji Temple. Please pray here like Japanese do. There are nice Japanese, French and Italian restautrants. In Spring, the cherry blossoms are beautiful along the Sumida River near there. Let's get on the ferry and head for the Hama-Rikyu Garden.

Pricey strip shopping. Asakusa is busy and watch out for the guys touting tours in ninja shoes! Good spot for buying souvenirs and a neat sushi train restaurant called Sushi Go Round located in the arcade.

A very nice place to be!. Asakusa is a district which combines tradition and entertainment! There is a grand Temple full of colours which is usually surrounded by hundreds of visitors(especially during August where the Omatsuri festivals take place).It is really a nice place for taking some photos and also you can find a large open-air market where you can buy beautiful porcelain souvenirs! In Asakusa there is a variety of restaurants where you can eat and drink while resting.I strongly recommend it!

Disappointing. The temple is very nice (although not with the serenity and local beauty of temples in Kyoto. The area around it felt more like honky-tonk than genuine "old Tokyo." Lots of tacky souvenir shops and fast-food stalls.
nice temple, more authentic than others. nice area with stalls and local feeling, less commerical feeling than other parts of the city
Nice local gathering place!. Asakusa is a very original downtown Tokyo. If you want to see real Tokyo, this is the place!

Great place to see and many shops. My wife and I spent about an hour here. Cost is free to see it. The old style buildings are fascinating and beautiful. It gives you a great feel for traditional Japanese culture and spiritual. As you enter the attraction, there are probably 100 small shops to buy all sorts of trinkets, gifts, toys, souvenirs, and food. Out in front, there are young men selling 10, 30, and 60 minute rickshaw rides. We didn't do that because it was still kind of pricy (3,000 yen for just 10 min) but it looked like so much fun. We loved this place!
Nice neighbourhood. if you wish to stay in a quet area with not much traffic or skyscrapers, this is the place!
Interesting "old" part of Tokyo. So much "old world" character but only downfall is it is not on JR line (only 2 stops away from a JR line station though).

Beautiful sights of traditional Japan/Tokyo - vast choices of souvenirs albeit tourist centric. Not sure because it was a weekend during our visit but the whole place were super congested! The place was flooded with tourist from HK, Taiwan and Msia/S'pore plus those from US. There were also loads of university students... Nonetheless, the place was very interesting amongst the hustle bustle of little souvenir and bakery shops before the ancient majestic shrine and pagoda display before you. The landscape and architecture were amazing with a mix of historical appreciation. With the walking distance, there were also some unique eateries for those who are keen to try out but on the pricey side since this is a touristy location. We spent a good 2 hrs here exploring the nearby places as well which has the famous young troops all dressed up for Cosplay! Something unique...weird amidst across a road from the ancient shrines and historical architecture.

Well worth a visit.. This is a great place, I went twice, once by train and once by boat. There are beautiful temples, a pagoda, a traditional looking restaurant and a large market. There are rickshaw drivers who will take you on a ride through the nearby park by the river.

Huge Shrine Complex. complete with thousands of tiny shops. Stroll through, taste fresh hot baked sweet potatoes, try sweet rice drink, buy a kimono, or pick up small souvenirs. Above all, people watch. All manner of people flock here every day. And if you ever wanted a rickshaw ride, here's the place to take one.

Great place to spend the day. This is my favorite area of tokyo. There's always something interesting going on and you're bound to meet cool people. The temple is awesome but have sadly removed their English descriptions of the charms you can buy. The fortunes(omikuji) are written in English though. This is a great place to buy gifts and find interesting things. Make sure to get lost exploring the alleyways.

Asakusa : Tokyo before WWII. Historical Fact: Asakusa used to be the heart of Tokyo, before WWII bombings (politics aside). Therefore, when you travel through Asakusa, you are in fact seeing the *real* Entertainment District of Japan.Couple of things you should know here:[1] the shops on the main road leading to the Senso-Ji Temple are TOURIST TRAPS!![2] HOWEVER, the food stands are AWESOME.[3] HOWEVER-2, if you deviate from the Senso-Ji Temple, there are some GREAT shops : made in Japan bags, coats, clothes; made in Japan pencils, pens; etc. now, i was wandering, but i want to stay it's north? of the senso-ji temple, but within walking distance.
my wishing god. you can see the most pretty temple and grant your wish as i do .

A complete temple experience. Getting to Sensouji temple you walk through the streets filled with tiny shops. They are quite touristy, but there are so many unique items and specialty foods, it's really a lot of fun. It has a very old-Japan feel, which is so atmospheric and really makes the trip.
Overcrowded, still a must-visit. My wife and I were overwhelmed with other tourists and couldn't find a spot to take good pictures. Still, this is still a nice place with some nice small shops in it.

Must visit!. We just loved this place. You can see temple and walk to temple is full of little shops and street food or restaurants. Best place to shop, sightseeing and food all-in-one. We visited this place again on our last day in Tokyo.

Traditional Tokyo. This is the old entertainment district so lots of restaurants and a really cute / shabby old amusement park, one of the most popular temples in Tokyo and the start of a great cruise down the river to Odaiba.

Touristy, but also Local !. Very easy to visit, with one main shopping street straight to the Senso-ji Shrine. Wonderfully Photogenic, especially the huge Lantern. You can often see school excursion students in their pretty uniforms, families, tourists from overseas, and also, local people !! A variety of cheap but nice food to dine out. And now you can also have a good view of SKY TREE.

Worth a visit. As others have stated, this area was very crowded but it was still worth seeing. It combined Old Japan with new & honestly the place where we got most of our souvenirs to bring back to the States.One thing not to miss...there is a stand (at the temple) where you drop in a coin, shake a canister and a stick with a Japanese character falls out. You match that character/symbol up with the corresponding drawer and in the drawer is a paper with your fortune. Very interesting!

Historic and fun - a must!. Whether it's enjoying the sights, smells and sounds of Senso-ji on a festival summer night, shopping on Nakamise street, or enjoying beer and gyoza with new friends, Asakusa has it all and then some. Historic and famous by Tokyo standards, this is the place the Japanese like to come visit as much as foreigners so whether it's a couple dressed up in their weekend Kimonos getting a Rickshaw tour or getting your fortune at a Buddhist temple, a trip to Asakusa is a must!

Get a feel of ancient Japan shoulder to shoulder with the other tourists.. Good luck getting a photo of anything that looks old school Japan without having some other tourist holding up a camera in your shot.Saying that, your memories of this place are better than any photo you can take.Head into the small shops and listen to the staff try and speak English to you. The mistakes they make are priceless.
nice place. there are a lot of shops to buy souvenirs.Many restaurants too and a beautiful shrine to visit.The place is crowded with tourists, but you can find some quiet places.
Beautiful mega temple. Huge compound, lots of little shops on the walkway leading to the temple.
Temple with shopping combined. Old temple with great selection of food and souvenirs just round the corner
Lots of shopping and sightseeing. Great area with lots to see. Literally overflowing with tourists. Avoid if you hate crowds.

Brilliant. The temple was very quaint even though there were upgrades occurring. The stalls leading up to the temple were full of lots of treasures, save your money for this area, I brought lots of goody's home.
We took a rickshaw ride here also. So much fun. Will definitely go back when we return to Japan in the future.
Interesting rather touristy area of Tokyo. The Senso-ji Temple is most spectacular when lit up at night.

Breathtaking!. Loved the experience we had of the temple and it is absolutely beautiful!! We LOVED these sticky rice balls covered in peanut powder that they sold at the stores before you go inside the temple accompanied by hot sweet sake! We went to eat that almost everyday after we tried it the first time! You HAVE to try it! It's this pink store with a white rabbit as their logo. You'll see it cuz there are crowds of people all the time lining up for it.

Only worth going for Senso-ji temple. The main tourist street has plenty of shopping for traditional gifts as well as tourist tat. The temple is impressive, but there are plenty like it, although this one is probably the best in Tokyo.
Don't buy souvenir here!. Crowded place. The souvenir here are all over priced.
Value for moeny. Good place for shoppingtraditional templenice place to buy leather bags (at cheaper price)take a cruise and enjoy your ride to Odiaba.

Great for a Day in 'Old Tokyo'. A fun experience in a preserved old section of Tokyo. The Temple there is very nice to walk through, as well as the old-school shopping bazaar in front. Great place to buy inexpensive or expensive souvenirs, go on a ricksaw ride, eat some "DoJo," a dish of tofu and cooked baby eels. Lots of tourists there, but still a fun day. Definitely eat at some of the restaurants around the outside of the shopping "mall."
Sensoji. very touristy place with lots of tourist. However, the river cruise is a good choice for excursion.

Must see for Tokyo. ANyone visiting Tokyo for siteseeing should spend at least a day here. Go to the temples, Kappa Bashi street, and walk around any random back alleys. This is old Tokyo, and most people who live here have lived here for generations and quite friendly as a result.

Great for Souvenirs. This is one place I'll visit when I am in Tokyo. Naka-mise dori is a great place to buy souvenirs and crackers. Even cheap yutaka can be found here.
You can walk to Asakusa from the Ueno station (about 25mins) or transfer to the GInza metro line from Ueno.
The Asakusa Kannon temple is definitely worth a visit.

Great neighbourhood with many things to offer. A visit to Asakusa and the Sensoji temple makes a great program for 2-4 hours. The temple is in the middle of the city, beautiful and its small garden well-maintained. The place is clearly very popular and revered by the Japanese. Even on a late Monday afternoon very crowded. The street towards the temple is packed with small souvenir and snack stalls, quite touristy but not too much. The best thing though, after your visit to the temple, is to wander the side streets, especially on the west side and in the smaller streets. Many small and informal shops and street bars and restaurants. Also some very trendy shops. Likely that you finally run into something that is worth buying.

Explore the streets beyond Asakusa Dori--Japanese Textiles. Asakusa holds more treasures beyond its beautiful shrine and the sembei stalls that line Nakamise Dori. Step into the side streets to find delightful gifts. While a seemingly unusual item for textile art, you'll find dishtowels artfully decorated that will no doubt delight as gifts. Ranging in price from over 1000 yen for the most artful tenugui that can be used as framed art (go to Fujiya at 2-2-15 Asakusa, Taito-ku) to a few hundred yen, visit the shops in the side streets to the right of Nakamise Dori nearer the shrine. If you have time, venture further west on Asakusa Dori (near the Tawaramachi station for the Ginza line) to find stores selling traditional ceremonial items for Obon, Japan's August holiday to honor the return of ancestors' spirits. Continue to the corner of Asakusa Dori and Kappabashi Dori for household goods shopping. There are two store on the corners (Dr. Goods and Dengama) that offer items nicely priced. Explore up that side of Kappabashi Dori.

One of my favourite areas to visit in Tokyo. Asukasa, or specifically the Lantern shrine area is one of my favourite places to visit when I have a half day free.It has a bit of everything. Impressive shrines and Temples, especially the Sensoju Buddist temple, a nice Japanese garden area, and then the main shopping street, Nakamise, with all its tourist stalls and shops and fast food stalls (fast food Japan style)..It's a bit tricky to find first time, but well worth the effort. And as a half day round trip from central Tokyo I would recommend travelling here by the underground and then return to cetral Tokyo by taking the river boat ferry back to Tokyo Bay.

Edgy Site Next to Asakusa: Tokyo Sky Tree Construction Site. "Wow."That's the first word you can come up with. Here's Asakusa (one of the most popular tourist spots in Tokyo) area's new edgy attraction, Tokyo Sky Tree. The tower will be complete in 2012 and it will be one of the world's tallest tower structures -- 634m.What's so edgy about the tower? It's not the tower itself -- it's the massive construction site. As mentioned earlier, the tower is still well under construction, and currently its hight is 303m. (as of February 23, 2010.)From Narihirabashi Station's platform (A stop away from Asakusa Station by Tobu Line, or 15 minutes walk from the central Asakusa area.), there's a flat 180-degrees view of the site.Enjoy and feel the power of Japanese construction right in front of you.(Note: There's a poster in the platform, saying "Due to the passing trains, don't lean towards the track to take pictures." So, please watch out.)

I would say a 'Tokyo must'. We were in Tokyo for 7 days and enjoyed this place so much, we went twice!Excellent market in which to buy souvenirs, albeit a little touristy and a great place to take a few photos of shrines and Buddha statues. We wandered a little away from the main temple, down a side street, and found some great authentic Japanese restaurants.

Cherry Blossom at Asakusa. We love our visit to Japan. Everything is so well connected. We arrived from the plane, clear custom and down we went striaght to the train that takes us downtown. It took us about an hour and it was just merely JPY1000. We decided to stay at Asaukusa as I heard so much nice things about it. One of the comment was that Asakusa being the oldest place in Japan and viewing cherry blossom was the right place to be.So, we took the chance after much research and emails, we book a hotel there. It was rather hard to find a typical ryokan. Nearly everywhere I tried looking at Asakusa was fully book because of the cherry blossom season. Luckily, we found hotel gyminso. They offered me a Japanese style room facing the Sumida River & park. It was awesome. It was already dark when we arrived from the airport but we could see the whole row of cherry blossom trees just outside from our window. It was really pink everywhere. So pretty! Not only that, the hotel is clean, close to all the subways and just across Tobu train station. It is a stone throw to the attractions and the view is just breathtaking during spring.The next morning, we spent the whole morning just walking up and down at Sumida Park, enjoying the beautiful cherry blossoms. Later in the morning, we walked down to visit Sensoji Temple & Nakamise street. It was a crowded place with lots of small shops selling Japaneses items. After lunch, we took a cruise ride from the Sumida Park pier to Hamrikyu gardens. The boat ride took just 30 minutes where we could see the various types of bridges along the river and of course cherry blossom trees. The japanese garden landscape was interesting but did not have as many cherry blossom trees to see as the Sumida Park.There are many small food stores everywhere. There are many category of food to choose from but we preferred the typical soba noodles the small shops have to offer. A must try.View my pictures online. at http://babyforshee.blogspot.com I have a video to watch as well. BTW, you can also see nice cherry blossoms at Ueno Park as well. Just be aware that anywhere you go, there will be lots of people everywhere.Enjoy...April 2007

Good place to buy many souvenirs. Asakusa is a great place for walking, taking pictures of a significant sites and buying cute souvenirs, which are always a good quality. We bought yukatas and kimonos for all our friends, the choise was huge,not like in Duty free at Narita airport. This is also a convenient place to take a boua to Odaiba island for more shopping and incredible vistas of architecture of the future.
